(ii) Refuting the analogy of there being no difference

gal te snod bcud mi bskyed pa'i gnas skabs dang khyad par med kyang dbang phyug snod bcud kyi rgyu yin te/ dper na myu gu'i rgyu sa bon kyang ma tshogs pa'i sa sogs dang khyad par med kyang myu gu'i rgyu yin pa bzhin no zhe na/ dpe de nyid mi 'thad do zhes bstan pa'i phyir/

Well then, even though there is no distinction from the times when he is not creating the universe, Īśvara is the cause of the universe. As an analogy, it is just as how a seed—the cause of a shoot—is not different when the soil and so forth are not assembled, but it is still the shoot's cause, you say. To teach that such an analogy is illogical:
myu gu bskyed la sa la sogs/ / rang bzhin yongs su 'gyur na ni/ / rgyu yin de legs byas pa na/ / de yi khyad par mthong phyir ro/ /
27. If the nature of the soil and so forth Transforms in the production of a shoot, They are the cause. This is because if they Are properly done, the difference is seen.

zhes smos te/ myu gu dngos su bskyed pa la sa la sogs pa rgyu'i rang bzhin du yongs su 'gyur na ni myu gu'i rgyu yin te/ zhing sa de chu la sogs pa rkyen gyis legs par 'dus byas pa myu gu la sogs pa 'bras bu de'i khyad par bzang ba dang mang ba tshad mas mthong ba'i phyir ro/ /

If the soil and so forth transform into the nature of a cause in the actual production of a shoot, they are the shoot's cause. This is because if they (the field and soil) are properly combined with water and other such conditions, the difference in the results such as sprouts and so forth—goodness and plentifulness—is validly seen.
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
gal te ji ltar yul dbang po/ / tshogs pa khyad med blo rgyu yin/ / de ltar 'di yin ce na/ /
28a-c “As objects and the faculties assembled Aren't different, but are the cause of mind, This is like that,” you say.

zhes smos te/ gal te dpe ji ltar na yul dang dbang po dang yid byed la sogs pa ma tshogs pa'i re re ba dang / tshogs pa la khyad par med kyang dbang blo'i rgyu yin pa de ltar du dbang phyug 'di yang snod bcud mi bskyed pa'i gnas skabs dang khyad par med kyang snod bcud kyi rgyu yin no zhe na/ bshad pa/

As an analogy, just as the objects—the faculties, attention, and so forth—are not different when separate and not assembled from when they are assembled, but are the cause of sensory minds, this Īśvara is like that—he may not be different from the times when he is not creating the universe but he is the cause of the universe, you say. To explain:
min/ / de la'ang khyad par yod phyir ro/ /
28c-d It is not so, Because there is a difference there as well.

zhes smos te/ dbang blo bskyed pa la yul dbang yid byed tshogs pa dang ma tshogs pa la khyad par med pa min te/ yul sogs tshogs pa dang ma tshogs pa de la'ang dbang shes bskyed pa dang mi bskyed pa'i khyad par yod pa'i phyir ro/ /

It is not so that there is no difference between the object, faculty, and attention when assembled and when not, because there is the difference there with object and so forth being assembled or not assembled as well as to whether they produce a sensory consciousness or not.
gtan tshigs ma grub bo zhe na/ bshad pa/
The reason is not established, you say. To explain:
so so so sor nus med rnams/ / rang bzhin khyad par med pa na/ / tshogs kyang nus pa med 'gyur bas/ / de phyir khyad par grub pa yin/ /
29. If those, which lacked capacity when separate, Do not have a distinctive nature, then Assembled they would lack capacity, too. So therefore the distinctiveness is proven.

ces smos te/ yul dbang yid byed ma tshogs pa'i so so ba dbang shes so sor bskyed pa'i nus pa med pa rnams dang / de dag tshogs pa la rang bzhin khyad par med pa yin na yul dbang yid byed tshogs pas kyang dbang shes bskyed pa'i nus pa med par 'gyur bas na/ de ltar 'dod par mi nus pa de'i phyir yul dbang yid byed tshogs pa dang / ma tshogs pa la dbang shes bskyed pa dang mi bskyed pa'i khyad par grub pa yin no/ /

If those (the object, faculty, and attention), which lacked capacity to produce sensory consciousness on their own when unassembled and separate, do not have a distinctive nature when assembled, then assembled, they (the object, faculty, and attention) would lack capacity to produce a sensory consciousness as well. One cannot agree to this, so therefore the distinction between assembled and unassembled object, faculty, and attention in producing or not producing a sensory faculty is proven.
gsum pa don bsdu ba ni/
(iii) Summary
de phyir so sor gang nus med/ / tshogs na yon tan srid 'gyur ba/ / de dag rgyu yin dbang phyug sogs/ / ma yin khyad par med phyir ro/ /
30. Therefore what lacks capacity on its own In combination may have qualities. Those are the causes. Īśvara and so forth Are not, because there is no difference.

zhes smos te/ yul dbang yid byed tshogs pa las dbang shes dngos su skye ba de'i phyir yul dbang yid byed so sor gang yang rung ba re re la dbang shes bskyed pa'i nus pa med la/ yul sogs tshang bar tshogs na dbang shes la phan 'dogs pa'i yon tan srid par 'gyur bas yul sogs tshogs pa de dag dbang shes kyi rgyu yin cing / dbang phyug dang bdag sogs ni snod bcud kyi rgyu ma yin te/ snod bcud mi bskyed pa'i gnas skabs kyi dbang phyug dang khyad par med pa'i phyir ro/ /

Sensory consciousnesses actually arise from the combination of object, faculty, and attention. Therefore, any one of the object, faculty, or attention on its own lacks the capacity to produce sensory consciousness, but if the combination of object and so forth is complete, they may have the quality to benefit the sensory consciousness. Therefore those (the object and so forth in full combination) are the causes of sensory consciousness. Īśvara, the self, and so forth are not the cause of the universe, because there is no difference between them and the Īśvara at the time he is not creating the universe.
bzhi pa tshad ma yin na lkog gyur gyi don thams cad shes dgos pa dgag pa la/
(d) Refuting that if the Bhagavan is valid, he should know all hidden objects.
'dod pa brjod pa/ de dgag pa'o/ /
This has two topics: (i) Stating the position, and (ii) Refuting it.
dang po ['dod pa brjod pa] ni/
(i) Stating the position
tshad ma lkog gyur don shes yin/ / de sgrub byed kyang med pa'i phyir/ / nan tan byed pa yod ma yin/ / zhes ni kha cig rab tu brjod/ /
31. There are those who state, “Validity Is knowing hidden objects, but because There is not any method to achieve that, There is not anyone who would make efforts.”

ces smos te/ rgyang 'phen pa dang / rgyal dpog pa dag na re/ sgrub byed la bltos tshad yin rigs/ / zhes zer ba mi 'thad de/ tshad ma'i skyes bu yin na srin bu'i grangs sogs dang rgyang ring po'i lkog gyur gyi don ma lus pa shes pa zhig dgos pa yin la/ de shes pa sgrub byed kyi thabs kyang med pa'i phyir dang / thabs de la nan tan du byed pa su yang yod pa ma yin de'i phyir zhes ni rgyang 'phen sogs kha cig rab tu brjod par byed do/ /

The Cārvākas and Jaiminīyas claim that it is not logical to say: Thus based on the means To achieve that, it's logical he is valid.[71] There are those Cārvākas and so forth who state that this is because if he were a valid being, he would have to know every single hidden object such as the number of insects and so forth or distant objects, but there is not any method to achieve that knowledge, and there is not anyone who would make efforts at such methods.
gnyis pa de dgag pa la/
(ii) Refuting it.
spyi yi don dang / tshig gi don gnyis las/
This has two topics: A. General discussion, and B. The meaning of the text.
dang po [spyi yi don] ni/
A. General discussion

'dir slob dpon gyis chos thams cad mkhyen pa 'gog par mdzad dam zhe na/ de ni ma yin te/ phyi rol pa dag thar pa thob pa'i thabs mi shes kyang lkog gyur gyi don nyi tshe ba tsam shes pa la ston par khas 'che ba dag yod pas de 'gog par mdzad kyi/ thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes ni ma dag pa byis pa'i blo can rnams la shin tu lkog tu gyur pa'i phyir bsam gyis mi khyab pas 'dir dpyad par ma mdzad de/ ji skad du/ gzugs sogs dang ni sems de ltar/ / gzung ba'i mtshan nyid dpyod pa 'di/ / ma dag blo can la yin gyi/ / rnal 'byor rtogs pa bsam mi khyab/ / ces dang / rgyud gzhan grub pa las kyang / bcom ldan 'das kyis don thugs su chud pa ni bsam gyis mi khyab ste/ rnam pa thams cad shes pa dang brjod pa'i yul las 'das pa'i phyir ro/ / zhes gsungs pas so/ /

Is the master refuting here the omniscience of knowing all phenomena? you ask. He is not. There are non-Buddhists who contend that those who do not know the methods to achieve liberation but who do know a trifling hidden object are teachers, so he is refuting them. Omniscient wisdom is extremely remote for those with childish impure minds, so it is inconceivable. Thus he does not examine that here. As it is said: Thus analyzing form, et cetera, And mind as apprehended characteristics Is for those who have impure minds. The yogi's Realization is inconceivable.[72] From Establishing Others' Continua: The Bhagavan's comprehension of objects is inconceivable because it transcends the objects of knowledge and speech in all ways.[73]

'o na so so'i skye bos rnam pa thams cad du thams cad mkhyen pa'i yul la dpyod par mi nus sam zhe na/ thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes kyi yul la 'jug tshul ni byis pa so so'i skye bos dngos po stobs zhugs kyi tshad mas rtogs dka' ba la dgongs nas de skad du gsungs kyi/ yid ches pa'i lung tshad ma la brten nas ni rtogs par nus te/ ji skad du rgyas pa las/ gnas gsum par ni 'pho ba na/ / bstan bcos len pa rigs ldan yin/ / zhes gsungs so/ / 'o na yid ches pa'i lung las ji ltar rtogs zhe na/ 'di la chos ji snyed pa mkhyen pa'i ye shes ni/ rnam rtags mtshan mas bsdus pa'i chos thams cad thugs su chud pa'i ye shes te/ ji skad du rgyal ba'i yum bar ma las/ rab 'byor rnam pa gang dag dang / rtags gang dag dang / mtshan ma gang dag gis chos rnams rab tu brjod pa'i rnam pa de dag dang / rtags de dag dang / mtshan ma de dag de bzhin gshegs pas thugs su chud do/ / zhes gsungs pas so/ / chos ji lta ba mkhyen pa'i ye shes ni/ chos gcig gi chos nyid dang / chos thams cad kyi chos nyid dbyer med par mkhyen pa'i ye shes te/ ji skad du yum stong phrag brgya pa las/ chos gcig gi mdo dang rgyas pa shes na/ chos thams cad kyi mdo dang rgyas pa shes par 'gyur ro/ / zhes gsungs la/ slob dpon 'phags pa lhas kyang / dngos gcig dngos po kun gyi ngo bo nyid/ / dngos kun dngos po gcig gi ngo bo nyid/ / gang gis dngos gcig de bzhin nyid mthong ba/ / de yis dngos kun de bzhin nyid du mthong / / zhes gsungs so/ /

Well then, are ordinary individuals in all aspects unable to examine the object of omniscience? you ask. The manner in which omniscient wisdom engages an object is difficult for ordinary individuals to realize through valid cognition proceeding from the power of facts, and this is said with that in mind. Omniscience can be understood through the validity of authoritative scriptures. As it says in the Commentary: When moving on to the third area, It's logical to accept the treatises.[74] Well then, how does one understand it from authoritative scriptures? you ask. With regard to this, there is the wisdom that knows the variety of all phenomena—the wisdom that comprehends all phenomena that are included among aspects, signs, and attributes. As is said in the Middle Length Mother of the Victors: Subhūti, in this way the Tathagata comprehends those aspects, signs, and attributes that are aspects, signs, and attributes that describe phenomena...[75] The wisdom that knows phenomena as they are is the wisdom that knows that the dharma nature of one phenomenon and the dharma nature of all phenomena are inseparable. As is said in the Great Mother in One Hundred Thousand Stanzas, “If one knows the long and short of one phenomenon, one will know the long and short of all phenomena.”[76] Master Āryadeva also said: One thing is the essence of all things. All things are the essence of one thing. Whoever sees the suchness of one thing Sees the suchness of all things.[77]

ji lta ba dang ji snyed pa mkhyen pa'i ye shes gnyis kas kyang ji lta ba dang ji snyed pa'i chos thams cad mkhyen na/ ye shes gnyis su dbye ba mi 'thad la/ mi mkhyen na gang yang rung ba gcig thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes su mi 'gyur ro/ / zhes 'ga' zhig sems par gyur na/ de'i phyir brjod par bya'o/ / chos kyi skye mched pa'i nam mkha' rjes su ma zhugs pa'i phra rags kyi dngos po 'ga' yang med pa ltar de bzhin gshegs pa'i de bzhin nyid rjes su ma zhugs pa'i chos ni 'ga' yang med do/ / de'i phyir chos gcig gi de bzhin nyid gang yin pa de ni chos thams cad kyi de bzhin nyid yin la/ chos thams cad kyi de bzhin nyid gang yin pa de ni de bzhin gshegs pa'i de bzhin nyid yin te/ yum stong phrag brgya pa las/ rab 'byor gzugs kyi de bzhin nyid gang yin pa de ni de bzhin gshegs pa'i de bzhin nyid de/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i de bzhin nyid gang yin pa de ni de bzhin gshegs pas thugs su chud de/ zhes bya ba la sogs pa rgya cher gsungs so/ / de bas na ji lta ba dang ji snyed pa mkhyen pa'i ye shes gnyis ni gdul bya'i blos ldog pa tha dad pa phye ba tsam du zad kyi don la tha dad pa ni med de/ chos thams cad kyi de bzhin nyid mkhyen pa'i ye shes de nyid kyis chos thams cad kyi chos nyid mkhyen pa na/ de dang gnyis su med pa'i chos thams cad kyang mkhyen pa'i phyir te/ mkhyen pa'i skad cig gcig gis ni/ / shes bya'i dkyil 'khor kun khyab can/ / zhes gsungs so/ / de bas na slob dpon gyis thams cad mkhyen pa 'gog par mdzad pa ni ma yin no/ /

Some people might think that if both the wisdom that knows the variety of all phenomena and the wisdom that knows all phenomena as they are know all phenomena, then it is not logical to divide them into two wisdoms. However, if they do not, one or the other of them would not be omniscient wisdom. For that reason, I shall explain: Just as there is no thing coarse or subtle at all that space (which is the sense base of dharmas) does not conjoin, there is no phenomenon at all that the Tathagata's suchness does not conjoin. For that reason, that which is the suchness of one phenomenon is the suchness of all phenomena, and that which is the suchness of all phenomena is the suchness of the Tathagata. This is explained at great length in the Great Mother in One Hundred Thousand Stanzas: Subhūti, that which is the suchness of form is the suchness of the Tathagata, and the Tathagata comprehends that which is the suchness of the Tathagata... Therefore the wisdoms that know the nature and variety are merely distinguished as separate isolates in students' minds, but in actuality there is no difference because when that very wisdom that knows the suchness of all phenomena knows the dharma nature of all phenomena, it also knows all phenomena, which are indivisible from that: A single instant of knowing Pervades the mandala of the knowable.[78] Therefore the master does not refute omniscience.

'o na/ 'di yis srin bu'i grangs mkhyen pa/ / nged la 'ga' yang nyer mkho med/ / ces gsungs pa ma yin nam zhe na/ de ni dbang phyug pa dag sdug bsngal zhi ba'i thabs mi shes pa'i dbang phyug ston par khas len cing / bde sdug thams cad kyi byed pa po dbang phyug yin pas de nyid srog gi mchod sbyin la sogs pas mnyes par byas pas mtho ris kyi bde ba la longs spyod par 'gyur ro/ / zhes tshad ma dang tshad min gyi rnam dbye la mi mkhas pas/ rigs pa ltar snang 'ga' zhig la brten nas mtho ris kyi thabs su phyugs kyi mchod sbyin dang / thar pa'i thabs su 'jug ngogs kyi khrus la sogs ston pa'i lung dang / lung de lta bu byed pa po'i skyes bu ston par khas len par byed do/ /

Well then, doesn't it say, “We have no use at all for whether / He knows how many bugs there are,” you ask. In regard to that, the Śaivas assert that Īśvara, who does not know the methods to pacify suffering, is a teacher, and since the creator of all pleasure and pain is Īśvara, by pleasing him with animal sacrifices and so forth, one will enjoy the pleasures of heaven. They do not know the distinction between the valid and the invalid, so based on some fallacious logics they accept scriptures that say sacrificing livestock is a method for the high realms and washing in a river is a method for liberation, and they assert that the being who created those scriptures is the teacher.

gzhan yang tshu rol mdzes pa ba dang / dpyod pa ba dag phyi nang gi dngos po thams cad 'jig rten 'dir rgyu med du byung ba tsam zhig yin gyi/ skye ba snga mar byas pa'i las kyi rnam par smin pa skye ba 'dir ram/ skye ba 'dir byas pa'i las kyi rnam par smin pa myong bar 'gyur ba'i 'jig rten snga phyi thams cad dang / mtho ris dang / thar pa dang / thams cad mkhyen pa la sogs pa shin tu lkog tu gyur pa'i chos rnams med de zhes skur ba 'debs par byed la/ de ltar 'dod pa dag gi ngor dngos po stobs zhugs kyi tshad ma shin tu lkog tu gyur pa'i don can thar pa dang thams cad mkhyen pa'i sgrub byed du mi 'gyur la/ yid ches pa'i lung tshad mar khas mi len pas re zhig la chos thams cad mkhyen pa btang snyoms su mdzad de/ dgos pa'i don kun mkhyen pa tsam zhig thar pa don gnyer gyi skyes bu rnams la nye bar mkho ba'i dbang du mdzad nas 'dir bstan pa yin no/ /

Additionally, the Cārvāka and Mīmāṃsaka schools say that all outer and inner things merely appear in this world without any cause. They say that there is no full ripening in this life of actions performed in a previous life, no previous and future worlds[79] in which the ripening of actions performed in this life is experienced, no higher realms, no liberation, no omniscience, and so forth, thus denying all extremely hidden phenomena. In the perception of those who make such assertions, valid cognition that engages the power of things does not provide proof of liberation and omniscience, which are extremely hidden objects. They do not accept the authoritative scriptures as valid, so for the time being the wisdom that knows all phenomena is put aside. Instead, merely knowing everything that is necessary is taught here in terms of being needed for those beings who long for liberation.

dbang phyug la sogs pas thar pa don gnyer gyi skyes bu la dgos pa'i don ji ltar mi mkhyen zhe na/ dbang phyug gis ni mtho ris dang thar pa'i don du srog gi mchod sbyin byed dgos par bstan la/ des ni thar pa thob pa lta smos kyang ci dgos/ mtho ris kyang mi thob ste/ ngan song gi rgyu las mtho ris 'byung ba 'gal ba'i phyir ro/ / de bzhin du tshu rol mdzes pa ba la sogs pas kyang thar pa don gnyer la dgos pa'i don mi shes te/ las rgyu 'bras la skur ba 'debs pa sogs lam phyin ci log tu ston pa'i phyir ro/ / des na dbang phyug la sogs pa ni thar pa don gnyer gyi skyes bu la tshad mar mi rigs la/ bden bzhi'i gnas tshul phyin ci ma log par rang nyid kyi thugs su chud nas gzhan la ston par nus pa ni srin bu'i grangs dang rgyang ring po'i don shes kyang rung / mi shes kyang rung thar pa don gnyer gyi skyes bu la tshad mar rigs pa yin no/ /

“How is it that Īśvara and such others do not know what is necessary for those beings who long for liberation?” you ask. Īśvara taught that one must perform animal sacrifices in order to attain the higher realms and liberation, but there is no need to speak of achieving liberation through that—one won't even achieve the higher realms, because it is contradictory for the higher realms to arise from the cause of lower realms. Similarly, the Cārvākas and so forth do not know what is necessary for those who long for liberation, because they teach an erroneous path denying karma, cause, and result. Therefore it is not logical that Īśvara and so forth should be valid authorities for those beings who long for liberation. Someone who has comprehended for themselves without error the nature of the four truths and is able to teach it to others is logically a valid authority, regardless of whether or not they know the insect population or far off objects.
gnyis pa tshig gi don bshad pa la/
B. The meaning of the text.
nye bar mi mkho ba shes pa tshad ma ma yin par bstan/ nye bar mkho ba mkhyen pa tshad mar bstan pa'o/ /
This has two points: 1. Teaching that knowing the unnecessary is not validity, and 2. Teaching that knowing the necessary is validity.
dang po [nye bar mi mkho ba shes pa tshad ma ma yin par bstan pa] ni/
1. Teaching that knowing the unnecessary is not validity
sdug bsngal zhi ba'i thabs shes pa ston par 'tshol gyi/ srin bu'i grangs sogs shes pa ston par mi 'tshol lo zhes bstan pa'i phyir/
To teach that we look for a teacher who knows the method to pacify suffering, not one who knows the number of insects and so forth:

mi shes ston par byed pa la/ / 'khrul par dwogs pa can rnams kyis/ / de bshad nan tan bya ba'i phyir/ / shes ldan 'ga' zhig 'tshol bar byed/ / de phyir de yi bsgrub bya ru/ / gyur pa'i ye shes rnam dpyad bya'i/ / 'di yis srin bu'i grangs mkhyen pa/ / nged la 'gar yang nyer mkho med/ /

32. People who have suspicions of being confused By those who, without knowledge, act as teachers Will look for someone who possesses knowledge In order to act upon their explanations. 33. And for that purpose, they examine The wisdom that they need to achieve. We have no use at all for whether He knows how many bugs there are.

ces smos te/ sdug bsngal zhi ba'i thabs mi shes bzhin du ston par byed pa de la 'khrul bar dwogs pa can sdug bsngal zhi bar 'dod pa rnams kyis sdug bsngal zhi ba'i thabs mkhyen par ston pa des bshad pa'i thabs la nan tan gyis bslab par bya ba'i phyir du sdug bsngal zhi ba'i thabs shes pa dang ldan pa 'ga' zhig ston par 'tshol bar byed kyi/ srin bu'i grangs mkhyen pa ston par 'tshol bar mi byed pa de'i phyir na/ zhi ba don gnyer de'i bsgrub bya ru gyur pa'i sdug bsngal zhi ba'i thabs mkhyen pa'i ye shes yod dam med ces rnam par dpyad nas brten par bya'i/ 'di yis srin bu'i grangs mkhyen pa ni zhi ba don gnyer nged la 'gar yang nyer mkho med do/ /

People who want to pacify suffering have suspicions of being confused by those who, without knowledge of the methods to pacify suffering, act as teachers. They will look for someone as a teacher who possesses knowledge of the methods to pacify suffering in order to train in acting ardently upon the methods explained by this teacher who knows the methods to pacify suffering. They do not look for someone who knows the size of the insect population as their teacher. And for that reason, before they will follow him, they examine whether or not a teacher has the wisdom that knows the methods to pacify suffering, which are what they who want peace need to achieve. We who long for peace have no use at all for whether he knows how many bugs there are.
gnyis pa nye bar mkho ba mkhyen pa tshad mar bstan pa ni/
2. Teaching that knowing the necessary is validity
blang dang dor bya'i de nyid ni/ / thabs dang bcas pa rig mdzad pa/ / gang de tshad ma nyid 'dod kyi/ / thams cad rig mdzad ma yin no/ /
34. We assert that making known the suchness of What should be taken up, what given up Along with the methods is validity. It is not making everything known.

zhes smos te/ kho bo cag gi dgos pa'i don kun mkhyen pa'i ston pa ni blang bya 'gog pa'i bden pa dang de thob pa'i thabs lam bden dang / dor bya sdug bsngal bden pa'i de nyid ni shes par bya ba dang / de zhi ba'i thabs kun 'byung spong ba dang bcas pa rig par mdzad pa gang yin pa de tshad ma nyid du 'dod kyi/ bden bzhi'i gnas tshul mi shes na srin bu'i grangs sogs thams cad rig par mdzad kyang thar pa don gnyer la nye bar mkho ba ni ma yin no/ / de'i phyir/

The teacher who knows everything that is necessary for us makes known what should be taken up (the truth of cessation) along with the method for achieving it (the truth of the path), and the suchness of what must be given up (the truth of suffering that is to be known), along with the method to pacify that (eliminating the origin). We assert that such a one is valid. Someone who does not know the nature of the four truths might make everything known including the number of insects there are, but that is not necessary for those who long for liberation. For that reason:
ring po mthong ba'am min yang rung / / 'dod pa'i de nyid mthong ba yin/ / gal te ring mthong tshad yin na/ / tshur shog bya rgod brten par gyis/ /
35. Whether or not they do see far away, They should see the suchness that is desired. If seeing far away is validity, Come here and let us worship vultures!

zhes smos te/ 'dir dgos pa'i don kun mkhyen pa ni rgyang ring por mthong ba'i srin bu'i grangs mkhyen pa min yang rung thar pa don gnyer gyi ston par 'os pa yin te/ thar pa don gnyer gyi 'dod pa'i don bden bzhi'i blang dor thabs dang bcas pa de nyid rang gis phyin ci ma log par mthong nas gzhan la ston pa'i thugs rje can yin pa'i phyir ro/ / gal te 'dod pa'i don mi mkhyen yang thag ring por mthong ba dang srin bu'i grangs shes pa tsam tshad ma yin na/ 'o na rgyang 'phen dang dpyod pa ba khyed rnams tshur shog la sdug bsngal zhi ba'i thabs mkhyen pa dor la thag ring por mthong ba'i bya rgod ston par brten par gyis shig/

Here, whether or not those who know the necessary meaning do know the number of insects seen from far away, they are worthy to be the teachers of those who long for liberation, because they themselves have seen without error the very meaning that is desired by those who long for liberation—what is to be adopted and rejected, the four noble truths along with the method—and have the compassion to teach it to others. If merely seeing far away and knowing the number of insects even without knowing the desired meaning is validity, well then, come here, you Cārvākas and Mīmāṃsakas. Cast aside those who know the methods to pacify liberation and worship far-seeing vultures as your teacher.
gnyis pa rgyas par bshad pa la/
2. Detailed explanation.
rgyu phun tshogs rgyas par bshad/ 'bras bu phun tshogs rgyas par bshad pa'o/ /
This has two topics: a. The detailed explanation of the perfect cause, and b. The detailed explanation of the perfect result.
dang po [rgyu phun tshogs rgyas par bshad pa] la/
a. The detailed explanation of the perfect cause.
bsam pa phun tshogs 'gro la phan bzhed bshad/ sbyor ba phun tshogs ston pa bshad pa'o/ /
This has two topics: i. The explanation of the wish to help beings, the perfect intent, and ii. The explanation of the teacher, the perfect training.
dang po [bsam pa phun tshogs 'gro la phan bzhed bshad pa] la/
i. The explanation of the wish to help beings, the perfect intent.
spyi'i don dang / tshig gi don gnyis las/
This has two topics: (1) General discussion, and (2) The meaning of the text.
dang po [spyi'i don] ni/
(1) General discussion

tshad ma bslu med can shes pa/ / zhes bshad pa'i 'bras bu tshad ma de/ sgrub byed la bltos tshad yin rigs/ / zhes sgrub byed kyi rgyu phun sum tshogs pa sngon du song ba la bltos par bshad na/ rgyu phun sum tshogs pa de'ang ci lta bu zhe na/

If the resultant validity explained in the line, “The valid is an undeceiving mind” is explained in the lines “Thus based on the means / To achieve that, it's logical he is valid” to be based upon the preceding perfect cause, then what is the perfect cause? you ask.
'di la rang gi lugs bzhag pa dang / rgyu 'bras la chad par lta ba'i mtha' spang ba gnyis las/
This has two topics: (a) Presenting our own tradition, and (b Refuting the extreme of a nihilist view toward cause and result.
dang po [rang gi lugs bzhag pa] ni/
(a) Presenting our own tradition

sngar ji skad bshad pa'i mchod brjod kyi yul du gyur pa'i tshad ma de ni rgyu bsam pa phun sum tshogs pa 'gro la phan par bzhed pa'i thugs rje chen po yang nas yang du goms par byas pa las 'khrungs pa yin la/ snying rje chen po de'ang 'gro ba ma lus pa sdug bsngal gyi rgya mtsho chen po las sgrol bar bzhed pa'i rnam pa can gyis sems can la dmigs pa'i snying rje chen po dang / chos la dmigs pa'i snying rje chen po dang / dmigs pa med pa'i snying rje chen po dang gsum ste/ skyes bu chen po rnams snying rje gsum po de dag gi gzhan dbang du gyur pa las sems can rnams sdug bsngal gyi rgya mtsho chen po las sgrol bar 'dod pa'i blo skye la/ de'ang rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas ma yin pa sus kyang mi nus par shes nas 'gro ba yongs kyi gnyen du gyur pa sangs rgyas nyid yang dag par thob par 'dod pa'i lhag pa'i bsam pa skye zhing / de thob pa'i thabs kyang sbyor bas lam nyams su len pa las gzhan med do/ / lam nyams su len pa'ang sems can gyi don kho na las gzhan ma yin te/ rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas thob pa ni byang chub tu sems bskyed pa'i rtsa ba can yin la/ byang chub tu sems bskyed pa'ang snying rje chen po'i rtsa ba can yin cing / snying rje de'ang sdug bsngal ba'i sems can rnams la dmigs nas skye ba'i phyir ro/ / de'i dbang du mdzad nas 'jigs bral gyi slob dpon zla ba grags pas kyang / nyan thos sangs rgyas 'bring rnams thub dbang skyes/ / sangs rgyas byang chub sems dpa' las 'khrungs shing / / snying rje'i sems dang gnyis su med blo dang / / byang chub sems ni rgyal sras rnams kyi rgyu/ / zhes dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsang ba'i mdo las kyang / bcom ldan 'das byang chub tu sems bskyed pa su'i lags/ rgyal po chen po gang gis lhag pa'i bsam pa ma 'khrugs pa'o/ / gsol pa/ bcom ldan 'das su'i bsam pa ma 'khrugs/ bka' stsal pa/ rgyal po chen po gang gis snying rje chen po skye ba'i'o/ / gsol pa/ bcom ldan 'das su'i snying rje chen po skye/ bcom ldan 'das kyis bka' stsal pa/ rgyal po chen po gang gis sems can thams cad la yongs su mi gtong ba'i sems skye ba'i'o/ / zhes dang / ji skad du chos bcu pa'i mdo las kyang / rigs kyi bu 'di la byang chub sems dpa'i rigs la gnas pa byang chub tu sems bskyed na/ de bzhin gshegs pa'am de bzhin gshegs pa'i nyan thos kyis bskul zhing skyob par byas/ yang dag par 'dzin du bcug ste/ bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sems bskyed pa 'di ni byang chub kyi sems la mos pa'i rgyu dang po'o/ / rdzogs pa'i byang chub bam byang chub kyi sems kyi bsngags pa brjod pa thos nas bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sems bskyed pa 'di ni rgyu gnyis pa'o/ / sems can mgon med pa dang skyabs med pa dang dpung gnyen med pa rnams mthong nas snying rje'i sems nye bar bzhag ste/ bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sems bskyed pa 'di ni rgyu gsum pa'o/ / des de bzhin gshegs pa'i rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog yongs su rdzogs pa mthong nas dga' ba bskyed de/ bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu sems bskyed pa 'di ni rgyu bzhi pa'o/ / zhes gsungs so/ / bstan bcos 'dir yang bsam pa phun sum tshogs pa 'gro ba la phan par bzhed pa'i thugs rje chen po dang / sbyor ba phun sum tshogs pa 'khor ba'i rtsa ba 'joms par byed pa'i bdag med pa rnam pa gnyis la rang nyid kyis mnyam par 'jog cing lam de lta bu gzhan dag la yang ston pa'i sgo nas rang don bde bar gshegs pa dang / gzhan don skyob pa'i sku zung du 'jug pa'i rang bzhin can gyi tshad ma'i skyes bu thob par 'gyur ba yin no zhes bya ba ni rigs pa'i dbang phyug rnam pa gnyis ka'i dgongs pa bla na med pa'o/ /

The validity that was the object of the verse of homage explained above is born out of the cause, repeatedly cultivating the perfect intent, the great compassion that wishes to help all wanderers. Because it has the aspect of wishing to free each and every sentient being from the great ocean of suffering, such great compassion has three types: great compassion focused on sentient beings, great compassion focused on dhar-mas, and nonreferential great compassion. Great individuals come under the power of those three types of compassion and thus develop the wish to liberate sentient beings from the great ocean of suffering. Knowing that no one other than a perfect buddha is able to do that, they develop the superior intent of wishing to truly achieve the state of a buddha, who is a friend for all beings. There is no other method to achieve that than the training of practicing the path. Practicing the path, as well, is not for anything other than solely the sake of sentient beings, because achieving perfect buddhahood has the resolve of bodhichitta as its root, and the resolve of bodhichitta has great compassion as its root. That compassion, as well, is born out of a focus on suffering sentient beings. It is in these terms that the fearless master Candrakīrti said: The listeners and mid-buddhas are born from the Sage. The buddhas are born from bodhisattvas. Compassionate wishes, a nondual mind, And bodhichitta are the causes of the victors' children.[80] From The Sutra of the Tathagata's Secret: “Bhagavan, who has the resolve of bodhichitta?” “Great King, those whose superior intent is not disturbed.” He asked: “Bhagavan, whose superior intent is not disturbed?” “Great king, those who develop great compassion.” He asked, “Bhagavan, who develops great compassion?” The Bhagavan spoke: “Great king, those who develop the resolve to never give up on any sentient being.”[81] And as it is also said in The Sutra of Ten Dharmas: Child of noble family, here when those who dwell in the family of the bodhisattvas arouse the resolve of bodhichitta, the Tathagata or the Tathagata's disciples encourage and protect them and make them properly uphold it. This resolve for unexcelled completely perfect enlightenment is the first cause of longing for bodhichitta. Arousing the resolve of unexcelled completely perfect enlightenment upon hearing someone praise perfect enlightenment or bodhichitta is the second cause. Recollecting the attitude of compassion upon seeing sentient beings who have no protector, no refuge, and no champion and then arousing the resolve for unexcelled completely perfect enlightenment is the third cause. Seeing the Tathagatas' supremely complete utter perfection, feeling joy, and then developing the resolve of unexcelled completely perfect enlightenment is the fourth cause.[82] According to this treatise as well, by way of the perfect intent— great compassion that wishes to benefit wanderers—and the perfect training—meditating on the two selflessnesses that destroy the root of samsara oneself and teaching that path to others as well—one achieves the state of a valid being whose nature is the union of the benefit for oneself—the sugata—and the benefit for others—the kayas of the protector. This is the unexcelled thought of both Lords of Reasoning.[83]
gnyis pa rgyu 'bras la chad par blta ba'i mtha' bsal ba la/
(b) Refuting the extreme of a nihilist view toward cause and result.
rgyang 'phen pa'i lugs brjod/ de dgag pa/ bkag pa'i dgos pa bshad pa'o/ /
This has three points: (i) Presenting the Cārvāka tradition, (ii) Refuting it, and (iii) Explaining why it is necessary to refute the nihilist view.
dang po [rgyang 'phen pa'i lugs brjod pa] ni/
(i) Presenting the Cārvāka tradition

tshad ma rgya mtsho mtha' yas las bshad pa ltar shes par bya ste/ rgyu la skur ba 'debs pa dang / 'bras bu la skur ba 'debs pa dang / ma mthong ba'i don la skur ba 'debs pa dang / tshad ma la skur ba 'debs pa dang / tshad ma'i skyes bu la skur ba 'debs pa ste rgyang 'phen pas skur ba rnam pa lnga 'debs pa yin no/ / dang po ni/ chos thams cad la rgyu med par 'dod de/ sems can skye ba las gzhan du dge ba dang mi dge ba'i las bsags pa'i rgyu can ma yin pa'i phyir te/ 'das pa'i 'jig rten de nas 'dir 'ong ba med pa'i phyir ro/ / des na dngos po rnams rgyu gtan med par skyes te/ sa la sogs pa 'dus pa'i phyi rol ni mngon par mi gsal ba'i sems can yin la/ srog chags rnams ni mngon par gsal ba'i sems can 'jig rten pha rol nas ma 'ongs pa'i skyes bu yin te/ pha'i sa bon dang ma'i khrag la sogs pa 'dus pa las gsal zhing rig par 'gyur ba'i phyir/ dper na nas dang phabs la sogs pa las chang byung ba bzhin no/ / dngos por gyur pa rgyu med pa las skye bar 'dod pa ni/ drang srong 'jug stobs can la sogs pa ste/ sran zlum tsher ma gzengs ring rno ba dang / / rma bya'i sgro gshog ri mo bkra ba dang / / nyi shar chu bo thur du 'bab pa ni/ / sus kyang ma byas ngo bo nyid kyi rgyu/ / zhes 'byung ste/ sran ma'i zlum po gzhan gyis ma byas pa la sogs pa dngos po thams cad rgyu med pa yin no zhes zer ro/ /

This should be known according to the explanation in Infinite Oceans of Validity. The Cārvākas have five kinds of denial: denial of cause, denial of result, denial of unseen objects, denial of validity, and denial of the valid being. As for the first, they assert that all phenomena have no cause. This is because other than birth, sentient beings are not caused by the accumulation of virtuous or unvirtuous actions, because there is no coming from a past world to this one. Therefore things arise without any cause at all. External assemblies of earth and so forth are unmanifest sentient beings, whereas living creatures are manifest sentient beings—individuals who do not come from another world—because clear awareness comes from the combination of the father's semen, the mother's blood, and so forth. For example, it is just as beer arises out of barley, yeast, and so forth. They assert that things arise without cause. The rishi Juktopchen[84] and others say: That peas are round, that long high thorns are sharp, That peacock feathers have such bright designs, And that the sun has light and waters flow down hill Are not made by anyone; the cause is in their essence. The roundness of peas is not made by anything else and so forth; all things have no cause, they claim.

'bras bu la skur ba 'debs pa ni/ 'tsho ba ma phyid pa'i skyes bu sgyu ma can gyis lam gyi bzhi mdor spyang ki'i rjes bris te/ grong khyer pa la srin po spyang ki zhes bya ba zhig gis grong khyer pa za bar 'gyur bas de bzlog pa'i rim gror zas dang nor phyi rol du bor la zhag bdun du khyim las ma 'gul cig ces smra ba bzhin du/ mang du thos pa'i dge sbyong go'u ta mas skye ba phyi ma'i 'jigs pa smras kyang de ni yod pa ma yin te/ blo lus kyi rang bzhin yin pas lus thal bar gyur pa na blo yang rgyun chad pas skye ba phyi ma med pa'i phyir te/ ma shi tshe na dga' mgur spyod/ / shi na de yi spyod yul min/ / lus kyang thal ba bzhin song bas/ / slar skye ba lta ga la yod/ / kye ma mang thos gang smra ba/ / de ni spyang ki'i rjes dang mtshungs/ / zhes dang / mdzes ma legs par spyod cing za bar gyis/ / lus mchog 'das gang de khyod la mi 'gyur/ / lus 'di tshogs par gyur pa tsam zhig ste/ / 'jig gam song ba ldog par mi 'gyur ro/ / zhes skye ba snga phyi med pas dge ba dang mi dge ba'i 'bras bu med do zhes zer ro/ /

As for denying the result: an illusionist whose livelihood was insufficient drew wolf prints at an intersection. He then told the townspeople that a demon called “The Wolf” would eat them all and that in order to prevent this, the townspeople should throw all food and wealth out- side and not leave their houses for seven days. Similarly, the learned renunciate Gautama spoke of the terrors of future lives, but those do not exist. Since the mind has a physical nature, when the body passes away, the mind also ceases. Thus there is no future life: Enjoy pleasures while you are not dead; Once you die, you can't enjoy them. Since the body as well will become ash, How can there be another birth? Alas, that which the learned one has said Is just the same as a wolf's prints. Also: Enjoy the beautiful girl well and eat. When your great body has passed away, you will not have them. This body is merely an assembly. What is destroyed and gone will not come back. Since there are no past or future lives, there are no results of virtue or nonvirtue, they say.

ma mthong ba la skur ba 'debs pa ni/ mngon sum gyi spyod yul ma yin pa lha dang sems can dmyal ba la sogs pa med do zhes zer ro/ / tshad ma la skur ba 'debs pa ni/ rjes dpag yul la 'khrul ba'i phyir tshad ma ma yin pas tshad ma ni mngon sum kho nar zad do zhes zer ro/ / tshad ma'i skyes bu la skur ba 'debs pa ni/ lus zhig pa na shes pa 'gags pas bskal ba du mar de kho na nyid goms pa mi 'thad pa dang / mngon sum gyis ma mthong bas thams cad mkhyen pa dang / sems 'dod chags dang bral ba med do zhes smra ba yin no/ / de dag gis kyang byed pa po'i bdag med pa dang / 'dus byas mi rtag pa mi spong yang 'du byed las dang nyon mongs las byung zhing skyes pa nyid nas 'chi ba'i sdug bsngal nye bar sbyor ba srid pa nas yang srid par sbyor zhing / 'khor ba sdug bsngal gyi rgya mtsho chen por gzhol ba la skur ba btab pas zag pa dang bcas pa thams cad sdug bsngal du khas mi len la/ thams cad mkhyen pa dang sems 'dod chags dang bral ba med par smra bas mya ngan las 'das pa zhi ba'ang khas mi len to/ /

As for denying the unseen, they say that gods, beings in hell, and so forth, which are not in the sphere of perception, do not exist. As for denying validity, they say that since inference is confused about the object, it is not valid, so only perception is valid. As for denying the valid being, they say that when the body perishes, the mind also ceases so it is not reasonable to meditate on suchness for many aeons. They also say that since they are not seen with perception, there is no omniscience and no mind that is free of desire. They do not refute that there is no self who is an agent or that all composites are impermanent. However, they deny that formations arise out of karma and afflictions, that the suffering of death is brought about by birth itself, that one existence is connected to the next, and that one sinks into the great ocean of samsaric suffering. Thus they do not accept that everything defiled is suffering. They say there is no omniscience or mind free from desire, so they also do not accept nirvana as peace.
gnyis pa de dgag pa ni/
(ii) Refuting it

blo ni blo snga ma sngon du song bar myong bas grub pas/ rgyu snga ma sngon du ma song ba'i blo mi srid de/ sa bon sngon du ma song ba'i myu gu mi srid pa bzhin no/ / des na rgyu la skur ba 'debs pa mi 'thad do/ / blo tsam la blo phyi ma bskyed pa'i nus pa yod par myong bas grub pas blo phyi ma mi bskyed pa'i blo med de/ 'od mi bskyed pa'i mar me mi srid pa bzhin no/ / mngon sum gyis ma mthong ba tsam las tshad ma'i skyes bu khegs na/ khyod nyid kyi mig dang / snying dang / so yang ma mthong ba'i phyir med par 'gyur ro/ / ma mthong ba'i rtags las thams cad mkhyen pa sogs med par sgrub pa dang / rjes dpag tshad ma med par khas len pa 'gal ba'i phyir ro/ / des na ma mthong ba'i don dang / rjes su dpag pa dang / tshad ma'i skyes bu la skur ba 'debs pa rnams mi 'thad do/ /

Experience proves that cognition is preceded by a previous cognition. Thus a cognition not preceded by a cause is impossible, just as a shoot not preceded by a seed is impossible. Therefore it is not logical to deny the cause. That mere cognition has the capacity to produce the next cognition is proven by experience. Thus there is no cognition that does not produce a later cognition, just as a lamp that does not produce light is impossible. If you refute the existence of a valid being just because you do not perceive him, then your eyes, heart, and teeth also do not exist because you do not see them. Proving that omniscience and so forth do not exist because of the evidence that they are not seen and asserting that there is no inferential validity are contradictory.[85] Therefore it is not logical to deny unseen objects, inference, and valid beings.
gsum pa de bkag pa'i dgos pa bshad pa ni/
(iii) Explaining why it is necessary to refute the nihilist view

de ltar skye ba snga phyi med pa dang / tshad ma'i skyes bu med pa la gnod byed kyi rigs pa mthong ba na shugs kyis 'jig rten pha rol dang tshad ma'i skyes bu yod par khong du chud par 'gyur la/ de ltar khong du chud pa'i skyes bu ni tshe 'di yi bde ba 'ba' zhig don du gnyer ba ma yin gyi/ 'jig rten pha rol tu phan pa'i don 'ga' zhig kyang 'tshol bar byed de/ bdag la tshe 'di 'ba' zhig tu gnas pa'i dbang med kyi gdon mi za bar 'jig rten pha rol tu 'gro dgos so snyam du khong du chud par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / dper na yul khams gzhan du tshong la song ba'i skyes bu ni yul khams gzhan bde zhing skyid par mthong yang rang gi bu dang chung ma la sogs pa yid la byas nas/ kho bo yul 'dir gtan du gnas pa'i go skabs med kyi/ myur du rang gi yul du 'gro dgos so snyam ste/ yul de nas rang gi yul du nye bar mkho ba'i zong dag sgrub pa la brtson pa bzhin du 'jig rten pha rol du phan pa'i dngos po 'tshol bar 'dod pa de dag gis kyang 'jig rten pha rol du phan pa'i dngos po mngon par mtho ba dang nges par legs pa'i lam gyi dngos po 'tshol dgos pa yin la/ de yang mngon par 'dod pa'i don la bslu ba med cing yid ches pa'i gnas su gyur pa'i skyes bu'am/ yid ches pa'i lung 'ga' zhig las 'tshol bar byed dgos te/ rgyas pa las/ mi shes ston par byed pa la/ / 'khrul bar dogs pa can rnams kyis/ / de bshad nan tan bya ba'i phyir/ / shes ldan 'ga' zhig 'tshol bar byed/ / ces pa ltar ro/ /

When one sees the logic that refutes the lack of past or future lives or the lack of a valid being, one automatically realizes that there are future lives and valid beings. People who have realized this are not interested only in the pleasures of this life but also make effort at some things that bring benefit in the next life, because they understand that they have no power to stay in this life alone and definitely must go to the next world. For example, a person who goes to another country on business may see the other country as nice and pleasant, but when they turn their attention to their children, spouse, and so forth, they think, “I do not have the opportunity to stay in this country forever but must quickly return to my own country.” They then strive to acquire in that land the merchandise needed in their own country. Similarly, those who wish to seek out things that will help in the next life should seek the things that help in the next world, the paths to higher states and true excellence. They must look for these from an authoritative individual whom they can believe or an authoritative scripture that will not deceive them about that for which they long. As it says in the Commentary: People who have suspicions of being confused By those who, without knowledge, act as teachers Will look for someone who possesses knowledge In order to act upon their explanations.[86]

kha cig ni/ 'jig rten pha rol yod par khas len kyang / der mkho ba'i thabs 'tshol ba la mkhas pa ma yin te/ tshad ma dang tshad min gyi rnam dbye la mi mkhas par rigs pa ltar snang 'ga' zhig la brten nas mtho ris kyi thabs su srog gi mchod sbyin dang / thar pa'i thabs su 'jug ngogs kyi khrus la sogs pa ston pa'i lung dang / lung de lta bu byed pa po'i skyes bu ston par khas len pa'i phyir ro/ / gang dag tshad ma'i mtshan nyid phyin ci ma log par shes pa dag ni lung la dad pa tsam gyis 'jug pa ni ma yin no/ / 'on kyang lung des mngon gyur dang lkog gyur bstan pa la go rim bzhin du mngon sum dang rjes su dpag pa'i tshad ma la brten pa'i rigs pas gnod pa yod med dpyad cing / gnas skabs thams cad du snga phyi'am dngos shugs 'gal ba la sogs pa lung byed pa po'i rang tshig gis gnod pa yod med dpyod par byed de/ rgyas pa las/ mthong dang ma mthong ba dag la/ / rigs pas grub dang rang tshig gis/ / gnod med bstan bcos gang yin te/ / gzung bar bya phyir dpyod 'jug 'gyur/ / zhes so/ / de ltar dpyad pa gsum gyis dag pa'i lung dang lung byed pa po mtshungs pa'i rtags las mtho ris dang thar pa la sogs pa'i shin tu lkog gyur gyi blang dor byed pa'i thabs ston pa'i lung dang / lung byed pa po'i skyes bu yang yid ches pa'i gnas su khas len par rigs pa yin te/ rgyas pa las/ yid ches tshig ni mi bslu ba'i/ / spyi las rjes su dpag pa nyid/ / ces so/ / de lta bu'i lung dang lung byed pa pos kyang bsod nams dang mi g.yo ba'i las mngon par 'du byas pa las 'dod khams kyi lha mi dang / khams gong ma'i bsam gtan gyi bde ba thob la/ bsod nams ma yin pa'i las mngon par 'du byas pa las ngan 'gro'i sdug bsngal 'byung ngo / / zhes sogs mngon mtho dang nges legs kyi lam phyin ci ma log par ston pas/ de dag yid ches kyi gnas su khas len pa dag gis kyang de dag gis rjes su bstan pa ltar nyams su len pa'i phyir ro/ /

Some accept that there is a next world, but do not know how to seek the methods necessary for it. Not knowing the distinction between valid and invalid, on the basis of some fallacious reasonings they accept scriptures that teach live sacrifice as a method to achieve the high realms and bathing on a river bank as a method for liberation, and they accept the individuals who created those scriptures as teachers. Those who unmistakenly know the characteristics of validity do not proceed merely out of faith in scriptures. Instead, through those scriptures they analyze the teachings about the evident and the hidden through logic based respectively on perceptual and inferential validity to see whether or not they are contraverted. At all times, they examine whether the words of the scriptures' author contradict their own words in earlier or later passages either explicitly or implicitly. As it says in the Commentary: In order to retain them, one engages In the analysis of scriptures that Establish logically the seen and unseen Or do not contradict their own words.[87] Thus from the evidence of scriptures purified by the three analyses[88] and the authors of such scriptures being comparable, it is logical to assert that scriptures that teach the extremely hidden methods of what to adopt and what to reject for the high realms and liberation and the authors of those scriptures are authoritative sources. From the Commentary: Authoritative words are inference From universals that are undeceiving.[89] Such scriptures and authors also teach the unmistaken paths to the higher states and true excellence, saying that by performing meritorious and unmoving karma, one achieves the pleasures of the gods and humans of the Desire realm and of the dhyanas of the higher realms, whereas from performing nonmeritorious acts the suffering of the lower realms arises. Thus those who assert that these are authoritative sources practice what they teach.

de ltar tshe 'dir dge sdig la blang dor phyin ci ma log par byed pa ni tshad ma'i mtshan nyid ston pa'i bstan bcos las shes pa tshe 'dir thob pa'i phan yon yin no/ / tshe phyi mar thob pa'i phan yon ni/ de ltar blang dor byas pa las ma 'ongs pa'i skye bar ngan song gi 'gro ba rgyang ring du spangs nas mngon par mtho ba lha mi'i bde ba thob pa'o/ / mthar thug gi dgos pa ni/ ji skad du bstan bcos 'bring las/ bsam pa las byung ba nyid kyi shes rab goms par byas pas rnam par 'khrul bas 'khrul ba dben zhing dri ma med pa don dam pa'i tshad ma mngon du byed do/ / zhes gsungs pa ltar/ shes rab kyis phyi nang gi dngos po rnams la mi rtag pa dang bdag med pa la sogs pa dngos po'i gnas lugs la yongs su dpyad nas rim gyis goms par byas pa las goms pa rab kyi mthar phyin pa na/ goms bya bdag med pa'i don la gsal snang rab kyi mthar phyin pa thob pa'i don dam pa'i tshad ma mngon du byed par 'gyur la/ de ltar bdag med pa mngon sum du rtogs pa don dam pa'i tshad ma mngon du gyur pa na bdag dang bdag gir 'dzin pa'i mtshan nyid can gyi 'jig tshogs la blta ba ldog cing / de log pas kyang de'i rjes su 'brang ba'i 'khor bar skye ba'i rgyu las dang nyon mongs pa mtha' dag log par 'gyur bas/ mthar 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal thams cad gtan du zhi ba'i thar pa bla na med pa'i bde ba dam pa thob pa ni 'dir mthar thug gi dgos pa dam pa yin no/ / de ltar na rtag pa dang chad par blta ba'i lta ba ngan pa dang phyin ci log gi lam rigs pas sun phyungs nas yang dag pa'i lta ba dang lam phyin ci ma log pa la 'jug par 'gyur ba'i dgos pa khyad par can dang ldan pa'i tshad ma'i mtshan nyid kyi bstan bcos ni bstan pa dang sems can la phan par 'dod pa'i lhag bsam dang ldan pa dag gis brtsam par bya zhing / bdag gzhan legs su 'dod pa rnams kyis thos pa dang bsam pa bsgom pa'i sgo nas 'jug par bya'o/ /

Therefore unmistakenly practicing virtue and giving up misdeeds in this life is a benefit one receives in this life from knowing what is taught in the treatises that teach the characteristics of validity. The benefits received in future lives is that by thus doing what should be done and giving up what should not, one leaves future rebirth in the lower realms far behind and achieves the pleasures of the higher states of gods and humans. The ultimate purpose is as described in the Ascertainment: Cultivating the intelligence produced by contemplation separates one from the confusion of misunderstanding and manifests the ultimate stainless validity.[90] After thoroughly analyzing with intelligence the nature of things— impermanence, selflessness, and so forth—in external and internal things, one gradually cultivates them. When one has come to the culmination of that training, the ultimate valid cognition achieved as the culmination of the clear appearance of the meaning of selflessness that one cultivated becomes manifest. When selflessness is thus directly realized and ultimate validity becomes manifest, personality view, which has the characteristic of clinging to me and mine, is stopped. Stopping that prevents the causes of rebirth in samsara that follow it, all karma and afflictions. In the end, one achieves the sublime bliss of unexcelled liberation, which is the pacification of all samsaric suffering forever. This is the sublime, utmost purpose. In this way, after the wrong views of eternalism and nihilism and the erroneous paths have been disproven through logic, one will enter the right view and unmistaken path. This is the special purpose of treatises that teach the characteristics. These treatises are written by those who have the altruistic wish to help the teachings and sentient beings. Those who wish for excellence for themselves and others engage them through listening, contemplating, and meditating.
gnyis pa tshig gi don la/
(2) The meaning of the text.
rang gi gzhung 'dzugs pa dang / de la rtsod pa spang ba'o/ /
This has two topics: (a) Establishing our own position, and (b) Refuting criticism.
dang po [rang gi gzhung 'dzugs pa] ni/
(a) Establishing our own position
sgrub byed la bltos tshad yin rigs/ / zhes bshad pa'i sgrub byed de gang zhe na/ bshad pa/
When it says, “Thus based on the means / To achieve that, it's logical he is valid” what are the means? you ask. To explain:
sgrub byed thugs rje goms las de/ /
36a The means is compassion. That's from cultivation.

zhes smos te/ tshad ma'i skyes bu de'i sgrub byed kyi rgyu phun sum tshogs pa ni 'gro ba ma lus pa sdug bsngal gyi rgya mtsho chen po las gtan du sgrol bar bzhed pa'i rnam pa can gyi thugs rje chen po de nyid skye ba du mar yang dang yang du goms par byas pa las tshad ma'i skyes bu de grub pas na de'i sgrub byed kyi rgyu yin no/ /

The perfect cause that is the means to achieve the state of a valid being is the cultivation repeatedly over many lifetimes of the great compassion that wishes to liberate all wandering beings forever from the great ocean of suffering. One achieves the state of a valid being from that, so that is the cause by which one achieves that state.
gnyis pa de la rtsod pa spang ba la/
(b) Refuting criticism.
skye ba du mar goms pa mi 'thad pa'i rtsod pa spang ba/ goms kyang thams cad mkhyen pa mi srid pa'i rtsod pa spang ba'o/ /
This has two topics: (i) Refuting the argument that cultivation over many lifetimes is not tenable, and (ii) Refuting the argument that even with cultivation, omniscience would be impossible.
dang po [skye ba du mar goms pa mi 'thad pa'i rtsod pa spang ba] la/
(i) Refuting the argument that cultivation over many lifetimes is not tenable.
rtsod pa dgod pa dang / de rigs pas spang ba gnyis las/
This has two topics: A. Presenting the criticism, and B. Refuting it logically.
dang po [rtsod pa dgod pa] ni/
A. Presenting the criticism
tshu rol mdzes pa ba na re/
The Cārvākas say:
blo ni lus la brten pa'i phyir/ / goms pas grub pa med ce na/ /
36bc They say, “The mind's supported by the body So it is not achieved through cultivation.”

zhes smos te/ snying rje la sogs pa'i blo ni lus 'bras yin la/ lus kyi 'bras bu thams cad lus kyi yon tan yin pas lus la brten pa'i phyir lus zhig pa na blo yang 'jig par 'gyur ro/ / dper na rtsig pa dang ri mo bzhin no/ / de'i phyir snying rje skye ba du mar goms pas tshad ma'i skyes bur grub pa med do zhe na/

Compassion and other mental states are results of the body, and all the results of the body are physical qualities. Thus the mind is supported by the body, so when the body perishes, it perishes as well. As an analogy, it is like a wall and mural. For that reason, it (the state of a valid being) is not achieved through the cultivation of compassion for many lives, they say.
gnyis pa de rigs pas spang ba la/
B. Refuting it logically.
mdor bstan pa dang / rgyas par bshad pa'o/ /
This has two topics: 1. Brief overview, and 2. Detailed explanation.
dang po [mdor bstan pa] la/
1. Brief overview.
skye ba snga phyi med pa dgag/ dbang sogs rang gi rigs la ltos med du 'byung ba las byung bar 'dod pa dgag pa'o/ /
This has two points: a. Refuting that there are no past or future lives, and b. Refuting the assertion that the faculties and so forth arise without depending on their own kind.
dang po [skye ba snga phyi med pa] ni/
a. Refuting that there are no past or future lives
ma yin rten ni bkag phyir ro/ /
36d Not so, since the support has been refuted.
zhes smos te/ snying rje la sogs pa'i blo ni lus la brten pa'i rgyu mtshan gyis lus zhig pa na rgyun chad pa ma yin te/ lus blo yi rten yin pa de ni tshad mas bkag pa'i phyir ro/ /

It is not so that compassion and other mental states cease when the body perishes because of being supported by the body. This is since it has been validly refuted that the body is the support for the mind.
tshad mas ji ltar bkag ce na/ bshad pa/
How is it validly refuted? you say. To explain:
skye ba yongs su len pa na/ / 'byung rngub dbang po blo dag ni/ / rang gi rigs la bltos med can/ / lus nyid 'ba' zhig las skyes min/ / ha cang thal phyir/
37. When one takes birth, the inhalation and The exhalation, faculties, and mind Do not arise from just the physical Without depending upon their own kind, 38a For that would be absurd.

zhes smos te/ sems can rnams skye ba yongs su len pa na dbugs 'byung rngub dang / mig sogs dbang po dang blo dag ni rang gi rigs 'dra snga ma la bltos pa med pa can du lus nyid 'ba' zhig las skyes pa ma yin te/ de ltar min na sa chu la sogs pa'i 'byung ba yang dbugs 'byung rngub dang dbang po dang sems dang ldan par ha cang thal ches pa'i phyir ro/ /

At the time when sentient beings take birth, the inhalation and the exhalation of breath, faculties such as the eye faculty, and the mind do not arise just from the physical body without depending upon previous instances of their own kind, for otherwise there would be the extremely absurd consequence that the elements of earth, water, and so forth would have respiration, faculties, and mind.
gzhan yang /
In addition:
mtshams sbyor dang / / nus ldan mthong ba gang de la/ / ci zhig yod 'gyur gang med pa/ / gang gis phyi nas mtshams sbyor med/ /
38a-d What else is there Than the capacity to make a link That has been seen? There is not anything. And due to what would it no longer link?

ces smos te/ dbugs 'byung rngub dang dbang sogs de dag sngar skye ba len pa'i dus su rang gi rigs 'dra phyi mar mtshams sbyor bar nus pa dang ldan par mthong ba gang yin pa de la phyis 'chi ba'i rang gi rigs 'dra phyi ma mtshams mi sbyor ba'i rgyu lhag po ci zhig yod par 'gyur te gang yang med pa'i phyir ro/ / rgyu mtshan gang gis na rang gi rigs 'dra snga ma des phyi nas mtshams sbyor ba med par 'dod de 'dod mi rigs so/ /

That inhalation and exhalation, the faculties, and so forth have the capacity to make a link to a subsequent instance of their own kind has been seen previously at the time of taking birth. What else—what extra cause—is there that would later at the time of death prevent linking to a subsequent instance of their own kind? There is not anything. Due to what reason do you assert that the previous instance of its kind would no longer link? It is illogical to assert that.
gnyis pa dbang sogs rang gi rigs la bltos med du 'byung ba las 'byung bar 'dod pa dgag pa ni/
b. Refuting the assertion that the faculties and so forth arise without depending on their own kind

tshu rol mdzes pa ba na re/ dbang sogs rang gi rigs 'dra snga ma la bltos pa med par 'byung ba las skye yang sa chu sogs thams cad dbugs 'byung rngub dang / dbang po dang / sems dang ldan par thal ba'i skyon med de/ sa sogs 'byung ba'i cha shas 'ga' zhig la sems can gyi sa bon med la/ sa sogs 'ga' zhig mngon par gsal ba'i sems dang ldan pa'i srog chags su 'gyur ro zhe na/ bshad pa/

The Cārvākas say that the faculties and so forth do not arise in dependence on a previous instance of their kind. Though they arise, there is no fault that consequentially the earth, water, and so forth would have inhalation and exhalation, faculties, or mind. Some portions of the elements of earth and so forth lack the seeds for sentient beings, but some earth and so forth can become living beings who have manifestly clear minds, they say. To explain:
gang du drod gsher la sogs pa/ / skye bo skye bar mi 'gyur ba'i/ / sa sogs cha de 'ga' yang med/ / de phyir thams cad sa bon bdag/
39. There is not any portion at all of earth And so forth in which living beings may not Be born from warmth and moisture and so forth. Therefore all by nature is a seed.

ces smos te/ sa chu sogs 'byung ba'i cha gang du drod gsher dang / mngal dang rdzus skyes la sogs skye bo skye bar mi 'gyur ba'i sa sogs 'byung ba'i cha de 'ga' yang med pa de'i phyir/ sa sogs 'byung ba'i cha thams cad srog chags kyi sa bon gyi bdag nyid du 'gyur ro/ /

There is not any portion at all of the elements of earth and so forth in which living beings may not be born from warmth and moisture, the womb, miraculous birth, and so forth.[91] Therefore all portions of the elements of earth and so forth by nature are seeds of living beings.
des na sa sogs 'byung ba thams cad srog chags su 'gyur ro zhes bstan pa'i phyir/
Therefore, to teach that the elements of earth and so forth would all become living beings:
de phyir dbang sogs rang rig la/ / bltos med par ni 'byung yin na/ / ji ltar cis ni yongs 'gyur bzhin/ / kun 'gyur khyad par med phyir ro/ /
40. Therefore, if faculties and so forth were To arise without depending on their kind, Then just as one becomes, so too would all, Because there is not any difference.

zhes smos te/ sa sogs 'byung ba thams cad srog chags kyi sa bon yin pa de'i phyir/ yid blo dang dbang po dbugs 'byung rngub la sogs pa rnams rang gi rigs 'dra snga ma la bltos pa med par nyer len 'byung ba'i lus kho na las ni 'byung ba yin na/ ji ltar sa sogs 'byung ba'i cha gcig ni srog chags su yongs su 'gyur ba bzhin du sa sogs 'byung ba'i cha kun srog chags su 'gyur te/ srog chags kyi nyer len byed pa'i sa sogs dang 'byung bar khyad par med pa'i phyir ro/ /

Since all elements of earth and so forth are the seeds of living creatures, therefore if the mental mind,[92] faculties, breathing, and so forth were to arise solely from the substantial cause of the physical body made of elements without depending on previous instances of their own kind, then just as one portion of the elements of earth and so forth becomes a living creature, so too would all portions of the earth and so forth become living creatures, because there is not any difference between the elements and the earth and so forth that function as the substantial cause for living creatures.
gnyis pa rgyas par bshad pa la/
2. Detailed explanation.
sems lus kyi yon tan yin pa dgag/ lus sems rdzas gcig pa dgag/ sems lus kyi 'bras bu yin pa dgag/ rtsod pa spang ba'o/ /

This has four topics: a. Refuting that mind is a quality of the body, b. Refuting that mind and body are the same in substance, c. Refuting that mind is a result of the body, and d. Refuting criticism.
dang po [sems lus kyi yon tan yin pa dgag pa] la/
a. Refuting that mind is a quality of the body.

lus sems kyi bdag rkyen yin pa dgag/ shi lus la sems yod par thal bas dgag/ lus sems kyi nyer len yin pa dgag/ phan mi 'dogs pa'i don gzhan rten dang brten par 'dod pa dgag/ shes rab la sogs pa lus la brten pa bye brag tu dgag pa'o/ /

This has five topics: i. Refuting that the body is the dominant condition for the mind, ii. Refuting through the consequence that a dead body would have mind, iii. Refuting that the body is the substantial cause of the mind, iv. Refuting the assertion that objects that are other and do not affect each other are supporter and supported, and v. Refuting in particular that intelligence and so forth are supported by the body.
dang po [lus sems kyi bdag rkyen yin pa dgag pa] la/
i. Refuting that the body is the dominant condition for the mind.
dbang po 'gyur rjes su sems mi 'gyur bas rten du rung ba/ lus rtag pa yin pas rten du mi rung / skye ba phyi ma med pa'i rgyu mtshan dgag/ dbang po dang bcas ma bcas la brtags nas dgag pa'o/ /

This has four topics: (1) The mind does not change after the faculties change, so it should be the support, (2) Refuting that if the body were permanent, it could not be a support, (3) Refuting the reasons why there would be no future rebirth, and (4) Refuting by examining whether it arises from a body that has faculties or that does not.
dang po [dbang po 'gyur rjes su sems mi 'gyur bas rten du rung ba] la/
(1) The mind does not change after the faculties change, so it should be the support.
dngos dang / bcom ldan 'das kyi lung dang 'gal ba spang ba gnyis las/
This has two points: (a) Actual, and (b) Refuting that it is contradictory of the Bhagavan’s scriptures.
dang po [dngos] ni/
(a) Actual
dbang rnams re re la gnod na/ / yid blo la gnod yod ma yin/ / 'di 'gyur na ni de dag kyang / / 'gyur ba dag tu mthong ba yin/ /
41. If individual faculties Are harmed, there is not any harm To mental mind. But if that changes, Those are seen to change as well.

ces smos te/ mig sogs dbang po rnams re re la rkyen gzhan gyis gnod pa na/ yid blo la gnod pa yod pa ma yin pa'i phyir/ yid blo ni lus la brten pa ma yin no/ / des na lus yid blo la brten pa yin te/ yid blo 'di 'dod 'jigs dang mya ngan sogs kyis 'gyur na ni mig sogs dbang po de dag kyang 'gyur ba dag tu tshad mas mthong ba yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

If the individual faculties of the eye and so forth are harmed by some other condition, there is not any harm to the mental mind. For this reason, the mental mind is not supported by the body. Thus the body is supported by the mental mind, because if that mental mind is changed by desire, fear, sorrow, and so forth, those faculties of the eye and so forth are validly seen to change as well.
yid blo lus la ma brten kyang dbang sogs yid blo la brten par bstan pa'i phyir/
To teach that mental mind is not supported by the body but that the faculties and so forth are supported by the mental mind:
de phyir blo gnas pa yi rten/ / blo nyid la ni brten pa 'ga'/ / dbang po rnams kyi rgyu yin pas/ / de phyir blo las dbang po yin/ /
42. So therefore the support for mind to abide And some that are supported by the mind Are the causes of the faculties, and thus The faculties are from the mental mind.

ces smos te/ yid blo lus la brten pa ma yin par mig sogs dbang po yid blo la brten pa de'i phyir/ yid blo'i rgyun gnas pa'i rten dang rgyu rigs 'dra'i blo snga ma nyid la ni brten pa'i las sems pa'i ming can 'ga' zhig 'dod gzugs su skyes pa'i dbang po rnams kyi rgyu yin la/ rgyu yin pas de'i phyir yid blo las dbang po gzugs can rnams skye ba yin no/ /

The mental mind is not supported by the body, whereas the eyes and other faculties are supported by the mental mind. So therefore the support for the continuum of the mental mind to abide and some kar-mas called volitional that depend on the cause of previous instances of their own kind are the causes of the faculties that arise in the Desire and Form realms. As those are the causes, thus the physical faculties arise from the mental mind.[93]
gzhan yang /
Additionally:
de 'dra'i phan byed yod gyur na/ / phyis kyang de 'drar 'gyur ba yin/ /
43ab If there has been a propeller such as this, Later as well there will be such as that.

ces smos te/ skyes bu 'chi kha ma'i yid blo de ni sngar skye ba len pa'i dbang sogs de dang rigs 'dra ba'i dbang sogs 'phen byed kyi rgyur yod par 'gyur na/ phyis kyang sngar skye ba len pa'i gnas skabs de dang 'dra bar dbang sogs 'phen byed du 'gyur ba yin no/ /

If the mental mind of a being at the time of death has previously at the time of birth been the propelling cause for such faculties and so forth of the same kind as those faculties and so forth, later as well it will be the propeller for faculties and so forth such as that of the previous phase of taking birth.
gnyis pa bcom ldan 'das kyi lung dang 'gal ba spang ba la/
(b) Refuting that it is contradictory of the Bhagavan’s scriptures

gzhan dag na re/ yid blo lus la mi brten na/ bcom ldan 'das kyis chos mngon pa'i mdo las/ lus dang sems ni phan tshun rjes su byed pa can no/ / zhes yid lus la brten par gsungs pa dang 'gal lo zhe na/ de'i dgongs pa ni 'di yin no zhes bstan pa'i phyir/

Others say that if mental mind is not supported by the body, that contradicts the Bhagavan saying that mental mind is supported by the body in the Sutra of Abhidharma, where he states “Body and mind mutually act upon each other.” In order to teach the meaning of this:
de yi shes pas phan 'dogs phyir/ / yid ni lus la brten par bshad/ /
43cd Because its consciousness can benefit, The body is explained to support the mind.
ces smos te/ lus kyis lus shes la phan 'dogs la/ lus de yi shes pas brgyud nas yid la phan 'dogs pa yod pa'i phyir na/ yid ni brgyud nas lus la brten par dgongs nas de skad du bshad pa yin no/ /

The body affects the body consciousness, and its (the body's) consciousness can benefit the mind indirectly. Because of this, it was explained thus with the intention that the body supports the mind indirectly.
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
gal te dbang po med par blos/ / ma yin/
44ab “In that case, without faculties the mind Does not.”
ces smos te/ gal te yid blo dbang po la brten pa yin te/ mig sogs dbang po med par yid blo skye ba ma yin pa'i phyir ro zhe na/ bshad pa/
In that case, mental mind is supported by the faculties because without the faculties of the eye and so forth, the mental mind does not arise, you say. To explain:
de yang de med par/ / de lta'ang phan tshun rgyu nyid pas/ / de phyir phan tshun rgyu can yin/ /
44b-d And nor do those without it either. Accordingly they are each other's cause, So therefore they are mutual results.

ces smos te/ 'o na dbang po de yang yid blo la brten par 'gyur te/ yid blo de med par dbang po mi skye ba'i phyir/ 'dod pa de ltar na'ang mig sogs dbang po dang yid blo gnyis sngar skye ba len pa'i dus su yang phan tshun du gcig gis gcig shos kyi rgyu nyid byed par 'gyur la/ de yang 'dod na/ phan tshun gcig gis gcig shos kyi rgyu byed pas de'i phyir skye ba phyi mar yang de gnyis phan tshun rgyu dang rgyu can te 'bras bu yin par 'gyur ro/ / 'dod na ni skye ba snga phyi yod par 'grub bo/ /

Well then, the faculties as well are supported by the mental mind, because nor do those faculties arise without it (the mental mind) either. According to that assertion, they (the faculties such as the eye and the mental mind) acted as each other's mutual cause previously at the time of taking birth. And if you agree to that, since they function as each other's cause, so therefore in the next life as well they will be mutually cause and results. If you agree, that establishes that there are previous and future births.
gnyis pa lus rtag pa yin pas rten du mi rung ba ni/
(2) Refuting that if the body were permanent, it could not be a support
rim can min las rim can min/ /
45a Sequential is not from the non-sequential.
ces smos te/ rang rim can du 'byung ba ma yin pa'i lus de las yid blo rim can du skye ba min te lus rtag pa'i phyir ro/ /
The sequential arising of the mental mind is not from a body that does not arise sequentially, because the body would be permanent.[94]
gal te lus rtag kyang rkyen la bltos nas yid blo rim can du bskyed do zhe na/ bshad pa/
If you say the body may be permanent but produces the mind successively in dependence on conditions, to explain:
khyad par can min bltos pa'ang med/ /
45b Not different and not dependent either.
ces smos te/ lus kyi rkyen la bltos nas yid blo rim can du bskyed pa'ang med de/ lus can gyi khyad par du byas pa can ma yin pa'i rtag pa yin pa'i phyir ro/ /
There is no sequential production of the mental mind in dependence on the condition of the body, because the body is a permanent phenomenon is not differentiated physically.
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
lus las rim gyis blo 'gyur na/ /
45c If mind were in a sequence from the body
zhes smos te/ yid blo snga ma rnams rim can du skye ba la bltos nas lus las rim gyis yid blo phyi ma rnams skye bar 'gyur ro zhe na/ bshad pa/
Previous mental minds arise in succession, and later minds as well will arise in a sequence from the body dependent on that, you say. To explain:
de yi'ang rim pa gsal bar byed/ /
45d Then that would indicate its sequence, too.
ces smos te/ lus de yi'ang snga phyi rim pa gsal bar byed pa yin par 'gyur te/ lus la brten pa'i yid blo la snga phyi'i rim pa grub pa'i phyir ro/ /
Then that would indicate its (the body's) sequence of earlier and later, because the mental mind supported by the body is proven to have a sequence of earlier and later.
de'i gzhung 'dzugs par bya ba'i phyir/
To substantiate this:
skad cig snga ma snga ma ni/ / skad cig re re sngon med de'i/ / rgyu yin de yi phyir na rgyu/ / thams cad tshe na mthong ba nyid/ /
46. Earlier moments are the causes Of later moments, which had not Existed previously, and thus It's always seen that they are causes.

ces smos te/ sngar skye ba len pa'i dus su lus dang / dbang po dang / yid blo de dag gi skad cig snga ma snga ma ni rang gi rigs 'dra skad cig re re sngon med pa'i phyi ma phyi ma de'i rgyu yin pa de'i phyir na/ yid blo dang dbang po skad cig snga ma snga ma rnams skad cig phyi ma phyi ma'i rgyu yin par 'chi ba'i 'og rol la sogs pa thams cad kyi tshe na tshad mas mthong ba nyid du 'gyur ro/ /

At the time of taking birth in the past, earlier moments of the body, faculties, and mental mind are the causes of later moments of their own same kind, which had not existed previously, and thus for that reason it is always—after death and so forth—validly seen that they (earlier moments of the mental mind and faculties) are causes of later moments.
gsum pa skye ba phyi ma med pa'i rgyu mtshan dgag pa la/
(3) Refuting the reasons why there would be no future rebirth

gzhan dag na re/ yid blo dang dbang po la sogs pa de dag skad cig snga ma snga ma skad cig phyi ma phyi ma'i rgyu yin par 'chi ba'i 'og rol du yang mthong ba de ni ma yin te/ 'di ltar/ lam po che'i skyes bu 'chi kha ma'i sems chos can/ sems phyi ma mtshams sbyor ba ma yin te/ 'chi sems yin pa'i phyir/ dper na dgra bcom par 'dod pa'i 'chi sems bzhin no zhe na/ bshad pa/

Others say that it is not so that earlier moments of the mental mind, faculties, and so forth are seen as the causes of later moments prior to death. It is thus: the mind at the moment of death of a person on the great way, the subject, does not link to a later mind, because it is a mind of death. As an analogy, it is like the mind of death asserted for arhats. To explain:
mtha' ma'i sems ni sems gzhan dang / / mtshams sbyor ba la 'gal ci yod/ /
47ab How would it be contradictory For the last mind to link to another mind?

ces smos te/ skyes pa'i tha ma 'chi kha ma'i sems chos can/ lam po che'i skyes bu 'chi kha ma'i sems rig pa phyi ma mtshams mi sbyor bar sgrub par byed pa'i 'gal zla dmigs pa'i rtags yang dag ma yin par thal/ sems phyi ma ni gzhan dang mtshams sbyor ba la rigs pa dang 'gal ba ci zhig yod de med pa'i phyir/

It follows that the last mind of a person at the time of death, the subject, is not correct evidence from the observation of something contradictory that proves that the mind of a being on the great way at the time of death does not link to a later awareness, because how would it be contradictory of logic for it to link to another later mind? It would not be.
des na dpe mi 'thad do zhes bstan pa'i phyir/
To teach that the analogy is therefore not tenable:
dgra bcom sems gang yin de yang / / gang las mtshams sbyor med par 'dod/ /
47cd And why is it that you admit The mind of an arhat will not link?

zhes smos te/ tshu rol mdzes pa ba khyed dgra bcom pa 'chi kha ma'i sems gang yin pa de yang sgrub byed gang las rig pa phyi ma mtshams sbyor ba med par sgrub pa'i mthun dper 'dod de/ khyed la dgra bcom pa med pa'i phyir ro/ /

Why or by what reason is it that you Cārvākas admit that the mind of an arhat at the time of death is an analogy that proves that there is no linking to a later awareness, because for you there are no arhats?

gal te de la ma grub kyang sangs rgyas pa'i grub mtha' las mar me shi ba ltar de yi sems ni rnam par thar zhes bshad pas mthun dper bkod pa'o zhe na/ sangs rgyas pa'i lung de tshad ma yin na skye ba snga phyi yod par grub la/

You might say that even though that is not established, you are proposing it as an analogy since it is explained in the Buddhist school that their minds are liberated, just like a lamp going out. However, if that Buddhist citation is valid, then previous and future lives are proven.[95]
tshad mas ma grub don can gyi/ / grub mtha'i rjes su 'brang ngam ci/ /
48ab Why would you follow a philosophy That has not been established validly?

tshad ma min na tshu rol mdzes pa ba khyed lung don tshad mas ma grub pa'i don can gyi sangs rgyas pa'i grub mtha'i rjes su 'brang bar byas nas dgra bcom pa 'chi kha ma'i sems de mthun dpe yang dag tu mthong ngam/ ci ste tshad mas ma grub pa mthun dpe yang dag tu bkod pa mi rigs so/ /

If it is not valid, why would you Cārvākas follow a Buddhist philosophy that has not been established validly in either scripture or meaning and see the mind of an arhat at the time of death as a correct analogy? It is not logical to propose an analogy that has not been validly proven.
tshu rol mdzes pa ba na re/
The Cārvākas say:
gal te de rgyu bral phyir na/ /
48c And if you say, “Because it lacks the causes,”
zhes smos te/ gal te dgra bcom pa 'chi kha ma'i sems des sems phyi ma mtshams mi sbyor te/ sems phyi ma de'i rgyu lus dbang dbugs 'byung rngub sogs dang bral ba'i phyir zhe na/ bshad pa/
If you say that the mind of an arhat at the time of death does not link to a later mind because it lacks the causes of that later mind—the body, faculties, breathing, and so forth—to explain:
de nyid 'dir ni cis ma brjod/ /
48d Why did you not say just that here?

ces smos te/ lus dang / dbang po dang / dbugs 'byung rngub sogs dang bral ba de nyid skyes bu 'chi kha ma'i sems sems phyi ma dang mtshams mi sbyor ba sgrub pa 'dir ni sgrub byed yang dag tu cis ma brjod de brjod rigs so/ / 'dod pa kho na'o zhe na/ lus dang / dbang po dang / dbugs 'byung rngub sogs dang bral ba chos can/ skyes bu 'chi kha ma'i sems sems phyi ma mtshams mi sbyor bar sgrub pa'i rtags yang dag ma yin par thal/ khyab pa ma nges pa'i phyir ro/ /

Why did you not say here as correct proof establishing that a person's mind at the time of death does not link to a later mind that just that lack of body, faculty, breathing, and so forth is valid proof? It would have been logical to say so. If you say you agree completely, then it follows that the lack of body, faculties, breath, and so forth, the subject, is not correct evidence that proves that the mind of a being at the time of death does not link to a later mind, because the pervasion is indeterminate.
bzhi pa dbang po dang bcas ma bcas la brtags nas dgag pa la/
(4) Refuting by examining whether it arises from a body that has faculties or that does not.
dgag pa dngos/ rigs pa'i rnam grangs gzhan gyis dgag pa'o/ /
This has two points: (a) The actual refutation, and (b) Refuting it with other logic.
dang po [dgag pa dngos] ni/
(a) The actual refutation

yid blo lus las skye ba yin na dbang po dang bcas pa'i lus las skye ba'am/ 'on te dbang po med pa'i lus las skye ba gang yin/ phyogs dang po ltar na dbang po re re las skye ba'am/ thams cad tshogs pa las skye/ dang po ltar ro zhe na/ bshad pa/
