If mental mind arises from the body, does it arise from a body that has faculties or from a body that does not have faculties? In the first case, does it arise from each of the faculties or from all of the faculties combined? If you say it is the former, to explain:
de blo bzhin du 'dzin 'gyur phyir/ / dbang po bcas las yid shes min/ /
49ab Since it would apprehend like consciousness, The mental's not from one with faculties.

ces smos te/ yid shes rtog pa de mig dbang las dngos su skyes pa ma yin te/ de yin na mig dbang de la brten pa'i blo mig shes bzhin du gzugs gsal bar 'dzin par 'gyur ba las de ltar ma yin pa'i phyir/ des na bdag rkyen mig gi dbang po dang bcas pa'i nus pa las yid shes de dngos su skyes pa min no/ /

Thoughts in the mental consciousness do not arise directly from the eye faculty, since if they did, they would apprehend forms clearly like the eye consciousness that is supported by the eye, but that is not the case. Therefore the mental consciousness does not arise directly from a capacity with the eye faculty as a dominant condition.
'on te dbang po kun tshogs pa las skye'o zhe na/ bshad pa/
Well then, it arises from all the faculties combined, you say. To explain:
shes bskyed nus pa tha dad phyir/ / kun las kyang ni ma yin no/ /
49cd Since their capacity to produce knowing Is separate, not from all together either.

zhes smos te/ mig sogs dbang po lnga la so sor rang gi yul gzugs sgra sogs gsal bar 'dzin pa'i shes pa so sor bskyed pa'i nus pa tha dad par yod kyi/ yul thams cad gsal bar 'dzin pa'i shes pa bskyed pa'i nus pa ma mthong ba'i phyir na/ mig sogs dbang po kun tshogs pa las kyang gzugs sogs drug ka gsal bar 'dzin pa'i yid blo skye ba ma yin no/ / kyang gi sgra ni dbang po re re las mi skye bar ma zad ces pa'o/ / de ltar ma yin na yid blo gcig gis kyang yul drug ka gsal bar 'dzin pas dbang po du ma don med du 'gyur ro/ /

The five faculties of eye and so forth have separate capacities to produce distinct consciousnesses that apprehend their objects of form, sound, and so forth clearly, but do not have the capacity to produce awareness that apprehends all objects clearly. For this reason, a mental mind that clearly apprehends all six of form and so forth, does not arise from all of the faculties combined together. The word either means “not only does it not arise from individual faculties.” If it were otherwise, the one mental mind would apprehend all six objects clearly, so it would be pointless to have multiple faculties.
phyogs gnyis pa ltar dbang po med pa'i lus las skye'o zhe na/ bshad pa/
If you say that it is the second case, where mind arises from a body without faculties, to explain:
sems med nyid phyir gzhan las min/ /
50a As those have no awareness, not from others.

zhes smos te/ dbang po ma yin pa'i skra dang sen mo sogs ni rang gi bdag 'bras sems kyi skyed byed du med pa nyid yin pa'i phyir na/ mig sogs dbang po las gzhan pa'i skra dang sen mo sogs las yid blo skye ba min no/ /

As those—the hair, nails, and so forth, which are not faculties—do not produce any awareness as their dominant result, the mental mind does not arise from hair, nails, and so forth that are other than the eye and such faculties.
gal te yid blo ni lus la brten pa yin te/ lhan cig gnas pa'i phyir/ dper na mar me dang de'i 'od bzhin no zhe na/ bshad pa/
In that case, mental mind is supported by the body because it coexists with it, like, for example, a lamp and its light, you say. To explain:
rgyu gcig phyir na lhan cig gnas/ / dbang bzhin gzugs dang ro bzhin no/ /
50bc As these have the same cause, they coexist,[96] Just like the faculties, like form and flavor.

zhes smos te/ yid blo dang lus gnyis ni rgyu 'phen byed kyi las gcig gis 'phangs nas lhan cig tu skyes pa'i phyir na/ yid lus gnyis lhan cig tu gnas pa ni yin la/ de tsam gyis rten dang brten par mi 'gyur te/ dper na mig sogs dbang po lnga lhan cig tu gnas kyang rten dang brten pa ma yin pa bzhin dang / bu ram gyi gzugs dang ro gnyis lhan cig tu gnas kyang phan tshun rten dang brten pa ma yin pa bzhin no/ /

As these (the mental mind and body) are both propelled by the same propelling karma as their cause and then arise together, the mind and body coexist. However, they do not become supporter and supported just because of that. For example, it is just like the five faculties of eye and so forth, which coexist but are not supporter and supported, or like the form and flavor of sugar, which coexist but are not mutually supporter and supported.
gal te yid blo lus la brten te lus 'gyur na yid 'gyur bar mthong ba'i phyir zhe na/ / bshad pa/
In that case, the mental mind is supported by the body because when the body changes the mind is also seen to change, you say. To explain:
don gyi sgo nas 'gyur ba yin/ /
50d It is affected by way of the object.

ces smos te/ yid blo de lus gzung don gyi yul du byas pa'i sgo nas lus 'gyur na yid blo de'ang 'gyur ba yin gyi/ lus kyis bdag rkyen byas pa'i sgo nas 'gyur ba ma yin te/ dper na gzhan gyi khrag mthong ba las brgyal ba bzhin no/ /

If the body changes, it (the mental mind) is affected by way of taking the body as the apprehended object. It is not affected by way of the body functioning as the dominant condition. It is like fainting upon seeing another's blood, for example.
gnyis pa rigs pa'i rnam grangs gzhan gyis dgag pa ni/
(b) Refuting it with other logic
rtag tu de yi rjes 'jug phyir/ / gang zhig yod pas phan 'dogs byed/ / de rgyu de phyir bdun pa dang / / skyes phyir zhes ni bshad pa yin/ /
51. That which by being present benefits Since that is always consequent to it Is a cause. Therefore he used the locative And said “because this has arisen.”

ces smos te/ 'bras bu ni rtag tu rang gi rgyu gang yin de'i rjes su 'jug pa'i phyir dang / gang zhig rgyu yod pas rang gi 'bras bu la phan 'dogs par byed pa de 'dra ba ni 'bras bu de'i rgyu yin pa de'i phyir/ bcom ldan 'das kyis kyang sA lu ljang pa'i mdo las/ 'di yod pas 'di 'byung / zhes rgyu mtshan can gyi bdun pa gnas gzhi'i sgra dang / 'di skyes pa'i phyir 'dir skye/ zhes lnga pa 'byung khungs kyi sgras ni rgyu dang 'bras bu'i rnam par dbye ba bshad pa yin la/ de lta bu'i rgyu 'bras kyi 'brel ba lus sems gnyis la ma mthong ngo / /

Since that result is always consequent to that which is its cause and because that cause which by being present benefits the result is a cause, therefore when the Bhagavan said, “When this exists, that arises” in the Śālistambha Sutra,[97] he used the locative case to indicate a reason and used the ablative case when he said, “Because this has arisen, that arises.” This explains the distinction between cause and result. Such a relation of cause and result is not seen between the body and mind.

'di la slob dpon lha dbang blo ni/ lus dang sems ni rgyu 'bras su mi 'grub ste/ mngal la sogs par sngar dmigs shing sems phyis dmigs par nges pa'i rjes su 'gro ldog med pa'i phyir ro/ / zhes gsungs so/ / rgyan las/ yid ni lus kyi 'bras bu ma yin te/ rtag tu rjes su 'gro ldog ma grub pa'i phyir ro/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

Here Master Devendrabuddhi says that the body and mind are not established as cause and result because there is no entailment or reverse entailment that the body is first observed in the womb and the mind observed afterward.[98] Prajñākaragupta says that the mind is not the result of the body because it is not always proven to be entailed or reverse entailed by it.[99]
des na lus nyid sems la phan 'dogs pa tsam byed srid kyang nyer len gyi rgyu ma yin no/ / zhes bstan pa'i phyir/
Therefore, although it is possible that the body might merely benefit the mind, it is not the substantial cause. To teach this:
'ga' zhig tshe na sems rgyun la/ / phan 'dogs byed pa'ang yin sla ste/ / bum sogs la ni me sogs bzhin/ / de tsam gyis ni ldog pa min/ /
52. There are, of course, some instances where it May benefit the mind's continuum, But like a jug and such with fire and so forth, Just that alone does not cause mind to cease.

ces smos te/ 'dod pa dang gzugs kyi khams su skye ba'i gnas skabs 'ga' zhig gi tshe ni lus kyis lus shes dngos su bskyed pa'i sgo nas lus shes kyi rjes su 'byung ba'i sems kyi rgyun la brgyud nas phan 'dogs par byed pa'ang yin pa ni sla ste/ de tsam gyis ni lus sems kyi nyer len gyi rgyur mi 'gyur te/ lus ldog pas sems ldog pa min pa'i phyir ro/ / dper na bum pa sogs la ni me la sogs pas phan 'dogs kyang me ldog pa na bum pa ldog pa med pa bzhin no/ /

There are, of course, some instances of the time of birth in the Desire and Form realms where by way of directly producing a body consciousness, it (the body) may benefit indirectly the mind's continuum that follows the body consciousness. However, just that alone does not make the body the substantial cause of the mind, because the body ceasing does not cause the mind to cease. For example, fire and so forth can benefit jugs and such, but putting the fire out does not cause the jug to cease.
gnyis pa shi lus la sems yod par thal bas dgag pa la/
ii. Refuting through the consequence that a dead body would have mind.
thal ba dngos/ mthun rkyen med pa dgag/ 'gal rkyen nye bar gnas pa dgag/ rang la rtsod pa spang ba'o/ /
This has four points: (1) The actual consequence, (2) Refuting that the favorable conditions are absent, (3) Refuting that impediments are present, and (4) Rebutting criticism of our position.
dang po [thal ba dngos] ni/
(1) The actual consequence
lus ni gnas pa nyid na sems/ / ldog pa med par thal bar 'gyur/ /
53ab There would be the consequence that if The body remained, the mind would not cease either.
zhes smos te/ shi ba'i 'og rol tu sems kyi rgyu lus ni ma 'gags par gnas pa nyid kyi phyir na/ shi ba'i lus la sems ldog pa med par gnas par thal bar 'gyur ro/ /
There would be the consequence that if the body—the cause of the mind—were to remain without ceasing after death, the mind would remain in the body without ceasing.
gnyis pa mthun rkyen med pa dgag pa ni/
(2) Refuting that the favorable conditions are absent
shi ba'i lus la sems kyi mthun rkyen dbugs 'byung rngub med pas sems gnas pa med do zhe na/ bshad pa/
You might say that breathing, which is a requisite for the mind, is not present in a dead body, so the mind does not remain. To explain:
de yod yod dang dbang gyur phyir/ / de las 'byung rngub de ma yin/ / rlung 'byin pa dang 'dren pa ni/ / 'bad rtsol med par gang las yin/ /
53cd There if it's there and under its control, So breathing is from it, not it from that. 54ab Without exertion where would inhalation And exhalation of the breath be from?

ces smos te/ yid blo de yod na dbugs 'byung rngub yod pa dang / dbugs 'byung rngub de yang yid blo'i gzhan dbang du gyur pa yin pa'i phyir na/ yid blo de las dbugs 'byung rngub skye ba yin gyi/ dbugs 'byung rngub de las yid blo skye ba ma yin no/ / de'i phyir skyes bus rlung phyir 'byin pa dang nang du 'dren pa ni sems kyi 'bad rtsol med par gang las nus pa yin te ma yin no/ /

The inhalation and exhalation of breath is there if it (the mental mind) is there, and that inhalation and exhalation of breath is under its (the mental mind's) control. So for these reasons, the inhalation and exhalation of breath is from it (the mental mind), and it (the mental mind) is not from that (the inhalation and exhalation of breath). Therefore without mental exertion, where would the power for a person to inhale and exhale the breath be from? It would not be.

'di la slob dpon lha dbang blos/ dper na 'dod pa mngon du song ba can gyis lag pa'i brkyang ba dang bskum pa lta bu ste/ dbugs 'byung rngub dag kyang sems kyi 'dod pa'i dbang gis 'jug pa dang ldog pa yin no zhes bya ba ni rang bzhin gyi gtan tshigs so/ / zhes bshad do/ /

Master Deven-drabuddhi explains that this is similar to how it is due to a prior wish that one stretches or bends their arms. The inhalation and exhalation of breath are also initiated or stopped under the power of a mental wish. This is a reason of nature.[100]
des na dbugs 'byung rngub sems kyi rgyu yin na/ dbugs 'phel 'grib dag gis sems kyang 'phel 'grib tu 'gyur ro zhes bstan pa'i phyir/
Therefore if inhalation and exhalation were the cause of mind, the increase or decrease of the breath would also make the mind increase or decrease. To teach this:
de dag phul byung 'grib pa las/ / phul byung 'grib pa thob par 'gyur/ /
54cd From them diminishing or increasing, It also would diminish or increase.

zhes smos te/ dbugs 'byung rngub sems kyi rgyu yin na/ dbugs 'byung rngub de dag phul du byung zhing 'phel ba dang 'grib pa las sems kyang phul du byung zhing 'phel ba dang 'grib pa rigs pas thob par 'gyur te/ dbugs 'byung rngub sems kyi rgyu yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

If inhalation and exhalation were the cause of mind, from them (inhalation and exhalation) diminishing or increasing, it (the mind) also would logically diminish or increase, because the inhalation and exhalation are the mind's cause.
lhas/ dper na shing la 'phel ba dang 'grib pa dag gis rgya mtsho chen po la 'phel ba dang 'grib pa med pa bzhin no/ / zhes gsungs so/ /
Devendrabuddhi says that it is just as how a tree increasing or diminishing does not make the great ocean increase or decrease.[101]
rigs pa des lus dbugs kyi rgyu yin pa la'ang mtshungs so zhes bstan pa'i phyir/
To teach that such logic is the same if the body is the cause of breathing as well:
de dag la yang thal ba mtshungs/ /
55a The consequence is the same for them as well.

zhes smos te/ lus dbugs 'byung rngub kyi rgyu yin par khas len pa de dag la yang shi ba'i lus la dbugs 'byung rngub yod pa dang de yod pas sems yod par thal ba mtshungs te/ dbugs kyi dngos rgyu lus gnas pa'i phyir ro/ /
If you say that for us there similarly would be the consequence that the mind would be present in the dead body because the continuum of the mind does not cease, to explain:
gal te sems rgyun chad pa med pa'i phyir shi ba'i lus la sems gnas par thal ba khyod la'ang mtshungs so zhe na/ bshad pa/

For them who assert that the body is the cause of respiration as well, the consequence is the same that the dead body would have respiration, and since that was present, it would have mind. This is because the body—the direct cause of the breath—is present.
sems rgyu yin na mtshungs ma yin/ / gnas pa'i 'phen byed gzhan dag kyang / / gang phyir rgyu ni yin par 'dod/ /
55b-d It is not similar if the mind's the cause, Because it is asserted other factors That propel remaining are the cause.

ces smos te/ kho bo cag sems nyid dbugs 'byung rngub las mi skye bar sems snga ma'i rgyu las byung zhing lus la gnas pa'i las zad pa yin pa'i phyir na/ shi ba'i lus la sems yod par thal ba'i skyon mtshungs pa ma yin no/ / 'o na lus sems lhan cig tu gnas pa ci yin ce na/ gang gi phyir lus sems lhan cig tu gnas pa'i 'phen byed kyi las gzhan dag kyang lus sems lhan cig tu gnas pa'i rgyu ni yin par 'dod pa de'i phyir/ lus sems kyi rgyu ma yin kyang re zhig lus sems lhan cig tu gnas pa'i rgyu med pa ma yin no/ /

We say that the mind itself does not arise from exhalation and inhalation; the previous mind is the cause from which it arises. Because the karma for it to remain in the body has been exhausted, there is no similar fault that there would consequentially be a mind in a dead body. Well then, why is it that the body and mind coexist? you ask. It is because it is asserted other factors—karmas that propel the body and mind to remain together—are the cause for the body and mind to coexist. For that reason, although the body is not the mind's cause, for the time being causes for the mind and body to coexist are not nonexistent.

lhas/ des na 'phen par byed pa'i dbang gis gnas pa'i dus nges pa yin pas/ de ltar na de phan chad rab tu 'jug pa ma yin pa'i phyir mtshungs pa ma yin no/ / zhes dang / rgyan las/ gnas pa 'phen par byed pa'i rgyu gzhan yin par 'dod pa'i phyir zhes bya ba la skyon mtshungs pa ma yin no/ / gang las she na/ sems ni sems kyi rgyu can yin na yang ngo / / ci'i phyir zhe na/ rgyu mtshan gang gis gnas pa zhes bya ba dus cung zad cig sdod pa'o/ / lus la sems gnas pa 'phen par byed pa'i rgyu gzhan ma rig pa 'du byed kyi bag chags rgyu yin pa'i phyir ro/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

Devendrabuddhi says: Therefore the duration it remains is determined by the force of the propulsion. Thus since that does not engage from then on, it is not the same.[102] Prajñākaragupta comments that in saying that we assert that there is another cause that propels remaining, the fault is not the same. Why is that, you ask? The mind has mind as a cause as well. Why is that? you ask. “The reason why it stays” means it remains for a short while. The other cause that propels the mind to remain in the body is the imprints of formations from ignorance, which are the cause, he says.
gsum pa 'gal rkyen nye bar gnas pa dgag pa la/
(3) Refuting that impediments are present
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
gal te sdong bu la sogs bzhin/ / nyes pas mi mthun lus rgyu min/ /
56ab “Like wicks and so forth, it has been degraded By humors, so the body is not the cause.”

ces smos te/ gal te dper na chu la sogs pa rlan pa'i sdong bu la sogs pas mar me la sogs pa mi bskyed pa bzhin du 'gal rkyen nyes pa rlung mkhris kyis mi mthun pa'i gegs byas pa'i phyir/ shi ba'i tshe lus yod kyang shi lus sems gnas pa'i rgyu min no zhe na/ bshad pa/

Just as wicks and so forth that are sodden with water and so forth cannot produce lamplight and so forth, the adverse condition of the humors of bile and wind creates the impediment of degradation, so for that reason at the time of death there is a body, but the dead body is not the cause of the mind to remain, you might say. To explain:
shi bas nyes pa mnyam 'gyur tshe/ / slar yang 'tsho ba dag tu 'gyur/ /
56cd When death has brought the humors into balance,[103] It once again would be brought back to life.

zhes smos te/ 'o na shi bas kyang 'gal rkyen nyes pa rims dang dug la sogs pa ni shi ba dang mnyam du log cing mthun rkyen lus la tshang bar gyur pa de'i tshe na/ shi lus slar yang sems dang bcas shing 'tsho ba dag tu 'gyur ro zhes pa lha'i'o/ /

Well then, death also reverses the adverse conditions such as the humors, contagion, poison, and so forth together with death, and the positive conditions are complete in the body. When that occurs, it (the dead body) once again would have a mind and be brought back to life. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
gal te me ni ldog na yang / / shing gi 'gyur ba mi ldog bzhin/ / de ni ldog pa med ce na/ /
57a-c “But even though a fire might be reversed, The changes to the wood are not turned back, And likewise that cannot be brought back either.”

zhes smos te/ gal te shing 'gyur ba'i rgyu me ni ldog na yang mes byas pa'i shing gi 'gyur ba sol ba la sogs pa slar yang shing du mi ldog pa bzhin du sems 'gyur ba'i rgyu rims la sogs pa ldog na yang shi ba'i gnas skabs na rims kyis 'gyur ba sems de ni slar yang ldog pa med do zhe na/ bshad pa/

But even though a fire—a cause for wood to change—might be reversed, the changes the fire made to the wood—ashes and so forth— are not turned back into wood again. Likewise, even if the cause for the mind to change such as contagion and so forth are reversed, that mind that has been changed by contagion cannot be brought back at the time of death either, you say. To explain:
ma yin gso sbyor yod phyir ro/ /
57d Not so, since remedies can be applied.

zhes smos te/ rims dang dug la sogs pa'i skyon gyis lus dang sems ldog pa med pa de ni ma yin te/ nad gso ba'i sman gyi sbyor thabs yod pas slar ldog tu rung ba'i phyir ro zhes lha rgyan gnyis ka'i'o/ /

It is not so that the body and mind cannot be brought back due to the damage from contagion, poison, and so forth, because since there are methods for medicinal remedies to be applied, they are able to be reversed, according to both Devendrabuddhi and Prajñākaragupta.
slar ldog pa dang mi ldog pa'i chos can gnyis yod par bstan pa'i phyir/
To teach that there are reversible and irreversible phenomena:

slar mi 'byung bar 'ga' zhig ni/ / la lar 'gyur ba skyed par byed/ / 'ga' zhig ldog pa yin phyir dper/ / shing dang gser la me bzhin no/ / dang po chung yang ldog pa min/ / slar ldog rung bar 'gyur byas gang / / de ni slar yang 'byung 'gyur te/ / gser gyi sra ba nyid bzhin no/ /

58. There are some instances where changes made To certain things make them not rearise. For other things, they are reversible, Like fire with wood or gold as an example. 59. The first, even small, is not reversible. But as with the solidity of gold, That to which the alterations made Are reversible will once again arise.

zhes smos te/ slar mi 'byung bar byas pa'i chos can 'ga' zhig ni gnas skabs la lar mi ldog pa'i 'gyur ba skyed par byed pa'ang yod la/ chos can 'ga' zhig ni 'gyur ba slar ldog pa yod pa yin pa'i phyir/ rnam pa thams cad du 'gyur ba mi ldog par nges pa ma yin te/ dper na mes shing la sol ba la sogs pa slar mi ldog pa'i 'gyur ba bskyed pa dang / gser la mes zhu ba'i 'gyur ba bskyed nas slar yang sra bar 'gyur ba bzhin no/ / des na slar ldog tu mi rung ba ni dang po mes byas pa'i sol ba chung ngu yang shing du ldog pa min la/ rims dang dug sogs kyis lus dang sems la slar ldog tu rung bar 'gyur ba bskyed par byas pa 'chi ba'i mtshan nyid can gyis 'gyur ba chen po gang yin pa de ni slar yang ldog cing nad med pa 'byung bar 'gyur te/ dper na mes bzhus pa'i gser gyi zhu ba chen po yang me dang bral ba na shin tu sra ba nyid du 'gyur ba bzhin no zhes pa lha rgyan gnyis ka'i'o/ /

There are some instances where irreversible changes made to certain things make them not rearise. For other things, they (the changes) are reversible. Therefore it is not certain that change is irreversible in all aspects. For example, fire produces in wood the irreversible change into ashes and so forth, but when fire produces the change of melting in gold, the gold once again becomes solid. As for the first (the irreversible), even a small amount of ash made by fire is not reversible into wood. But that body and mind to which the great alteration whose characteristic is death made by contagion, poison, and so forth is reversible will once again be brought back and arise without illness. It is as with, for example, great molten gold that has been melted by fire being removed from the fire and once again becoming completely solid. This is according to both Devendrabuddhi and Prajñākaragupta.
bzhi pa rang la rtsod pa spang ba ni/
(4) Rebutting criticism of our position
gzhan dag na re/ nad 'ga' zhig gso bya ma yin par bshad pa dang 'gal lo zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others say that this contradicts the explanation that some illnesses are incurable. To explain:
cung zad gso bya min brjod pa/ / 'chos byed rnyed par dka' phyir ram/ / tshe zad phyir ro nyes 'ba' zhig/ yin na gso min med pa nyid/ /
60. It's said some illnesses are totally Incurable since cures are to find Or life has been used up, but if it is Solely the humors, none is incurable.

ces smos te/ nad kyi rigs 'ga' zhig cung zad kyang gso bya min par brjod pa'i rgyu mtshan ni/ nad 'chos par byed pa'i sman dang sman pa rnyed par dka' zhing 'phrad par mi nus pa'i phyir ram/ sngon gyi las kyis 'phangs pa'i tshe zad pa'i phyir na gso bya ma yin pa'i nad du brjod pa yin la/ sman dang sman pa rnyed cing 'phen byed kyi las dang tshe ma zad na ni de gsor rung ba yin no/ / khyed la nad de sngon gyi las dang sems snga ma sngon du ma song bar nyes pa bad kan dang mkhris pa sogs 'ba' zhig gis bskyed pa yin par 'dod pa'i phyir na gso bar rung ba min pa med pa nyid du 'gyur te/ slar 'byung ba'i 'gyur ba rtsom par byed pa'i phyir ro zhes rgyan gyis so/ /

The reason it is said that some types of illness are totally incurable is since the medicine or doctor that cures the illness is hard to find and one cannot encounter it, or since the life propelled by past actions has been used up. This is why they are described as incurable illnesses. But if one finds medicine and a doctor and the propelling karma and life have not been depleted, they are curable. Because you assert that those illnesses are not preceded by past actions or the mind and are produced solely by the humors of phlegm, bile, and so forth, none would be incurable, because the changes in the elements would begin once again. This is according to Prajñākaragupta.
gzhan yang /
Additionally:
shi ba'i dug sogs ldog phyir ram/ / de yi sos zin bcad las kyang / / 'gyur ba'i rgyu dang bral ba na/ / de cis slar yang 'tsho mi 'gyur/ /
61. If the causes of deterioration[104] are Removed by halting poison and so forth In the dead, or cutting out the bite as well, Why would they not come back to life?

zhes smos te/ srog chags shi ba'i lus las dug dang rims la sogs pa ldog pa'i phyir ram/ skyes bu shi ba na lus kyi dug dag dug sbrul de yi sos zin pa'i rma'i gnas gang yin der lus par 'gyur ba de bcad pa las kyang 'gal rkyen 'chi bar 'gyur ba'i rgyu dug sogs dang bral zhing 'tsho ba'i mthun rkyen lus tshang bar yod pas na/ dug sbrul sogs kyi rkyen gyis shi ba de cis te slar yang 'tsho bar mi 'gyur te 'gyur ro/ / de bas na/ lus ni gnas pa nyid na sems/ / ldog pa med par thal bar 'gyur/ / zhes pa'i thal ba so na gnas so/ /

Poison, disease, and so forth are halted in a dead being's body, or else when a being dies from the bite of a venomous snake, the poison remains in the wounded area of the snake bite, and cutting out that bite removes the causes of dying such as poison while the requisites for living are all present. Thus why would they who have died because of snake bites and so forth not come back to life? They would. Therefore the absurd consequence in “There would be the consequence that if / The body remained, the mind would not cease either” stands.
gsum pa lus sems kyi nyer len yin pa dgag pa ni/
iii. Refuting that the body is the substantial cause of the mind
nyer len 'gyur ba med pa na/ / nyer len can dag 'gyur bar ni/ / byed par mi nus dper 'jim pa/ / 'gyur ba med par bum sogs bzhin/ /
62. Without a change in the substantial cause, It is not possible to make a change In what is caused, for instance like a basin And so forth without changes to the clay.

zhes smos te/ ji ltar nye bar len pa'i rgyu lus gzhan 'phel 'grib tu 'gyur ba med pa na/ nyer len can gyi 'bras bu sems dag 'phel 'grib tu 'gyur bar mi byed par ni nus te/ dper na 'jim pa 'gyur ba med par rdza bum sogs su 'gyur ba med pa bzhin no/ /

Without a change of increase or decrease in the substantial cause (the body), which is other, it is not possible to make a change of increase or decrease in the result which is caused, the awarenesses. For instance it is like a basin and so forth that do not change without a change to the clay.
de bas na nyer len 'gyur ba med par 'bras bu 'gyur ba mi rigs so zhes bstan pa'i phyir/
Therefore it is not logical that a result could change without change in its substantial cause. To teach this:
dngos gang 'gyur ba med pa na/ / dngos po gang zhig rnam 'gyur ba/ / de de'i nyer len mi rigs te/ / ba lang ba men la sogs bzhin/ /
63. It would not be logical for a thing That is not changed to be the substantial cause Of something else that does get changed, Like gaur and oxen and so forth.

zhes smos te/ dngos po gang du 'gyur ba med pa na dngos po gang zhig de rnam par 'gyur ba de ni rgyu de'i nyer len du mi rigs te/ dper na ba lang 'gyur ba med par ba men 'gyur bar byas pas ni ba lang ba men gyi nyer len ma yin pa la sogs pa me chu la'ang de bzhin no/ /

It would not be logical for a thing that is not changed at all to be the substantial cause of something else that does get changed. For example, a gaur changes without an ox changing, so the ox is not the substantial cause of the gaur. Water and fire and so forth are similar as well.
dpe de bzhin du lus sems gnyis la yang 'gyur ro zhes bstan pa'i phyir/
To teach that the body and mind as well are like that analogy:
sems dang lus kyang de bzhin no/ /
64a The mind and body are like that, too.
zhes smos te/ sems dang lus gnyis kyang nyer len can dang nyer len du ma grub pa ni dper na me dang chu la rjes su 'gro ldog ma grub pas nyer len can dang nyer len du ma grub pa de bzhin no/ /

The mind and body as well are proven not to be the substantial result and substantial cause. They are like fire and water, for example, which do not entail or reverse entail each other and thus are proven not to be substantial result and substantial cause.
gzhan dag na re/ lus sems lhan cig tu gnas par nges pas de dag ni nyer len dang nyer len can yin te/ sgron me dang sgron me'i 'od bzhin no zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others say that the body and mind are ascertained to always coexist, so they are substantial cause and result, like a torch and torchlight. To explain:
de rgyu lhan cig byed pa las/ / skye ba'i 'bras bu lhan cig gnas/ / me dang zangs ma'i zhu nyid bzhin/ /
64b-d Results that arise from its cause Cooperating coexist, Just as with fire and molten copper.

ces smos te/ lus de'i nyer len gyi rgyu mngal gyi gnas skabs su nur nur po la sogs pas sems kyi lhan cig byed pa dang / sems kyis lus kyi nyer len gyi rgyu'i lhan cig byed rkyen du gyur pa las skye ba'i 'bras bu tshogs pa gcig yin pas lus sems gnyis lhan cig tu gnas pa yin te/ dper na mes zangs bzhus pa'i tshe na me dang zangs ma'i zhu ba nyid lhan cig tu gnas kyang nyer len dang nyer len can ma yin pa bzhin no/ /

The body's substantial cause—the fetal stages of mushiness and so forth[105]—act as the cooperating condition of the mind, and the mind also acts as the cooperating condition of the body's substantial cause. The results that arise from that are a single conglomeration, so the body and mind coexist. It is, for example, like when fire melts copper: the fire and the molten copper coexist, but they are not substantial cause and result.
bzhi pa phan mi 'dogs pa'i don gzhan rten dang brten par 'dod pa dgag pa la/
iv. Refuting the assertion that objects that are other and do not affect each other are supporter and supported.
'gog byed kyi rigs pa dngos/ de la rtsod pa spong ba/ don bsdu ba'o/ /
This has three topics: (1) The actual logic of the refutation, (2) Rebutting criticism of this, and (3) Summary.
dang po ['gog byed kyi rigs pa dngos] la/
(1) The actual logic of the refutation.
rten dang brten par mi 'thad pa'i rgyu mtshan/ ha cang thal ba'o/ /
This has two points: (a) The reason why it is not tenable for them to be supporter and supported, and (b) The absurd consequence.
dang po [rten dang brten par mi 'thad pa'i rgyu mtshan] ni/
(a) The reason why it is not tenable for them to be supporter and supported
yod med dag la rten med phyir/ /
65a What is and what is not are not supported.

zhes smos te/ sems ni rang gnas par yod na rten mi dgos la/ rang gnas par med pa dag la gang yang rten du dgos pa med pa'i phyir/ lus kyis sems gnas par byas pa'i sgo nas sems lus la brten pa ma yin no/ / lhas/ gang gis gang la cung zad kyang mi byed pa de ni de'i rten ma yin te/ 'bigs byed kyis gangs can lta bu'o/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

If the mind is and persists, it does not need a support, and what is not and does not persist does not need any support at all. For that reason, the mind is not supported by the body in terms of the body causing the mind to persist. Devendrabuddhi says, “That which does not do anything for something else is not its support, like, for example, Mount Vindhya and Mount Himavān.”[106]
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
ma yin yod pa'i gnas rgyu ni/ / rten yin ce na/
65bc If that's not so and the support is the cause For it to persist,
ces smos te/ gal te de ltar ni ma yin te/ lus des sems grub zin yod pa mi 'jig par gnas pa'i rgyu byed pa'i sgo nas ni sems kyi rten byed pa yin ce na/
Well then, is that persistence of the mind that the body creates the same as the mind or different? If you say it is the former, to explain:
'o na lus kyis byas pa'i sems kyi gnas pa sems dang gcig gam tha dad gang yin/ dang po ltar ro zhe na/ bshad pa/
You might say that is not so. The body functions as the support of the mind in terms of functioning as the cause for it to persist without perishing after being established, you say.
'di rten med/ / gnas pa po las gzhan min phyir/ / gzhan yin na yang de rgyu nyid/ / des na dngos po ci zhig byas/ /
65cd it has no support Since that's not other than that which persists. 66ab If other, it is just the cause of that. What is the entity that it has made?

zhes smos te/ sems 'di rten lus kyis gnas par byas pa med de/ lus med kyang gnas pa po'i sems las gnas gzhan min pa'i phyir ro/ / phyogs gnyis pa ltar gzhan yin no zhe na yang lus des ni sems kyi dngos po ci zhig gnas par byas te ma byas par thal/ gnas pa sems dang rdzas gcig mi bskyed par sems dang rdzas gzhan pa'i gnas pa de'i rgyu kho na nyid yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

This mind has no support—the body—that makes it persist, since even without the body, that (the persistence) is not other than the mind that persists. In the second case, if you say it is other, then what is the entity of the mind that it (the body) has made persist? It follows it has not made it persist, because it does not produce persistence that is the same in substance as the mind, but is just the cause of that persistence which is substantially other than the mind.
gnyis pa ha cang thal ba ni/
(b) The absurd consequence
'jig pa med par thal bar 'gyur/ /
66c Consequentially, it would never perish.
zhes smos te/ sems ni nam yang 'jig pa med par ha cang thal bar 'gyur te/ mi 'jig par gnas pa'i rgyu lus rtag brtan du yod pa'i phyir ro/ /
There would be the absurd consequence that it (the mind) would never perish, because the cause for it to persist without perishing—the body—is permanently and stably present.
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
gal te de 'jig rgyu las 'dod/ /
66d “That's from a cause of perishing,” you assert,
ces smos te/ gal te lus kyis sems gnas par byed mod kyi/ 'on kyang sems de 'jig rgyu dang 'phrad pa las 'jig par 'dod do zhe na/ bshad pa/
Well, the body does make the body persist, but that mind perishes from encountering a cause of perishing, you assert. To explain:
de la'ang thal ba mtshungs pa yin/ /
67a But there as well, the consequence is the same,

ces smos te/ de ltar 'dod pa la'ang 'jig rgyu rang dang don gzhan du gyur pa'i 'jig pa bskyed dam/ don gzhan ma yin pa'i 'jig pa bskyed/ dang po ltar na/ 'jig pa po las gzhan min phyir/ / gzhan yin na yang de rgyu nyid/ / des ni 'jig pa ci zhig byas/ / zhes pa'i thal ba mtshungs pa yin no/ / phyogs gnyis pa ltar na 'jig rgyu mi dgos so/ /

Even if you assert that, does the cause of perishing produce perishing that is a different object from itself, or perishing that is not a different object? In the first case: Since that's not other than what perishes. If other, it is just the cause of that. What is the perishing that it has made? The consequence is the same. In the second case, a cause of perishing would be unnecessary.
gzhan yang /
Additionally:
gnas pa'i rgyus kyang ci zhig byas/ /
67b And what would the cause of persistence do?
zhes smos te/ sems gnas pa'i rgyu lus des kyang sems mi 'jig par gnas par ci zhig byas te ma byas par thal/ 'jig rgyus 'jig par byas pa'i phyir ro/ /
And what would the cause that makes the mind persist—the body— do to make the mind persist without perishing? It follows that it does nothing, because the cause of perishing makes the mind perish.
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
gal te 'jig rgyu 'phrad bar du/ / de gnas/
67cd “That makes it persist till it meets the cause Of perishing.”

zhes smos te/ gal te gnas pa'i rgyu med na 'jig rgyu dang ma 'phrad pa'i snga rol du ngo bo nyid kyis 'jig pa las gnas pa'i rgyu des 'jig rgyu dang 'phrad kyi bar du gnas pa de gnas par bya ba yin no zhe na/ bshad pa/

You might say that without the cause of persistence, it would perish of its own essence before meeting the cause of perishing. Instead, the cause of persistence makes it persist until it meets the cause of perishing. To explain:
'jig pa dngos chos nyid/ / yod pa 'di gnod med pa'i phyir/ / gnas pa'i rgyus ni ci zhig byas/ /
67d The nature of things is 68ab To perish. There is nothing to prevent this,[107] So what would the cause of persistence do?

zhes smos te/ sems rang gi ngo bo nyid kyis 'jig pa'i bdag nyid can de ni dngos po'i chos nyid du yod pa 'di la gnod byed kyi tshad ma med pa'i phyir na/ sems gnas pa'i rgyu lus des ni sems mi 'jig par gnas par ci zhig byas te ma byas par thal lo zhes pa lha'i'o/ /

The mind by its very essence has the nature of perishing. This is present as the nature of things and there is nothing valid to disprove[108] this. For that reason, what does the cause of the mind's persistence—the body—do to make it persist without perishing? It follows it does not do anything. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
gnyis pa de la rtsod pa spang ba la/
(2) Rebutting criticism of this.
dpe mi 'thad pa/ des gzhan yang khegs pa'o/ /
This has two points: (a) The analogy is not tenable, and (b) How this refutes other things as well.
dang po [dpe mi 'thad pa] ni/
(a) The analogy is not tenable
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
gal te dper na chu sogs kyi/ / rten bzhin zhe na/
68cd “For instance, like a support for water and So forth,” you say.
zhes smos te/ gal te dper na snod ni chu la sogs kyi dngos po mi 'jig par gnas pa'i rten yin pa bzhin du lus kyang sems mi 'jig par gnas pa'i rten yin no zhe na/ bshad pa/

You might say that just as a bowl, for instance, is a support for things such as water and so forth to persist without perishing, the body is also the support for the mind to persist without perishing. To explain:
'di la'ang mtshungs/ /
68d It is the same for this,

zhes smos te/ snod kyis chu mi 'jig par gnas pa'i rten byed pa 'di la'ang / yod med dag la rten med phyir/ / zhes pa'i thal ba thams cad mtshungs so/ / ji ltar mtshungs she na/ chu la sogs pa rang gnas yod na rten mi dgos la/ rang gnas par med pa dag la gang yang rten du dgos pa med pa'i phyir snod kyis chu gnas par byas pa'i sgo nas chu ni snod la brten pa ma yin no zhes mtshungs so/ /

For this action of a bowl as a support for water to remain without perishing, all the consequences of the line “What is and what is not are not supported” are the same. How are they the same? you ask. If water and so forth have their own persistence, they do not need a support, but that which does not have persistence does not need anything as a support. For that reason, water is not supported by the bowl—it is the same.
des na snod ni chu la sogs pa mi 'jig par gnas pa'i rten ma yin no zhes bstan pa'i phyir/
Thus to teach that a bowl is not a support for the water to persist without perishing:
dngos rnams skad cig re rer ni/ / 'jig na/
69a As when things perish each and every instant,
zhes smos te/ snod ni chu la sogs pa mi 'jig par gnas pa'i rten ma yin te/ chu sogs kyi dngos po rnams skad cig re rer ni skye zhing 'jig pa'i phyir na'o/ /
A bowl is not the support for water to persist without perishing, because water and other such things arise and perish each and every instant.
de ltar mi 'jig par gnas pa'i rten ma yin mod kyi/ 'on kyang gnas skabs su thur du mi 'bo ba'i rten yin par bstan pa'i phyir/
Thus it is not the support for water to persist without perishing. However, it is temporarily the support for the water not to spill. To teach this:

dngos rgyun de lta bu/ / skye rgyu yin phyir de rten yin/ / de ltar min na rigs ma yin/ / 'bo ba yi ni gegs byed phyir/ / chu sogs kyi ni rten 'gyur gyi/ / 'gro ba med can yon tan spyi/ / las rnams la ni rten ci dgos/ /

69b-d A thing's continuum is thus the cause Of it arising, hence that is the support. Otherwise it would not be logical. 70. Because it prevents movement,[109] it is thus A support for water and so forth. But why Would qualities, universals, or else actions That do not move need a support?

zhes smos te/ snod ni chu la sogs pa'i dngos po'i rigs rgyun phyi ma rnams rigs rgyun snga ma de lta bur thur du mi 'bo bar skye ba'i rgyu yin pa'i phyir/ chu la sogs pa de'i rten yin la/ snod las chu la sogs pa'i rgyun skye ba de ltar min na snod dang chu la sogs pa rten dang brten pa rigs pa ma yin no/ / de ltar na snod kyi chu thur du 'bo ba yi ni gegs byed cing mi ltung bar bskyed pa'i phyir dang / snod chu sogs kyi ni rten du 'gyur ba yin gyi/ gzhan dang gzhan du 'pho zhing 'gro ba'i bya ba med pa can yin pa'i phyir/ yon tan dang spyi dang las rnams la ni chu sogs mi 'jig par gnas pa'i rten du ci dgos te mi dgos so/ /

A bowl is the cause for later instances in the continuum of the same kind of thing—water and so forth—to arise without spilling in this way, like the earlier instances of that continuum. For that reason, it is the support of water and so forth. Otherwise it would not be logical for a bowl and water to be the support and supported if it were not so that the continuum of water and so forth arose from the bowl. Therefore, because it (the bowl) prevents water from spilling down and produces a lack of falling, and because it (the bowl) is thus a support for water and so forth, it does not otherwise have any other action of moving or going. But why would qualities, universals, or else actions need a support to remain without perishing like water? They do not need one.
gnyis pa des gzhan yang khegs pa ni/
(b) How this refutes other things as well
'dis ni 'phrod pa 'du ba dang / / 'phrod pa 'du ba can rgyu dang / / rigs la sogs pa rnams gnas nyid/ / rten med phyir na bsal ba yin/ /
71. This disallows inherence and Causes that would have inherence As well as that a kind would dwell, Because there is not any support.

ces smos te/ phan mi 'dogs pa'i don gzhan rten dang brten par 'dod pa 'gog pa'i rigs pa 'dis ni lus sems gnyis rten dang brten par 'brel bar byed pa'i 'phrod pa dang 'du ba dang lus la sems 'phrod pa dang 'du ba can gyi rgyu bdag gis byas pa dang / gsal ba rnams rigs dang snam bu la sogs pa la khyad par gyi chos dkar po sogs grub zin pa'i don gzhan rnam par gnas pa nyid du 'dod pa rnams bsal ba yin te/ grub zin pa'i don gzhan rten dang brten par med pa bstan pa'i phyir na'o/ /

This logic that refutes the assertion that other objects that have no effect could be support or supported also dissallows the assertions that there is inherence that makes a relation between mind and body as supporter and supported; that for the body, the self would act as a cause that has inherence with mind; and that a kind would dwell in instances or that predicated features—other already established objects such as white and so forth—would dwell in blankets and so forth because it teaches that there is not any supporter or supported for other already established objects.[110]
gsum pa don bsdu ba ni/
(3) Summary
gal te gzhan las dngos 'jig na/ /
72a If something else were to make a thing perish,

zhes smos te/ gal te sems la sogs pa'i rten bcas kyis dngos po rnams 'jig rgyu dang ma 'phrad na ngang gis gnas pa yin pa la/ 'jig rgyu don gzhan dang 'phrad pa las sems sogs rten bcas kyi dngos po rnams 'jig pa yin ce na/ bshad pa/

If you say that supported things such as the mind persist by their nature if they do not meet the cause of perishing, but meeting something else that is the cause of perishing makes supported things such as the mind perish, to explain:
de yi gnas rgyus ci zhig bya/ / de gzhan med par 'jig na yang / / gnas pa'i rgyu rnams nus med yin/ /
72b-d Then what would its cause of persistence do? If it still perishes without another, The causes of persistence have no power.

ces smos te/ sems de'i gnas rgyu lus kyis sems gnas pa ci zhig byas te ma byas par thal/ sems de la 'jig rgyu don gzhan med par rang gi ngang gis 'jig pa yin na yang sems gnas pa'i rgyur 'dod pa'i lus rnams la sems mi 'jig par gnas par byed pa'i nus pa med pa yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

Then what would the body—its (the mind's) cause of persistence— do to make the mind persist? It follows that it does nothing, because if it (the mind) still perishes of its own nature without another object that is a cause of perishing, then the body asserted to be the cause of the mind's persistence would have no power to make the mind persist without perishing.
gal te gtan tshigs ma grub bo zhe na/ bshad pa/
If you say that the reason is not proven, to explain:
rten bcas thams cad gnas ldan dang / / skye ba can kun rten bcas yin/ / de phyir dngos po thams cad ni/ / 'ga' zhig tshe na'ang 'jig mi 'gyur/ /
73. Everything with support would have persistence, And all that arises would have a support. Thus for that reason, no thing ever At any time would perish.

zhes smos te/ sems la sogs pa'i rten bcas thams cad 'jig rgyu dang ma 'phrad kyi bar du rtag par gnas pa dang ldan pa dang / rgyu las skye ba can gyi dngos po kun mi 'jig par gnas par byed pa'i rtag pa'i rdzas kyi rten dang bcas pa yin pa de'i phyir/ sems la sogs pa'i dngos po thams cad ni 'jig rgyu dang ma 'phrad pa'i dus 'ga' zhig gi tshe na'ang nam yang 'jig par mi 'gyur bar thal lo/ /

Everything with support such as mind and so forth would permanently have persistence until it encounters the cause of perishing, and all things that arise from a cause would have the support of a permanent substance that would make them persist without perishing. Thus for that reason, it would follow that no thing such as the mind and so forth would ever perish at any time until encountering the cause of perishing.
gzhan yang sems la sogs pa'i dngos po thams cad rang gi ngang gis 'jig gam 'on te mi 'jig/ dang po ltar na 'gal lo zhes bstan pa'i phyir/
Additionally, do all things such as mind perish of their own nature or not? To teach that it would be contradictory in the first case:
gal te rang 'jig ngang tshul bdag/ yin na de gnas byed gzhan gang / /
74ab And if their character is that they perish By their own nature, what else makes them stay?

zhes smos te/ gal te sems sogs dngos po rnams rang gi ngang gis 'jig pa'i ngang tshul can gyi bdag nyid yin pa'i phyir na/ sems sogs dngos po de gnas par byed pa'i rgyu gzhan lus sogs gang yod de med par thal lo/ /

If the character of things such as the mind is that they perish by their own nature, then for that reason what other cause of persistence such as the body and so forth else makes them (things such as the mind) persist or stay? It follows that there is none.
gnyis pa ltar na yang /
In the second case:
gal te rang 'jig ngang tshul bdag/ min na de gnas byed gzhan gang / /
74cd But if their character is not to perish By their own nature, what else makes them stay?
zhes smos te/ gal te sems sogs rang gi ngang gis 'jig pa'i ngang tshul can gyi bdag nyid min na/ sems sogs dngos po de gnas par byed pa'i rgyu gzhan lus sogs gang yod de med par thal lo/ /

If the character of the mind and so forth is not to perish by their own nature, then what other cause of persistence such as the body and so forth else makes them, things such as the mind, persist or stay? It follows that there is none.
lnga pa shes rab la sogs pa lus la brten pa dgag pa la/
v. Refuting in particular that intelligence and so forth are supported by the body.
shes rab sogs lus la mi brten pa'i 'thad pa/ chags sogs lus la mi brten pa'i 'thad pa/ de nyid dpe'i sgo nas bshad pa/ de dag sems la brten par bstan pa'o/ /

This has four points: (1) The logic of intelligence and so forth not being supported by the body, (2) The logic of desire and so forth not being supported by the body, (3) Explaining this with an analogy, and (4) Teaching that these two are supported by the mind.
dang po [shes rab sogs lus la mi brten pa'i 'thad pa] ni/
(1) The logic of intelligence and so forth not being supported by the body
lus kyi phul byung 'grib med par/ / blo yi byed pa'i khyad par gyis/ / shes rab la sogs phul byung dang / / 'grib pa dag tu 'gyur ba yin/ /
75. Without an increase or decrease of body, There can be an increase or a decrease In intelligence, et cetera, due to Distinctions in the action of the mind.

ces smos te/ lus dang shes rab dag nyer len dang / nyer len can gyi dngos po ma yin te/ lus kyi yon tan phul du byung zhing 'phel ba dang 'grib pa'i rjes su 'gro ldog byed pa med par blo rnam par shes pas nyer len du byed pa'i khyad par gyis shes rab dang / byams pa dang / snying rje dang / 'dod chags dang bral ba dang / 'dod chags dang zhe sdang dang gti mug la sogs pa phul du byung zhing 'phel ba dang 'grib pa dag tu 'gyur ba yin pa'i phyir ro zhes lha shAka gnyis kyis lus shes rab la sogs pa'i nyer len yin par 'gog par mdzad la/ rgyan las bdag rkyen yin pa 'gog par mdzad do/ /

The body and intelligence are not substantial cause and substantial result, since without being entailed by an increase or decrease in the qualities of the body, there can be an increase or a decrease in intelligence, loving-kindness, compassion, and freedom from desire, or desire, hatred, delusion, and such due to distinctions in the action of the mind consciousness functioning as the substantial cause. Devendrabuddhi and Śākyabuddhi both refute that the body is the substantial cause of intelligence and so forth, but Prajñākaragupta refutes that it is the dominant condition.[111]
gal te khyab pa ma nges so zhe na/ bshad pa/
If you say that the pervasion is indefinite, to explain:
'di ni mar me'i 'od la sogs/ / brten pa rnams la yod ma yin/ /
76ab Things that have support, such as the light Of a lamp, et cetera, do not have this.

zhes smos te/ lus 'phel 'grib byed pa'i rjes su 'gro ldog mi byed na lus kyi nyer len can ma yin pas khyab ste/ lus 'phel 'grib kyi rjes su mi 'gro bar nyer len blo'i rjes su 'gro ba 'di ni mar me'i 'od dang / myu gu dang / grib ma la sogs pa nyer len lus la brten pa rnams la yod pa ma yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

If something is not entailed or reverse entailed by the increase or decrease of the body, it is pervasively not the substantial result of the body. This is because things that have the support of a physical substantial cause such as the light of a lamp, shoots, shadows, et cetera, do not have have this entailment with the substantial cause of mind, which is not entailed by the increase or decrease of the body.
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
de las kyang 'di khyad 'gyur te/ /
76c “From that as well, there are distinctions in this.”

zhes smos te/ bcud len la sogs pas lus rgyas par byas pa de las kyang shes rab la sogs pa 'di khyad par 'phel bar 'gyur ba mthong ba'i phyir/ shes rab la sogs pa ni lus 'phel 'grib kyi rjes su 'gro ldog byed pa yin te zhe na/ bshad pa/

Taking nourishment and so forth makes the body increase, and from that as well it is seen that the distinctions in this (intelligence and so forth) increase. For that reason, intelligence and so forth are entailed and reverse entailed by the increase and decrease in the body, you say. To explain:
sems la phan 'dogs med phyir min/ /
76d Not so, since that does not affect the mind.

ces smos te/ bcud len gyis rgyas par byas pa'i lus des bdag rkyen lus la brten pa'i sems la dngos su phan 'dogs pa med pa'i phyir/ shes rab la sogs pa'i nyer len byas pa'i sgo nas dngos su bskyed pa min no/ / 'o na ci yin ce na/ bcud len la sogs pas lus la dngos su phan 'dogs pa'i sgo nas shes rab sogs la brgyud nas phan 'dogs pa tsam yin no/ /

Since that (the body that is increased by taking nourishment) does not directly affect the mind that is supported by the body as a dominant condition, it does not directly produce intelligence and so forth by way of being the substantial cause. Well then, how is it? you ask. Taking nourishment and so forth directly affects the body and in this way affects intelligence and so forth indirectly only.
gnyis pa chags sogs lus la mi brten pa'i 'thad pa ni/
(2) The logic of desire and so forth not being supported by the body
gzhan dag na re/ lus rgyas pa las 'dod chags dang / gud pa las zhe sdang skye bas shes rab sogs kyang lus las dngos su skye'o zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others say that desire arises from the body strengthening and aversion from it weakening, so intelligence and so forth also arise directly from the body. To explain:
'ga' tshe chags sogs rgyas sogs kyis/ / 'phel ba bde sdug las skyes yin/ / de yang khams snyoms la sogs pa/ / nang gi don ni nye ba las/ /
77. Increases of desire and such from thriving And such are sometimes born from pleasure or pain. They're from the presence of internal objects— The balance of the elements and so forth.

zhes smos te/ lus rgyas shing tshul min yid la byed pa'i dus 'ga' zhig gi tshe na chags pa dang sdang ba sogs skye ba de ni lus rgyas pa dang gud pa sogs kyi rkyen kho na las 'phel ba ma yin te/ yid shes 'khor du byung ba'i tshor ba bde sdug las dngos su skyes pa yin pa'i phyir dang / yid shes 'khor gyi tshor ba ni lus shes 'khor gyi tshor ba las skye ba/ de ltar na chags sdang gi rgyu dbang shes 'khor gyi tshor ba bde sdug de yang go rim bzhin du khams snyoms pa dang mi snyoms pa la sogs pa nang gi reg bya'i khyad par gzung don du ni nye ba las skyes pa'i phyir ro/ /

Sometimes when the body is thriving and there is inappropriate attention, desire, hatred, and such arise, but they do not increase solely from the conditions of the body thriving, weakening, and such, because they are born directly from the feelings of pleasure or pain that arise in association with the mental consciousness. The feelings associated with the mental consciousness arise from the feelings associated with the body consciousness. Therefore they (the causes of desire or aversion—the pleasures and pains associated with sensory consciousnesses) arise from the presence of internal objects—distinctions of internal sensations such as the balance or imbalance of the elements and so forth—as the apprehended object.
rigs pa des gzhan yang khegs par bstan pa'i phyir/
To teach how this logic also refutes other propositions:
'dis ni 'dus pa la sogs las/ / dran pa nyams sogs bshad pa yin/ / nang don khyad par las skyes pa'i/ / blos ni 'gyur bar byed phyir ro/ /
78. And this explains how loss of memory And such arise from fever and so forth, Because the mind born from distinctions of Internal objects makes the alteration.

zhes smos te/ tshor ba bde ba dang / sdug bsngal ni yul gyi sgo nas skye ba yin gyi/ lus la brten pa'i sgo nas skye ba ma yin par bshad pa'i rigs pa 'dis ni 'dus pa'i rims dang sbyar dug la sogs pa las byung ba'i dran pa nyams pa dang / rmongs pa dang / g.yeng ba la sogs pa yang lus kyis dngos su nyer len byas pa las skyes pa ma yin par bshad pa yin te/ rims dang sbyar dug la sogs pa la brten pa'i nang gi gzung don reg bya'i khyad par las skyes pa'i dbang po'i blos ni yid blo gzhan du 'gyur bar byed cing 'gyur ba las byung ba'i phyir ro/ /

This logic that explains how sensations of pleasure or pain arise by way of the object and not by way of the bodily support explains how loss of memory, stupefaction, distraction, and so forth arise from illness of fever, poisons, and so forth, not from the body functioning as the substantial cause. This is because the mind of the sense faculties born from the distinctions in touch of the internal apprehended objects due to disease, poisons, and so forth makes the mental mind change, and loss of consciousness and so forth arise from that alteration.
gsum pa de nyid du dpe'i sgo nas bshad pa ni/
(3) Explaining this with an analogy
dper rgyu khyad par 'ga' zhig las/ / stag nyid dang ni khrag la sogs/ / thos pa dang ni mthong ba las/ / rmongs pa la sogs 'byung 'gyur bzhin/ /
79. As an analogy, it is just as How certain types of individuals On hearing or else seeing tigers or Blood and such are stupefied and so forth.

zhes smos te/ dper na sdar ma'i shes rgyud mi brtan pa'i khyad par 'ga' zhig la stag nyid dang / bu shi ba la sogs pa'i sgra ni thos pa dang / de bzhin du ni khrag dang 'jigs su rung ba'i gnas mthong ba las rmongs pa dang / rnam par g.yeng ba dang / shi ba dang / brgyal ba dang / spu zing zhes byed pa la sogs pa 'byung bar 'gyur ba yang stag la sogs pas nyer len byas pa las skyes pa ma yin par yul du byas pa'i sgo nas brgyud nas skyes pa bzhin du dran pa nyams pa la sogs pa yang blo snga ma'i nyer len las byung ba'i phyir 'dus pa la sogs pa las yul gyi sgo nas skyes pa yin gyi/ nyer len du byas pa las skyes pa ma yin no/ / de'i phyir lus sems kyi nyer len ma yin no/ /

As an analogy, it is just as when certain unstable kinds of individuals with cowardly mental continua are stupefied, become distraught, die, faint, get goosebumps and so forth upon hearing a tiger, hearing of the death of a child and so forth, or seeing blood or terrifying things. This does not arise from the tiger and so forth being the substantial cause. Instead it arises indirectly by way of taking it as the object. Similarly, memory loss and so forth arise from the substantial cause of the previous cognition, so they arise from fever and so forth functioning as an object, not functioning as a substantial cause. For that reason, the body is not the substantial cause of the mind.
bzhi pa de dag sems la brten par bstan pa ni/
(4) Teaching that these two are supported by the mind
de phyir nges par gang nyid kyi/ / 'du byed kyi ni rjes 'jug pa'i/ / sems ni de med mi 'byung ba/ / de phyir sems la brten pa yin/ /
80. Therefore it won't arise without The mind to whose formations it Is definitely consequent. Thus it's supported by the mind.

ces smos te/ lus sems kyi nyer len ma yin pa de'i phyir/ nges par rigs mthun pa'i sems snga ma gang yin pa de nyid kyi 'du byed kyi ni rjes su 'jug pa'i sems phyi ma de ni sems snga ma de nyer len du med na mi 'byung ba de'i phyir/ sems snga mas nyer len byas pa la brten pa yin gyi/ lus nyer len gyi rgyu ma yin no zhes pa lha'i'o/ /

The body is not the substantial cause of the mind. Therefore it (the later mind that is definitely consequent to the formations of the preceding mind of the same kind) will not arise without that preceding mind as a substantial cause. For that reason, it is supported by the preceding mind functioning as the substantial cause; the body is not the substantial cause. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
gnyis pa lus sems rdzas gcig yin pa dgag pa la/
b. Refuting that mind and body are the same in substance.
'gog byed kyi rigs pa dngos/ skye gnas su 'jug tshul la rtsod pa spang ba/ ma mthong ba tsam skye ba snga phyi med pa'i sgrub byed ma yin pa'o/ /

This has three points: i. The actual logic of the refutation, ii. Rebutting criticism about the manner of entering the place of birth, and iii. Merely not seeing them does not prove that past and future births do not exist.
dang po ['gog byed kyi rigs pa dngos] ni/
i. The actual logic of the refutation
ji ltar sems la rten byas nas/ / thos sogs 'du byed sems la ni/ / dus gsal tha dad med pa'i phyir/ / de ltar lus la'ang yon tan 'gyur/ /
81. Just as formations of listening and such, Formed in the mind, at times are evident In mind, these qualities would also be In the body, as it is not separate.

zhes smos te/ ji ltar goms pa'i dbang gis sems la brten par byas nas thos pa dang bzo'i las kyi man ngag la sogs pa nan tan du 'du byed pa'i sems la ni dus 'ba' zhig gi tshe thos sogs kyis yon tan mngon par gsal ba de ltar lus la'ang thos pa dang bzo'i yon tan mngon par gsal bar 'gyur te/ lus sems tha dad med pa'i phyir zhes lha'i'o/ / rgyan las/ nyer len myong ba mngon du song ba can gyi thos pa la sogs pa'i 'du byed gnyid log pa la sogs pa'i tshe mi gsal kyang / sad pa'i gnas skabs su gsal ba bzhin du lus la yang gsal bar 'gyur ba dang / lus kyi yon tan nag po la sogs pa gzhan gyis dmigs pa bzhin du sems kyi yon tan bzo'i las la sogs pa yang dmigs par ci ste mi 'gyur/ zhes gsungs so/ /

Just as through the power of cultivating them, the qualities of listening and so forth—formations from earnestly pursuing listening, instructions in the crafts, and such, which are formed on the support of the mind—at times are evident in the mind, similarly these qualities of listening and the crafts would also be evident in the body, as it (the body) is not separate from the mind. This is according to Devendrabuddhi. The Ornament says: Just as formations of listening preceded by... experience (the substantial cause), are not evident during periods of deep sleep but are evident... during waking periods, they would also be evident in the body... Just as qualities of the body such as darkness are observed by others, why would not the mental qualities of the crafts and so forth also be observed?[112]
gnyis pa skye gnas su 'jug tshul la rtsod pa spang ba la/
ii. Rebutting criticism about the manner of entering the place of birth

gzhan dag na re/ sems can rnams 'byung ba chen po rnams las byung ba ma yin par skye ba gzhan nas mngal la sogs pa'i gnas su 'ongs pa yin na/ de'i phyir mi gtsang ba'i yul du 'ongs pa mi rigs shing mi 'dod bzhin du dbang phyug gis bskul ba'ang mi 'thad do zhe na/ bshad pa/

Others say that if sentient beings came to the womb and so forth from another birth instead of arising from the great elements, it would not be logical for them to come to an unclean place, and neither would it be logical for Īśvara to send them against their will. To explain:
bdag la chags pa dang ldan pa/ / sems can gzhan gyis bkri min pa/ / bde sdug dor thob 'dod pas na/ / dman pa'i gnas ni yongs su len/ /
82. Those who have attachment to a self Are not led by another sentient being. They embrace inferior places from the wish To obtain happiness and avoid suffering.

ces smos te/ bdag la chags pa dang ldan pa'i sems can rnams dbang phyug la sogs pa gzhan gyis dbang med du bkri ba min par grub kyang / rang bde ba thob pa dang sdug bsngal dor bar 'dod pa'i mngon par chags pa sngon du song bas na/ chags pa'i dbang gis dman pa'i gnas mngal ni yongs su len pa ste/ dper na sbrang bu dag mi gtsang ba'i gnas len pa'am/ 'dod pa can dag bud med kyi ro'i lus yongs su len pa lta bu'o zhes pa lha'i'o/ / rgyan ni/ bdag la chags pas bskul ba ni dman pa'i gnas kyang phyin ci log tu 'dzin pas blang byar gyur pa de ni las kyi nus pa nyid yin te/ dper na chags ldan smad 'tshong ma'i khang par 'jug pa bzhin no gsungs/

It has been proven that those sentient beings who have attachment to a self are not led powerless by another sentient being such as Īśvara. Instead, due to the preceding attachment of wishing to obtain happiness and avoid suffering for themselves, they embrace inferior places such as the womb due to attachment. It is, for example, just as how wasps will take to unclean places or lustful people will embrace the corpse of a woman. This is according to Devendrabuddhi. Prajñākaragupta says that it is the power of karma that those who are incited by lust perceive even inferior places erroneously and embrace them. For example, it is like a lustful man entering a prostitute's house.
de yang sred pa nyid skye ba len pa'i rgyu yin no zhes bstan pa'i phyir/
To teach that craving alone is the cause for taking birth:
sdug bsngal phyin ci log blo dang / / sred pas kun nas 'ching ba ni/ / skye rgyu gang la de med pa/ / de ni skye bar mi 'gyur ro/ /
83. Craving and the cognition that Misconstrues suffering are the bonds That cause rebirth. Whoever lacks them Is someone who will not be born.

zhes smos te/ dman pa'i gnas mngal la sogs pa sdug bsngal yin pa la bde bar phyin ci log tu 'dzin pa'i blo dang sdug bsngal dang bde ba dor ba dang thob par 'dod pa'i sred pas mngal du kun nas 'ching bar byed pa ni mngal du skye ba'i rgyu yin te/ gang la sred pa dang phyin ci log gi blo de med pa de ni mngal du skye bar mi 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ /

The cognition that erroneously misconstrues inferior places such as the womb, which are suffering, as pleasurable and the craving that wants to avoid suffering and gain happiness bind one to the womb and are the causes of rebirth in the womb. Whoever lacks them, craving and the erroneous cognition, is someone who will not be born in a womb.
gsum pa ma mthong ba tsam skye ba snga phyi med pa'i sgrub byed ma yin pa ni/
iii. Merely not seeing them does not prove that past and future births do not exist
gal te 'gro 'ong ma mthong na/ /
84a If going and coming are not seen,

zhes smos te/ tshu rol mdzes pa ba na re/ tshe 'di nas phyi mar 'gro ba dang / snga ma nas mngal gyi gnas su 'ong ba ma mthong ba'i phyir na/ bar srid nas mngal gyi gnas su skye ba len pa med do zhe na/ bshad pa/

The Cārvākas say that going from this life to the next and coming from the previous to the place of the womb are not seen, so therefore there is no being reborn from a between state to the place of the womb. To explain:
dbang po mi gsal phyir ma mthong / / dper na mig mi gsal ba yis/ / du ba chung ngu mi mthong bzhin/ /
84a-d it is Because the faculties are not acute That they cannot be seen, as for example Those with poor vision don't see wisps of smoke.

zhes smos te/ rgyang 'phen khyod kyi dbang po mi gsal ba'i phyir/ des ma mthong ba yin la/ de tsam gyis bar srid nas mngal du skye ba len pa med par mi 'grub ste/ dper na mig mi gsal ba'i skyes bu yis du ba chung ngu mi mthong bas ni du ba med par mi 'grub pa bzhin no/ / skyes bu thams cad kyis bar srid ma mthong ba ni ma grub ste/ rigs mthun pa dang lha mig dag pas mthong ba'i phyir zhes rgyan gyi'o/ /

You Cārvākas, it is because your faculties are not acute that you do not see it, but that alone does not prove that there is no being reborn from the between state to the womb. As for example, that those people with poor vision do not see a wisp of smoke does not prove that there is no smoke. It is not proven that all beings do not see the between state, because it is seen by those of the same class and the pure divine eye. This is according to Prajñākaragupta.[113]
gal te bar srid lus can yin pas thogs pa dang bcas par 'gyur ro zhe na/ bshad pa/
If you say that the between state is corporeal, so it should be obstructive, to explain:
lus can yin yang phra ba'i phyir/ / 'ga' zhig la lar thogs med de/ / chu bzhin gser la dngul chu bzhin/ / ma mthong phyir na med pa min/ /
85. Although they are corporeal, they are subtle. Thus some are not obstructive to some things, Like water or like mercury with gold. It does not not exist from not being seen.

ces smos te/ lus can yin yang phra zhing dwangs pa'i phyir te/ srid pa bar ma'i lus 'ga' zhig ni rmi lam gyi lus bzhin du la lar thogs pa med de/ dper na rdza so ma btang ba la chu bzhin dang / gser la dngul chu thogs pa med pa bzhin no/ / des na bar do'i srid pa rgyang 'phen khyod kyis ma mthong ba'i phyir na med pa min ces rgyan gyi'o/ /

Although they are corporeal, they are subtle and limpid. Thus some bodies of the between state are, like bodies in dreams, not obstructive to some things. For example, it is just as water is not obstructed by clay that has not been fired or gold is not obstructed by mercury. Therefore, it (the between state) does not not exist because of not being seen by you Cārvākas. This is according to Prajñākaragupta.
gsum pa sems lus kyi 'bras bu yin pa dgag pa la/
c. Refuting that mind is a result of the body.
yan lag can rgyu yin pa dgag/ yan lag rgyu yin pa dgag pa'o/ /
This has two topics: i. Refuting that a whole could be a cause, and ii. Refuting that parts could be a cause.
dang po [yan lag can rgyu yin pa dgag pa] la/
i. Refuting that a whole could be a cause.
yan lag can gcig yin pa dgag/ de la rtsod pa spang ba'o/ /
This has two topics: (1) Refuting that the whole is single, and (2) Refuting criticism.
dang po [yan lag can gcig yin pa dgag pa] ni/
(1) Refuting that the whole is single
lus sems kyi rgyu yin na lus de cha shas med pa'i yan lag gcig yin nam/ cha shas dang bcas pa'i du ma yin grang / dang po ltar zhe na/ bshad pa/
If the body is the cause of the mind, is that body a single element with no parts, or is it multiple with parts? If you say it is the first, to explain:
lag sogs g.yo na thams cad dag/ g.yo bar 'gyur phyir 'gal ba can/ / las ni gcig la mi rung phyir/ / gzhan du tha dad grub par 'gyur/ /
86. If the arm or so forth were to move, then all Would move. Thus contradictory actions are Illogical in a single entity, So they'd be proven separate, au contraire.

zhes smos te/ skyes bu chos can/ lag pa sogs yan lag gcig g.yo na yan lag thams cad dag g.yo bar 'gyur bar thal/ g.yo ba'i yan lag dang yan lag lhag ma rnams cha med gcig yin pa'i phyir/ khyab ste/ g.yo mi g.yo 'gal ba can gyi las ni chos gcig la 'du bar mi rung ba'i phyir/ gal te de'i tshe yan lag g.yo ba yin gyi/ yan lag can g.yo ba ma yin pas skyon med ce na/ yan lag can chos can/ rang gi yan lag las go sa tha dad du grub par 'gyur bar thal/ yan lag g.yo ba'i tshe na g.yo ba las gzhan du mi g.yo bar gnas pa'i skyes bu'i yan lag can yin pa'i phyir/

It follows that for a person, the subject, if one limb such as the arm or so forth were to move, then all the limbs would move, because the moving limb and all the other limbs are a singular entity that lacks parts. This pervades because it is illogical that the contradictory actions of moving and not moving could be combined in a single entity. You might say that when the limb is moving, the whole is not, so there is no fault. So it follows that the whole, the subject, is proven to have a separate state from its limbs, because when the limbs are moving, the whole of the person on the contrary remains unmoving.
gzhan yang /
Additionally:
gcig bsgribs pa na thams cad dag/ bsgrib par 'gyur ba'am ma bsgribs na/ / mthong 'gyur gcig tshon gyis bsgyur na/ / bsgyur ram ma bsgyur rtogs par 'gyur/ / de phyir tshogs pa gcig yod min/ /

87. If one were covered, all would then be covered, Or if not covered, all would be visible. If one changed color, all would change or else It would be realized that it did not change. 88a Therefore conglomerations are not single.

ces smos te/ skyes bu chos can/ rang gi yan lag gcig gos kyis bsgribs pa na yan lag lhag ma thams cad dag gos kyis bsgrib par 'gyur bar thal/ bsgribs pa'i yan lag dang yan lag lhag ma rnams cha med gcig yin pa'i phyir/ dper na bum pa'i ngo bo bzhin no zhes pa'am/ yang gal te de'i tshe yan lag bsgribs na yang yan lag can ma bsgribs pas skyon med ce na/ gos kyis bsgribs pa'i skyes bu'i gdong pa chos can/ rang 'dzin mig shes kyis sngar ma bsgribs pa ltar rdzogs par mthong bar 'gyur te/ bsgribs pa'i gdong pa dang ma bsgribs pa'i yan lag can cha med gcig yin pa'i phyir/ gzhan yang skyes bu chos can/ yan lag gcig tshon gyis bsgyur na yan lag lhag ma thams cad tshon gyis bsgyur bar thal/ tshon gyis bsgyur ba'i yan lag dang ma bsgyur ba'i yan lag lhag ma rnams cha med gcig yin pa'i phyir zhes pa'am/ yang na tshon gyis bsgyur ba'i phyogs kyang ma bsgyur bar thal/ tshon gyis bsgyur ba'i yan lag dang ma bsgyur ba'i yan lag cha med gcig yin pa'i phyir zhes rtogs shing shes par 'gyur ro/ / de ltar na yan lag can skyes bu'i lus de yan lag du ma tshogs pa can gyi rdzas gcig tu yod pa min te/ g.yo ba dang mi g.yo ba la sogs pa'i rdzas 'gal ba du mar gnas pa de'i phyir/

For a person, the subject, it follows that if one of their limbs were covered by cloth, all the remaining limbs would then be covered by cloth, because the covered limb and the remaining limbs are a single entity that lacks parts. It is like the essence of a jug, for example. If you reply that although the limb is covered, the whole is not covered so there is no fault, then it follows a person's face that is covered by cloth, the subject, would be fully visible to the eye consciousness that apprehends it just as it was previously when not covered, because the covered face and the uncovered whole are a single entity that lacks parts. Additionally, for a person, the subject: it follows that if one of their limbs changed color, all the remaining limbs would change color, because the limb whose color changed and remaining limbs whose color did not change are a single entity that lacks parts. Or else it would follow that the portion that changed color also did not change color, because the limb whose color changed and the limbs whose color did not change are a single entity that lacks parts. This would be realized and known. Therefore the whole—the individual's body—does not exist as a single substance that is a conglomeration of many parts, because it dwells in many substances such as moving, unmoving, and so forth that are exclusive of each other.
gnyis pa de la rtsod pa spang ba la/
(2) Refuting criticism.
rtsod pa dang / lan bstan pa'o/ /
This has two topics: (a) The dispute and (b) Teaching the response.
dang po [rtsod pa] ni/
(a) The dispute
du ma nyid na'ang snga ma bzhin/ / khyad med phyir dang phra rab phyir/ / rtogs min zhe na/
88b-d You say, “It's multiple. Because there's no Distinction from before, because of atoms It therefore is not realized.”

zhes smos te/ bye brag pa na re/ phyogs gnyis pa ltar skyes bu'i lus de cha shas dang bcas pa'i du ma nyid yin la/ de ltar na'ang rdul phra rab rnams snga ma ma tshogs pa'i gnas skabs su dbang shes kyi yul ma yin pa bzhin du phyis rdul phra rab rnams tshogs pa'i tshe na'ang dbang shes kyis rtogs pa min te/ dbang po las 'das par khyad par med pa'i phyir dang / rdul phra rab yin pa'i phyir ro zhe na/

Some Vaiśeṣikas say it is the second case: a person's body is multiple and has parts. In that way, because just as the atoms previously before being assembled were not an object of a sensory consciousness, later when they are assembled as well they therefore are not realized by the sensory consciousnesses, because there is no distinction in them transcending the faculties and because they are atoms.
gnyis pa de'i lan bstan pa la/
(b) Teaching the response.
gtan tshigs ma grub pas dgag/ khyab pa ma nges pas dgag/ ma dmigs pas dgag/ de la rtsod pa spang ba'o/ /

This has four topics: (i) A refutation from the reason not being established, (ii) A refutation from the pervasion being indeterminate, (iii) Refutation from nonobservation, and (iv) Rebutting criticism.
dang po [gtan tshigs ma grub pas dgag pa] ni/
(i) A refutation from the reason not being established
khyad med par/ / ma grub khyad par can rnams ni/ / dbang yul de phyir rdul phran min/ /
88d It's not proven 89ab There's no distinction, because the distinguished Are objects of the faculties; atoms aren't.

ces smos te/ skyes bu'i lus ni bum pa sogs dbang shes kyi yul las 'das pa'i gnas skabs kyi rdul ma tshogs pa dang khyad par med par gtan tshigs ma grub ste/ rdul phran so so ba las dbang shes bskyed nus su skyes pa'i rdul phran khyad par can rnams ni dbang shes kyi gzung yul yin pa de'i phyir ro/ / rdul phra rab yin pa'i gtan tshigs gnyis pa yang ma grub pa yin te/ lus la sogs pa'i tshogs pa'i gnas skabs can gyi rdul phran rnams la yang rdul phran gyi tha snyad byed pa ma yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

The reasoning that there is no distinction between a person's body, a jug, or so forth and the unassembled atoms during the period when they transcend the object of a sensory consciousness is not proven, because the atoms that are distinguished from individual atoms in that they arise with the ability to produce sensory consciousness are the apprehended objects of the sensory faculties. Nor is the second reason (that they are atoms) proven, because the atoms during the period of being assembled in a body or so forth are not called by the convention atoms.[114]
dpe gzhan yang khegs par bstan pa'i phyir/
To each that this logic also refutes other analogies:
'di ni sgrib byed la sogs pa/ / med pa dag kyang bsal ba yin/ /
89cd And this disproves as well that they Would not obscure, et cetera.

ces smos te/ gtan tshigs gnyis ma grub par bstan pa 'dis ni yan lag can rdzas gcig pa med na skyes bus lus sogs kyi sgrib byed dang thogs pa la sogs pa med par thal/ cha tshogs pa'i rdul phra rab so so ba la sgrib thogs med pa'i rdul phra rab yin pa'i phyir snyam pa'i klan ka de dag kyang bsal ba yin te/ de la yang gtan tshigs ma grub pa'i lan bstan pa'i ched yod pa'i phyir ro/ /

This teaching that the second reason is unproven disproves as well such objections as thinking that if there were no whole that was a single substance, it would follow that they (people's bodies and so forth) would not obscure, obstruct, et cetera, because the individual atoms assembled are non-obscuring and unobstructive.[115] This is to teach the response that such reasons are not proven.
gnyis pa khyab pa ma nges pas dgag pa la/
(ii) A refutation from the pervasion being indeterminate.
dgag pa dngos/ de'i yang lan dgag pa'o/ /
This has two points: A. The actual refutation, and B. Rebutting the response.
dang po [dgag pa dngos] ni/
A. The actual refutation
dngul chu gser sogs dang 'dres pa'am/ / rdo tshon la sogs ji ltar snang / / dbang sogs so sor nus med rnams/ / rtogs pa dag ni ji ltar yin/ /
90. How could a mix of gold and mercury Or so forth or hot rocks or such appear? How would the faculties and such, which lack Capacity individually, perceive?

ces smos te/ dngul chu dang gser 'dres pa dang chu dang 'o ma la sogs pa 'dres pa'am/ yang na me rdul dang 'dres pa'i rdo tshon dang shing tshon la sogs pa rnams chos can/ dbang shes la ji ltar snang ste mi snang bar thal/ yan lag can gyi rdzas gcig med pa'i phyir te/ rdul rigs mi mthun pa dag rdzas rtsom pa med pa'i phyir ro/ / de bzhin du dbang po dang / yul dang / yid byed la sogs pa rnams chos can/ yul rtogs pa'i shes pa dag ni ji ltar bskyed pa yin te ma yin par thal/ khyod rnams so sor ma tshogs pa na dbang shes bskyed pa'i nus pa med pa rnams dang yan lag can rdzas gcig med pa dang khyad par med pa'i phyir ro/ /

How could a mixture of gold and mercury or water and milk and so forth, or alternately hot rocks, hot wood, or such that are mixed with atoms of fire—the subject—appear to the sensory consciousnesses? It follows they would not appear, because there is no single substance of a whole, as particles of incompatible kinds do not compose a substance. Similarly, how would the faculties, object, attention, and such, the subject, produce a cognition that perceives an object? It follows they would not, because there is no whole that is a single substance nor any distinction from those that are unassembled and lack the capacity to produce a sensory consciousness individually.
de la gzhan dag na re/
Others respond to this:
ldan las shes na/
91a If from conjunction,
zhes smos te/ gal te dbang po dang yul dang yid byed gsum las ldan pa skye la/ de las dbang shes skye bas skyon med do zhe na/ bshad pa/
Well then, from the faculties, object, and attention there arises a conjunction,[116] and the sensory consciousnesses arise from that, so there is no fault, you say. To explain:
'dir thal mtshungs/ /
91ab here the consequence Is the same.

zhes smos te/ rkyen gsum gyis ldan pa bskyed pa'i skabs 'dir yang dbang sogs kyis ldan pa gcig bskyed pa'i sgo nas dbang shes mi bskyed par thal ba mtshungs te/ rdzas med pa'i du mar khyad par med pa'i phyir ro/ /

Here in this context as well where three conditions produce conjunction, the consequence that the faculties and so forth would not produce a sensory consciousness by way of producing a single conjunction is the same, because there is no difference in it being multiple and lacking substance.
gnyis pa de'i yang lan dgag pa ni/
B. Rebutting the response
gal te gser dang dngul chu ni/ / ldan pas snang ba yin zhe na/ /
91bc And if you say that the conjunction Of gold and mercury appears,

zhes smos te/ gal te gzhan dag na re/ gser dang dngul chu la sogs pa 'dres pa ni rdzas med kyang rigs mi mthun pa'i rdul phan tshun 'phrad pa'i ldan pa yod pas/ de dbang shes la snang ba yin zhe na/ bshad pa/

Others might say that although the mixture of gold and mercury is not substantial, there is the conjunction that is atoms of different kinds meeting. That is what appears to the sense consciousness, they say. To explain:
rten mthong med par gang las rtogs/ /
91cd without A visible support, how is it realized?

zhes smos te/ ldan pa'i rten gser dang dngul chu'i rdul 'phrad pa tshad mas mthong ba med pa'i phyir na/ dbang shes kyis gser dang dngul chu'i rdul 'phrad pa'i ldan pa gang las rtogs te mi rtogs par thal lo/ /
