If the support for conjunction—the meeting of atoms of gold and mercury—is not visible by valid cognition, how is it (the conjunction that is the meeting of gold and mercury atoms) realized by a sensory consciousness? It follows that it is not realized.
gzhan yang /
Additionally:
ro gzugs la sogs ldan par 'gal/ /
92ab Conjunctions of form, flavor, and so forth Are contradictory.

ces smos te/ ji ltar lge'u gsher dang bu ram la sogs pa sbyar ba rdzas sna tshogs pa'i mtshan nyid can gyi btung ba de la ro zhim pa dang / gzugs bzang ba dang / dri dang reg bya'i yon tan la sogs pa dang ldan par 'gal bar 'gyur te/ yan lag can gyi rdzas med pa'i rdul rigs mi mthun du ma tshogs pa'i yon tan yin pa'i phyir ro/ / 'dod par mi nus te/ 'jig rten na btung ba gzugs bzang zhes dang / btung ba zhim zhes pa'i tha snyad mthong ba'i phyir zhes pa lha yi'o/ /

It would be contradictory for drinks whose characteristic is that they are made from a combination of various substances such as juices, molasses, and such to be a conjunction of qualities such as a delicious flavor, a good visual form, smell, touch, and so forth, because those are qualities of a combination of many particles of different kinds that have no substance of a whole. You cannot agree, because terms such as “The drink looks nice” or “The drink is delicious” are seen in the world. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
de la gzhan dag na re/
Others say about this:
gal te nye bar btags pa las/ / 'dod na/
92bc If you assert It's attribution,

zhes smos te/ gal te btung ba'i ro gzugs rgyun gyi rdzas gcig la ldan pa 'du ba yin pas ro la sogs pa'i rdul ldan pa nye bar btags pa las btung ba ro zhim gzugs bzang zhes pa'i tha snyad byed par 'dod do zhe na/ bshad pa/

If you assert that the conjunction is contained in the one substance of the continuum of the flavor and form, so the conventions “the drink's flavor is delicious” or “its form is fine” are made from attributing conjunction to the atoms of flavor and so forth, to explain:
blo tha dad par 'gyur/ / ji ltar phreng ring zhes byar 'gyur/ /
92cd there'd be separate minds. How could one say a row is long?

zhes smos te/ rdzas sna tshogs sbyar ba'i btung ba dang 'o ma'i ro gnyis blo la ro'i ngo bo dang btags pa ba tha dad par snang bar 'gyur te/ de gnyis ro yi ngo bo gcig btags pa ba yin pa'i phyir/ dper na ba lang khra bo dang nag sgur dag bzhin no/ / gzhan yang ji ltar bya mang po tshar du bsgrigs pa'i phreng ba la tshar du dngar ba'i ring po zhes bya bar btags nas ston par 'gyur te mi 'gyur bar thal/ ring po dang rdzas gcig la 'phrod pa 'du ba'i 'brel ba med pa'i phyir te/ / gang la 'du ba'i bya re re la ring po mi 'du ba'i phyir ro zhes lha'i'o/ /

The two flavors of a drink made from various substances and of milk would appear separately to the mind as an essence of flavor and as an attribution, because of the two, one is the essence of the flavor and one is an attribution. As an analogy, it is like spotted and brown cows. Additionally, how could one indicate a long row of birds in formation, designating it by saying it is a long row? It follows one could not, because there is no relation of inherence that is substantially the same as length. This is because length is not contained within any individual bird in which it would have to be contained. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
gsum pa mi dmigs pas dgag pa la/
(iii) Refutation from nonobservation.
rtags dgod pa/ de nyid ma grub pa spang ba/ rnam dbye'i sgra mi srid pa spang ba/ tshogs pa'i sgra mi srid pa spang ba'o/ /
This has four topics: A. Giving the evidence, B. Rebutting that it is not proven, C. Refuting that declension would be impossible, and D. Rebutting that expressions of collection would be impossible.
dang po [rtags dgod pa] ni/
A. Giving the evidence
de ldan rang gi ngo bo dang / / brjod pa dag la tha dad par/ / grangs ldan las la sogs pa yi/ / ngo bo blo la mi snang ngo / /
93. The essences of number, conjunction, action, Et cetera, do not appear to mind Separate from the essence of that which Possesses them or separate from expressions.

zhes smos te/ gzugs sogs de dang ldan pa'i bum pa ni rang gi ngo bo dang rdzas kyi ngo bo tha dad par brjod pa'i sgra dag las rdzas tha dad pa'i gcig la sogs grangs dang / don gzhan ldan pa dang 'degs 'jog la sogs pa'i las dang rnam par dbye ba dang / gzhan nyid dang ma yin pa dang spyi la sogs pa'i don ni yod pa ma yin te/ rdzas tha dad du yod na snang du rung ba las ngo bo blo la mi snang ba'i phyir ro zhes lha yi'o/ /

Form and so forth; phenomena such as a number of one and so forth; conjunction with another object; action of lifting, placing, and so forth; declension, otherness, nonbeing, universals, et cetera do not exist as separate substances from the essence of a jug that possesses them or separate from expressions that signify the essence of a substance separately. This is because if they did exist as a separate substance, they would be able to appear, but their essences do not appear to the mind. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
gnyis pa de nyid ma grub pa spang ba la/
B. Rebutting that it is not proven.
sgra shes tha dad kyang don tha dad du ma nges pa de'i lan dgag pa/ yon tan gyi grangs don gzhan dgag pa'o/ /
This has three points: 1. Though words and cognition are separate, the object is not definitely separate, 2. Refuting the response, and 3. Refuting that the number of qualities is another object.
dang po [sgra shes tha dad kyang don tha dad du ma nges pa] ni/
1. Though words and cognition are separate, the object is not definitely separate
gzhan dag na re/ bum pa'i grangs dang ldan pa la sogs pa ni bum pa las rdzas tha dad du yod de/ sgra dang shes pas tha dad du dmigs pa'i phyir zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others say that the number, conjunction, and so forth of a jug exist as separate substances from the jug, because words and cognition focus on them separately. To explain:
sgra shes dngos po tha dad pa'i/ / rjes 'brang rnam rtog btags don can/ / dper na yon tan la sogs pa'am/ / zhig dang ma skyes dag la bzhin/ /
94. Objects of words and of cognitions are Projected by thoughts that follow separate things, Like qualities and so forth for example, Or like the perished and unborn.

zhes smos te/ bum pa'i yon tan dang grangs sogs tha dad du brjod pa'i sgra dang shes pa la grangs sogs rang mtshan tha dad par snang ba ma yin te/ log sa tha dad las log pa'i ldog pa'i dngos po tha dad pa'i rjes su 'brang ba'i rnam rtog gis sgro btags pa'i btags don yul du byed pa can yin pa'i phyir/ dper na gzugs la sogs pa'i yon tan la gcig dang yang dag par ldan pa zhes bya ba la sogs pa'i sgra dang shes pa la 'jug pa'am/ yang na zhig nas med pa dang ma skyes nas med pa dag la yang gcig dang gnyis dang mang po la sogs pa'i sgra shes 'jug pa bzhin no/ / des na khyab pa ma nges so/ /

The number and so forth of a jug do not appear as separate specific characteristics to words and cognitions that signify the jug's qualities, number, and so forth. This is because they take nominal objects that are projected by thoughts that follow separate things that are isolates, which are the reverse of separate bases for opposition.[117] It is just as cognitions and words such as one, possess, and so forth can refer to qualities of form and so forth, for example. Or it is just as how words and cognitions such as singular, dual, plural, and so forth can apply to that which does not exist from having perished or that which does not exist from not yet being born.[118] Therefore the pervasion is indeterminate.
gnyis pa de'i lan dgag pa ni/
2. Refuting the response
gal te 'dir ni btags 'dod na/ /
95a If you propose that here it's nominal,
zhes smos te/ gal te gzhan dag na re/ gzugs la sogs pa'i yon tan rnams la gcig la sogs pa'i grangs sogs brjod pa 'dir ni btags ming tsam du 'jug par 'dod do zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others propose that saying a number of singular and so forth for the qualities of form and so forth here is merely applying it nominally as a nickname.[119] To explain:
rgyu mtshan gang gis de 'dod pa/ / de ni dngos po thams cad la/ / de dag gis rgyus cis mi 'dod/ /
95b-d Why would you not assert, then, that the reason Because of which you posit that would be The cause of those for every entity?

ces smos te/ rgyu mtshan gang gis na gzugs la sogs pa'i yon tan rnams la grangs sogs brjod pa btags ming du 'jug pa de ltar 'dod pa de ni bum pa la sogs pa'i dngos po thams cad la grangs sogs brjod pa btags ming du 'jug par sgra dang shes pa de dag gis rgyus cis mi 'dod de 'dod dgos so zhes lha yi'o/ / rgyan las/ thog ma med pa'i rtog pas sgro btags pa nyid rgyu mtshan yin gyi/ dngos por btags pa'i skabs yod pa ma yin no/ / zhes bshad do/ /

Why would you not assert that the reason because of which you posit that expressions of number and so forth apply to qualities such as form and so forth nominally as nicknames would be the cause of those words and cognitions applying expressions of number and so forth to every entity such as a jug and so forth nominally as nicknames? It follows that you should. This is according to Devendrabuddhi. Prajñākaragupta explains: That they have been projected by beginningless thoughts would be the reason, but there is no time when they could be designated things.[120]
de la gzhan dag na re/
Others respond to this:
gal te kun la nyer btags min/ / tha dad khyad par gtso bo zhes/ / bya nyid gang las tha dad pa/ / med na tha dad don med na/ /
96. “They are not nominal in every case. The separate features are called principal. If that from which it's separate should be absent, The separate would not have an object,” you say.

zhes smos te/ gal te bum pa'i grangs sogs kyi sgra de yul kun la nye bar btags nas 'jug pa min te/ yul bum pa'i grangs sogs la btags ming las tha dad pa'i khyad par gtso bor dngos ming du 'jug pa yang yod pa'i phyir ro/ / de ltar ma yin na grangs sogs kyi sgra bum pa'i grangs sogs la gtso bor 'jug pa dang / yon tan gyi grangs sogs la btags nas 'jug pa zhes bya ba de nyid gang las rtogs par 'gyur te/ bum pa'i grangs sogs brjod pa'i sgra des brjod bya tha dad pa med pa la grangs sogs tha dad par brjod pas sgra tha dad du brjod pa don med du 'gyur ba'i phyir zhe na/ bshad pa/

In that case, they (expressions such as “the number of jugs”) do not refer to all objects[121] nominally, because they can also refer to the object, the number of jugs, as an actual name for the features that are separate from the nickname as the principal. If it were otherwise, expressions such as “number” would refer to the number of jugs and so forth as the principal and to the number of qualities and so forth nominally. What would that be realized from? The expression that signifies the number of jugs and so forth would signify number and so forth separately for signified objects that are not separate, so expressions that signify them with separate expressions would have no object, you say. To explain:
don gzhan rgyu mtshan can min yang / / dkar la sogs pa grangs sogs dang / / ldan pa'i sgra ni rnam grangs min/ /
97a-c Though not an object with another reason, Expressions for white and such, number and such, As well as conjunction aren't synonymous.

ces smos te/ bum pa'i grangs sogs brjod pa'i sgra ni sgra rnam grangs pa ma yin te/ brjod bya'i don rdzas gzhan pa'i rgyu mtshan can min yang yon tan dkar po la sogs pa'i grangs dang las la sogs pa dang / yang dag par ldan pa zhes pa'i sgra rnams ni sgra rnam grangs pa min par khyed nyid kyang 'dod pa'i phyir ro/ /

Expressions that signify the number of jugs and so forth are not synonymous expressions, because though the signified object does not have a reason that is substantially other, expressions for the number, action and such of white and such, as well as conjunction are not synonymous expressions, as you yourself have asserted.
gsum pa yon tan gyi grangs don gzhan dgag pa ni/
3. Refuting that the number of qualities is another object
gal te de la'ang don gzhan na/ /
97d If those were to have other objects, too,
zhes smos te/ gal te gzhan dag na re/ dkar po sogs yon tan de dag la'ang grangs la sogs pa dang ldan pa can gyi yon tan don gzhan tha dad pa yod pas ma nges pa yin no zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others might say that those qualities of white and so forth have qualities that are other separate objects such as number and so forth or conjunction, so it is indeterminate. To explain:
yon tan rdzas ni khyad med 'gyur/ / don gzhan min yang ldog pa yi/ / dbye bas tha dad pa yin te/ / las rdzas min pa'i sgra bzhin no/ /

98. There'd be no distinction between qualities And substance. They'd be separate through distinctions In isolates, though they're not other objects, As in the phrases “not action” and “not substance.”

zhes smos te/ de ltar yin na yon tan dang rdzas kyi mtshan nyid ni khyad par med par 'gyur te/ yon tan ni grangs dang ldan pa la sogs pa'i yon tan gzhan gyi rten byed pa'i phyir ro/ / de bas na gzugs sogs yon tan gyi grangs sogs brjod pa'i sgra ni brjod bya don gzhan yod pa min yang sgra dang rtog pa tha dad du 'jug pa yin te/ ldog pa tha dad pa'i dbye bas sgra dang rtog pa tha dad du 'jug pa yin pa'i phyir te/ dper na las ma yin ces pa'i sgra dang rdzas min ces pa'i sgra gnyis ldog pa tha dad pa'i sgo nas 'jug par 'dod pa bzhin no/ /

If that were so, there would be no distinction between the characteristics of qualities and substance, because qualities would support other qualities such as number, conjunction, and so forth. Therefore although there is not any other signified object, expressions that signify the number and so forth of qualities such as form would engage word and thought separately, because they would engage word and thought separately through distinctions of their separate isolates. For example, it is just as how the phrases “not action” and “not substance” are asserted to engage by way of separate isolates.
gsum pa rnam dbye'i sgra mi srid pa spang ba la/
C. Refuting that declension would be impossible
gal te bum pa'i grangs sogs rdzas tha dad du yod de/ bum pa'i grangs zhes pa'i rnam dbye'i sgra 'jug pa'i phyir/ dper na lha byin gyi ril ba spyi blugs lta bu'o zhe na/ bshad pa/
You might say that the number of jugs and so forth are substantially separate because the phrase “the number of jugs” can be declined, just as with the expression “Devadatta's pitcher.” To explain:
dngos po brjod pa'i sgra rnams kyis/ / grangs sogs de dang ldan pa las/ / tha dad gzhan du bstan gang de'ang / / chos gzhan khyad par byed pa yin/ /
99. Also expressions signifying things That indicate the number and so forth As separate from that which possesses them Make a distinction from the other features.

ces smos te/ dngos po chos brjod pa'i sgra rnams kyis bum pa'i grangs la sogs pa de dang ldan pa'i bum pa las tha dad pa bzhin du bstan pa gang yin pa de'ang / bum pa'i grangs sogs bum pa las rdzas tha dad du yod pa'i dbang gis 'jug pa ma yin te/ bum pa'i grangs zhes pa'i sgra des bum pa'i chos gzhan kha dog la sogs pa rnam par gcod pa'i khyad par du byed pa tsam yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

Expressions signifying predicated things that indicate the number of jugs and so forth as if they were separate from the jugs that possess them do not refer to the number of jugs and so forth by force of them being separate substances from the jugs. This is because the expression “the number of jugs” merely makes a distinction that excludes the other features of the jugs such as their color and so forth.
de bas na bum pa'i grangs sogs brjod pa'i sgra des bum pa dang bum pa'i grangs sogs rdzas tha dad du ma bstan kyang ldog pa tha dad par brjod par bstan pa'i phyir/

Therefore expressions that signify the number of jugs and so forth do not indicate that the jugs and the number of jugs are separate substances but indicate that the isolates are separately signified.
de tsam shes par 'dod pa la/ / gzhan kun 'phangs pa med par ni/ / la lar sor mo'i ldan pa zhes/ / tha dad chos bzhin rjod par byed/ /
100. In certain cases, one might say to those Who want to know just that, without implying Anything else, “that which a finger possesses” As if it were a separate predicate.

ces smos te/ bum pa'i grangs sogs brjod pa'i sgra des bum pa'i kha dog sogs khyad chos du ma'i nang nas bum pa'i grangs sogs kyi ldog pa de tsam zhig shes par 'dod pa la bum pa'i khyad par gyi chos gzhan kun blo yul du 'phangs pa med par bum pa'i grangs sogs tsam ni ston pa'i phyir/ bum pa'i grangs sogs de bum pa dang rdzas tha dad du mi ston kyang ldog pa tha dad pa'i chos bzhin du rjod par byed de/ dper na sor mo'i khyad par gyi chos gshibs pa tsam zhig brjod par 'dod pa'i skabs la lar sor mo dang sor mo'i ldan pa rdzas tha dad pa med kyang sor mo'i ldan pa zhes pa'i sgra 'jug pa bzhin no zhes lha rgyan gnyis ka'i'o/ /

Expressions that signify the number of jugs and so forth indicate just the number of jugs and so forth without implying anything else—the other predicated features of the jug—as a mental object to those who want to know just the isolate of the number of jugs among the many features of the jugs such as their color and so forth. For that reason, the number and so forth of jugs is not indicated as separate in substance from the jugs, but is spoken of as if it were a predicate with a separate isolate. For example, in certain cases where one wants to signify merely the predicated feature of a finger's straightness, although the finger and that which it has are not separate substances, the expression “that which a finger possesses” can be used. This is according to both Deven-drabuddhi and Prajñākaragupta.
de'i phyir chos brjod kyi sgra dang chos can brjod pa'i sgra gnyis la khyad par gzhan spong ba dang mi spong ba'i khyad par ma gtogs brjod bya rdzas tha dad pa med do zhes bstan pa'i phyir/

For that reason, the only difference between expressions that signify predicates and expressions that signify subjects is whether or not they exclude other features. The signified are not separate in substance. To teach this:
don gcig brjod kyang thams cad ni/ / 'phen phyir sor mo ldan 'gyur zhes/ / chos can brjod par grags yin te/ / de ltar brdar ni byas pa yin/ /
101. “The finger that is possessed” designates The selfsame object but it implies all, So it is called a phrase that signifies The subject. In this way the sign is made.

ces smos te/ chos dang chos can brjod pa'i sgra gnyis kas brjod bya'i don gcig brjod par mtshungs kyang sor mo'i khyad chos thams cad dang ldan par 'gyur ba ni 'phen cing brjod pa'i phyir na/ sor mo ldan par 'gyur ro zhes brjod pa'i sgra ni chos can brjod pa'i sgra yin par grags pa yin te/ de'i phyir sor mo'i ldan pa zhes brjod pa'i sgra dang sor mo ldan par 'gyur ro zhes pa'i sgra gnyis la brjod bya rdzas tha dad pa med kyang / brjod bya'i khyad par gzhan spong ba dang mi spong ba de ltar shes par bya ba'i ched du brda sbyar bar ni byas pa yin no zhes pa lha yi'o/ /

Expressions that signify predicates and those that signify subjects both comparably designate the selfsame signified object, but since it implies and signifies that it possesses all the features of the finger, the phrase “the finger that is possessed” is called a phrase that signifies the subject. For that reason, that which is signified by the two phrases “that which the finger possesses” and “the finger that is possessed” is not substantially separate, but in order to know in this way whether the signified's other features are thus excluded or not, the combination of signs is made. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
bzhi pa tshogs pa'i sgra mi srid pa spang ba ni/
D. Rebutting that expressions of collection would be impossible

gzhan dag na re/ yan lag can med mod kyi/ 'on kyang ro la sogs pa yan lag gi tshogs pa tsam yod pa ma yin na/ de'i tshe bum pa'i gzugs la sogs pa zhes pa'i sgra 'jug par mi 'gyur te/ gzugs kyi gzugs shes pa'i sgra 'jug par mi 'gyur ba bzhin no zhe na/ bshad pa/

Others might say that there may be no whole, but if the mere assembly of the parts such as flavor and so forth did not exist, then expressions such as “the jug's form” and so forth would not apply, just as the expression “the form's form” does not apply. To explain:
gzugs sogs nus pa'i khyad par ni/ / spong bas de mtshungs 'bras bu yi/ / rgyu min par ni rnam gcod pa/ / bum pa'i sgra ni 'jug par 'gyur/ /
102. By eliminating distinctions of the power Of form and so forth, the word jug refers To the exclusion of that which is not A cause of a comparable result.

zhes smos te/ bum pa brjod pa'i sgra ni tshogs pa brjod pa'i sgra yin te/ brjod bya bum pa de rdul rdzas brgyad tshogs pa yin pas/ de la yod pa'i gzugs sogs rdul rdzas brgyad po rnams kyis rang rang 'dzin pa'i shes pa so sor bskyed pa ni bye brag gi 'bras bu yin la/ rdul rdzas brgyad po 'dus pa des chu skyor ba bskyed pa ni spyi'i 'bras bu yin pas na/ bum pa zhes pa'i sgra des bum pa'i gzugs sogs rdul rdzas brgyad po rnams kyis rang rang 'dzin pa'i shes pa bskyed pa'i nus pa'i khyad par ni brjod byar spong bas na gzugs sogs rdul rdzas brgyad po de dag la mtshungs par rjes su 'gro ba'i thun mong gi 'bras bu chu 'dzin par byed pa'i rgyu min pa shing la sogs pa ni rnam par gcod pa'i phyir na/ bum pa zhes brjod pa'i sgra ni bum pa'i rdul rdzas brgyad po'i thun mong gi 'bras bu chu 'dzin pa'i don byed nus pa de la 'jug par 'gyur ro/ /

The word that signifies jug is an expression that signifies a collection. The signified jug is a collection of atoms of the eight substances,[122] so the eight substances of the atoms of form and so forth within it producing the individual awarenesses that apprehend themselves is a result of the particular, whereas the combination of the atoms of the eight substances producing the ability to hold water is a result of the general.[123] Therefore by eliminating from being the signified the distinctions of the power of the atoms of eight substances of the jug's form and so forth to produce awareness that apprehends themselves, the word jug excludes that which, such as wood and so forth, is not a cause of making it hold water, which is the common result that is comparably entailed by the atoms of the eight substances. For that reason, the word that signifies a jug refers to that which is able to perform the function of holding water, the common result of the jug's atoms of the eight substances.
des na yan lag can gcig med kyang tshogs pa du ma'i 'bras bu gcig la bum pa zhes brjod pa'i sgra ni nus pa gcig brjod par 'dod pa las yin no zhes bstan pa'i phyir/
Therefore, though there is not a single whole, words that call the single result of a collection of many a “jug” are from the wish to signify a single capacity. To teach this:
des na bum pa gzugs so zhes/ / gzhi gcig pa can sgra ma yin/ /
103ab For that reason, “the jug is form” is not An expression with a single referent.

ces smos te/ bum pa'i sgra des bum pa'i gzugs brjod byar spang ba des na bum pa brjod pa'i sgra dang bum pa'i gzugs so zhes brjod pa'i sgra gnyis brjod bya gzhi mthun cing gcig pa can gyi sgra ma yin no/ /

The word jug excludes the jug's form as the signified. For that reason, the word that signifies the jug and the expression that signifies the jug's form are not expressions with a single, common signified referent.
bzhi pa de la rtsod pa spong ba ni/
(iv) Rebutting criticism
gzhan dag na re/ gzhi gcig pa can sgra ma yin/ / ces pa mi 'thad de/ bum pa'i sgra ni bum pa'i khyad par la bltos nas rigs brjod pa'i phyir zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others say that it is not tenable to say “not an expression with a single referent,” because in relation to a jug's features, the word jug signifies a kind.[124]
des na 'di ni rigs dang ni/ / tshogs pa brjod pa'i khyad par yin/ /
103cd Therefore this is the difference between Signification of kind and of collection.

ces smos te/ bum pa'i sgra 'di ni gser bum gyi sgra la bltos nas brjod bya gzhi mthun pa dang / bum gzugs kyi sgra la bltos nas brjod bya gzhi mi mthun pa'i khyad par yod pa des na gser bum la bltos nas rigs brjod kyi sgra bum gzugs la bltos nas ni tshogs pa brjod pa'i sgra yin pa'i sgo nas khyad par gzhan spong ba dang mi spong ba'i khyad par yod pa bzhin no/ / 'dir tshogs pa'i sgra ni gnyis te/ tshogs pa du ma la 'jug pa can dang / gcig la 'jug pa can no/ / du ma la 'jug pa can ni/ bum pa dang shing la sogs pa'i sgra lta bu'o/ / gcig la 'jug pa can ni ri bo 'bigs byed la sogs pa'i sgra lta bu'o/ /

There is the distinction that in relation to the expression “golden jug,” the word “jug” shares a common signified, whereas in relation to the term “the jug's form,” it does not share a common signified. Therefore there is the difference of excluding or not excluding other features between being an expression that signifies kind in relation to a gold jug and being an expression that signifies collection in relation to a jug's form. Here there are two types of expressions that signify collection: those that refer to many collections and those that refer to one. Those that refer to many are such as the words “jug” and “wood.” Those that refer to one are such as the expression “Mount Vindhya” and so forth.[125]
gal te gzhan dag na re/ bum pa dang bum gzugs rdzas tha dad du med pa'i phyir/ bum pa'i gzugs zhes pa'i sgra des bum pa dang bum gzugs tha dad du ma brjod par 'gyur ro zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others might say that because a jug and the jug's form are not separate substances, the expression “the jug's form” would not signify the jug and its form separately. To explain:
de spyi yan lag tu byas te/ / bum pa yi ni gzugs so zhes/ / de nus khyad par ston par byed/ / phyogs 'dis gzhan la'ang brjod par bya/ /
104. Saying “the form and so forth of a jug” Makes its universal into a part And indicates distinctions in its power. This proposition also describes others.

zhes smos te/ bum pa dang bum gzugs rdzas tha dad du med kyang sgra tha dad du 'jug pa mi 'gal te/ bum pa'i rdzas brgyad po de'i spyi bum pa de yan lag gam khyad par du byas te bum pa yi ni gzugs so zhes pa'i sgra de ni bum pa'i gzugs 'dzin pa'i mig shes de bskyed par nus pa'i bum gzugs de ka ba'i gzugs las khyad par du phye nas ston par byed pa'i phyir ro/ / rigs pa rnam dag gi phyogs 'dis ni gzhan tsan+dan gyi dri zhes pa la'ang dri las rdzas tha dad pa'i tsan+dan med kyang tsan+dan dang dri tha dad du ston pa tsam yin ces brjod par bya zhes pa lha yi'o/ /

A jug and the jug's form are not substantially separate, but it is not contradictory for separate expressions to refer to them, because making the universal of the jug's eight substances—the jug—into a part or distinction and saying “the form of the jug” distinguishes the form of the jug that has the power to produce an eye consciousness that apprehends the form of a jug, which distinguishes it from the form of a pillar and then indicates it. This proposition of pure logic also describes others: in saying “the scent of sandalwood” as well, there is no sandalwood that is a separate substance from the scent, but the sandalwood and scent are indicated separately. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
gnyis pa yan lag rgyu yin par dgag pa la/
ii. Refuting that parts could be a cause.
tshogs pa dang ma tshogs pa la brtags nas dgag/ de'i lan dgag/ rang la mtshungs pa spang ba'o/ /
This has three topics: (a) Refuting by examining parts that are assembled and unassembled, (b) Refuting the response, and (c) Rebutting that it is comparable for ourselves.
dang po [tshogs pa dang ma tshogs pa la brtags nas dgag pa] ni/
(a) Refuting by examining parts that are assembled and unassembled

lus gcig sems kyi rgyur yod pa ma yin pas/ lus sems kyi rgyur 'dod pa khyod kyis lus kyi yan lag du ma sems kyi rgyur 'dod dgos la/ de ltar yin na yan lag du ma tshogs pa'am/ gang yang rung ba re re sems kyi rgyu yin grang / dang po ltar lus kyi yan lag ma lus pa sems kyi rgyu yin ce na/ bshad pa/

Since a single body is not the cause of mind, you who assert that the body is the cause of cognition must assert that the many parts of the body are the cause of the, mind. If that is so, then either the assembly of multiple parts must be the cause, or any single one must be. If you say that it is the first—that all the parts of the body together are the cause of mind—to explain:
ma lus rgyu nyid yin na ni/ / yan lag gcig dang bral na'ang min/ /
105ab If the entirety should be the cause, Then not when even one part is removed.

ces smos te/ lus kyi tshogs pa ma lus pa sems kyi rgyu nyid yin na ni lus kyi yan lag sna bcad pa lta bu gang rung gcig dang bral na'ang gang zag de'i lus la yid kyi rnam par shes pa skye ba min par 'gyur te/ rgyu tshogs ma tshang ba'i phyir/

If the entire assembly of the body were the cause of mind, when even any one part of the body is removed, such as the nose being cut off, then the mental consciousness would not arise in that individual's body, because the assembly of causes would be incomplete.
phyogs gnyis pa ltar yan lag gang rung re re sems kyi rgyu yin ce na/ bshad pa/
If you say it is the second case—that any one part is the cause of mind—to explain:
re re nus pa nyid yin na'ang / / cig car mang po 'byung bar 'gyur/ /
105cd If each one had capacity as well, Then many would occur at the same time.

zhes smos te/ skyes bu'i lus kyi rdul phra rab re res yid kyi rnam par shes pa skyed par nus pa nyid yin na'ang dus cig car du lus kyi rdul phra rab re re las yid kyi rnam par shes pa mang po 'byung bar 'gyur te/ yid kyi rnam shes du ma'i dngos rgyu tshogs pa tshang ba'i phyir ro zhes pa lha rgyan gnyis ka'i'o/ /

If each single atom in a person's body had the capacity to produce a mental consciousness as well, then many mental consciousnesses would occur simultaneously from each atom in the body at the same time, because the assembly of direct causes of multiple mental consciousnesses would be complete. This is according to both Deven-drabuddhi and Prajñākaragupta.
gnyis pa de'i lan dgag pa la/
(b) Refuting the response.
dbugs gsal byed kyi rgyu yin pa mi srid pa/ srid kyang rigs pas mi 'thad pa'o/ /
This has two topics: (i) It is impossible for breath to be the cause of knowing, (ii) Even if possible, it would not be logically tenable.
dang po [dbugs gsal byed kyi rgyu yin pa mi srid pa] la/
(i) It is impossible for breath to be the cause of knowing.
dbugs du ma rgyu yin par mi 'thad/ dbugs gcig rgyu yin par mi 'thad/ de'i yang lan mi 'thad pa'o/ /
This has three points: A. It is untenable for multiple breaths to be the cause, B. It is untenable for a single breath to be the cause, and C. The untenability of the response.
dang po [dbugs du ma rgyu yin par mi 'thad] ni/
A. It is untenable for multiple breaths to be the cause
gzhan dag na re/ dbugs 'byung rngub gcig las med la/ 'byung rngub gcig pu des sems mngon par gsal bar byed pas cig car rnam shes mang por 'gyur ba ma yin no zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others say that there is no more than one breath. A single breath makes the mind know, so there will not be multiple simultaneous consciousnesses.[126] To explain:
du ma nyid du mtshungs pa'i phyir/ / 'byung rngub dag ni nges byed min/ /
106ab As they are the same in being multiple, The out- and in-breaths aren't determinant.
ces smos te/ skyes bu'i lus kyi yan lag gi rdul dang du ma nyid du mtshungs pa'i phyir na/ dbugs 'byung rngub dag ni yid kyi rnam par shes pa gcig nges pa kho nar skyed par byed pa min no/ /
As they are the same as the atoms that are part of a person's body in being multiple, the out-breath and in-breath do not definitely produce one mental consciousness.
gnyis pa dbugs gcig rgyu yin pa mi 'thad pa ni/
B. It is untenable for a single breath to be the cause
gzhan dag na re/ gtan tshigs ma grub ste/ dbugs rnams rdzas gcig nyid yin pa'i phyir ro zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others say the reason is not proven, because breaths are only one single substance. To explain:
gcig nyid na yang mang gsal 'gyur/ / de rgyu rtag tu nye phyir ro/ /
106cd Even if single, many would manifest, Because their causes always would be present.

zhes smos te/ dbugs rnams rdzas gcig nyid yin pa de ltar na yang yid kyi rnam shes snga phyi mang po cig car du da lta gsal bar skye bar 'gyur te/ yid kyi rnam shes de'i rgyu lus dang dbugs 'byung rngub la sogs pa rtag tu nye bar yod pa'i phyir ro/ /

Even if breaths were one single substance, many earlier and later mental consciousnesses would simultaneously arise manifest in the present, because their (those mental consciousnesses') causes—the body, the inhalation and exhalation of breath, and so forth—would always be present.
de la gzhan dag na re/
Others respond:
gal te du ma'i rgyu min na/ /
107a If you say they are not the cause of many,
zhes smos te/ gal te dbugs 'byung rngub dang lus nyid ma yin na'ang rnam shes gcig nyid cig car du bskyed par nus kyi/ du ma cig car du bskyed pa'i rgyu min ce na/ bshad pa/

You might say that although the inhalation and exhalation and body themselves may be multiple, they can only produce a single consciousness at one time; they are not a cause that produces many simultaneously. To explain:
rim gyis kyang min khyad med phyir/ /
107b Since there's no difference, not successive either.
zhes smos te/ lus dang dbugs gnyis rim gyis kyang rnam par shes pa du ma'i rgyu min par 'gyur te/ cig car du rnam par shes pa du ma'i rgyu ma yin pa gang zhig snga phyi khyad par med pa'i phyir ro/ /

The body and breath would not be the cause of many successive consciousnesses either, because there is no difference between the earlier and later in that which does not cause multiple simultaneous consciousnesses.
gzhan yang dbugs dang lus ni rnam par shes pa gcig kho na'i rgyu min pa yang ma nges so zhes bstan pa'i phyir/
Additionally, to teach it is inconclusive that the breath and body are not the cause of only a single consciousness:
dbugs gcig la yang don du ma/ / 'dzin phyir de las nges ma yin/ /
107cd Since multiple objects can be apprehended During one breath, no certainty from that.
ces smos te/ dbugs gcig gi yun la yang don du ma 'dzin pa'i rnam par shes pa du ma skye bar mthong ba'i phyir na/ dbugs gcig gi yun de las rnam par shes pa gcig kho na skye bar nges pa ma yin no/ /

Since it is seen that even during the duration of one breath, multiple consciousnesses that apprehend multiple objects arise, there is no certainty that only one single consciousness will arise from that duration of one breath.
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
du ma blo gcig gis shes na/ /
108a If one mind were to cognize multiple,
zhes smos te/ rnam par shes pa go rim dang ldan pa skad cig du mas don du ma shes pa ma yin gyi/ don du ma blo gcig gis cig car du shes pas skyon med ce na/ bshad pa/
You might say that it is not that successive consciousnesses know multiple objects over multiple moments, but that one mind cognizes multiple objects simultaneously, so there is no fault. To explain:
de ni cig car nyid 'gyur te/ / 'gal ba med phyir rim gyis kyang / / mi 'gyur khyad par med phyir ro/ /
108b-d That would be simultaneous because There's nothing contrary. It would not be Successive either, since there's no distinction.

zhes smos te/ dbugs gcig gi yun la don du ma rim gyis 'dzin pa'i blo de ni don du ma cig car 'dzin par byed pa nyid du 'gyur te/ cig car 'dzin pa la tshad ma dang 'gal ba med pa'i phyir te/ snga phyi'i rang bzhin la khyad par med pa'i blo yin pa'i phyir/ de ltar ma yin na rim gyis kyang don du ma 'dzin par mi 'gyur te/ snga ma'i rang bzhin las skad cig snga phyi khyad par med pa'i phyir ro zhes lha yi'o/ /

That mind that successively apprehends multiple objects during one breath would apprehend multiple objects simultaneously, because there is nothing validly contrary to it apprehending them simultaneously. This is because it is a mind where there is no distinction in its nature earlier or later. If that were not so, it would not apprehend multiple objects successively either, since there is no distinction of earlier and later moments from the nature of the earlier. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
gsum pa de'i yang lan mi 'thad pa ni/
C. The untenability of the response
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
rang rigs min pa'i dus can gyis/ / dbugs kyi skad cig mang po dag/ gal te de 'dra'i sems nyid kyi/ / rgyu yin par ni rtog byed na/ /
109. If you should think that many instants Of respiration that are at times That aren't of their own kind should be The causes of suchlike cognitions,

zhes smos te/ gal te la la dag lus rtag pa la rdzas du ma rim can du 'byung ba yin gyi/ rang gi rigs 'dra snga ma las byung ba min pa'i dus can gyi dbugs kyi skad cig snga phyi mang po dag de 'dra'i sems snga phyi rim can du 'byung ba nyid kyi rgyu yin pas/ cig car 'byung ba'i skyon med ces rtog par byed na/ bshad pa/

Some think that in the permanent body, multiple substances arise sequentially, while the many earlier and later instants of respiration that are at times of not arising from previous instants of their own kind are the causes of suchlike cognitions arising in a sequence of earlier and later, so there is no fault of occurring simultaneously. To explain:
go rim ldan pa'i rgyu med par/ / de dag rim ldan ji ltar 'gyur/ /
110ab How could they be sequential if They lack a cause to be sequential?
zhes smos te/ snga phyi go rim dang ldan par 'gyur ba'i rgyu med par dbugs 'byung rngub de dag rim ldan du 'byung bar ji ltar 'gyur te mi 'gyur ro/ /
If they (the inhalation and exhalation) lack a cause to have a sequence of earlier and later, how could they arise sequentially? They would not.
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
rang rigs snga ma rgyu nyid na/ /
110cd If the cause is the previous instance of Its own kind,
zhes smos te/ gal te rang gi rigs 'dra snga ma rgyu nyid yin gyi/ lus rgyu min ce na/ bshad pa/
If you say the cause is the previous instance of its own kind, and the body is not the cause, to explain:
dang po 'byung bar mi 'gyur te/ / de rgyu de 'dra yod ma yin/ /
110d then the first would not occur 111a Because a similar cause does not exist.

ces smos te/ de ltar min na mngal la sogs par dang por skyes ma thag dbugs gsar du 'byung bar mi 'gyur te/ dbugs de'i rgyu rigs 'dra snga ma de 'dra ba yod pa ma yin pa'i phyir ro/ / ma grub na tshe snga ma grub la/ 'dod na dbugs sems kyi rgyu ma yin par grub bo/ /

If that were so,[127] then at first immediately after birth in the womb and so forth, breath would not occur anew, because the cause of that breath—a similar previous instance of its own kind—does not exist. If you say the reason is not established, a previous lifetime is proven, but if you agree, then it is proven that the breath is not the cause of the mind.
gnyis pa srid kyang rigs pas mi 'thad pa la/
(ii) Even if possible, it would not be logically tenable.
blo cig car du skye bar thal bas dgag/ dbugs ma tshang na mi skye bar thal bas dgag/ shes pa la khyad par yod par thal bas dgag pa'o/ /

This has three points: A. Refuting through the consequence that cognitions would arise simultaneously, B. Refuting through the consequence that it would not arise if the breath were incomplete, C. Refuting through the consequence that there would be a distinction in cognitions
dang po [blo cig car du skye bar thal bas dgag pa] ni/
A. Refuting through the consequence that cognitions would arise simultaneously
dbugs 'byung tha dad yul can phyir/ / yod kyang du ma nyid du nges/ / de phyir blo ni cig car skye/ /
111b-d If so, they'd certainly be multiple Because the breaths have separate locations. Thus minds would simultaneously arise.

zhes smos te/ dbugs yid blo'i rgyu yin pa yod du chug kyang zhes khas blangs brjod nas dbugs ni 'byung yul tha dad nas 'byung ba'i yul can yin pa'i phyir na/ du ma nyid du nges par 'gyur te/ dper na phyugs kyi khyu bzhin no/ / de ltar dngos rgyu dbugs du ma cig car du yod pa de'i phyir/ blo du ma ni cig car du skye bar 'gyur ro/ /

Even if it were so (to state the assertion) that breath were the cause of mind, because the breaths have separate locations of origin from which they arise, they would certainly be multiple, like a herd of livestock, for example.[128] Therefore because the direct cause—the breath—would be a simultaneously present multiple, thus multiple minds would simultaneously arise.
gnyis pa dbugs ma tshang na mi skye bar thal bas dgag pa ni/
B. Refuting through the consequence that it would not arise if the breath were incomplete
gal te du ma'ang gcig dus can/ / sems gcig gi ni rgyu yin na/ /
112ab And if though multiple, those were the causes Of a single cognition at one time,
zhes smos te/ gal te gzhan dag na re/ dbugs 'byung rngub du ma'ang cig car du tshogs pa'i dus can thams cad sems gcig gi ni rgyu yin ce na/
Others say that though inhalations and exhalations may be multiple, those assembled simultaneously at one time are all the cause of a single cognition.
dbugs rgyu zhan pa la sogs su/ / gcig ma tshang na'ang mi 'byung 'gyur/ /
112cd If even one were absent, it would not Arise, as when the breathing is weak and so forth.

zhes smos te/ dbugs kyi rgyu ba zhan pa dang chad pa la sogs pa'i dus su dbugs kyi yan lag gcig ma tshang na'ang rnam par shes pa mi 'byung bar 'gyur te/ dbugs kyi yan lag tshogs pa thams cad rnam par shes pa'i rgyu yin pa'i phyir ro zhes rgyan gyi'o/ /

At times when the breathing is weak, ceases, and so forth, if even one aspect of the breath were absent, it (consciousness) would not arise, because the entire assembly of all the aspects of breath is its cause. This is according to Prajñākaragupta.
gsum pa shes pa la khyad par yod par thal bas dgag pa ni/
C. Refuting through the consequence that there would be a distinction in cognitions
ci ste ji ltar yod rgyu yin/ /
113a Supposing they were causes as they are,
ces smos te/ ci ste yang gzhan dag na re/ dbugs drag pa dang zhan pa dang ring ba sogs ji ltar yod pa de rnam par shes pa'i rgyu yin ce na/ bshad pa/
Supposing others say that they (heavy, weak, long, and so forth breaths) are causes of consciousness just as they are. To explain:
shes pa la yang khyad yod 'gyur/ / gang zhig gang gi tha dad las/ / tha dad min te de 'bras min/ /
113b-d There'd be a distinction in cognition, too. It is not a result of that if it Does not differ from differences in that.

zhes smos te/ skyes bu'i dbugs lhag par 'byung ba de'i tshe rnam par shes pa gsal ba dang / dbugs mi 'byung ba'i tshe rnam par shes pa la yang mi gsal ba'i khyad par yod par 'gyur te/ shes pa dbugs kyi dngos 'bras yin pa'i phyir ro/ / thal ba las rnam par shes pa ni dbugs de'i dngos 'bras min te/ rnam par shes pa gang zhig dbugs gang gi 'phel 'grib dang tha dad pa las 'phel 'grib dang tha dad du 'gyur ba min pa'i phyir te zhes lha yi'o/ /

There would be a distinction in cognition, too, in that it would be clearer when a person's breath became stronger and unclear when there was no breathing, because consciousness is a direct result of breath. Consequentially, it (consciousness) is not a direct result of that breath, because it (consciousness) does not become different by increasing and decreasing from differences in that breath increasing and decreasing. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
gsum pa rang la mtshungs pa dgag pa ni/
(c) Rebutting that it is comparable for ourselves
gzhan dag na re/ khyed cag gis kyang shes pa snga ma las shes pa phyi ma skye bar khas blangs pas shes pa du ma cig car du skye bar thal ba'i nyes pa mtshungs so zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others might say that we also assert that later cognitions arise from earlier ones, so the consequence that many cognitions would appear simultaneously also applies to us. To explain:
rnam shes nus pa nges pa'i phyir/ / gcig ni gcig gi rgyu yin te/ / rnam shes don gzhan chags pa yi/ / nus med don gzhan mi 'dzin phyir/ /
114. The power of consciousness is ascertained, So one is the cause of one. Consciousness lacks The ability to cling to other objects, Because it does not grasp another object.

zhes smos te/ rnam par shes pa snga ma snga mas phyi ma phyi ma rim can du bskyed pa'i nus pa so sor nges pa yin pas cig car du du ma skye ba'i rgyu ma tshang ba'i phyir/ rnam par shes pa snga ma gcig ni rang dang rigs mtshungs pa'i rnam shes phyi ma gcig gi rgyu yin pa ste/ de ltar na rigs mtshungs pa'i rnam shes du ma cig car skye ba ma yin no/ / rnam shes snga mas rnam shes phyi ma bskyed pa'i nus pa so sor nges pa yin te/ rnam shes yul don gzhan so so la chags pa yis sngon po 'dzin pa'i nus pa med pa na/ don gzhan sngon po mi 'dzin pa'i phyir zhes lha yi'o/ /

The power of earlier consciousnesses to successively produce later consciousnesses has been distinctly ascertained, so the causes for multiple to arise simultaneously are not complete. For that reason, the one single previous consciousness is the cause of one single later consciousness of a similar class. Therefore, multiple consciousnesses of a comparable class do not arise simultaneously. The power of the earlier consciousness to produce the later consciousness is distinctly ascertained, because if a consciousness lacks the ability to apprehend blue by clinging to another separate object, it does not grasp another blue object. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
de la gzhan dag na re/
Others respond:
gal te lus las cig car blo/ / skyes shing phyis ni rang rigs las/ / nges na/
115a-c And if the mind were to arise one time From the body and afterward to definitely Arise from its own kind,

zhes smos te/ gal te dang por mngal la sogs pa lus la cig car yid kyi blo skyes shing phyis ni rang gi rigs 'dra snga ma snga ma las phyi ma phyi ma skye bar nges pas blo du ma cig car du skye ba'i skyon med ce na/ bshad pa/

You might say that at first in the womb and so forth, the mental mind arises one time from the body, and afterward later ones definitely arise from earlier ones of their own kind, so multiple minds do not arise at the same time and there is no fault. To explain:
lus kyi nus pa ni/ / ci yi phyir na ldog pa yin/ /
115cd why is it that The body's capability would cease?

ces smos te/ lus kyi dngos po des ni dang por mngal la sogs par yid blo du ma cig car bskyed nus pa'i rtag pa yin pa'i phyir na/ phyis kyang yid blo du ma bskyed pa'i nus pa ni ci'i phyir na ldog par 'gyur ba yin te ma yin no/ /

Because the entity of the body is permanent and has the capacity to produce multiple simultaneous mental cognitions at first in the womb and so forth, later why is it that its capability to produce multiple mental cognitions would cease? It would not.
gnyis pa de la rtsod pa spang ba la/
d. Refuting criticism.
rtsod pa dang / lan gnyis las/
This has two topics: i. The criticism, and ii. The answer
dang po [rtsod pa] ni/
i. The criticism
gal te lus ni ldog pa na/ / rten min phyir na sems 'ba' zhig/ gnas 'gyur zhe na/
116a-c If you should say, “It is not the support, And for that reason when the body ceases The mind alone persists,”

zhes smos te/ gal te gzhan dag na re/ khyed cag gi lugs la lus sems kyi rten ma yin pas dbang po dang bcas pa'i lus ni shi ba'i gnas skabs su zhig cing ldog pa na lus sems kyi rten ma yin pa'i phyir/ shi ba'i 'og tu lus la bltos pa med par sems 'ba' zhig gnas par 'gyur ro zhe na/

Others say, “In your tradition, the body is not the mind's support, so when the body with the faculties perishes and ceases at the time of death, since it (the body) is not the support of the mind, after death, the mind alone will persist independent of the body.”
gnyis pa lan la
ii. The answer.
khams gsum la brtags te dgag/ sems phyi ma mtshams sbyor ba la rtsod pa spang / dbang po phyi ma mtshams sbyor ba'i sgrub byed dgod/ rgyu don gzhan las skye ba dgag pa'o/ /

This has four points: (1) Refuting it by analyzing the three realms, (2) Rebutting criticism about later cognitions linking rebirth, (3) Presenting the proof that later faculties link rebirth, and (4) Refuting that they are born from causes that are other objects.
dang po [khams gsum la brtags te dgag pa] ni/
(1) Refuting it by analyzing the three realms
'dod gzugs gnyis sam gzugs med gang la yin/ dang po ltar ro zhe na/ bshad pa/
Is that in the two realms of Desire and Form or in the Formless? If you say the former, to explain:
gal te de'i/ / rgyu 'jug thob phyir sems kyi rgyun/ / gnas rgyu yan lag mi 'gyur na/ /
116cd if it is from Acquiring the state of being a cause of that, 117ab The cause for the continuum of mind To stay does not become an element.

zhes smos te/ 'dod pa dang gzugs khams su skye bar 'gyur ba'i skyes bu 'chi kha ma'i sems de ni shi ba'i 'og tu lus la bltos med du gnas pa ma yin te/ gal te sems kyi rgyun lus la gnas pa'i lhan cig byed pa'i rgyur gyur pa'i sngon gyi las kyis rang 'bras lus phyi ma de'i rgyu 'jug thob pa ste lhan cig byed rkyen du 'gyur ba'i phyir/ gal te skye ba phyi ma'i lus bskyed pa'i lhan cig byed pa'i rkyen gyi yan lag tu mi 'gyur na de'i sems 'ba' zhig gnas par 'gyur te/ dper na gzugs med pa'i khams su skyes pa'i srog chags lta bu'o/ / de bas na gang gi tshe lus tha ma lus phyi ma dang nying mtshams sbyor ba'i phyir blo lhan cig byed pa'i rgyu nyid du yang 'gyur bas/ de'i tshe lhan cig byed pa yin pa'i phyir lhan cig tu gnas pa de ltar na 'gal ba med do zhes lha yi'o/ /

The mind of a dying person who will be reborn in the realms of Desire or Form does not abide independent of a body after death, because the prior karma that is the cooperating cause for the continuum of mind to stay in a body acquires the state of being a cause of its result (the next body) becoming a cooperating condition. If it does not become the element of a cooperating condition that produces the body of the next lifetime, the mind alone will persist, as for example with living beings who are born in the Formless realm. Therefore Devendrabuddhi says: When because of the last body linking rebirth to the next body, the mind becomes the cooperating cause. Since they cooperate at that time, they coexist. In this way there is no contradiction.[129]
'o na 'jig rten pha rol gyi lus kyi nyer len gang yin ce na/ bshad pa/
Well then, what is the substantial cause of the body in the next world? To explain:
tshe 'di nyid kyi skye mched lnga/ / lus gzhan bskyed pa'i rgyu nyid yin/ /
117cd The five sense bases of this lifetime are The causes that produce another body.

ces smos te/ tshe 'di nyid kyi 'chi kha'i skye mched mig sogs dbang po lnga ni lus gzhan phyi ma bskyed pa'i nyer len gyi rgyu nyid yin no/ / des na 'dod gzugs nas gzugs med du shi 'phos nas slar yang 'dod gzugs su skyes pa'i tshe sngar gyi 'dod gzugs kyi dbang po rgyu yin la/ dngos kyi nyer len ni gzugs med kyi sems la yod pa'i dbang po'i sa bon nyid yin no/ /

The five sense bases—the five faculties of the eyes and so forth—at the time of death in this lifetime are the substantial causes that produce another (the next) body.[130] Therefore, when one dies in Desire or Form and migrates to Formless and then once again takes birth in Desire or Form, the previous faculties from Desire and Form are the cause, though the actual substantial cause is the seed of the faculties present in the mind of Formless.
gnyis pa sems phyi ma mtshams sbyor ba la rtsod pa spang ba ni/
(2) Rebutting criticism about later cognitions linking rebirth
gzhan dag na re/ skyes bu 'chi kha ma'i sems de lus phyi ma'i lhan cig byed rkyen dang / de'i lus de lus phyi ma'i nyer len gyi rgyu ma yin te/ de ltar du ma dmigs pa'i phyir zhe na/ bshad pa/

Others say that a person's mind at the time of death is not the cooperating condition of the next body and his body is not the substantial cause of the next body because it is not observed to be so. To explain:
de yi yan lag dngos po dang / / rgyu nyid 'gog la mi dmigs pa/ / nges byed min par rab tu bshad/ / dbang sogs kyang ni lhag ldan yin/ /
118. In denying that things are its elements Or its causation, that they are not observed Does not bring certitude, as was explained, And faculties and such are inconclusive.

ces smos te/ skyes bu 'chi kha ma'i sems de ni skye ba phyi ma'i lus de'i lhan cig byed pa'i yan lag gi dngos po yin pa dang / de'i lus de ni skye ba phyi ma'i lus kyi nyer len gyi rgyu nyid yin pa 'gog pa la de dang der ma dmigs pa tsam rtags su bkod pa ni de ltar nges par byed pa'i rtags yang dag min par/ ma mthong phyir na med pa min/ / ces par rab tu bshad zin la/ gzhan yang skyes bu 'chi kha ma'i lus ni lus phyi ma'i nyer len ma yin te/ dbang po yin pa'i phyir dang / lag pa dang ldan pa'i phyir dang / sems ni lus phyi ma'i lhan cig byed pa'i rkyen ma yin te/ sems yin pa'i phyir zhes sogs rtags su bkod pa de dag kyang ni rtags yang dag ma yin te/ de ltar sgrub pa'i khyab pa la the tshom gyi lhag ma dang ldan pa'i gtan tshigs yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

In denying that the mind of a person at the time of death is a thing that is a cooperating element of it (the body of the next birth) or that their body is the substantial cause of the body of the next birth, merely stating as evidence that those are not observed as such is not correct evidence that would bring certitude, as was explained thoroughly in the line, “It does not not exist from not being seen.”[131] Additionally, giving reasons such as that the body of a person at death is not the substantial cause of the next body because it is a faculty or because it has hands, or that the mind is not the cooperating condition of the next body because it is mind and other such reasons are not correct reasons, because they are inconclusive reasons that leave doubt about the pervasion they should prove.
gsum pa dbang po phyi ma mtshams sbyor ba'i sgrub byed 'god pa ni/
(3) Presenting the proof that later faculties link rebirth
dbang po snga mas rang rigs la/ / nus pa dag ni mthong ba yin/ /
119ab It has been seen that earlier faculties Have the capacity for their own kind.

ces smos te/ skyes bu 'chi kha ma'i dbang po chos can/ gegs med na dbang po phyi ma bskyed rung yin te/ dbang po yin pa'i phyir/ dper na tshe 'di'i mig sogs dbang po snga mas rang gi rigs 'dra dbang po phyi ma la phan 'dogs pa'i nus pa dag ni tshad mas mthong ba bzhin du 'dir yang yin no/ /

The faculties of a person at the time of death, the subject, are able, if nothing prevents them, to produce later faculties because they are faculties. For example, just as it is it is validly seen that earlier faculties of the eye and so forth in this life have the capacities to benefit subsequent faculties of their own same kind, it is the same here as well.
de la gzhan dag na re/ dbang po rnams rang bzhin tha dad med pas dbang po snga ma dag phyi ma'i rgyu ma yin pa'i phyir/ dpe chos can la ma grub bo zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others say that the faculties do not have separate natures, so earlier faculties are not causes of later ones, and for that reason, the analogy is not established in the subject. To explain:
'gyur ba mthong phyir gzhan dang gzhan/ / skye ba dag kyang 'grub pa nyid/ /
119cd Since change is seen, it is established that The subsequent ones will arise as well.

ces smos te/ dbang po phyi ma phyi ma rnams dbang po snga ma snga ma'i dwangs pa dang rnyog pa'i rjes su 'gyur ldog byed par mthong ba'i phyir/ dbang po snga ma snga ma las phyi ma gzhan dang gzhan skye ba dag kyang tshad mas grub pa nyid yin pa'i phyir/ dpe chos can la ma grub pa ma yin no/ /

Since it is seen that later faculties change as entailed or reverse entailed by the clarity or haziness of earlier faculties, it is validly established that the subsequent faculties will arise from earlier faculties as well. Therefore, it is not so that the analogy is not established in the subject.
bzhi pa rgyu don gzhan las skye ba dgag pa ni/
(4) Refuting that they are born from causes that are other objects
gal te lus las de skye na/ /
120a If they were to arise from the body,
zhes smos te/ gal te gzhan dag na re/ tshe 'di'i mig sogs dbang po lnga po de lus las skye ba yin gyi/ rigs 'dra snga ma las skye ba ma yin no zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others say that they, the five faculties of the eye and so forth in this life, arise from the body, not from previous instances of their own kind. To explain:
snga ma bzhin du thal bar 'gyur/ /
120b The consequence would be as before.
zhes smos te/ shi ba'i lus la dbang po yod par 'gyur te/ de rgyu rtag tu nye phyir ro/ / zhes pa'i skyon snga ma bzhin du thal bar 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ /
A deceased body would also have faculties, because the consequence would be the same fault as before in the line “Because their causes always would be present.”[132]
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
sems las she na/
120c If from the mind,
zhes smos te/ da ltar gyi dbang po 'di sems las skye bas skyon med do zhe na/ bshad pa/
If you say that these present faculties arise from the mind, so there is no fault, to explain:
lus gzhan yang / / 'di nyid las ni skye bar 'gyur/ /
120cd another body Would also arise from this same.
zhes smos te/ skye ba phyi ma'i lus gzhan dbang po lnga po yang sems 'di nyid las ni skye bar 'gyur te/ skye ba 'di'i dbang po lnga po de dag sems las skye ba'i phyir ro/ /
The five faculties of another body—that of the next life—would also arise from this same mind, because the five faculties of this life arise from the mind.
des na lus sems kyi nyer len ma yin par grub bo zhes bstan pa'i phyir/
Therefore it is proven that the body is not the substantial cause of the mind. To teach this:
des na rgyu dang bral ba'i phyir/ / mtha' ma yi ni sems rnams kun/ / mtshams sbyor med pa min de'i phyir/ / de 'dra'i sgrub byed lhag ldan 'dod/ /
121. Thus it cannot be not so that since the cause Is absent, all final cognitions do not link, And for that reason we assert That proofs like that are inconclusive.

ces smos te/ lus sems kyi nyer len ma yin pa des na so skye dang / dgra bcom par 'dod pa'i skyes bu 'chi kha ma'i sems chos can/ rig pa phyi ma mtshams mi sbyor te/ mtshams sbyor ba'i rgyu dang bral ba'i phyir zhes bya ba'i gtan tshigs ma grub la/ 'chi kha'i sems yin pa'i phyir zhes bya ba de 'dra ba'i sgrub byed bkod pa ni lhag ldan gyi gtan tshigs yin par 'dod do/ / des na so skye dang dgra bcom pa tshe 'di'i mtha' ma 'chi kha ma yi ni sems rnams kun rig pa phyi ma mtshams sbyor ba med pa min pa de'i phyir 'jig rten pha rol yod par grub bo/ /

The body is not the substantial cause of the mind. Therefore in saying “All minds at the time of death of ordinary individuals and those asserted to be arhats, the subject, do not link to later awareness, because the cause of linking is absent,” the reason is not established, and we assert that proofs like that and “because it is a mind at the time of death” are inconclusive reasons. Thus, not all the final cognitions at the time of death of ordinary individuals and arhats in this life do not link to the next cognition. For that reason, the next world is proven to exist.
gnyis pa goms kyang thams cad mkhyen pa mi srid pa'i rtsod pa spang ba la/
(ii) Refuting the argument that even with cultivation, omniscience would be impossible.
rtsod pa dgod/ de dgag pa/ de'i yang nyes spong gi lan no/ /
This has three topics: A. Presenting the criticism, B. Refuting it, and C. Responding to rebuttals of that.
dang po [rtsod pa dgod pa] ni/
A. Presenting the criticism
goms pas khyad par 'gyur na yang / / mchongs dang chu yi drod bzhin du/ / rang bzhin las 'das min ce na/ /
122. If you should say, “Though there may be Distinctions due to cultivation, It cannot transcend its own nature, Like jumping or else heating water,”

zhes smos te/ gzhan dag na re/ sgrub byed thugs rje goms las te/ / zer ba mi 'thad do/ / ci'i phyir zhe na/ snying rje la sogs pa goms pas khyad par cung zad 'phel bar 'gyur na yang rang gi rang bzhin las 'das nas thams cad mkhyen pa la sogs pa'i bdag nyid du 'gyur ba min te/ dper na mchongs pa legs par goms pa'i skyes bus mchongs pa goms par byas kyang cung zad bgrod pa srid kyi/ rgyang grags dang dpag tshad la sogs par mi mchongs pa dang / chu ji ltar dros kyang de'i drod mtha' med du 'phel te 'bar ba nyid du mi 'gyur ba bzhin du'o zhe na/

Others say that it is not tenable to state, “The means is compassion. That's from cultivation.”[133] The reason is that there may be slight distinctions of improvement due to cultivating compassion and so forth, but it (compassion) cannot transcend its own nature to become the essence of omniscience and so forth. As an analogy, people who train well in jumping may well have trained in jumping, and it is possible they might go slightly further, but they cannot jump an earshot, a league, or so forth.[134] Or no matter how much one heats water, its heat does not increase infinitely and it will not catch fire.
gnyis pa de dgag pa la/
B. Refuting it.
mchongs pa dang chu'i drod mtha' med du mi 'phel ba'i rgyu mtshan/ dpe de brtse sogs la mi mtshungs pa/ brtse sogs khyad par du 'phel ba'i rgyu mtshan no/ /

This has three points: 1. The reason why jumping and the heat of water do not increase infinitely, 2. The reason those are not analogous to love and so forth, and 3. The reason love and so forth especially increase.
dang po [mchongs pa dang chu'i drod mtha' med du mi 'phel ba'i rgyu mtshan] ni/
1. The reason why jumping and the heat of water do not increase infinitely

byas te gal te slar yang ni/ / 'bad rtsol la ni bltos 'gyur ram/ / rten mi brtan pa nyid 'gyur na/ / khyad par dag ni mi 'phel na/ / rang bzhin de 'dra ma yin te/ / de la phan 'dogs nus pa rnams/ / khyad par phyi ma dag la ni/ / sgrub pa'i nus pa med phyir dang / / rtag tu rten gnas ma yin phyir/ / khyad par 'phel yang rang bzhin nyid/ / min phyir/

123. Once done, if doing it again depends On effort or if the support's not stable, Then the distinctions will not multiply. If that is so, their natures aren't like that 124. Because the abilities to benefit those Do not have the capacity to effect Later distinctions, because the support Does not persist in perpetuity, 125ab And since though they might increase, the distinctions Are not the nature.

zhes smos te/ mchongs pa la sogs pa gang dang gang goms par byas te lus kyi 'bad rtsol la gal te mi bltos na mtha' med du 'phel ba srid kyang / slar yang mchongs pa de ni lus kyi 'bad rtsol la ni bltos par 'gyur pa'am/ yang na rang gi rten lus mi brtan pa nyid du gyur na mchongs sogs de dang de goms kyang khyad par dag ni mtha' med du mi 'phel na ni brtse sogs goms pa ltar gong nas gong du 'phel ba'i rang bzhin de 'dra ba'ang ma yin te/ mchongs pa dang chu bsro ba de dag la phan 'dogs pa'i nus pa rnams ni goms zin lus la ma bltos par rtsol ba'i khyad par phyi ma dag la ni mchongs sogs mtha' med du 'phel ba sgrub pa'i nus pa med phyir dang / de gnyis ka yang goms zin lus kyi 'bad rtsol la bltos pa'i phyir dang / khyad par du mchongs pa dang drod kyi rten lus dang chu de ni rtag tu gnas pa ma yin par zad par 'gyur ba'i phyir dang / mchongs pa dang chu bsros pa las khyad par cung zad 'phel bar 'gyur na yang mtha' med du 'phel ba'i rang bzhin nyid min pa'i phyir ro/ /

If whatever one cultivates such as jumping and so forth does not depend upon physical effort, it would be possible for it to increase infinitely. However, jumping again depends on physical effort. Or if the support—the body—is not stable, though one might practice jumping and so forth, the distinctions will not multiply infinitely. If that is so, their natures are not like that of compassion and so forth, which grow stronger and stronger as one cultivates them. This is because the abilities to benefit those (jumping and heating water) do not have the capacity to effect an infinite increase in later distinctions of jumping and so forth without depending upon the body that has been trained. It is also because they both depend upon efforts of the trained body. In particular, it is because the supports for jumping and heating—the body and water—do not persist in perpetuity but instead will be depleted. It is also because although the distinctions might increase somewhat from jumping or heating water, it is not their nature to increase infinitely.
gnyis pa dpe de brtse sogs la mi mtshungs pa ni/
2. The reason those are not analogous to love and so forth
gang tshe byas gyur pa/ / yang rtsol la bltos mi 'gyur na/ / rtsol gzhan khyad par byed par 'gyur/ /
125b-d Whereas once they're made, If they do not depend on further effort, Other efforts will create distinctions.

zhes smos te/ gang gi tshe goms pa khyad par du byas zin par gyur pa slar yang 'byung bar 'gyur ba 'bad rtsol skyar ma la bltos par mi 'gyur zhing / rten brten pa zhig yin pa de'i tshe na 'bad rtsol phyi ma gzhan khyad par du byed par 'gyur la/ mchongs pa dang chu bsro ba la ni de 'dra ba med do/ /

Whereas once cultivation has made distinctions, if they do not depend upon further repeated effort to arise again and are supporter and supported, other later efforts will create distinctions, while jumping and heating water are not like that.
sems la brtse sogs goms skye ba/ / rang gi ngang gis 'jug 'gyur te/ / me la sogs pas shing dag dang / / dngul chu dang ni gser sogs bzhin/ /
126. Like fire and such with wood, like mercury, Like gold and such, compassion in the mind And so forth that arise from cultivation Naturally engage upon their own.

de'i phyir sems la brtse ba dang / dga' ba dang / btang snyoms la sogs pa shin tu goms pa'i dbang gis rang gi rigs 'dra snga ma las phyi ma gong 'phel du skye ba yin te/ goms zin nas lus kyi 'bad rtsol la mi bltos par goms pa snga ma tsam las rang gi ngang gis 'jug cing gong nas gong du 'phel bar 'gyur ba'i phyir te/ dper na shing bsreg pa'i me la sogs pas gegs byed pa med na ji srid shing dag thal bar ma gyur gyi bar du 'bad rtsol la mi bltos par phyi ma sreg par byed cing rang gi ngang gis 'jug pa dang / dngul chu dang ni rdza'i snod kha sbyar du bzhu ba'i gser dang zangs ma la sogs pa rnam par dag pa'i mtshan nyid can gyis byas pa'i yon tan de ni kha sbyar gnyis par bzhu ba la bltos pa med par rang gi ngang gis 'jug pa bzhin no zhes lha'i'o/ /

For that reason, later instances of compassion, joy, equanimity, and so forth in the mind arise stronger than previous instances of their own kind due to thorough cultivation. This is because after they have been cultivated, they naturally engage upon their own from just the previous cultivation without depending on physical effort, and they grow stronger and stronger. As an analogy, unless there is something to prevent it, fire that burns wood and such naturally engages on its own and burns further without relying on effort until the wood has been consumed. It is like mercury and gold, copper, and such that have been smelted in a closed earthen crucible: their qualities of refinement that have the character of purity do not depend upon a second smelting but naturally engage on their own. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
gsum pa brtse sogs khyad par du 'phel ba'i rgyu mtshan ni/
3. The reason love and so forth especially increase
de phyir de dag las skyes te/ / ngo bo nyid skyes yon tan yin/ / des na rtsol ba phyi ma dang / / phyi mar khyad par byed pa yin/ /
127. Therefore the quality that's born Of those arises as its nature, Thus subsequent and subsequent Efforts produce distinctions.

ces smos te/ brtse ba la sogs pa sems kyi chos ni goms zin 'bad rtsol la mi bltos shing / rten brtan pa yin pa de'i phyir rang gi rigs 'dra snga ma de dag goms pa las skyes pa yin te/ rang gi ngang gis 'jug pa'i sems kyi ngo bo nyid du skyes pa'i yon tan yin pa des na/ rtsol ba la sogs pa ni rtsol ba snga ma snga ma las phyi ma dang phyi mar khyad par du mthar phyin pa'i bar du byed pa yin no/ /

When it has been cultivated, a quality of the mind such as compassion or so forth does not depend on effort, and its support is stable. Therefore, it is born of the cultivation of those earlier instances of its own kind; it is a quality that arises as the nature of the mind and naturally engages on its own. Thus subsequent and subsequent efforts produce distinctions from earlier ones until the culmination is reached.
de dag skabs su babs pa'i bsgrub bya la sbyar ba'i dbang du byas nas/
To correlate that to the thesis in question:
gang phyir rigs mthun snga ma yi/ / sa bon las ni 'phel ba can/ / brtse ba la sogs blo de dag/ goms par gyur na gang na gnas/ /
128. Because those minds of compassion and so forth Multiply out of the preceding seeds Of instances of a homogeneous kind, If cultivated, where would they stay still?

zhes smos te/ gang gi phyir brtse ba la sogs par rigs mthun pa'i rang gi rigs 'dra snga ma'i sa bon te nyer len las ni goms shing 'phel ba can yin pa de'i phyir/ brtse ba la sogs pa goms pa'i blo de dag ni goms pa dang ma bral bar gyur cing gegs med na tshad gang na gnas te tshad med du 'phel bar 'gyur ro/ /

Because compassion and so forth are cultivated and multiply out of the preceding seeds of instances of their homogeneous kind, for that reason if those minds of compassion and so forth are not deprived of cultivation and there are no hindrances, where—at what limit—would they stay still? They would increase without any limit.
de'i phyir na mchongs pa la ni de ltar ma yin no zhes bstan pa'i phyir/
To teach that for that reason jumping is not like that:
de ltar mchongs nyid las mchongs min/ / de rgyu stobs dang 'bad rtsol dag/ nus pa nges pa nyid kyi phyir/ / mchongs pa nges pa'i bdag nyid yin/ /
129. But jumping does not come in that same way From jumping—strength and exertion are its causes. As there's a limit to their capacity, Jumping is inherently limited.

ces smos te/ brtse ba la sogs pa rigs 'dra snga ma la brten nas brtse sogs phyi ma 'byung ba de ltar mchongs pa nyid rigs 'dra snga ma las mchongs pa phyi ma mtha' med du 'phel bar skye ba min cing / mchongs pa de'i nyer len gyi rgyu skyes bu'i lus kyi stobs dang 'bad rtsol de dag kyang nus pa tshad dang ldan par nges pa nyid kyi phyir/ mchongs pa ni tshad nges pa'i bdag nyid can yin no/ /

Subsequent jumping does not arise from previous instances of its own kind— jumping itself—and increase infinitely in that same way as compassion and so forth, where the later compassion and so forth arise because of previous instances of their own kind. The substantial causes of jumping are the strength and exertion of a person's body, which have a limit to their capacity. For that reason, jumping inherently has a defined limit.
gsum pa de'i yang nyes spong gi lan dgag pa la/
C. Responding to rebuttals of that

gzhan dag na re/ lus kyi stobs dang 'bad rtsol dag la mchongs pa skye ba yin gyi/ rang gi rigs 'dra snga ma las skye ba ma yin na goms pa'i dus su skyes bus ji tsam mchongs pa de ltar du sngar ma goms pa'i dus su yang ci'i phyir mi 'gyur te/ stobs ni sngon nyid du yang yod pa'i phyir ro zhe na/

Others say that if jumping arises from physical strength and exertion instead of previous instances of its own kind, why wouldn't a person jump as far at the earlier time when they have not trained as at the later time when they have trained, because they also had the strength earlier?
de'i yang lan bstan pa'i phyir/
To respond to this:
de ni dang po byis bzhin du/ / mchongs min lus mi mthun pa'i phyir/ / rtsol bas rim gyis mi mthun pa/ / bsal na rang stobs nyid du gnas/ /
130. At first they do not jump as later since The body has contrary qualities. Once effort gradually eliminates Contrarieties, they stay within their strength.

zhes smos te/ mchongs pa sbyong ba'i skyes bu de ni dang po nyid nas phyis mchongs pa 'byongs pa'i gnas skabs bzhin du mchongs pa min pa ni bad kan la sogs pas lus yang ba dang mi mthun par lci bar byas pa'i phyir/ phyis kyang mchongs sbyong ba'i rtsol bas rim gyis lus kyi mi mthun pa bad kan la sogs pa bsal nas lus lci ba med pa na/ lus rang nyid la stobs ci tsam yod pa de tsam nyid du bgrod cing gnas pa yin la/ de bas lhag par mchongs pa ni ma yin no zhes lha rgyan gnyis ka'i'o/ /

At the very first, people who train in jumping do not jump as they do later during the period when they have trained in jumping, because phlegm and so forth have made the body heavy, which is contrary to lightness. Later, the effort of training in jumping gradually eliminates the contrary bodily qualities of phlegm and so forth. Once the body has no heaviness, they can jump as far as they have the strength to and stay within that, but they cannot jump any further. This is according to both Devendrabuddhi and Prajñākaragupta.
gzhan dag na re/ brtse sogs goms pa'i dbang gis mtha' med du 'phel ba yin na/ skyes bu thams cad la brtse ba la sogs pa yod par 'gyur ro zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others say that if compassion and so forth were to increase infinitely by force of cultivation, all beings would have compassion and so forth. To explain:

brtse rang sa bon las byung ba/ / gal te rang sa bon rgyu can/ / mi mthun phyogs kyis gnod med na/ / sems la de bdag nyid du 'gyur/ / 'di ltar goms pa snga ma dang / / snga ma'i sems chos brtse ba dang / / chags bral blo sogs gzhan dag gi/ gsal ba yi ni rtsa ba yin/ /

131. Compassion rises out of its own seeds. If not impeded by contrary factors Originating from seeds of their own, The mind will become that in character. 132. And thus the previous cultivation is The root of the acuity of further Qualities of mind such as compassion, Detachment, intelligence, et cetera.

ces smos te/ brtse ba la sogs pa rang gi rigs 'dra snga ma'i sa bon las byung ba can goms pa'i dbang gis mtha' med du 'phel ba yin kyang / skyes bu thams cad la brtse ba sogs mtha' med du 'phel bas ma khyab ste/ mthun rkyen rgyun chags su goms pa dang bral ba dang / 'gal rkyen mi mthun pa'i phyogs zhe sdang sogs kyis gnod pa srid la/ gal te rang gi sa bon tshul min yid byed sogs rgyur yod pa can gyi mi mthun pa'i phyogs zhe sdang sogs kyis gnod pa med cing / mthun rkyen goms pa dang ma bral bar gyur na sems la brtse ba la sogs pa de'i bdag nyid du 'gyur ba'i phyir te/ 'di ltar brtse ba la sogs pa goms pa snga ma dang snga ma'i sems kyi chos brtse ba chen po dang / chags pa dang bral ba dang / chos rab tu rnam 'byed kyi blo dang / gzhan yang yid kyi yon tan dga' ba dang / btang snyoms la sogs pa gzhan phyi ma phyi ma dag gi khyad par gsal zhing je gsal du 'gyur ba yi ni rtsa ba'am rgyu yin pa'i phyir ro/ / goms pa ni gsal ba 'ba' zhig bsgrub par bya ba yin gyi/ skye ba'i rgyu ma yin no zhes lha rgyan gnyis ka'i'o/ / des na skyes bu rnams la thog ma med pa nas brtse ba la sogs pa yod kyang goms par byed pa med pas mtha' med du 'phel bar ma nus pa yin no/ /

Compassion and so forth, which arise out of their own seeds—previous instances of their own kind—can increase without limit through power of cultivation. However, it is not pervasively so that compassion and so forth increase limitlessly in all sentient beings. It is possible that the favorable condition—continual cultivation—be absent and that the impediments—the contrary factors of hatred and so forth—would prevent it. If there is no impediment by the contrary factors of hatred and so forth, which originate from their own seeds (inappropriate attention and so forth), and the favorable condition of cultivation is not lacking, the mind will become that (compassion and so forth) in character. Thus the previous cultivation of compassion and so forth is the root or cause for the further later distinctions of the qualities of mind— great compassion, detachment, the intelligence that discerns phenomena, and additionally other mental qualities such joy, equanimity, et cetera—to grow more acute and clearer. Cultivation creates only the clarity; it is not the cause of their arising. This is according to both Devendrabuddhi and Prajñākaragupta. Therefore, beings have had compassion and so forth since beginningless time, but they have not cultivated it and thus have not been able to increase it limitlessly.
des na mthun rkyen goms pa dgos par bstan pa'i phyir/
To teach that therefore it is necessary to cultivate the favorable conditions:
goms las brtse ba'i bdag nyid de/ / chags bral chags dang yid log bzhin/ /
133ab A compassionate nature is from cultivation As with detachment, desire, and disgust.

zhes smos te/ de ltar ji skad bshad pa'i brtse ba la sogs pa goms pa las sems can shin tu sdug bsngal ba las yongs su skyob par bzhed pa'i brtse ba chen po'i bdag nyid du 'gyur ba yin te/ dper na sems grol ba thob pa na 'dod chags dang bral ba thob pa dang / 'dod chags la shin tu goms pa can gyi skyes bu 'dod chags la rang gi ngang gis 'jug pa dang / mi gtsang ba la smod pa'i skyes bu goms pa'i dbang gis mi gtsang ba la yid log pa thob pa bzhin no/ /

Thus as explained, it is from cultivating compassion and so forth that one's nature becomes the great compassion that wishes to fully protect sentient beings from terrible suffering. As analogies, when the mind achieves liberation, one achieves detachment; persons who are thoroughly habituated to desire naturally engage in desire; and individuals who despise the unclean achieve disgust for filth by force of habituation.
gnyis pa sbyor ba phun tshogs ston pa bshad pa la/
ii. The explanation of the teacher, the perfect training.
brtse ba las ston pa byung ba'i tshul/ de las byung ba'i ston pa dngos bshad pa/ de nyid la ston par 'dogs pa'i rgyu mtshan bshad pa'o/ /

This has three topics: (1) How the teacher arises from compassion, (2) The actual explanation of the teacher, which arises from compassion, and (3) The explanation of why this is called the “teacher.”
dang po [brtse ba las ston pa byung ba'i tshul] ni/
(1) How the teacher arises from compassion
brtse ldan sdug bsngal gzhom pa'i phyir/ / thabs rnams la ni mngon sbyor mdzad/ / thabs byung de rgyu lkog gyur pa/ / de 'chad pa ni dka' ba yin/ /
133cd To drive away suffering, the compassionate Apply themselves to training in the methods.[135] 134ab If what is born from method and its cause Are hidden, it is difficult to explain it.

ces smos te/ rgyu'i gnas skabs nas yod pa'i ngang tshul can gyi brtse ba dang ldan pa'i byang chub sems dpa' ni sems can gzhan gyi sdug bsngal nye bar zhi ba don du gnyer ba can yin pas gzhan gyi sdug bsngal gzhom pa'i phyir du sdug bsngal rab tu zhi ba'i thabs bden pa bzhi po rnams rtogs pa la ni mngon sum du sbyor ba la goms par mdzad pa yin te/ rang nyid sdug bsngal zhi ba dang rjes su mthun pa'i thabs de gzhan la phyin ci ma log par ston par bzhed pa'i phyir ro/ / khyab pa ma nges pa ma yin te/ gzhan gyi don la 'jug pa'i skyes bu la thabs las byung ba 'gog pa'i bden pa dang / de'i rgyu thabs lam gyi bden pa de dag ni lkog tu gyur pa las rang gi mngon sum du ma byas na gdul bya gzhan la lam de 'chad pa ni dka' bar gnas pa yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

Bodhisattvas, who have a compassionate character that has been naturally present since the causal phase, seek to pacify the suffering of other sentient beings. Thus to drive away others' suffering, they apply themselves to cultivating the training in the method to completely pacify suffering, directly realizing the four truths. This is because they wish to unerringly teach those methods that are congruent with the pacification of their own suffering to others. The pervasion is not indeterminate, because for people who engage in the benefit of others, if that which is born from the method (the truth of cessation) and its cause (the methods of the truth of the path) are hidden and not made manifest to oneself, it would remain difficult to explain it (the path) to other students.
gnyis pa de las byung ba'i ston pa dngos bshad pa la/
(2) The actual explanation of the teacher, which arises from compassion.
bden bzhi bsgom pa'i tshul/ goms pa las gsal snang 'byung ba'i tshul lo/ /
This has two points: (a) The manner of meditating on the four truths, and (b) The manner in which clear appearances arise from cultivation of that.
dang po [bden bzhi bsgom pa'i tshul] ni/
(a) The manner of meditating on the four truths

lung dang rigs pas rnam dpyod pa/ / sdug bsngal nyid kyi khyad par gyis/ / sdug bsngal rgyu dang de mi rtag/ la sogs rang bzhin rtog par mdzad/ / gang phyir de ltar rgyu gnas pa/ / 'bras log gzigs pa med phyir ro/ /

134cd They investigate through scripture and through logic And analyze the cause of suffering, 135. Its nature of impermanence and so forth By way of the attributes of suffering, Because they see that if the cause remains, There's no elimination of the result.
