zhes smos te/ bden pa bzhi rtogs pa'i thabs ni lung gi rjes su 'brang ba'i thos pa las byung ba'i shes rab dang / rigs pa'i rjes su 'brang ba bsam pa las byung ba'i shes rab dang / de gnyis ka'i rjes su 'brang ba sgom pa las byung ba'i shes rab kyis so sor rtog cing rnam par dpyod pa'i sgo nas yul sdug bsngal de nyid kyi khyad par gyi chos res 'ga' skye ba dang 'phel 'grib byed pa la sogs pa mi rtag pa nyid du khong du chud par bya ba'i phyir sdug bsngal de la rgyu yod dam med ces pa dang / rgyu yod na de rtag pa'am/ 'on te mi rtag pa dang / rgyu de'i mtshan nyid dang 'phel ba'i rgyu la sogs pa'i rang bzhin ni gang yin ces pa'i sgo nas rtog par mdzad rigs te/ gang gi phyir na sdug bsngal de'i rgyu kun 'byung bden pa ni mi 'jig pa de ltar gnas pa yin na 'bras bu sdug bsngal log pa'i thabs gzigs shing mkhyen pa med pa'i phyir ro/ /

The method to realize the four truths is to examine and investigate through the intelligence born of listening that follows upon scripture, the intelligence of contemplation that follows upon logic, and the intelligence born of meditation that follows upon both. With this, one analyzes whether that suffering has a cause or not; if there is a cause, what its nature is—whether it is permanent or impermanent; what the cause's characteristics are; what makes it increase; and so forth in order to comprehend that the attributes of that suffering itself are impermanent—occasionally arising, increasing, waning and so forth. This is logical because they see and know that if the cause—the truth of origin—remains in this way without being destroyed, there is no method to eliminate the result, suffering.
des na sdug bsngal gyi rgyu spang bar 'dod pas de'i gnyen po lam bsgom par rigs so zhes bstan pa'i phyir/
Therefore, in order to teach that it is logical for those who wish to eliminate the cause of suffering to meditate on its antidote, the path:
de rgyu gzhom phyir de yi ni/ / mi mthun phyogs la brtag par mdzad/ / rgyu yi ngo bo rtogs pa'i phyir/ / de mi mthun phyogs kyang nges 'gyur/ /
136. In order to eliminate its cause, They examine what is contrary to it. From realizing the essence of the cause, Its contrary is recognized as well.

zhes smos te/ sdug bsngal gyi rgyu spong ba'i thabs la goms par mdzad pa'i skyes bu ni sdug bsngal de'i rgyu kun 'byung gzhom pa'i phyir du kun 'byung de yi ni mi mthun pa'i phyogs lam gyi bden pa la brtag par mdzad nas sdug bsngal gyi rgyu kun 'byung de'i mi mthun phyogs su gyur pa'i gnyen po lam gyi bden pa de dag kyang nges par 'gyur te/ sdug bsngal gyi rgyu'i ngo bo kun 'byung legs par rtogs pa'i phyir ro/ / dper na nad kyi rgyu'i ngo bo rtogs na de'i gnyen po sman shes par 'gyur ba bzhin no/ /

In order to eliminate its (suffering's) cause, people who meditate on the methods to abandon the origin—the cause of suffering—examine the truth of the path that is contrary to it (the origin). Then the antidotes—the truth of the path—that are the contrary of the origin that is the cause of suffering will be recognized as well, because they have fully realized the essence of the origin, the cause of suffering. It is just as how one who realizes the essence of an illness' cause will also know the medicine that is its remedy.
skye ba'i mtshan nyid can gyi sdug bsngal gyi rgyu dang / de dang 'gal ba'i gnyen po'i chos gang zhe na/ bshad pa/
If you ask what are the causes of the suffering whose characteristic is birth and what dharma is the antidote that is exclusive of that, to explain:
bdag dang bdag gir 'dzin byas pa/ / 'dus byas spyod yul can chags ni/ / rgyu yin de yi gnod byed ni/ / bdag med mthong ba 'gal ba yin/ /
137. The cause is the attachment formed by clinging To me and mine whose sphere of experience Is the composite. What opposes that Is seeing selflessness, exclusive of it.

ces smos te/ sdug bsngal gyi rgyu ni bdag dang bdag gi bar mngon par zhen cing 'dzin par byas pas 'dus byas shing / bdag dang bdag gi ba'i spyod yul can gyi sred pas chags pa ni sdug bsngal gyi rgyu yin la/ bdag dang bdag gir 'dzin pa de'i gnod byed kyi gnyen po ni bdag med pa mngon sum du mthong ba'i shes rab de nyid yin te/ de dang dmigs pa dang rnam pa 'gal bas sun 'byin nus yin pa'i phyir/

The cause of suffering is formed by clinging and being attached to me and mine; fixation through craving whose sphere of experience is me and mine is the cause of suffering. The antidote which opposes that clinging to me and mine is the intelligence of directly seeing selflessness, because its focus and aspects are exclusive of it and thus can eliminate it.
gnyis pa de goms pa las gsal snang 'byung ba'i tshul ni/
(b) The manner in which clear appearances arise from cultivation of that
rnam pa du mar thabs mang po/ / yun ring dus su goms pa las/ / de la skyon dang yon tan dag/ rab tu gsal ba nyid du 'gyur/ /
138a-d From a long time of cultivation In many ways with many methods, The faults and qualities in them Have become evident,

zhes smos te/ skyes bu chen po dag gis rnam pa du mar stong pa nyid kyi rnam pa can gyi bdag med par rtogs pa'i shes rab la sogs rnam pa sna tshogs pa'i thabs mang po yun ring po'i dus bskal pa la sogs pa rnams su goms par mdzad pa las/ goms pa po de la skyon spang bya dang yon tan gnyen po dag rab tu gsal ba nyid du 'gyur ro/ /

Great beings cultivate for a long time—aeons and so forth—and in many ways the intelligence that realizes selflessness and has the aspect of emptiness with many various methods. From this, the faults to be eliminated and the qualities that are antidotes will become evident to them, the meditators.[136]
de bas na thub pa chen po dang / nyan rang gnyis gzhan don rgya che chung gi khyad par ni rgyu'i bag chags spangs pa dang / ma spangs pa las yin no zhes bstan pa'i phyir/

Therefore the distinction between the great sages and the listeners and self-buddhas in the extent of their benefit to others is from whether they have eliminated the imprints of the cause or not. To teach this:
des na thugs kyang gsal ba'i phyir/ / rgyu yi bag chags spangs pa yin/ / thub chen gzhan don 'jug can gyi/ / bse ru la sogs khyad 'di yin/ /
138d and thus 139. Because their minds are clear, they have abandoned The cause's imprints. This is the distinction Between great sages, who work for others' weal, And the rhinoceroses and so forth.

ces smos te/ yun ring po nas thabs mang po la goms par mdzad pa'i dbang las spang gnyen la blang dor mdzad pa des na/ thub pa chen po ni thabs mang po goms pa'i dbang gis blang dor gyi gnas la thugs kyang shin tu gsal ba'i phyir na/ sdug bsngal gyi rgyu kun 'byung de'i bag chags dang bcas pa spangs pa yin pas/ thub pa chen po ni rgyu'i dus su bsam sbyor phun sum tshogs pa sngon du song ba'i sgo nas gzhan don rgya chen po la 'jug pa dang bag chags spangs pa can yin gyi/ bse ru lta bu'i rang sangs rgyas dang / nyan thos dgra bcom pa la sogs pa ni de ltar ma yin pas khyad par ni 'di yin no/ /

From the power of meditating for a long time on many methods, they have taken up the antidotes and given up the discards. Thus by force of cultivating many methods, it is very clear in their (the great sages') minds what is to be done and what is to be given up. Because of this, they have abandoned the origin, the cause of suffering, along with its imprints. Thus the great sages are preceded by the excellent intent and training during the phase of the cause, and in this way they work for the vast weal of others and have abandoned the imprints. The rhinoceros-like self-buddhas,[137] listener arhats, and so forth, are not like that, so this is the distinction between them.
gsum pa de nyid la ston par 'dogs pa'i rgyu mtshan bshad pa ni/
(3) The explanation of why this is called the “teacher”
de don phyir na thabs goms pa/ / de nyid ston pa yin par 'dod/ / grub las dang po 'byung ba'i phyir/ / gnyis po 'di ni rgyu ru bshad/ /
140. Because it has that purpose, cultivating The means itself is said to be the teacher. They happen first, before accomplishment, And so the two are described as the cause.

ces smos te/ 'bras bu'i gnas skabs kyi ston pa phun sum tshogs pa'i rgyu yin pa de'i don gyi phyir na/ sbyor ba phun sum tshogs pa'i gnas skabs kyi thabs goms pa de nyid kun las btus kyi phyag 'tshal ba'i tshigs su bcad par bshad pa'i ston pa yin par 'dod de/ rgyu la 'bras bu'i ming gis btags pa'i phyir ro/ / btags pa'i dgos pa ni sems can rnams la ston par rung ba'i thabs thob pa nyid kyi khyad par can gyi ming gis bstan pa yin no/ / de'i phyir bde bar gshegs pa grub pa de las dang por bsam pa phun tshogs 'gro la phan bzhed pa dang / sbyor ba phun tshogs ston pa sngon du song ba las 'bras bu bde bar gshegs pa 'byung ba'i phyir na/ bsam sbyor phun sum tshogs pa gnyis po 'di ni bde bar gshegs pa dang skyob pa'i rgyu ru bshad pa yin te/ ston pa dngos ni bde bar gshegs pa nyid kyi rgyu ma yin no/ / de'i phyir thabs goms pa nyid ston pa yin gyi/ gzhan ni ma yin no zhes lha rgyan gnyis ka'i'o/ / sbyor ba phun sum tshogs pa'i spyi'i don ni 'og tu bden pa bzhi'i skabs su rgya cher 'chad par 'gyur bas der shes par bya'o/ /

Because it has that purpose of being the cause of the perfect teacher in the phase of the result, cultivating the means during the phase of the perfect training itself is said to be the teacher in the Compendium's verse of homage, because the name of the result is given to the cause. The reason for this designation is that the distinctive name of the achievement itself indicates the methods for becoming able to teach sentient beings. For that reason, they (the perfect intent of the wish to benefit beings and the perfect training of the teacher) happen first, before the accomplishment of sugatahood, preceding the result of the sugata which arises from them, and so the two (the perfect intent and training) are described as the cause of the sugata and protector. The actual teacher is not the cause of sugatahood. For that reason, cultivating the methods itself, not anything else, is the teacher. This is according to both Deven-drabuddhi and Prajñākaragupta. The general discussion of the perfect training will be explained in detail below in the section on the four truths, so it should be known from that.
gnyis pa 'bras bu phun tshogs tshad ma rgyas par bshad pa la/
b. The detailed explanation of the perfect result.
rang don phun tshogs bde gshegs bshad pa/ gzhan don phun tshogs skyob pa bshad pa'o/ /
This has two topics: i. The explanation of the perfect benefit for oneself, the sugata, and ii. The explanation of the perfect benefit for others, the protector.
dang po [rang don phun tshogs bde gshegs bshad pa] la/
i. The explanation of the perfect benefit for oneself, the sugata.
spyi'i don dang / tshig gi don gnyis las/
This has two topics: (1) General discussion, and (2) The meaning of the text.
dang po [spyi'i don] la/
(1) General discussion.
de bzhin gshegs pa'i spangs pa dang / zhar las byung ba nyan rang dgra bcom pa'i spangs pa'o/ /
This has two points: (a) What the sugata has abandoned, and (b) Tangentially, what the listener and self-buddha arhats have abandoned.
dang po [de bzhin gshegs pa'i spangs pa] ni/
(a) What the sugata has abandoned

sangs rgyas kyi 'gog pa'i bden pa ste/ bdag med pa rnam pa gnyis rtogs pa'i lam gyi bral 'bras mthar thug yin la/ de'ang khyad par gsum gyis 'jig rten pa dang / slob pa dang / mi slob pa'i chags bral las khyad par du 'phags pa yin no/ / khyad par gsum po gang zhe na/ legs par spangs pa dang / slar mi ldog par spangs pa dang / ma lus par spangs pa'o/ / ci'i phyir legs par spangs pa yin ce na/ dam pa rnams kyis bsngags par 'os pa yin pa'i phyir legs par spangs pa'o/ / de yang 'di ltar yang srid pa'i sdug bsngal 'byung ba'i rten mi byed par spangs pa'i phyir te/ gnyen po bdag med rtogs pa'i shes rab kyis byas pa'i phyir dang / de ni srid pa'i gnyen po yin pa'i phyir ro/ / de ltar yang rgyas pa las/ rgyu spangs yon tan gsum bde gshegs/ / nyid yin sdug bsngal rten min phyir/ / legs yin de ni bdag med pa/ / mthong ba'am sbyor ba las yin no/ / zhes gsungs so/ / 'jig rten pa'i lam gyis 'og sa la 'dod chags dang bral ba'i 'jig rten pa'i spangs pa de ni legs par spangs pa ma yin te/ yang srid pa'i sdug bsngal 'byung ba'i rten byed pas dam pa rnams kyis bsngags par 'os pa'i spangs pa ma yin pa'i phyir ro/ / ci'i phyir sdug bsngal gyi rten yin ce na/ spangs pa de lta bu ni sa gong 'og la zhi rags su lta ba'i lam gyi 'bras bu yin cing / de lta bu'i lam yang gzugs dang gzugs med pa'i sa gong ma dag tu skye ba'i rgyu yin pa'i phyir dang / sa de dag kyang 'gyur ba'i sdug bsngal dang 'du byed kyi sdug bsngal ci rigs pa dang ldan pa'i phyir te/ ji skad du/ sdug bsngal nyid gsum ldan pa'i phyir/ / ci rigs ma lus sdug bsngal lo/ / zhes gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ / ci'i phyir slar mi ldog pa spangs pa yin ce na/ slar ldog pa'i rgyu bdag lta'i sa bon ma lus par spangs pa'i phyir te/ ji skad du/ bdag lta'i sa bon spangs pa'i phyir/ / slar mi gshegs pa nyid yin no/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

The buddhas' truth of cessation is the ultimate result of removal[138] through the path of realizing the twofold selflessness. It is superior to the detachment of the worldly, the learners, and the nonlearners[139] through three distinctions. What are the three distinctions? you ask. Excellent abandonment, irreversible abandonment, and complete abandonment. Why is it excellent abandonment? you ask. Because it is worthy of praise by the exalted, it is excellent abandonment. This is because it is abandonment that does not provide the support for suffering to arise in another existence because it is done through the antidote, the intelligence that realizes selflessness, and because that is the antidote for existence. The Commentary says: Three qualities of abandoning the cause Are sugatahood. As it is not a support For suffering, it is excellent. It comes From seeing selflessness and from the training.[140] The worldly abandonment that is detachment from lower levels through worldly paths is not excellent abandonment, because it functions as a support for the arising of suffering in other existences and thus is not abandonment worthy of praise by the exalted. Why is it the support for suffering? you ask. It is because such an abandonment is the result of a path that views higher levels as peaceful and lower levels as coarse, and such paths are the cause for birth in the higher levels of Form and Formless. Those levels as well variously have the suffering of change and the suffering of formation. As it is said: ... Are suffering without exception Because they have three sufferings.[141] Why is it irreversible abandonment? you ask. It is because it has abandoned the cause of reversal, all of the seeds of the view of self. As it is said: He has abandoned the seeds of the self view, And thus he has gone irreversibly.[142]

phyi rol pa'i rnal 'byor pa dang phyir 'ong la sogs pa 'phags pa slob pa dag gis ni rang gi spang bya slar mi ldog par spangs pa ma yin te/ bdag tu lta ba'i sa bon ma bcom pas rang gi spangs pa las slar nyams pa srid pa'i phyir ro/ / de'ang 'di ltar/ sa de dang de dag tu skye ba'i rgyu nyon mongs pa re zhig spangs kyang slar yang ci zhig ltar sa de dag tu skye ba len pa dang / nyon mongs pa'i rnam pa 'ga' zhig spangs kyang de dag slar yang rgyud la 'byung ba ni spangs pa slar ldog pa zhes bya ba yin te/ ji skad du/ skye dang skyon ni kun 'byung dag/ slar yang ldog ces bshad pa yin/ / ces gsungs so/ / de'i phyir phyi rol pa'i rnal 'byor pa dag gi spangs pa slar ldog pa yin te/ de dag gis srid rtse'i bar gyi ting nge 'dzin thob ste/ ci yang med pa'i skye mched man chad kyi nyon mongs re zhig spangs kyang rkyen gyi stobs kyis ting nge 'dzin de dag las nyams pa'am/ re zhig ma nyams kyang mi g.yo ba'i las de'i 'phen pa zad pa na nam mkhar 'phangs pa'i mda' shugs zad pa ltar mnar med pa'i bar gyi 'gro ba dag tu slar yang skye ba len par 'gyur te/ bdag med rtogs pa'i shes rab dang bral bas bdag tu lta ba mngon gyur tsam yang ma spangs pa'i phyir ro/ / ji skad du/ khyad par 'phags bstod las/ khyod kyi bstan las phyir phyogs pa'i/ / skye bo ma rig gis ldongs pa/ / srid rtse'i bar du song nas kyang / / sdug bsngal yang 'byung srid pa sgrub/ / ces gsungs so/ /

Non-Buddhist yogis and noble learners such as once-returners do not have irreversible abandonment of their discards because they have not destroyed the seeds of the view of the self, so it is possible for them to regress from their abandonment. It is thus: though they may have temporarily abandoned the afflictions which cause rebirth on those levels, they will once again in some way take birth on those levels. Though they have abandoned some aspects of the afflicted, those will re-arise in their beings. Such is called reversible abandonment. As it is said: Reversibility is said to be The rearising of the faults and birth.[143] For that reason, non-Buddhist yogis' abandonment is reversible. They achieve the samadhis up through the Peak of Existence and temporarily abandon the afflictions up through the sense base of Nothingness, but by power of conditions, they either regress from those samadhis or, even if they do not regress for a time, the propulsion of that unmoving karma is exhausted. Then, just like an arrow shot into the sky whose momentum is exhausted, they will once again take rebirth in the migrations down to the Incessant Hell. This is because they lack the realization of selflessness, so they have not even abandoned the manifest view of the self. As it is said in In Praise of Superiority: Those people blinded by ignorance Who turn away from your Dharma May go up to the Peak of Existence, But suffering recurs; existence is created.[144]

slob pa phyir 'ong dang phyir mi 'ong dag gi spangs pa yang slar ldog par 'gyur te/ bdag lta lhan skyes ma spangs pas de la brten nas rang gis spangs pa'i nyon mongs pa skyes te 'bras bu las nyams pa srid pa'i phyir ro/ / rgyun du zhugs pa'i 'bras bu las nyams pa med de/ de ni mthong spang spangs pas rab tu phye ba yin la/ mthong spang ma lus pa bdag lta kun btags kyi rtsa ba can yin pas mthong lam thob pa na de drungs phyung ba'i phyir ro/ /

The abandonment of learner once-returners and nonreturners is also reversible, because they have not abandoned the instinctive view of the self,[145] so based on that, it is possible that the afflictions they have abandoned will arise again and they will regress from the result. There is no regression from the result of the stream-enterer, because that is distinguished by the abandonment of the discards of seeing, and all the discards of seeing are rooted in the imaginary view of the self[46] and thus eradicated when the path of seeing is achieved.

bye brag tu smra ba rnams dgra bcom pa'i 'bras bu las kyang nyams par 'dod pa ni mi 'thad de/ de ltar na thar pa la yid brtan du mi rung bar 'gyur zhing / dgra bcom pa la bdag tu lta ba med pas nyon mongs pa skye ba'i rgyu med pa'i phyir dang / nyon mongs pa ma skyes par dgra bcom pa'i 'bras bu las nyams par mi rung ba'i phyir ro/ /

The position of the Great Exposition that there is also regression from the result of arhat as well is not tenable, because if that were so, their minds would not be able to be stable toward liberation, and since the arhats have no view of the self, there is no cause for the afflictions to arise. It is illogical to regress from the result of arhat without the afflictions arising.

ci'i phyir ma lus par spangs pa yin ce na/ bskal pa dpag tu med par lam goms par byas pas spang gnyen gyi skyon yon la thugs gsal ba rab kyi mthar phyin pas sgo gsum gyi gnas ngan len ma lus par spangs pa'i phyir te/ ji skad du/ rnam pa du mar thabs mang po/ / yun ring dus su goms pa las/ / de la skyon dang yon tan dag/ rab tu gsal ba nyid du 'gyur/ / zhes dang / goms phyir ma lus spangs pa nyid/ / ces gsungs so/ / ji skad du/ mdzod las/ myur ba srid pa gsum gyi mthar/ / zhes dang / bse ru bskal pa brgya yi rgyus/ / zhes gsungs pa ltar/ nyan rang dag gis tshe gsum dang bskal pa brgya las lhag par lam sgom par mi byed pa'i phyir/ de dag la spang gnyen gyi skyon yon phra zhing phra ba la blo mi gsal bas rang stobs kyis gzhan la ye shes phyin ci ma log par ston par mi nus te/ ji skad du/ nyon mongs med dang nad med dang / / lam bshad mi gsal nyid lus yin/ / ces gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ /

Why is it complete abandonment? you ask. From cultivating the path for innumerable aeons, there is the perfect culmination of the clarity of the mind toward faults and qualities of the discards and antidotes. Thus all of the negativities of the three gates without exception have been abandoned. As it is said: From a long time of cultivation In many ways with many methods, The faults and qualities in them Have become evident...[147] And: All are abandoned through the cultivation.[148] According to the Treasury, “The swiftest in three lives are freed”[149] and “Following / One hundred aeons, a rhino appears.”[150] As these say, the listeners and self-buddhas do not meditate for more than three lifetimes or one hundred aeons. Thus their minds are not clear about the subtlest of subtle faults of the discards or the subtlest of subtle qualities of the antidotes. Therefore they are on their own unable to unerringly teach wisdom to others. As is said: Though free of the afflictions and disease... ... unclarity in teaching the path remains.[151]
gnyis pa zhar byung nyan rang gi dgra bcom pa'i spangs pa ni/
(b) Tangentially, what the listener and self-buddha arhats have abandoned

'jig rten las 'das pa'i shes rab kyis nyon mongs pa'i sa bon bcom pa'i spangs pa yin la/ de'ang phung po lhag ma dang bcas pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa dang / lhag ma med pa'i mya ngan las 'das pa rnam pa gnyis so/ / dang po ni/ nyon mongs pa'i kun 'byung tsam gnyen pos kun tu bcom pas rab tu phye ba'i so sor brtags pa'i 'gog pa'o/ / gnyis pa ni/ zag bcas ma lus pa 'gags pas rab tu phye ba'i so sor brtags pa'i 'gog pa'o/ / de la rdo rje lta bu'i ting nge 'dzin gyis nyon mongs pa'i kun 'byung ma lus pa slar mi skye ba'i tshul gyis spong la/ de las gzhan pa'i zag pa dang bcas pa'i chos ma lus pa ni 'dun pa'i 'dod chags dang bral ba'i tshul gyis spong gi/ slar mi 'byung ba'i tshul gyis ni ma yin te/ dgra bcom pa rnams la ji srid sku tshe'i 'du byed ma dor ba de srid du sdug bsngal gyi phung po rjes su 'brel ba'i phyir ro/ / gang gi tshe sku tshe'i 'du byed 'dor ba de'i tshe mig la sogs pa'i zag bcas ma lus pa bud shing zad pa'i me bzhin du rang bzhin gyis 'gags te phung po lhag ma med pa'i dbyings su yongs su mya ngan las 'das so zhes bya ba'i ming thob bo/ / de ltar na lhag bcas kyi myang 'das ni nyon mongs pa'i kun 'byung gnyen pos kun tu bcom pas rab tu phye ba yin la/ lhag med kyi myang 'das ni zag bcas ma lus pa 'gags pas rab tu phye ba yin no/ / des na nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas dag gi spangs pa ni gang zag gi bdag med pa tsam rtogs pa dang / de'i steng du gzung med tsam rtogs pa'i lam gyi bral 'bras yin no/ /

This is abandonment that eliminates the seeds of the afflicted through supramundane intelligence. There are two types: nirvana with the remainder of the aggregates and nirvana without remainder. The first is the analytic cessation[152] distinguished by the destruction of just the origin that is afflictions through the antidotes.[153] The second is analytic cessation distinguished by the cessation of everything defiled. The vajra-like samadhi abandons the entire origin that is afflictions in a manner that it will not arise again. All other defiled dharmas are abandoned by way of being free of the desire of interest, but not in the manner of not arising again, because as long the arhats have not discarded the formations of life, they are connected to the aggregates of suffering. Once they have discarded the formations of life, the eye and everything else defiled naturally cease at that time, like a fire whose fuel is exhausted, and they achieve the appellation of “passing into the complete nirvana without any remainder of the aggregates.” In this way, nirvana with remainder is distinguished by the elimination by the antidote of the origin that is afflictions, and nirvana without remainder is distinguished by the cessation of everything defiled without exception. Therefore the abandonments of the listeners and self-buddhas are the results of removal achieved by the paths that realize merely the selflessness of the individual and the nonexistence of the apprehended in addition to that.[154]
gnyis pa tshig gi don bshad pa la/
(2) The meaning of the text.
bde bar gshegs pa dngos/ de la rtsod pa spang ba'o/ /
This has two topics: (a) The actual sugata, and (b) Refuting criticism.
dang po [bde bar gshegs pa dngos] la/
(a) The actual sugata.
mdor bstan pa dang / rgyas par bshad pa'o/ /
This has two topics: (i) Overview and (ii) Detailed explanation.
dang po [mdor bstan pa] ni/
(i) Overview
rgyu spangs yon tan gsum bde gshegs/ / nyid yin/
141ab Three qualities of abandoning the cause Are sugatahood.

ces smos te/ 'dir bde bar gshegs pa ni su ga ta zhes pa'i sgra las drangs nas/ su'i sgra ni legs pa ste spangs rtogs gnyis la bshad pa las/ 'dir spangs pa'i sgo nas bshad par bya ste/ de'ang thub pa sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das ni sdug bsngal gyi rgyu bdag dang bdag gir 'dzin pa bag chags dang bcas pa legs par spangs pa dang / slar mi ldog par spangs pa dang / ma lus par spangs pa'i yon tan gsum dang ldan pa'i phyir na bde bar gshegs pa nyid yin no/ /

In the word sugata, the syllable su- means excellent, and is explained as either abandonment or realization. Of these two, here it is explained in terms of abandonment. Because the Sage, the Bhagavan Buddha, has the three qualities of excellently abandoning the cause of suffering (clinging to self and mine) along with its imprints; irreversibly abandoning it; and completely abandoning it, he is the sugata.
gnyis pa rgyas par bshad pa la/
(ii) Detailed explanation.
legs par gshegs pa/ slar mi ldog par gshegs pa/ ma lus par gshegs pa'o/ /
This has three points: A. Excellently gone, B. Irreversibly gone, and C. Completely gone.
dang po [legs par gshegs pa] ni/
A. Excellently gone
sdug bsngal rten min phyir/ / legs yin de ni bdag med pa/ / mthong ba'am sbyor ba las yin no/ /
141b-d As it is not a support For suffering, it is excellent. It comes From seeing selflessness and from the training.

zhes smos te/ 'dir bde bar gshegs pa ni sdug bsngal gyi rten du yod pa min cing / zad par spangs pa'i phyir na legs par gshegs pa yin te/ de nyid kyi phyir yang srid par skye ba len pa'i sdug bsngal gyi rten min pa de ni bdag dang bdag gir 'dzin pa'i gnyen po bdag med pa mngon sum du mthong ba'am sbyor ba goms pa las sdug bsngal spangs pa yin no/ /

Here, as the sugata is not a support for suffering and has abandoned and extinguished it, he has gone excellently. For that reason, not being a support for the suffering of taking rebirth in existence is the abandonment of suffering from directly seeing selflessness—the antidote for clinging to a self and mine—and from the training of cultivation.
gnyis pa slar mi ldog par gshegs pa ni/
B. Irreversibly gone
skye dang skyon ni kun 'byung dag/ slar yang ldog ces bshad pa yin/ / bdag lta'i sa bon spangs pa'i phyir/ / slar mi gshegs pa nyid yin no/ / de bden tha dad bdag nyid kyis/ /

142. Reversibility is said to be The rearising of the faults and birth. He has abandoned the seeds of the self view, And thus he has gone irreversibly 143a Since that and truth have separate characters.

zhes smos te/ so so skye bo la sogs pas ni bdag tu lta ba'i sa bon ma spangs pa'i phyir/ skye ba las kyi kun 'byung dang / 'dod chags sogs nyon mongs pa'i skyon gyi ni kun 'byung dag yod na spangs pa slar yang ldog ces bshad pa yin la/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyis ni bdag tu lta ba'i sa bon spangs pa'i phyir/ slar mi ldog par gshegs pa nyid yin no/ / ci'i phyir zhe na/ bdag med par rtogs pa'i ye shes de ni yul bden pa bdag med pa'i don phyin ci ma log par rtogs pas bdag tu lta ba dang dmigs rnam tha dad cing 'gal bar 'jug pa'i bdag nyid yin pa nyid kyis so/ / bdag 'dzin ni de las log pa'o/ /

Ordinary individuals and so forth have not abandoned the seeds of the view of the self. Thus if there are both birth—the origin of karma— and the origin[155] of the faults of the afflictions such as desire and so forth, that which has been abandoned is said to be reversible. The Bhagavan Buddha has abandoned the seeds of the view of the self, and thus he has gone irreversibly. Why is that? you ask. Since that wisdom that realizes selflessness realizes without error the object, the truth—the meaning of selflessness—its character is to engage aspects and focuses that are separate from and exclusive of the view of the self. Clinging to a self is the opposite of that.
gsum pa ma lus par gshegs pa ni/
C. Completely gone
lus ngag sems kyi gnas ngan len/ / nyon mongs med dang nad med dang / / lam bshad mi gsal nyid lus yin/ / goms phyir ma lus spangs pa nyid/ /
143b-d Though free of the afflictions and disease, Unskillfulness of body, speech, and mind And unclarity in teaching the path remain. 144a All are abandoned through the cultivation.

ces smos te/ 'phags pa nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas rnams kyis ni lus dang ngag dang sems kyi gnas ngan len ma spangs pas lus mchong zhing 'gro ba la sogs pa dang / ngag bre mo'i gtam brjod pa dang / sems rtag tu mnyam par ma bzhag pas lung du ma bstan pa'i sems kyi gnas skabs te spang bya'i lhag ma cung zad lus pa las yin la/ de ltar na yang gnas ngan len de nyid nyon mongs pas kun nas bslang ba ni ma yin te/ 'dod chags la sogs pa'i nyon mongs pa dang / nyon mongs pa can gyi ma rig pa med pa dang / de med pas slar yang 'khor ba'i nad dam sdug bsngal bskyed pa'i nus pa med pa dang ldan pa'i yon tan can yin no/ / de'i phyir nyon mongs pa dang / nyon mongs pa can med kyang spang bya'i lhag ma lus pa yin te/ nyon mongs can ma yin pa'i ma rig pa ma spangs pa'i dbang gis lam phyin ci ma log par bshad pa byed pa la thugs mi gsal ba nyid yin pa'i phyir te/ yun ring por rnam pa du mar lam goms par ma byas pa'i phyir ro/ / bde bar gshegs pas ni bdag med pa gnyis mngon sum du mthong ba'i lam shin tu goms pa mthar thug pa'i phyir/ spang bya'i dri ma ma lus par spangs pa nyid yin no/ /

Noble listeners and self-buddhas have not abandoned all the unskillfulness of body, speech, and mind, so they skip as they walk with their bodies, chitchat pointlessly with their speech, or do not rest their minds always in equipoise, and thus have neutral mind states. Thus there remain some remnants of the discards. Though that is so, such unskillfulness is not motivated by the afflictions because they are free of the afflictions of desire and so forth as well as afflicted ignorance. As they are free of those, they have the quality of lacking the capacity to ever again produce the disease of samsara, suffering. Therefore although they have no afflictions nor anything afflicted, some discards do remain. Because they have not abandoned unafflicted ignorance, their minds are unclear in teaching the path without error, since they have not cultivated it for a long time and in many ways. The Sugatas have come to the culmination of thorough cultivation of the path that directly sees the two selflessnesses, so they have abandoned all of the stains of the discards.
gnyis pa de la rtsod pa spang ba la/
(b) Refuting criticism.
rtsod pa dang lan gnyis las/
This has two points: (i) The criticism, and (ii) The response.
dang po [rtsod pa] ni/
(i) The criticism
kha cig smra sogs phyir na skyon/ / zad min zhes zer/
144bc Some say he has not exhausted all the faults Because he speaks and so forth.

zhes smos te/ rgyal dpog pa la sogs pa kha cig na re/ khyod kyi bcom ldan 'das ni ngag smra ba'i phyir dang / sems la sogs pa dang ldan pa'i phyir na skyon zad pa ma yin no/ / de'i phyir ma lus pa spangs par ji ltar 'gyur zhes zer ro/ /
Some Jaiminīyas and others say, “Because your Bhagavan speaks and has cognition and so forth, he has not exhausted all the faults. Therefore how can his abandonment be complete?”
gnyis pa lan ni/
(ii) The response
'di ldog la/ / the tshom za ba de phyir 'khrul/ /
144cd This sows doubt About the reversal and is thus mistaken.

ces smos te/ ngag smra ba'i rtags kyis bcom ldan 'das skyon zad pa ma yin par sgrub pa'i rtags 'di ni mthun phyogs dang 'gal ba med pa tsam gyis ldog pa'i tshul la the tshom za ba de'i phyir 'khrul ba'i rtags yin no/ /

Proving the Bhagavan has not exhausted all the faults because of the reason that he speaks sows doubt about the mode of the reversal by merely being not exclusive of the similar class. For that reason, it is thus mistaken evidence.
de bas na ma lus par spangs pa mi srid pa gang las yin zhes brtag pa'i phyir/
Thus to examine why they would say complete abandonment is impossible:
rtag nyid phyir ram thabs med phyir/ / yang na thabs ni mi shes phyir/ / skyon rnams mi zad pa nyid ces/ / bya bar yongs su rtog grang na/ /
145. They think the faults are inexhaustible Because they're permanent or else because There are no methods or else it may be Because he has no knowledge of the methods.

zhes smos te/ chags sogs skyon rnams ni rtag pa nyid yin pa'i phyir ram/ spong ba'i thabs med pa'i phyir ram/ yang na spong ba'i thabs yod kyang thabs de ni mi shes pa'i phyir/ skyon rnams mi zad pa kho na nyid yin ces bya bar yongs su rtog cing khas len pa yin grang na/ gang ltar yang rigs pa ma yin no zhes bstan pa'i phyir/

They think and assert that the faults of desire and so forth are solely inexhaustible because they (the faults) are permanent, because there are no methods to abandon them, or else because even though there may be methods to abandon them, he has no knowledge of those methods. To teach that any of these cases is illogical:
rgyu yod phyir dang rgyu yi ni/ / gnyen po goms pas zad phyir dang / / rgyu yi rang bzhin shes pa yis/ / de shes pa yang grub pa yin/ /
146. They have a cause. The cultivation of The cause's antidote extinguishes them. His understanding the nature of the cause Establishes that he knows that as well.

ces smos te/ 'dod chags la sogs pa'i skyon rnams skyed byed kyi rgyu yod pa'i phyir rtag par ma grub pa dang / spong ba'i thabs med pa yang ma yin te/ rgyu bdag dang bdag gir 'dzin pa'i skyon ni gnyen po bdag med par rtogs pa'i shes rab goms pas skyon thams cad zad par 'gyur ba'i phyir dang / bdag dang bdag gir 'dzin pa gnyis po skyon thams cad kyi rgyu'i rang bzhin du shes pa yis de spong ba'i thabs de shes par yang grub pa yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

Because they (the faults of desire and so forth) have a cause that produces them, they are proven not to be permanent It is also not so that there is no method to abandon them, since cultivating the intelligence that realizes selflessness—the antidote of the cause, which is the fault of clinging to a self and mine—extinguishes all of them (the faults). His understanding that the nature of the cause of all faults is the twofold clinging to a self and mine establishes that he knows that (the method to eliminate them) as well.
gnyis pa gzhan don phun tshogs skyob pa bshad pa ni/
ii. The explanation of the perfect benefit for others, the protector
skyob pa nyid gzigs lam gsung ba/ / 'bras med phyir na brdzun mi gsung / / thugs brtse ldan phyir brtsam kun kyang / / gzhan gyi don du sbyor phyir ro/ / de phyir tshad yin/

147. The protector teaches the path he has seen. He tells no falsehoods as that would be fruitless. Because he is compassionate, all the efforts He undertakes are for the sake of others. 148a Thus he is valid.

ces smos te/ bde bar gshegs pa sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das de ni sems can rnams 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal las skyob par mdzad pa nyid yin te/ rang nyid kyis ji ltar gzigs pa'i sdug bsngal zhi ba'i thabs sam lam de nyid phyin ci ma log par gzhan la gsung bar mdzad pa'i phyir dang / lam log par gsungs la 'bras bu'am dgos pa med pa'i phyir na sems can rnams bslu ba'i phyir du brdzun mi gsung ba yin te/ lam phyin ci log tu ston pa la rgyu med pa'i phyir te/ lam log par ston pa'i rgyu skyon dang lam gyi yul mi shes pa thams cad spangs pa'i phyir ro/ / shes su zin kyang brtse ba med pas bslu bar 'gyur ro snyam na/ de'ang bde bar gshegs pa la mi mnga' ste/ sems can la thugs brtse ba chen po dang ldan pa'i phyir dang / sngon slob pa lam gyi gnas skabs su nyon mongs pa zad pa'i thabs dang lam gyi brtsam pa kun kyang gzhan gyi don du mngon par sbyor bar mdzad pa gang yin pa de'ang sems can la phan pa'i ched du mdzad pa'i phyir ro/ / gang gi phyir rang nyid kyis gzigs shing thugs su chud pa'i thar pa'i lam de nyid phyin ci ma log par gzhan la ston par mdzad pa de'i phyir na bde bar gshegs pa ni sems can thams cad kyi skyob pa yin pas tshad ma yin par rigs pa yin no/ /

The sugata, the Bhagavan Buddha, acts as the protector for sentient beings from the suffering of samsara because he unerringly teaches others the very methods or path to pacify suffering just as he himself has seen them. As teaching a wrong path would be fruitless or pointless, he tells no falsehoods to deceive sentient beings. This is because there is no cause for him to teach the path incorrectly as he has abandoned all the faults that are causes for teaching the path wrongly and any lack of knowledge about the object of the path. You might think that he may know, but he would deceive since he has no love. The sugata does not have any deceptiveness either, because he has great compassion for all sentient beings. Previously during the period he was on the path of learning, all the efforts he undertook toward the path and the methods for extinguishing the afflictions were for the sake of others; they were done to benefit sentient beings. Because he teaches others unerringly the path to liberation he himself has seen and internalized, the sugata is the protector of all sentient beings. Thus it is logical that he is valid.
gnyis pa lugs las ldog ste bshad pa la/
B. Explaining the homage in reverse order.

gzhan don phun tshogs skyob pa bshad/ de las rang don phun tshogs bde gshegs grub/ de las sbyor ba phun tshogs ston pa grub/ de las bsam pa phun tshogs 'gro la phan bzhed grub/ des na tshad mar grub pa'o/ /

This has five topics: 1. Explaining the perfect benefit for others, the protector; 2. Establishing from that the perfect benefit for self, the sugata; 3. Establishing from that the perfect training, the teacher; 4. Establishing from that the perfect intent, the wish to benefit others; and 5. Thus establishing he is valid.
dang po [gzhan don phun tshogs skyob pa bshad pa] la/
1. Explaining the perfect benefit for others, the protector.
bden bzhi ston pas skyob par bstan pa/ bstan bya bden pa bzhi'i rang bzhin bshad pa'o/ /
The first has two topics: a. Teaching that he is the protector because he teaches the four truths, and b. Explaining the nature of the four truths that he taught.
dang po [bden bzhi ston pas skyob par bstan pa] la
a. Teaching that he is the protector because he teaches the four truths.
spyi'i don dang / tshig gi don gnyis las/
This has two points: i. General discussion, and ii. The meaning of the text.
dang po [spyi'i don] ni/
i. General discussion

gzhan don phun sum tshogs pa'i skyob pa de nyid gang zhe na/ sems can rnams la gnas skabs su mngon mtho dang / mthar thug nges legs kyi lam phyin ci ma log par ston pa'i gzugs kyi sku ste/ des bstan par bya ba'i chos ni gang zag gi bdag med pa dang chos kyi bdag med pa'o/ /

What is the protector, the perfect benefit for others? you ask. It is the form bodies that unerringly teach sentient beings the temporary paths to the higher realms and the ultimate truly excellent paths. The dharma they teach is the selflessness of the individual and the selflessness of phenomena.

gang zag gi bdag med pa ni bden pa bzhi'i yang dag pa'i rnam pa bcu drug ste/ de dag tshul bzhin du bsgoms pa las bdag tu lta ba dang / de'i rgyu can gyi nyon mongs pa ma lus pa spong bar 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / yang dag pa'i rnam pa bcu drug de dag kyang gang zhe na/ mi rtag pa dang / sdug bsngal dang / stong pa dang / bdag med pa rnams ni sdug bsngal gyi bden pa'i rnam pa'o/ / rgyu kun 'byung rab skye rkyen rnams ni kun 'byung gi bden pa'i rnam pa'o/ / 'gog pa zhi ba gya nom pa nges 'byung rnams ni 'gog pa'i bden pa'i rnam pa'o/ / lam rigs pa sgrub pa nges 'byin gyi rnam pa bzhi ni lam gyi bden pa'i rnam pa'o/ / de'ang rkyen la rag lus pa'i phyir mi rtag pa'o/ / gnod pa'i bdag nyid yin pa'i phyir sdug bsngal lo/ / bdag gi ba'i mi mthun phyogs yin pa'i phyir stong pa'o/ / bdag tu lta ba'i mi mthun phyogs yin pa'i phyir bdag med do/ / sa bon gyi tshul gyis rgyu'o/ / 'byung ba'i tshul gyis kun 'byung ba'o/ / 'brel ba'i tshul gyis rab skye'o/ / mngon par bsgrub pa'i tshul gyis rkyen no/ / phung po zhig pa'i phyir 'gog pa'o/ / me gsum zhi ba'i phyir zhi ba'o/ / 'tshe ba med pa'i phyir gya nom pa'o/ / skyon rnams dang bral ba'i phyir nges par 'byung ba'o/ / bgrod pa'i don gyis lam mo/ / rigs pa dang ldan pa'i don gyis rigs pa'o/ / yang dag par bsgrub pa'i don gyis sgrub pa'o/ / shin tu yang dag par 'das par byed pa'i don gyis nges par 'byin pa'o/ /

The selflessness of the individual is the sixteen true aspects of the four truths, because the view of the self and the afflictions it causes are abandoned in their entirety by meditating on them properly. What are the sixteen true aspects? you ask. Impermanent, suffering, empty, and selfless are the aspects of the truth of suffering. Cause, origin, production, and condition are the aspects of the truth of the origin. Cessation, peace, sublime, and emancipation are the aspects of the truth of cessation. Path, reasoning, accomplishing, and deliverance are the aspects of the truth of the path. Because of being dependent on conditions, impermanent. Because of being inherently harmful, suffering. Because of being incompatible with mine, empty. Because of being incompatible with the view of the self, selfless. In the manner of a seed, cause. In the manner of arising, origin. In the manner of consequence, production. In the manner of manifestly establishing, condition. Because the aggregates have been destroyed, cessation. Because the three fires are pacified, peace.[156] Because there is no hostility, sublime. Because of being free of all faults, emancipation. Through the meaning of going, path. Through the meaning of being logical, reasoning. Through the meaning of completely accomplishing, accomplishing. Through the meaning of making one transcend utterly and completely, deliverance.

ci'i phyir rnam pa bcu drug tu nges she na/ sgro 'dogs pa dang skur ba 'debs pa'i lta ba bcu drug gi gnyen por de bcu drug tu bstan pa yin te/ rtag pa dang / bde ba dang / bdag gi ba dang / bdag tu lta ba'i gnyen por rim pa bzhin du mi rtag sdug bsngal stong bdag med bzhi'o/ / rgyu med par smra ba dang / bdag dang gtso bo la sogs pa rgyu gcig pur lta ba dang / rang bzhin dang sgra yi tshangs pa 'gyur bar lta ba dang / dbang phyug sogs skyes bu'i blo sngon du gtong bar lta ba'i gnyen por rim pa bzhin du rgyu kun 'byung rab skye rkyen te rnam pa bzhi'o/ / thar pa med do snyam du lta ba dang / tshangs pa dang khyab 'jug la sogs pa sdug bsngal las thar ba yin no snyam du lta ba dang / bsam gtan gyi bde ba gya nom par lta ba dang / yang nas yang du lam nyams par 'gyur ba'i sgo nas thar pa gtan du ba ma yin par lta ba rnams kyi gnyen por rim pa bzhin du 'gog pa zhi ba gya nom nges 'byung gi rnam pa bzhi'o/ / lam med par lta ba dang / bdag med rtogs pa'i lam ngan par lta ba dang / bdag bsgom pa la sogs pa lam yin no snyam du lta ba dang / lam 'di slar yang mi rtag go snyam du lta ba rnams kyi gnyen por rim pa bzhin du lam rigs pa sgrub pa nges par 'byin pa'i rnam pa bzhi'o/ / ji skad du rgyas pa las/ bden pa bzhi la brten pa dang / / bde dang nga dang nga'i zhes sogs/ / yang dag min pa rnam bcu drug/ sgro btags nas ni yongs su sred/ / de nyid la ni de 'gal don/ / de nyid rnam pa rjes rtogs can/ / legs sgom yang dag lta ba yis/ / srid pa rjes 'brang bcas 'joms byed/ / ces gsungs so/ / bden pa bzhi po so so'i ngo bo ni 'og nas 'byung ba ltar gzhung so so'i skabs su shes par bya'o/ /

Why are there definitely sixteen aspects? you ask. They are taught to be sixteen as antidotes for sixteen views that are exaggerations or denials. The four of impermanent, suffering, empty, and selfless are respectively antidotes for the views of permanence, bliss, mine, and self. As antidotes for the view that proposes there are no causes, the view that there is a single cause such as the self or the primal substance,[157] the view that they are manifestation of a nature or cosmic sound,[158] and the view that the mind of Īśvara or another being precedes creation, respectively, there are the four aspects of cause, origin, production, and condition. As antidotes for the view that there is no liberation; the view of thinking that Brahma, Viṣṇu, and so forth are freed from suffering; the view of the bliss of dhyāna as sublime; and the view that liberation is not forever since one regresses repeatedly from the path, respectively, there are the four aspects of cessation, peace, sublime, and emancipation. As antidotes for the view that there is no path, the view that the path of realizing selflessness is inferior, the view that thinks that meditating on the self is the path, and the view that thinks, “This path is once again impermanent,” respectively, there are the four aspects of path, reasoning, accomplishing, and deliverance. As it says in the Commentary: Projecting onto the four truths The sixteen unreal aspects of Being stable, pleasurable, me, And mine, and so forth, one has craving.[159] The essences of each of the four truths will appear below and should be known from their respective appearances in the text.

chos kyi bdag med pa ni mtshan nyid gsum gyi sgo nas shes par bya ste/ gsum po de dag kyang gang zhe na/ gzhan gyi dbang gi mtshan nyid dang / kun btags pa'i mtshan nyid dang / yongs su grub pa'i mtshan nyid do/ /

The selflessness of phenomena is known by way of the three characteristics. What are the three? you ask. The characteristic of dependence, the characteristic of the imaginary, and the characteristic of the absolute.

de la gzhan gyi dbang gi mtshan nyid ni/ gang kun gzhi'i rnam par shes pa'i sa bon yang dag pa ma yin pa'i kun tu rtog pas bsdus pa'i rnam par rig pa'o/ / de dag kyang gang zhe na/ lus dang lus can dang / zab mo'i rnam par rig pa dang / des nye bar spyad par bya ba'i rnam par rig pa dang / de la nye bar spyod pa'i rnam par rig pa dang / dus dang grangs dang yul dang tha snyad kyi rnam par rig pa dang / bdag dang gzhan dang bde 'gro dang ngan 'gro dang 'chi 'pho ba dang skye ba'i rnam par rig pa'o/ / de la kun gzhi'i steng na bag chags rnam pa gsum ste/ spros pa'i bag chags dang / bdag tu lta ba'i bag chags dang / srid pa yan lag gi bag chags so/ / spros pa'i bag chags ni gzugs nas rnam mkhyen gyi bar gyi chos thams cad kyi ming gi rnam pa can gyi rtog pas bsgos shing tha snyad sna tshogs 'byung ba'i rgyur gyur pa'i sa bon no/ / gnyis pa ni nyon mongs pa can gyi yid kyis bsgos shing ma 'ongs pa na bdag dang bdag gi ba'i rnam pa can gyi blo skyed par byed pa'i sa bon no/ / gsum pa ni tshogs drug gi dge ba dang mi dge bas bsgos shing ma 'ongs pa'i kun gzhi rnam smin gyi cha skyed par byed pa'i sa bon no/ / las kyi bag chags sam rnam smin gyi bag chags zhes kyang bya'o/ / de la lus dang lus can dang za ba po dang des nye bar spyad par bya ba dang de la nye bar spyod pa dang dus dang grangs dang yul dang tha snyad kyis rnam par rig pa gang yin pa ni spros pa'i bag chags las byung ba'o/ / bdag dang gzhan gyi rnam par rig pa ni bdag tu lta ba'i bag chags las byung ba'o/ / bde 'gro dang ngan 'gro dang 'chi 'pho ba dang skye ba'i rnam par rig pa gang yin pa ni srid pa'i yan lag gi bag chags las byung ba'o/ / lus dang lus can gyi rnam par rig pa ni mig sogs nang gi khams drug yin no/ / za ba po dang nye bar spyod pa'i rnam par rig pa ni mig gi rnam par shes pa la sogs pa'i khams drug yin no/ / des na nye bar spyad par bya ba'i rnam par rig pa ni gzugs la sogs pa phyi'i khams drug tu rig par bya'o/ / rnam par rig pa lhag ma rnams ni rnam par rig pa 'di dag gi rab tu dbye ba'o/ /

The characteristic of dependence is any awareness assembled by seeds in the ground consciousness, incorrect misconceptions. What are those? you ask. The awareness of body and that which has a body, the awareness of the consumer;[160] the awareness of what that enjoys, the awareness of what in that enjoys; the awarenesses of time, number, object, and designations; and the awarenesses of self, other, higher realms, lower realms, death and migration, and birth.[161] There are three types of imprints in the ground consciousness: conceptual imprints, imprints of viewing the self, and imprints of the elements of existence. Conceptual imprints are the seeds stained by thoughts that have the aspect of the names of all phenomena from form to omniscience[162] and are the causes for various conventions to arise. The second type is the seeds stained by the afflicted mind that in the future will produce cognitions that have the aspect of self or mine. The third type is the seeds stained by the virtue and nonvirtue of the six consciousnesses that in the future will produce the fully ripened portion of the ground consciousness. These are also called karmic imprints or the imprints of full ripening. The awarenesses of body, that which has the body, the consumer, what that enjoys, what in that enjoys, time, number, object, and conventions arise from conceptual imprints. The awarenesses of self and other arise from the imprints of viewing the self. The awarenesses of the high realms, low realms, death and migration, and birth arise from the imprints of the elements of existence. Awarenesses of body and that which has a body are the six inner elements of the eye and so forth.[163] Awarenesses of consumer and enjoying are the six inner elements of the eye consciousness and so forth.[164] Awarenesses of what they enjoy are known as the six outer elements of form and so forth.[165] The remaining awarenesses are classifications of these awarenesses.

de la kun btags pa'i mtshan nyid ni/ gzhan dbang gi gzung cha la rnam par rtog pas bdag dang chos su sgro btags par gyur pa tha snyad du so so skye bo'i shes pa'i spyod yul du yod cing / rigs pas dpyad mi bzod pas rdzas kyi ngo bor cung zad ma grub pa'o/ / de la rtog byed gang gis rtog bya gang la rnam pa ji ltar kun tu rtog par byed ce na/ yid kyi rnam par shes pas kun tu rtog par byed de/ shes pa gzhan ni rnam par rtog pa can ma yin pa'i phyir ro/ / yid kyi rnam par shes pa de ni rang gi spros pa'i bag chags las byung zhing / rnam par rig pa gzhan thams cad kyi spros pa'i bag chags kyi sa bon las kyang byung bas dbang po dang yul dang rnam par shes pa la sogs pa mtha' yas pa'i yul can du 'byung la/ de'ang rang gi rnam pa dang rjes su mthun par bdag dang chos kyi ngo bo dang khyad par sna tshogs par sgro btags nas de dang der tha snyad 'dogs par byed do/ / de'i phyir yid shes rtog pa nyid kyis kun tu rtog par byed do/ / gzhan gyi dbang gi ngo bo nyid ni des kun tu rtog par bya ba'i gzhi yin te/ lus dang lus can dang za ba po'i rnam par rig pa ni bdag kun tu brtag par bya ba'i gzhi yin pa'i phyir te/ nang gi phung po dang / khams dang / skye mched dag la bdag tu 'dzin pa'i phyir dang / nang gi phung po la sogs pa dag kyang rnam par rig pa gsum po de tsam du zad pa'i phyir ro/ / des nye bar spyad par bya ba dang / de la nye bar spyod par byed pa'i rnam par rig pa ni chos su kun tu btag par bya ba'i gzhi yin te/ byis pa so so'i skye bo dag yul dang yul can du snang ba tsam la gzung ba dang 'dzin par mngon par zhen par byed cing / yul dang yul can du snang ba yang rnam rig gnyis po de tsam du zad pa'i phyir ro/ / gzhan dbang rnam rig tsam de dag ji srid gnas ma gyur gyi bar du bdag dang chos kyi ngo bor mtshan mar 'dzin par byed/ de dang der mngon par zhen par byed/ tha snyad 'dogs par byed/ de dang der ma grub kyang de dang der yod ces sgro 'dogs par byed pa ni rtog par bya ba gzhan gyi dbang la rtog byed yid kyi shes pas ji ltar kun btags pa'i rnam pa'o/ /

The characteristic of the imaginary is the apprehended portion of the dependent that is projected as being a self or phenomena by thought. Conventionally, this exists as the sphere of ordinary individuals' cognition, but it cannot withstand analysis and thus cannot be established as even the slightest substantial nature. In what aspect does which thinker imagine what object of thought? you ask. The mental consciousness imagines, because the other consciousnesses do not have thought. The mental consciousness arises from its own conceptual imprints as well as from the seeds of the conceptual imprints of all other awarenesses. Thus it is the subject of infinite faculties, objects, consciousnesses, and so forth. Congruently with its own aspects, it projects a self, the essence of phenomena, and various features, and then labels them as being so with conventions. For that reason, the thoughts in the mental consciousness themselves imagine. The dependent nature is the basis for its imagination, because the awarenesses of body, that which has the body, and consumer are the basis imagined to be the self. This is because it holds the internal aggregates, elements, and sense bases to be a self, and the internal aggregates are nothing more than those three awarenesses. The awarenesses of what that enjoys and what in that enjoys are the basis imagined to be phenomena, because childish ordinary individuals fixate upon the appearances of object and subject as apprehended and apprehender, and the appearances of object and subject are nothing more than those two awarenesses. Until those mere dependent appearances are transformed, they are apprehended as the attributes of the essence of self and phenomena. They are fixated upon as such and conventionally labeled. Projecting that they exist as such-and-such even though they are not established as such is the aspect of how the thinking mental consciousness imagines the dependent about which it thinks.

yongs su grub pa'i mtshan nyid ni/ gzhan dbang yang dag pa ma yin pa'i kun tu rtog pa de nyid ji skad bshad pa'i kun btags kyi ngo bor gdod ma nas ma grub pa'i stong pa nyid rnam par mi rtog pa'i ye shes kyi spyod yul du gyur pa chos kyi bdag med pa'i ngo bor 'gyur ba'o/ / de nyid gnas skabs thams cad du gzhan du mi 'gyur ba'i phyir de bzhin nyid do/ / phyin ci ma log pa'i phyir yang dag pa'i mtha'o/ / spros pa nye bar zhi ba'i phyir mtshan ma med pa'o/ / ye shes dam pa'i spyod yul yin pa'i phyir don dam pa'o/ / de rtogs pas 'phags pa'i chos rnams 'thob par 'gyur bas 'phags pa'i chos kyi rgyu yin pa'i phyir chos kyi dbyings so/ / ji skad du dbus mtha' las/ de bzhin nyid dang yang dag mtha'/ / mtshan ma med dang don dam ste/ / chos kyi dbyings rnams rnam grangs so/ / gzhan min phyin ci log ma yin/ / de 'gags 'phags pa'i spyod yul dang / / 'phags pa'i chos kyi rgyu yi phyir/ / rnam grangs don de go rim bzhin/ / ces gsungs so/ /

The characteristic of the absolute is the emptiness of those same dependent incorrect misconceptions never having been established as the essence of the above-described imaginary. It is the essence of the phenomenal selflessness that is the sphere of thought-free wisdom. Because that never changes into anything else during any phase, it is suchness. Because it is unmistaken, it is the right end. Because conceptual elaborations have fully subsided, it is the absence of attributes. Because it is the sphere of exalted wisdom, it is the ultimate. Because one achieves the noble qualities by realizing it, it is the cause of the noble qualities, and thus the dharma expanse. As is said in Differentiating the Middle from Extremes: The synonyms of emptiness In brief are suchness, the right end, Absence of attributes, the ultimate, And the dharma expanse. Respectively, the meanings of the synonyms Are since it is not other, not wrong, Their cessation, the sphere of the nobles, And the cause of noble qualities.[166]

de lta bu'i yongs su grub pa de'ang rnam pa gnyis te/ dngos po med pa'i stong pa nyid dang / dngos po med pa'i ngo bo nyid stong pa nyid do/ / dang po ni gzhan gyi dbang la gang zag dang chos kyi bdag don gzhan gyis dben pa'i stong pa nyid med par dgag pa'i rang bzhin no/ / gnyis pa ni gzhan dbang de nyid bdag gnyis kyi ngo bor ma grub pa'i stong pa nyid ma yin dgag gi rang bzhin te/ gzhan dbang rnam rig gi gnyug ma'i ngo bo sems rang bzhin gyi 'od gsal ba zhes brjod pa gang yin pa'o/ / ji skad du dbus mtha' las/ gang zag dang ni chos rnams kyi/ / dngos po med 'dir stong pa nyid/ / de dngos med pa'i dngos yod pa/ / de ni de las stong nyid gzhan/ / ces gsungs so/ /

There are two types of the absolute: the emptiness of the absence of things and the emptiness of the essence of the absence of things. The first is the nature of the emptiness no-negation[167] that is the dependent devoid of other meanings, the individual and phenomenal self. The second is the nature of the emptiness not-negation[168] of that dependent not being established as the essence of the two selves. It is that which is called the natural essence of dependent awareness, the luminous nature of mind. As is said in Differentiating the Middle from Extremes: The absence of things that are Individuals or phenomena is emptiness here. The thing that is their absence exists. In that, there is another emptiness.[169]

yang dag pa ma yin pa'i kun tu rtog pa de nyid ji ltar na gzhan dbang yin la/ ci'i phyir gzhan dbang zhes bya zhe na/ rang gi bag chags kyi sa bon las skyes pas rkyen gzhan dbang yin la/ skyes nas kyang skad cig la lhag par mi gnas pa'i phyir gzhan gyi dbang zhes bya'o/ / gang zag dang chos su sgro btags pa de dang ji ltar na kun btags pa yin la/ ci'i phyir kun btags pa zhes bya zhe na/ yid kyi rnam shes kun tu rtog pa dpag tu med pa'i rnam pa can rnams kyi dmigs pa yin pa'i phyir kun btags pa yin la/ rang gi mtshan nyid du grub pa med cing kun tu rtog pa tsam du dmigs pas na kun btags pa'o/ / stong pa nyid de ji ltar na yongs su grub pa yin la/ ci'i phyir yongs su grub pa zhes bya zhe na/ gzhan du mi 'gyur ba'i phyir yongs su grub pa yin la/ chos kun gyi mchog yin pa'i phyir yongs su grub pa zhes bya ste/ rnam par byang ba'i dmigs pa yin pa dang / dge ba'i chos kun gyi mchog yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

How is incorrect misconception dependent, and why is it called the dependent? you ask. As it arises from the seeds of its imprints, it is dependent upon conditions, and it does not persist longer than an instant after arising. Therefore it is called dependent. How is that which is projected as being an individual or phenomenon imaginary, and why is it called imaginary? you ask. Because it is the focus of misconceptions in the mental consciousness that have infinite aspects, it is imaginary. Since it cannot be established as its characteristics and is merely observed as a misconception, it is imaginary. How is emptiness absolute, and why is it called the absolute? you ask. Because it never becomes anything else, it is absolute, and because it is supreme of all dharmas, it is called absolute. This is because it is the focus of the utterly pure, and it is the supreme of all virtuous dharmas.

gzhan dbang la rnam pa du yod ce na/ rgyas par phye na tshad med de/ yang dag pa ma yin pa'i kun tu rtog pa'i dbye ba ji snyed pa kun de'i dbye ba yin pa'i phyir ro/ / bsdu na bag chags kyi gzhan dbang dang / kun byang gnyis kyi ngo bor ma grub pa'i gzhan dbang gnyis so/ / dang po ni yang dag pa ma yin pa'i kun tu rtog pa 'di nyid rang gi bag chags kyi sa bon gyi dbang gis gnyis su snang bar skyes pa'i cha nas bzhag la/ gnyis pa ni rang bzhin gyi rnam par dag pas mtha' gcig tu kun nas nyon mongs pa'i ngo bor ma grub la/ glo bur du kun nas nyon mongs pas dkrugs pas mtha' gcig tu rnam par byang ba'i ngo bor yang ma grub pa'o/ / kun btags la rnam pa du yod ce na/ rgyas par phye na tshad med de/ rnam par rtog pa mtha' yas pa'i phyir de dag gis kun btags pa yang de snyed yod pa'i phyir ro/ / bsdu na gnyis te/ ngo bo nyid du kun tu rtog pa dang / khyad par du kun tu rtog pas kun btags pa'o/ / yongs su grub pa rnam pa du yod ce na/ de ni nam mkha'i dkyil 'khor ltar chos kyi dbyings kyi ngo bor ro gcig pa'i phyir don dam par dbye ba cung zad kyang med do/ / 'on kyang spros pa la dga' ba'i ngor 'khor dang bcas pa'i dbye ba'i dbang du byas na rnam pa gnyis yin la/ de'ang rnam par byang ba'i lam dang / de'i dmigs pa'o/ / dang po la'ang rgyu dang 'bras bu gnyis las/ dang po ni rang bzhin du gnas pa'i rigs yin te/ de'ang kun gzhi la yod pa'i zag med kyi sa bon thog ma med pa nas brgyud de 'ongs pa chos nyid kyis thob pa'o/ / de'ang gang zhe na/ chos kyi dbyings kyi rgyu mthun pa dam pa'i chos thos pa'i bag chags gdod ma nas chos nyid kyis gnas pa'o/ / thos pa'i bag chags de yang gang zhe na/ gang gis sangs rgyas la sogs pa la chos thos pa na de'i don rtogs pa'i thos pa las byung ba'i rgyur gyur pa'i sa bon te/ de'ang thog ma med pa nas chos nyid kyis gnas pa yin no/ / thos pas ni de gsos 'debs par byed pa yin gyi/ gsar du skyed par byed pa ni ma yin no/ /

How many types of the dependent are there? you ask. If you classify them extensively, they are innumerable because all of the classifications of incorrect misconception are its classifications. If combined, there are two: the dependent that is imprints and the dependent that is not established as the essence of either the all-afflicted or the utterly pure. The first is presented in terms of the incorrect misconception appearing dualistically due to the seeds of its imprints. The second is not established categorically as the essence of the all-afflicted as it is naturally pure, but it is not established categorically as the essence of the utterly pure either as it is adventitiously stirred up by the all-afflicted. How many types of the imaginary are there? you ask. If you classify them extensively, they are innumerable because thoughts are infinite, so there as many as those thoughts imagine. If combined, there are two: the imaginary misconceived as an essence and the imaginary misconceived as features. How many types of the absolute are there? you ask. Just as with the mandala of space, there is a single flavor to the essence of the dharma expanse, so ultimately there are no classifications at all. However, from the perspective of those who like complication, in terms of the classifications of what is associated with it, there are two types: the utterly pure path and its focus. The first as well has two, the cause and result. The first is the naturally present family. This is the seeds of the undefiled in the all-ground that have been passed down from beginningless time and gained by the dharma nature. And what are those? you ask. They are the imprints of listening to True Dharma that have been primordially present because of the dharma nature and that are causally compatible with the dharma expanse, And what are the imprints of listening? you ask. When someone listens to dharma from the Buddha and so forth, these are the seeds arisen from listening that cause them to realize its meaning. These as well have been present from beginningless time due to the dharma nature. Listening revives them but does not produce them anew.

de'ang theg pa chen po bsdus pa las slob dpon thogs med kyis gsungs pa 'di lta ste/ de la thos pa'i bag chags chung ngu dang / 'bring dang chen po yang chos kyi sku'i sa bon du blta ste/ kun gzhi'i rnam par shes pa'i gnyen po yin pas kun gzhi'i rnam par shes pa'i ngo bo nyid ma yin pa dang / 'jig rten pa yang yin/ 'jig rten las 'das pa'i chos kyi dbyings shin tu rnam par dag pa'i rgyu mthun pa yang yin pas 'jig rten las 'das pa'i sems kyi sa bon du 'gyur ro/ zhes gsungs so/ / de la slob dpon 'phags pa thogs med kyi bzhed pas chos nyid de bzhin nyid rang bzhin du gnas pa'i rigs ma yin la/ ji skad bshad pa'i thos pa'i bag chags nyid rang bzhin du gnas pa'i rigs yin te/ thos pa'i bag chags de ni sems can rnams kyi nang gi skye mched drug rigs so so tha dad pas 'byed par byed pa'i phyir ro/ / de'i phyir skye mched drug gi khyad par zhes bya ba zhig rang bzhin du gnas pa'i rigs yin no/ / de'ang ji ltar zhe na/ theg pa chen po'i lam gyi rgyur gyur pa'i thos pa'i bag chags kyis ni rang gang gi rgyud la yod pa'i nang gi skye mched drug po de dag de dang mi ldan pa'i sems can gyi nang gi skye mched las khyad par du 'byed par byed de/ des rang gang gi rgyud la yod pa'i sems can de nyid theg pa chen po'i rigs can du mtshon par byed pa'i phyir ro/ / de bzhin du nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas kyi lam gyi rgyur gyur pa'i thos pa'i bag chags des kyang rang gang gi rgyud la yod pa'i sems can de dag nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas kyi rigs can du mtshon pa'i sgo nas nang gi skye mched drug gzhan las khyad par du byed pa yin no/ / de bas na nang gi skye mched drug las ma gtogs pa'i theg pa gsum gyi rigs can gyi gang zag ces bya ba gzhan cung zad kyang med do/ / de ltar na ji skad bshad pa'i thos pa'i bag chags de nyid la gzhung gi cha 'ga' zhig tu sgrib pa spang rung la bshad cing / kha cig tu zag pa med pa'i sa bon du bshad/ kha cig tu skye mched drug gi khyad par du bshad do/ /

In The Compendium of the Mahayana, Master Asanga says: The lesser, medium, and greater seeds of the imprints of listening are viewed as the seeds of the dharmakāya. As they are the antidote to the ground consciousness, they are not the essence of the ground consciousness. They are both worldly and causally compatible with the transworldly, thoroughly pure dharma expanse, so they are the seeds of transworldly cognitions.[170] Thus according to Noble Master Asaṅga, the dharma nature suchness is not the naturally present family, whereas the imprints of listening described above are themselves the naturally present family. This is because the imprints of listening make the distinctions of each separate family in sentient beings' inner six sense bases. For that reason, the so-called “distinctions of the six sense bases” are the naturally present family. And how is that? you ask. The imprints of listening that are the cause of the mahayana path distinguish the six inner sense bases of someone who has them in their being from the inner sense bases of sentient beings who do not, because they indicate that the sentient beings who have them in their being are in the mahayana family. Similarly, the imprints of listening that are the causes of the paths of the listeners and self-buddhas also indicate that the sentient beings who have them in their beings are in the families of the listeners and self-buddhas and in this way distinguish their six inner sense bases from others'. Therefore other than the six inner sense bases, there is nothing at all that can be called an individual in the families of the three vehicles. In some parts of the canon, the above-described imprints of listening are described as obscurations that should be discarded. In other parts, they are described as the seeds of the undefiled and in others as distinctions of the six sense bases.

ci'i phyir de nyid yongs su grub pas bsdus she na/ kun btags dang gzhan dbang ni ma yin te/ kun nas nyon mongs pa'i gnyen pos bsdus pa'i phyir te/ de skad du yang / theg pa chen po bsdus pa las/ byang chub sems dpa' las dang po ba rnams kyis 'jig rten pa yin kyang chos kyi skur bsdus pa dang / nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas rnams kyi rnam par grol ba'i lus su bsdus par blta'o/ / zhes gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ / gnyis pa de'i 'bras bu'i lam ni byang chub kyi phyogs kyi chos sum cu rtsa bdun dang / pha rol tu phyin pa drug la sogs pa theg pa gsum gyi lam gyis bsdus pa rnams so/ / de'i dmigs pa ni theg pa gsum gyi dam pa'i chos sde snod rin po che rnam pa gsum la sogs pa rnams kyang yongs su grub pas bsdus te/ rnam par byang ba'i rgyu yin pa'i phyir kun btags pa ma yin la/ kun nas nyon mongs pa'i sa bon las byung ba ma yin par chos kyi dbyings shin tu rnam par dag pa rtogs pa'i rgyu mthun gyi 'bras bu yin pa'i phyir gzhan dbang ma yin no/ / de ltar na gzhan dbang ni sgyu ma'i sprul gzhi lta bu yin la/ kun btags ni sgyu ma'i sprul gzhi de nyid skyes pa dang bud med la sogs pa sna tshogs su med kyang de dang der snang zhing snang ba ltar du sgro 'dogs pa lta bu yin cing / yongs grub ni kun btags ltar med pa la yod pa'am/ yod pa la med par yang sgro btags pa yang ma yin/ gzhan dbang ltar kun nas nyon mongs pa'i bag chags kyi sa bon gyi rkyen gzhan gyi dbang las byung ba yang ma yin no/ / 'on kyang yongs su grub pa ni gzhan dbang las de nyid dang gzhan du brjod du med do/ / de'i phyir yongs su grub pa ni gzhan dbang dang ngo bo dbyer med cing blos tha dad du btags pa tsam yin te/ chos can dang chos nyid yin pa'i phyir te/ ji skad du sum cu par/ de phyir de nyid gzhan dbang las/ / gzhan min gzhan ma yin pa'ang min/ / mi rtag la sogs bzhin du brjod/ / ces gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ /

Why are these included in the absolute? you ask. They are not either imaginary or dependent, because they are included among the antidotes to the all-afflicted. The Compendium of the Mahayana says: Though worldly, those of beginner bodhisattvas should be viewed as included in the dharmakāya and those of listeners and self-buddhas as included in the body of liberation as well.[171] Second, the path that is their result is the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, six transcendences, and so forth included in the paths of the three vehicles. Their focus, the three precious baskets of the True Dharma of the three vehicles and so forth, is also included within the absolute. Because they are the cause of the utterly pure, they are not imaginary, and because they do not arise from the seed of the allafflicted but instead are causally compatible with the realization of the thoroughly pure dharma expanse, they are not dependent.[172] In this way, the dependent is like the basis for emanating illusions, and the imaginary is like projecting that basis for emanating illusions, which appears variously as men, women and so forth though there are none, as being what it appears to be. Unlike the imaginary, the absolute does not project nothing as being something or something as being nothing, and unlike the dependent, it does not arise in dependence upon other conditions—the seeds of all-afflicted imprints. However, the absolute cannot be described as either the same as or other than the dependent. For that reason, the absolute is indivisible in essence from the dependent and merely mentally labeled as separate, because they are phenomena and the phenomenal nature.[173] As it says in The Thirty Verses: Therefore it said to be neither different Nor not different from the dependent, Like impermanence and so forth.[174]

'o na mtshan nyid gsum po 'di dag las kun rdzob tsam du grub pa gang / don dam par grub pa gang zhe na/ gzhan dbang dang kun btags gnyis ni kun rdzob tsam du grub pa yin te/ 'khrul ba dang 'khrul ba'i snang ba yin pa'i phyir ro/ / yongs su grub pa ni don dam par grub pa yin te/ dam pa 'jig rten las 'das pa'i ye shes kyi yul du bden pa'i phyir ro/ / ji skad du dbus mtha' las/ dam pa'i don ni gcig pus so/ / zhes dang / de'i 'grel pa las kyang / gzhan gyi dbang gi mtshan nyid tha snyad du yod kyang de kho na ma yin te/ 'khrul ba'i phyir ro/ / zhes sogs gsungs pas so/ / de bas na rnal 'byor spyod pa'i lugs la gzhan dbang bden par grub par smra ba de dag ni rnam par shes pa smra ba la rnal 'byor spyod pa'i dbu ma par 'khrul ba'i gyi na tsam du zad do/ /

Well then, which of the three characteristics is established merely in the relative, and which as ultimate? you ask. Two, the dependent and imaginary, are established merely in the relative, because they are confusion and confused appearances. The absolute is established to be ultimate, because it is true as the object of exalted transworldly wisdom. As it says in Differentiating the Middle from Extremes, “The ultimate is singular.”[175] Its commentary also says, among other things, that the dependent characteristic exists conventionally but is not true, because it is confused.[176] Therefore saying that the dependent is truly established in the Yogācāra tradition is merely the laziness of confusing Idealism for the Yogācāra Middle Way.

yang kha cig snang ba sems su smra ba dang / mtshan nyid gsum khas len pa de dag thams cad sems tsam par 'dod la/ de ni ma yin te/ mdo sde pas kyang snang ba sems su khas len pa'i phyir dang / yum gyi byams zhus kyi le'u las/ gzugs nas rnam mkhyen gyi bar gyi chos thams cad mtshan nyid gsum gyi sgo nas gtan la phab nas bstan pa'i phyir/ de dang de nyid kyang sems tsam pa dang de'i lugs su 'gyur ro/ /

There are some who assert that saying appearances are mind and accepting the three characteristics are all Mind Only, but that is not the case, because even the Sutra school asserts that appearances are mind, and because in the chapter requested by Maitreya from the pra-jñāparāmita sutras, all phenomena from form to omniscience are determined and taught by way of the three characteristics. Thus the Sutra school would be Mind Only and that text its tradition.

des na 'phags pa thogs med sku mched kyi rjes su 'brang ba'i rnal 'byor spyod pa'i dbu ma chen po rnams kyi de kho na nyid la sgrib par byed pa'i gzung ba dang 'dzin pa gnyis su snang ba ltar du ma grub par gtan la phab nas sems rang rig rang gsal rtogs pa'i ye shes gtso bor ston par mdzad la/ 'phags pa klu sgrub yab sras kyis ni de kho na nyid la sgrib par byed pa'i bden 'dzin yul dang bcas pa rnams gtan tshigs chen po rnams kyis legs par dpyad nas rang bzhin med par gtan la phab ste/ sems gsal ba'i ngo bo stong pa nyid du gnas pa gtso bor ston par mdzad do/ /

Therefore the Yogācāra Great Middle Way that follows Noble Asaṅga and his brother determines that the apprehended and appre-hender, which obscure suchness, are not established to be two as they appear. It primarily teaches the wisdom that realizes the self-aware, self-knowing mind. Through the great reasonings, Noble Nāgārjuna and his disciples thoroughly analyze clinging to truth, which obscures suchness, and its object, establishing that those have no nature. They primarily teach that the essence of the clear mind resides in emptiness.

shing rta'i srol gnyis ka'ang mthar thug de kho na nyid ston pa la khyad par yod pa ma yin te/ sems gsal ba'i ngo bo de nyid dang po nyid nas stong pa nyid yin la/ stong pa nyid de'ang dang po nas gsal ba'i bdag nyid du gnas pa'i phyir ro/ / de'i phyir slob dpon phyogs kyi glang po dang / dpal chos kyi grags pa gnyis kyang 'phags pa thogs med nas nye bar brgyud pa'i shing rta'i srol nyid dri ma med pa'i rigs pas gtan la phab nas 'dzin par mdzad pas na rnal 'byor spyod pa'i dbu ma par grub la/ de'i gzhung kun las btus sde bdun dang bcas pa'i mthar thug gi dgongs pa ni rnal 'byor spyod pa'i gzhung lugs su gzhol zhing 'bab pa yin no zhes bya ba 'di 'thad pa yin no/ /

In teaching the ultimate suchness, there is no distinction at all between the two great traditions, because the clear essence of mind has been emptiness from the very beginning, and that emptiness has abided as the character of clarity from the very beginning. Therefore, both Master Dignāga and glorious Dharmakīrti came to understanding through the logics of the stainless tradition that descends from Noble Asaṅga and uphold that tradition, so they are proven to be Yogācāra Middle Way. Thus it is reasonable to say that the final intent of their texts including The Compendium of Validity and the seven treatises fits within and falls within the textual tradition of the Yogācāra.
gnyis pa tshig gi don ni/
ii. The meaning of the text
yang na skyob/ / bden pa bzhi ni ston mdzad pa'o/ /
148ab Or else the protector Is he who teaches the four noble truths.

zhes smos te/ mdo'i mchod brjod lugs 'byung gi sgo nas 'gro la phan bzhed pa la sogs pa rgyu snga ma snga mas 'bras bu phyi ma phyi ma rjes su dpog pa'i rang bzhin gyi gtan tshigs las bcom ldan 'das tshad mar grub par bshad pa las/ yang na lugs las ldog ste 'bras bu phyi ma phyi ma las rgyu snga ma snga ma sgrub par byed pa'i 'bras bu'i gtan tshigs kyis bcom ldan 'das tshad mar bsgrub par bya ste/ de'ang bcom ldan 'das ni sdug bsngal rab tu zhi ba don du gnyer ba rnams kyi skyob pa yin te/ de la 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal rab tu zhi ba'i thabs 'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi ni phyin ci ma log par ston par mdzad pa'i phyir ro/ / phyi rol pa la sogs pas ni srog gi mchod sbyin sogs lam phyin ci log tu ston pa'i phyir sdug bsngal las skyob nus pa ma yin no/ /

It has been explained in terms of the forward order of the Compendium's homage how reasons of nature by which one infers later results from earlier causes such as wishing to benefit beings prove the Bhaga-van is valid. Or else in reverse order, reasons of result that prove earlier causes from the later results establish the Bhagavan to be valid. The Bhagavan is the protector of those who wish to fully pacify suffering, because he teaches them unerringly the method to fully pacify the suffering of samsara, the four noble truths. Because non-Buddhists and so forth teach erroneous paths such as animal sacrifice, they are not able to protect from suffering.
gnyis pa bstan bya bden pa bzhi'i rang bzhin bshad pa la/
b. Explaining the nature of the four truths that he taught.
shes bya sdug bsngal gyi bden pa/ spang bya kun 'byung gi bden pa/ mngon du bya ba 'gog pa'i bden pa/ blang bya lam gyi bden pa bshad pa'o/ /

This has four topics: i. What is to be known, the truth of suffering: ii. What is to be abandoned, the truth of the origin; iii. What is to be manifested, the truth of cessation; and iv. What is to be adopted, the truth of the path.
dang po [shes bya sdug bsngal gyi bden pa] la
i. What is to be known, the truth of suffering.
spyi'i don dang / tshig gi don gnyis las/
This has two topics: (1) General discussion, and (2) The meaning of the text.
dang po [spyi'i don] ni/
(1) General discussion

sdug bsngal gyi bden pa de'ang gang zhe na/ 'gro ba kun gyi bdag tu 'dzin pa'i gzhir gyur pa'i phung po lnga po yin te/ ji skad du rgyas pa las/ sdug bsngal 'khor ba can phung po/ / zhes gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ / shes bya gtan la 'bebs pa'i dbang du byas nas phyi snod kyi 'jig rten yang sdug bsngal du bshad pa yin te/ ji skad du/ chos mngon pa las/ sdug bsngal gyi bden pa gang zhe na/ sems can skye ba dang skye ba'i gnas kyis kyang rig par bya'o/ / zhes bshad la/ bstan bcos 'dir nang gi phung po tsam la sdug bsngal du bshad pa ni nyams su len pa'i dbang du byas pa'o/ / de'ang 'jig tshogs la lta bas phung po la bdag tu lta ba yin te/ ji skad du/ bcom ldan 'das kyis mdo las/ dge sbyong dang bram ze gang la la bdag tu lta ba de dag ni nye bar len pa'i phung po lnga po 'di dag la yin te/ zhes gsungs pa'i phyir dang / rnal 'byor pas kyang 'jig tshogs la lta ba'i gnyen por bdag med par sgom par byed pa'i phyir te/ ji skad du rgyas pa las/ de phyir grol 'dod thog med pa'i/ / rgyu can rigs mthun sa bon las/ / byung ba'i 'jig tshogs lta ba dag/ rtsa ba nyid nas dbyung bar gyis/ / zhes dang / 'jigs bral gyi slob dpon zla bas kyang / nyon mongs skyon rnams ma lus 'jig tshogs la/ / lta las byung bar blo yis mthong gyur cing / / bdag ni 'di yi yul du rtogs byas nas/ / rnal 'byor pa yis bdag ni 'gog bar byed/ / ces gsungs pas so/ / de ltar na sdug bsngal gyi rgyu bdag tu 'dzin pa'i mtshan nyid can gyi ma rig pa'i zhing sa gshin por rnam par shes pa'i skyes bus dge ba dang mi dge ba'i las mngon par 'du byas te 'gro ba drug gi sa bon btab pas/ de nyid ci zhig ltar sred pa dang len pa'i rlan gyis bran pa na skye ba bskyed pa'i nus pa mthu can du gyur pa'i srid pa zhes bya ba'i yan lag tu 'gyur ro/ / de las skye ba'i myu gu 'byung ngo / / de las ming dang gzugs kyi sdong po mngon par grub bo/ / de las kyang skye mched drug gi lo 'dab dang yal ga rnams rgyas par 'gyur ro/ / de las kyang reg pa dang tshor ba'i me tog mngon par grub bo/ / de las kyang rga ba'i 'bras bu smin par gyur
