nas mthar 'chi ba'i thang la lhung bar 'gyur te/ de ltar na srid pa'i ljon shing chen po de thog ma med pa nas ji srid mya ngan las 'das pa'i sa la phyin gyi bar du 'dug pa'i tshul de'ang 'phrul 'khor mkhan gyis byas pa'i zo chun gyi 'khor lo 'phyan pa dang 'dra ste/ 'di ltar rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba yan lag bcu gnyis kyi zo chun rnams las dang nyon mongs pa'i thag pas dam du bsdams pa/ rnam par shes pa'i 'phrul 'khor mkhan gyis drag tu bskyod pa/ srid pa'i rtse mo nas mnar med pa'i bar srid pa gsum gyi khron pa gting zab cing khyon yangs par 'phyan te/ ngan 'gro'i thur du rang gi ngang gis 'jug cing bde 'gro'i gyen du 'bad pas drang bar bya dgos pa/ ma rig pa nas rga shi'i bar la nyon mongs pa dang / las dang / skye ba'i kun nas nyon mongs pa'i gnas skabs gsum dang ldan kyang thog ma dang dbus dang mtha' ma nges par mi zin pa/ nyin re bzhin du sdug bsngal gyi sdug bsngal dang / 'gyur ba'i sdug bsngal dang / 'du byed kyi sdug bsngal gsum gyis rgyun mi chad du mnar bar byed pa ste/ de ltar na sdug bsngal du gyur pa'i 'khor ba'i phung po 'di ni zo chun 'phyan pa dang chos mthun pa yin no/ / mdor na sdug bsngal de dag gi rgyur gyur pa ni bdag tu 'dzin pa'i rtsa ba can yin pas sdug bsngal zhi bar 'dod pa rnams kyis bdag tu 'dzin pa de nyid gzhom pa la brtson par bya'o/ /

What is the truth of suffering? you ask. It is the five aggregates that are the basis all sentient beings hold to be a self. As it says in The Commentary, “Suffering is the samsaric aggregates,”[177] In terms of coming to understand the knowable, the external environment of the world is also explained to be suffering. As explained in the abhidharma, “If you ask what the truth of suffering is, it is also known as the births and places of birth of sentient beings.” The explanation in this treatise of just the inner aggregates as suffering is from the perspective of practice. The aggregates are viewed as a self by personality view.[178] This is because, as the Bhagavan said in a sutra: Any spiritual person or brahmin who views a self views these five aggregates of grasping.[179] It is also because the yogis meditate on selflessness as the antidote for personality view. As it says in The Commentary: Therefore all those who wish for freedom should Eradicate the personality views That arise out of seeds of the same kind In a beginningless continuum.[180] The fearless Master Candrakīrti also said: The faults of the afflictions all arise From personality view, the mind can see. After realizing its object is the self, The yogi refutes the self.[181] In this way, in the fertile field of ignorance that has the characteristic of ego-clinging, the cause of suffering, conscious individuals perform virtuous and unvirtuous acts, planting the seeds of the six migrations. When these are in some way watered with the moisture of craving and grasping, they become the link called becoming that has the power to produce birth. From that, the seedling of birth arises. From that, the trunk of name and form is established. From that spread the limbs and branches of the six sense bases. From those come the flowers of contact and feeling. From those ripens the fruit of aging, which eventually falls onto the field of death. Until one arrives at the level of nirvana, the great tree of existence exists in this way from beginningless time in a manner similar to how a mechanic hangs buckets from a windlass in a well. Thus the buckets of the twelve links of interdependence are tied with the rope of karma and afflictions, moved furiously by the mechanic who is consciousness, and hung in the deep and broad well of the three realms that reaches from the Peak of Existence to the Incessant Hell. They naturally fall down into the lower realms but must be hauled up to the higher realms with effort. From ignorance to aging and death, there are the all-afflicted three phases of the afflicted, karma, and birth, but no beginning or middle or end can be definitely recognized. One is tormented every single day without interruption by the three sufferings of the suffering of suffering, the suffering of change, and the suffering of formation. In this way, these samsaric aggregates that are suffering are similar to buckets in a well. In brief, that which is the cause of those sufferings has clinging to a self as its root, so those who wish to pacify suffering strive to defeat that clinging to a self.
gnyis pa tshig gi don bshad pa la/
(2) The meaning of the text.
sdug bsngal ngos bzung ba/ de nyid rtags kyis bsgrub pa/ de'i rnam pa bshad pa'o/ /
This has three topics: (a) Identifying suffering, (b) Proving that through reasons, and (c) Explaining its aspects.
dang po [sdug bsngal ngos bzung ba] ni/
(a) Identifying suffering
sdug bsngal 'khor ba can phung po/ /
148c Suffering is the samsaric aggregates.
zhes smos te/ sdug bsngal gyi bden pa gang zhe na/ las dang nyon mongs pa'i dbang gis 'khor bar 'khor ba can gyi nye bar len pa'i phung po lnga po 'di nyid do/ /
What is the truth of suffering? you ask. It is the five aggregates of grasping that cycle in samsara by force of karma and the afflictions.
gnyis pa de nyid rtags kyis bsgrub pa la/
(b) Proving that through reasons.
goms pa'i/ lus dang rnam pa mtshungs pa'i/ rnam shes min pas rnam shes kyi nyer len mi byed pa'i rtags kyis bsgrub pa/ skye ba snga ma med na ha cang thal ba dang bzhi'o/ /

This has four topics: (i) Proving suffering through the evidence of habituation, (ii) Proving the aggregates are samsara through the evidence that the mind’s aspects would be similar to the body's, (iii) Proving samsara through the evidence that what is not consciousness is not the substantial cause of consciousness, and (iv) The absurd consequence if there were no past lives.
dang po [goms pa'i rtags kyis bsgrub pa] la/
(i) Proving samsara is suffering through the evidence of habituation.
dngos dang / rtsod pa spang ba'o/ /
This has two topics: A. Actual, and B. Refuting criticism.
dang po [dngos] ni/
A. Actual
'khor ba sdug bsngal du mi rigs te/ skye ba snga ma nas 'dir 'ong ba dang / 'di nas phyi mar 'gro ba'i 'khor ba nyid med pa'i phyir zhe na/ bshad pa/
It is not logical for samsara to be suffering because there is no samsara where one comes from a previous life to this one and goes from this to a next, you say. To explain:
goms las 'dod chags sogs gsal ba/ / mthong phyir/
148d It's seen habituation intensifies 149a Desire and so forth.

zhes smos te/ skye ba 'dir yang skyes bu 'ga' zhig sngar 'dod chags dang / shes rab la sogs pa shas chung ba la rkyen ji lta ba bzhin du goms pa las/ phyis 'dod chags dang shes rab la sogs pa shin tu ches gsal bar 'gyur ba mthong ba'i phyir/ skyes ma thag pa'i 'dod chags dang shes rab la sogs pa yang skye ba snga ma'i chags pa dang shes rab la sogs pa goms pa las 'byung la/ 'di'i chags sogs las skye ba phyi ma'i chags sogs 'byung bas 'khor ba 'di grub bo zhes pa lha rgyan gnyis ka'i'o/ /

It is seen even in this life, that in some people who previously had little desire, intelligence, and so forth, habituation according to circumstances later greatly intensifies desire, intelligence, and so forth. For this reason, immediately after birth, desire, intelligence, and so forth also arise from habituation to desire, intelligence, and so forth in previous lives. From the desire and so forth of this life, the desire and so forth of future births will arise, so samsara is proven. This is according to both Devendrabuddhi and Prajñākaragupta.
gnyis pa rtsod pa spang ba la/
B. Refuting criticism.
chags sogs rgyu med du skye ba dgag/ rlung sogs las skye ba dgag/ 'byung ba las skye ba dgag pa'o/ /

This has three topics: 1. Refuting that desire and so forth arise without cause, 2. Refuting that desire and so forth arise from wind and so forth, and 3. Refuting that desire and so forth arise from the elements.
dang po [chags sogs rgyu med du skye ba dgag pa] la/
1. Refuting that desire and so forth arise without cause
kha cig na re/ 'dod chags la sogs pa goms pa las 'byung ba ma yin te/ rgyu med du 'byung ba'i phyir zhe na/ bshad pa/
Some say that desire and so forth do not arise from habituation because they arise without cause. To explain:
'dod rgyal nyid min te/ / rgyu med skye ba 'gal phyir ro/ /
149ab It's not happenstance— Arising without cause is contradictory.
zhes smos te/ 'dod chags la sogs pa ni rgyu med par 'dod rgyal nyid du 'byung ba min te/ res 'ga' rgyu las skye ba mthong ba'i phyir te/ rgyu med par res 'ga' skye ba 'gal ba'i phyir ro/ /

Desire and so forth do not arise without a cause by happenstance, because they are seen to arise intermittently from causes, and because arising without cause is contradictory of arising occasionally.
gnyis pa rlung sogs las skye ba dgag pa la/
2. Refuting that desire and so forth arise from wind and so forth.
'gog byed kyi rigs pa dngos dang / de'i lan dgag pa'o/ /
This has two topics: a. The actual logic of the refutation, and b. Dismissing the rebuttal.
dang po ['gog byed kyi rigs pa dngos] ni/
a. The actual logic of the refutation

gzhan dag na re/ bad kan dang / mkhris pa dang / rlung rnams las rim pa bzhin du 'dod chags dang zhe sdang dang gti mug rnams dngos su skye ba yin gyi/ goms pa'i dbang gis skye ba ma yin ce na/ bshad pa/
Others say that desire, hatred, and delusion actually arise respectively from phlegm, bile, and wind; they do not arise from the power of habituation. To explain:
'khrul phyir rlung sogs chos ma yin/ /
149cd As that's fallacious, they're not qualities Of wind and so forth.

ces smos te/ gti mug la sogs pa ni rlung dang mkhris pa la sogs pa las dngos su skyes pa'i 'bras bu'i chos ma yin te/ rlung sogs yod med kyi rjes su 'gro ldog byed pa 'khrul ba'i phyir ro/ / bad kan can gyi skyes bu zhe sdang che zhing 'dod chags chung ba yang mthong ba'i phyir ro/ /

They (delusion and so forth) are not resultant qualities that are actually produced by wind, bile, and so forth, as that (the entailment and reverse entailment with the presence of wind and so forth) is fallacious. There are also people with phlegm who have a lot of hatred and little desire.
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
gal te rang bzhin 'dres pa'i phyir/ / skyon med ce na/
149d If there were no fault 150a Because the nature is mixed,
zhes smos te/ gal te bad kan can zhe sdang che ba la yang zhe sdang gi dngos rgyu mkhris pa'i rang bzhin 'dres pa'i phyir/ zhe sdang mkhris pa dang rjes su 'khrul ba'i skyon med do zhe na/ bshad pa/

If you say that in phlegmatic people with great anger, their nature is mixed with bile, the direct cause of hatred, and because of this there is no fault of anger not being entailed by bile, to explain:
de yi chos/ / de las gzhan yang cis ma mthong / /
150ab then why would not Its other qualities be seen as well?

zhes smos te/ 'o na ni bad kan can gyi skyes bu de la mkhris pa de'i dngos 'bras kyi chos zhe sdang de las gzhan yang dri nga ba dang / rdul dang / skal ba ngan pa'i chos kyang cis ma mthong ste mthong bar 'gyur te/ dri nga ba la sogs pa de dag gi dngos rgyu mkhris pa yod pa'i phyir ro/ /

Then why would not its (bile's) other qualities than its direct result hatred, such as bad odor, sweat, and bad fortune, be seen in that phlegmatic person as well? They would be seen, because bile, the direct cause of bad odor and so forth, is present.
gal te 'dod chags zhe sdang gti mug gsum ka'ang rlung mkhris bad kan gsum ka'i 'bras bu yin pas skyon med do zhe na/ bshad pa/
If you say that desire, hatred, and delusion are all the result of the three—wind, bile, and phlegm—so there is no fault, to explain:
thams cad 'dod chags mtshungs par ni/ / thal phyir kun gyi chos ma yin/ /
150cd It's not a quality of all because All would have equal desire as a consequence.

ces smos te/ 'dod chags sogs re re'ang rlung sogs thams cad las skye ba de ltar yin na/ skyes bu thams cad 'dod chags che chung mtshungs par ni thal ba'i skyon yod pa'i phyir/ 'dod chags ni rlung mkhris bad kan kun gyi dngos 'bras su gyur pa'i chos ma yin no/ / de bzhin du zhe sdang dang gti mug dang nga rgyal dang khengs pa dang phrag dog dang ser sna dang shes rab la sogs pa'i yon tan dang ldan par mtshungs par 'gyur te/ rgyu mtshungs pa nyid kyi phyir ro zhes pa lha'i'o/ /

If desire and so forth each arose out of all of them, wind and so forth, as a consequence there would be the fault that all people would have equal amounts of desire. For that reason, it (desire) is not a quality that is a direct result of all three, wind, bile, and phlegm. Likewise, everyone would also have similar qualities of hatred, delusion, pride, arrogance, jealously, stinginess, intelligence, and so forth, because they have the same causes. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
de la gzhan dag na re/
Others respond:
gzugs sogs bzhin skyon med ce na/ /
151ab “Like bodies and so forth, there is no fault,” You say,

zhes smos te/ gal te skyes bu'i lus rgyu 'byung ba las skyes par mtshungs kyang gzugs bzang ngan sogs mi mtshungs pa bzhin du rgyu rlung sogs mtshungs par yod kyang 'bras bu chags sogs mtshungs par yod dgos pa'i skyon med ce na/ bshad pa/

If you say that people's bodies are the same in arising from the cause of the elements, but there are dissimilarities in having a good or bad body and so forth, and likewise the causes—wind and so forth—are similarly present, but there is no fault that the results—desire and so forth—must be the same, to explain:
gal te de la khyad par can/ / las rnams bdag po ma yin na/ / der yang rtsod pa mtshungs pa yin/ /
151b-d but without any distinctive karmas That would be the dominant for that, The criticism here would be the same.

ces smos te/ gal te skyes bu'i gzugs bzang ngan de la rgyu khyad par can sngon gyi las bzang ngan rnams bdag po'i rkyen du yod pa ma yin par 'byung ba kho na las skye ba yin na/ der yang skyes bu kun chos can/ gzugs bzang ngan mtshungs par thal/ rgyu 'byung ba mtshungs par yod pa'i phyir zhes pa'i rtsod pa mtshungs par 'jug pa yin no zhes rgyan gyi'o/ /

If people's good or bad bodies arose solely from the elements without any distinctive cause, previous karma, that would the dominant condition for them, then the same criticism would apply here as well: It follows that all people, the subject, would have equally good or bad figures because the causes—the elements—are equally present. This is according to Prajñākaragupta.
gnyis pa de'i lan dgag pa ni/
b. Dismissing the rebuttal.
skyon rnams rlung sogs kyi rjes su 'gro ldog ma grub pas dgag/ dgag pa de nyid rgyas par bshad/ rjes su 'gro ldog grub na ha cang thal/ de la rtsod pa spang ba'o/ /

This has four topics: i. Refuting it because the faults are not proven to be entailed or reverse entailed by wind and so forth, ii. Explaining that refutation at length, iii. The absurd consequence if entailment and reverse entailment were proven, and iv. Rebutting criticism of that.
dang po [skyon rnams rlung sogs kyi rjes su 'gro ldog ma grub pas dgag pa] ni/
i. Refuting it because the faults are not proven to be entailed or reverse entailed by wind and so forth
skyon rnams khyad par yod na yang / / khyad par med phyir/
152ab Although there are distinctions in the faults, There's no distinction.

zhes smos te/ 'dod chags la sogs pa rnams ni bad kan la sogs pa'i dngos kyi 'bras bur mi 'gyur te/ skyon bad kan la sogs pa rnams 'phel ba'i khyad par yod na yang chags sogs 'phel ba'i khyad par med pa'i phyir ro/ /

Desire and so forth would not be the direct result of phlegm and so forth, since though there are distinctions of the faults—phlegm and so forth—increasing, there is no distinction of lust and so forth increasing.

gal te gtan tshigs ma grub ste/ rlung dang mkhris pa sogs thams cad rgyur mi 'dod kyi/ de'i 'gyur ba 'ga' zhig chags sogs kyi rgyu yin te/ mkhris pa 'phel nas lus sdug bsngal gyis gdung bas zhe sdang 'phel ba'i phyir ro zhe na/ bshad pa/

You might say that the reason is not proven, because you do not assert that wind, bile, and so forth are all the causes, but that some of their changes are causes, because when bile increases, the body is tormented by pain, increasing hatred. To explain:
ma grub nyid/ / ma yin thams cad 'gyur ba yis/ / 'gyur phyir/
152b-d It is not unproven, Because a change in all of them will make A change,

zhes smos te/ de tsam gyi gtan tshigs ma grub pa nyid ma yin te/ zhe sdang ni bad rlung thams cad 'gyur ba las skye bar mi 'gyur te/ bad rlung sogs 'phel zhing 'gyur ba yis lus sdug bsngal gyis gdungs nas skye bar 'gyur ba'i phyir zhes pa rgyan gyi'o/ /

By that alone, it (the reason) is not unproven, because hatred does not arise from a change in ail of them (phlegm and wind) but does arise from an increase and change in phlegm and wind that distresses the body with pain.[182] This is according to Prajñākaragupta.
gal te zhe sdang rlung mkhris sogs kun las skye bas skyon med ce na/
If you say that there is no fault because hatred arises from all of them—wind, bile, and so forth:
kun las skye ba'ang min/ /
152d and they do not arise from all.
ces smos te/ zhe sdang ni rlung sogs kun las skye ba'ang ma yin te/ thams cad 'dod chags mtshungs par ni thal phyir zhes pa'i nyes pa bshad zin pa'i phyir ro/ /
Hatred does not arise from all of them, wind and so forth, because of the fault previously explained: It's not a quality of all because All would have equal desire as a consequence.
gnyis pa dgag pa de nyid rgyas par bshad pa la/
ii. Explaining that refutation at length.
rgyu 'phel na 'bras bu 'grib pa mi 'thad/ sdug bsngal gyis gegs byas pa mi 'thad/ de'i lan dgag pa'o/ /
This has three points: (1) If the cause increases, it is not tenable for the result to decrease, (2) It is not tenable for pain to impede desire, (3) Refuting the response.
dang po [rgyu 'phel na 'bras bu 'grib pa mi 'thad pa] ni/
(1) If the cause increases, it is not tenable for the result to decrease
rgyu ni 'phel bar gyur pa na/ / 'bras bu 'grib par mi rung ste/ / tsha ba sogs bzhin/
153a-c If causes increase, it's illogical For the results to decrease, as with heat And so forth.

zhes smos te/ ji skad bshad pa de ltar rgyu bad kan ni 'phel bar gyur pa na/ 'bras bu 'dod chags 'grib par mi rung ste/ 'dod chags ni bad kan gyi dngos 'bras yin pa'i phyir/ dper na mkhris pa la sogs pa 'phel ba na/ tsha ba la sogs pa'i nad 'phel ba bzhin no/ / 'dis ni/ skyon rnams khyad par yod na yang / / zhes bya ba'i gzhung btsugs pa yin no zhes pa lha'i'o/ / gal te bad mkhris cha mnyam pa las 'dod chags dang / cha mi mnyam pa las zhe sdang skye bas na bad mkhris sogs las skye'o zhe na/ bshad pa/

As explained, if the cause phlegm were to increase, it would be illogical for the result (desire) to decrease, because desire is the direct result of phlegm. It is, for example, just as when bile and so forth increase, illnesses of heat and so forth increase. This supports the text “Although there are distinctions in the faults...” according to Devendrabuddhi. If you say that desire arises from a balance of phlegm and bile whereas hatred from an imbalance, so they do arise from phlegm and bile, to explain:
chags sogs kyi/ / 'gyur ba bde sdug las skyes yin/ /
153cd Changes of desire and so on Arise from pleasure and so forth.

zhes smos te/ bad mkhris cha mnyam pa las 'dod chags dang / cha mi mnyam pa las zhe sdang sogs kyi 'gyur ba bad mkhris kyi rgyu las dngos su skyes pa ma yin te/ bad mkhris sogs cha mnyam pa'i gnas skabs kyi nang gi reg bya'i khyad par gzung yul du yod pa'i lus shes 'khor du byung ba'i tshor ba bde ba dang / cha mi mnyam pa'i reg bya'i khyad par gzung yul du yod pa'i lus shes 'khor du byung ba'i tshor ba sdug bsngal las dngos su skyes pa yin pa'i phyir/ zhes chags sdang so sor sbyar ro/ /

The changes of desire from a balance of phlegm and bile and hatred and so on from an imbalance do not arise directly from the causes phlegm and bile. This is because they arise directly from the pleasure that arises in association with the body consciousness that has as its apprehended object particular internal feelings at times when phlegm, bile, and so forth are balanced or from the pain that arises in association with the body consciousness that has as its apprehended object particular internal feelings at times when phlegm, bile, and so forth are imbalanced.[183] This applies to desire and hatred respectively.
gnyis pa sdug bsngal gyis gegs byas pa mi 'thad pa la/
(2) It is not tenable for pain to impede desire
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
cha mi mnyam skyes sdug bsngal gyis/ / gal te 'dod chags mi bskyed na/ /
154ab And if desire is not produced because Of pain that was created by imbalance,

zhes smos te/ gal te bad kan la sogs pa 'phel na'ang 'dod chags la sogs pa mi 'phel ba ni bad mkhris sogs cha mi mnyam pa las skyes pa'i sdug bsngal gyis gegs byas pas 'dod chags mi bskyed pa yin no zhe na/ 'o na de'i rgyu gang yin dri ba'i phyir/

When phlegm and so forth increase but desire and so forth do not, the pain that was created by an imbalance in phlegm, bile, and so forth makes an impediment, so desire is not produced, you might say. Well then, to ask what its cause is:
cis skye smros shig cha mnyam las/ / khu 'phel de las 'dod chags yin/ /
154cd Do tell whence it arises. “Semen increases From balance, and desire increases from that.”
ces smos te/ 'o na 'dod chags ni rgyu ci las skye smros shig/ gal te nyes pa gsum cha mnyam pa'i rgyu las khu ba 'phel zhing / khu ba 'phel ba de las 'dod chags yin no zhe na/ bshad pa/
Well then, do tell what is the cause whence it (desire) arises. If you say, “Semen increases from the cause of a balance of the three humors, and desire increases from that increase of semen.”
cha mi mnyam la'ang chags can mthong / / gzhan ni cha mnyam na yang min/ / gzhan ni zad nas khrag 'dzag kyang / / bud med gcig la khu nges med/ / de gcig la chags drag mi 'gyur/ /

155. It's seen that even some with imbalances Are lustful, whereas some in balance aren't. Some are, though they emit blood, being depleted. Semen's not definite for any one woman, 156a And there might not be strong lust for that one.

zhes smos te/ 'dod chags ni nyes pa cha mnyam las byung ba'i khu ba'i 'bras bur mi rigs te/ nyes pa cha mi mnyam pa la'ang ches shin tu chags pa can 'ga' zhig mthong ba'i phyir dang / ngo bo nyid kyi chags pa chung ba can gzhan 'ga' zhig ni nyes pa cha mnyam pa yin na'ang chags pa dang ldan pa min pa'i phyir dang / yang gzhan chags ldan 'ga' zhig ni khu ba zad nas khrag 'dzag kyang 'dod chags shin tu che ba mthong ba'i phyir dang / khu ba shin tu mang ba can yang chags pa can ma yin par mthong ba'i phyir ro/ / de ltar na nyes pa cha mnyam pa dang khu ba 'phel ba ni 'dod chags kyi rgyu min te/ phan 'dogs byed du yod med kyi rjes su 'gro ldog byed pa med pa'i phyir ro/ / gzhan yang chags ldan gyi skyes bu ni bud med gzugs mdzes ma gcig la dmigs nas khu ba 'phel ba'i nges pa med pa'i phyir/ skyes bu de bud med gcig la dmigs nas chags pa drag po skye bar mi 'gyur na'ang 'ga' zhig la ni nges par 'gyur te/ des na khu ba 'phel ba 'dod chags kyi rgyu ma yin no zhes pa lha'i'o/ /

It is not logical that desire would be the result of semen arising from balanced humors, because it is seen that there are even some people with imbalances in the humors who are extremely lustful, and because some who naturally have little lust may have balanced humors but are not lustful. Also, some lustful men are seen to still be extremely desirous, even though they emit blood, as their semen has been depleted. And there are some who have large amounts of semen but are seen not to be lustful. Therefore, a balance of the humors and the increase of semen are not the cause of desire, because their presence or absence neither entail nor reverse entail any effect. Additionally, it is not definite that semen will increase in a lustful man after he observes any one beautiful woman.[184] That man might not have strong lust for that one woman but definitely would for others. Therefore an increase in semen is not the cause of desire. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
gsum pa de'i lan dgag pa la/
(3) Refuting the response
kha cig na re/
Others say:
gal te gzugs sogs kyang yan lag/
156b If figure and so forth were factors, too,

ces smos te/ gal te gzugs mdzes pa dang nye bar spyod pa la sogs pa dag gis kyang khu ba 'phel bar byed la/ de nyid bud med la chags pa skye ba'i lhan cig byed pa'i yan lag yin pas skyon med ce na/ bshad pa/
If you say that since a beautiful figure, courtship, and so forth increase semen, and those were cooperating factors in producing lust for a woman, too, there is no fault, to explain:
ma yin kun ma nges phyir ro/ / nges pa med par 'byung ba'ang yin/ / yon tan mi 'dzin pa la'ang 'gyur/ /
156cd Not so—it is not certain for everyone. It also is not definite. It would occur 157a For those who do not hold them qualities.

zhes smos te/ bud med kyi gzugs mdzes pa sogs dang khu ba 'phel ba ni bud med la 'dod chags dngos su skye ba'i rgyu ma yin te/ skyes bu khu ba mtshungs pa can dag gi nang nas bud med la dmigs na 'ga' zhig chags kyang 'ga' zhig sdang bar 'gyur bas skyes bu kun la 'dod chags skye bar ma nges pa'i phyir dang / 'dod chags can 'ga' zhig ni bud med kyi lus mdzes pa la chags pa'i nges pa med par gzugs ngan pa la 'dod chags spyod par 'byung ba'ang mthong ba'i phyir/ gzugs mdzes pa sogs chags pa'i rgyu ma yin la/ yang bud med la gtsang ba'i yon tan du mi 'dzin par mi gtsang bar so sor rtog pa'i yon tan dang ldan pa'i skyes bu de la rang 'dod chags skye bar 'gyur te/ dngos rgyu gzugs mdzes pa dang khu ba nye bar yod pa'i phyir ro/ /

It is not so that a woman's beautiful figure and so forth and an increase in semen are causes that actually produce desire, because among men with similar amounts of semen who focus on a woman, some feel lust and some feel aversion, thus it is not certain for every man that desire will arise. It is also because for some lustful men, it is not definite that they lust for a beautiful woman's body; it is also seen that they also act upon desire for ugly bodies. A beautiful figure and so forth are not the cause of lust. Additionally, it (lust) would also occur for those men who do not hold women to have the qualities of cleanliness but have the quality of perceiving them to be unclean, because the direct causes—a beautiful figure and semen—would be present.
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
gal te yon tan 'dzin de yang / / yan lag yin na/
157b If holding them as qualities were a factor,
zhes smos te/ gal te bud med kyi gzugs mdzes pa la yon tan du 'dzin pa de yang 'dod chags kyi lhan cig byed pa'i yan lag yin pas skyon med ce na/ bshad pa/
If you say that holding a woman's beautiful figure to be a quality is a cooperating factor for desire so there is no fault, to explain:
thams cad kyis/ / yon tan 'dzin pa can 'gyur te/ / rgyu la khyad par med phyir ro/ /
157cd Then all would hold them to be qualities Because there's no distinction in the cause.

zhes smos te/ bud med kyi gzugs mdzes pa mthong ba'i skyes bu thams cad kyis bud med kyi gzugs mdzes pa la yon tan du 'dzin pa can du 'gyur te/ bud med kyi gzugs mdzes pa la yon tan du 'dzin pa'i rgyu gzugs sam/ khu ba'am gzhan 'dod chags kyi rgyu nyid du bstan pa de nyid yod pa la khyad par med par mtshungs pa'i phyir ro zhes pa lha'i'o/ /

Then all men who see a woman's beautiful figure would hold that woman's beautiful figure to be a quality. This is because there is no distinction in the causes for holding a woman's beautiful body to be a quality—the body, semen, or others teaching it to be the cause of desire—themselves being comparably present. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
gsum pa rjes su 'gro ldog grub na ha cang thal ba ni/
iii. The absurd consequence if entailment and reverse entailment were proven
gnas skabs gang la chags can 'dod/ / de 'dra zhe sdang can mi 'gyur/ / de gnyis ngo bo mi mtshungs phyir/ / 'di la nges par mthong ba'ang med/ /
158. At times when someone is asserted to Be lustful, he would not be hostile since The essences of the two are disparate. That is not necessarily seen here either.

ces smos te/ gal te bad kan la sogs pa'i rang bzhin las 'dod chags sogs skye ba yin pa de'i tshe 'dod chags kyi dngos rgyu bad kan rgyun chags su yod pa'i gnas skabs gang yin pa'i skyes bu de 'dra ba de la 'dod chags rgyun chags su yod pa can du 'dod dgos pa'i phyir na/ zhe sdang can du mi 'gyur bar thal te/ 'dod chags dang zhe sdang de gnyis yul gcig la lhan cig tu dmigs pa'i ngo bo mi mtshungs pa'i phyir dang / bad kan can 'di la 'dod chags kho na dang ldan pa'i nges pa tshad mas mthong ba'ang med cing / res 'ga' zhe sdang dang phrag dog dang ser sna yang skye bar mthong ba'i phyir ro zhes pa lha'i'o/ / 'di la dus mtshungs pa nyid du nges par mthong ba ni med do zhes pa rgyan gyi'o/ /

If desire and so forth were to arise from the nature of phlegm and so forth, at times when the direct cause of desire, phlegm, were continually present, one would have to assert that a person in such a phase would be continually lustful. It would follow that he would not be hostile since the essences of the two—desire and hostility—are disparate and cannot focus on a single object simultaneously. It is not necessarily validly seen here that a phlegmatic person has only desire either, because it is seen that hatred, jealousy, and stinginess also arise periodically. This is according to Devendrabuddhi. Here Prajñākaragupta states, “Here they are not necessarily seen at the same time.”[185]
bzhi pa rtsod pa spang ba la/
iv. Rebutting criticism of that
gzhan dag na re/ khyed cag la'ang bad kan can gyi skyes bu'i rgyud la zhe sdang mi 'jug par thal ba mtshungs so zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others might say that the consequence that anger would not occur in a phlegmatic person's being is comparable for us as well. To explain:
gang gi 'dod chags la sogs pa/ / rigs mthun bag chags khyad par la/ / rag las pas ni 'jug 'gyur ba/ / de la skyon 'dir thal ba med/ /
159. Such faults are not a consequence For those to whom desire and such Engage dependent on distinctions In imprints that are the same class.

ces smos te/ sangs rgyas pa gang gi lugs la 'dod chags dang zhe sdang la sogs pa ni bdag dang bdag gir lta ba rigs mthun pa snga ma'i bag chags kyi khyad par la rag las pa ni 'jug cing skye bar 'gyur ba yin gyi/ bad kan la sogs pa las skye bar mi 'dod pa'i phyir/ chags sogs rang gi rigs mthun snga ma las skye ba de la bad kan can zhe sdang can du mi 'gyur ba'i skyon 'dir thal ba med do/ /

For those of the Buddhist tradition, desire, hatred, and such engage and arise dependent on distinctions in imprints that are of the previous instances' same class, the views of the self and mine. They do not assert that they arise from phlegm and so forth. For that reason, lust and so forth arise from previous instances of similar kind, and such faults as that phlegmatics would not get angry are not a consequence.
gsum pa 'byung ba las skye ba dgag pa la/
3. Refuting that desire and so forth arise from the elements.
chags sogs 'byung ba la brten pa dgag/ 'byung ba la brten par bshad pa'i dgongs pa/ de'i lan dgag pa'o/ /
This has three points: a. Refuting that desire and so forth are supported by the elements, b. The intent in explaining that they are supported by the elements, and c. Refuting the response.
dang po [chags sogs 'byung ba la brten pa dgag pa] la/
a. Refuting that desire and so forth are supported by the elements

tshu rol mdzes pa ba na re/ 'dod chags la sogs pa bad kan sogs las mi skye yang 'byung ba las skye ba yin te/ sa chu shas che ba las 'dod chags dang / me rlung las zhe sdang / chu rlung dag las gti mug skye ba'i phyir zhe na/ bshad pa/

The Cārvākas say that desire and so forth do not arise from phlegm and so forth but do arise from the elements, because desire arises from a predominance of earth and water, hatred from fire and air, and delusion from water and air. To explain:
'dis ni 'byung ba'i chos nyid bkag/ rten yang bkag pa nyid phyir ro/ /
160ab And this refutes an elemental nature, As the support as well has been disproven.

zhes smos te/ 'dod chags la sogs pa nyes pa las skye ba 'gog byed kyi rigs pa 'dis ni 'dod chags la sogs pa 'byung ba'i 'bras bu'i chos nyid yin par 'dod pa'ang bkag pa yin te/ sa sogs 'byung ba phan byed du yod med kyi rjes su 'gro ldog 'khrul ba'i phyir ro/ / rgyan ni/ gnas skabs gang la chags can 'dod/ / ces par bkag zin zhes so/ / rlung la sogs pa'i nyes pa ni 'byung ba'i rang bzhin yin pa'i phyir zhes lha'i'o/ / yod med dag la rten med phyir/ / zhes bya ba la sogs pas chags sogs 'byung ba la brten pa yang bkag pa nyid yin pa'i phyir ro zhes pa lha rgyan gnyis ka'i'o/ /

This logic that refutes that desire and so forth arise from the humors also refutes the assertion that the nature of desire and so forth is a result of the elements, because the entailment and reverse entailment with whether or not the sources such as earth are present as a beneficial factor is fallacious. Prajñākaragupta states that this has been refuted in the line, “At times when someone is asserted to / Be lustful...” Deven-drabuddhi says, “Because the nature of the humors of wind and so forth is the elements.”[186] Both Devendrabuddhi and Prajñākaragupta state that this is because “What is and what is not are not supported”[187] and so forth have also disproven that desire and so forth are supported by the elements.
la la na re/ ji ltar dkar po la sogs pa 'byung ba chen po la brten pa de bzhin du 'dod chags la sogs pa'ang yin no zhe na/ bshad pa/
Some might say that just as whiteness and so forth are supported by the elements, so too are desire and so forth. To explain:
dkar po la sogs sa sogs la/ / brten pa nyid ni ma yin no/ /
160cd Whiteness and so forth are not Supported by earth and so forth.

zhes smos te/ 'di ltar dkar po la sogs pa'i 'byung ba las gyur pa'i gzugs rnams ni sa la sogs pa'i 'byung ba rnams la mi 'jig par gnas pa'i tshul gyis brten pa nyid ni ma yin te/ 'byung ba las skyes pa yin pa'i phyir zhes pa lha'i'o/ / rgyan ni/ de'i tshe gzugs la sogs pa 'byung ba gang la tha dad par khas blangs pas rten dang brten pa'i ngo bor mi 'gyur ro/ / zhes so/ /

In this way, whiteness and so forth—forms that are derived from the elements—are not supported in the manner of remaining without perishing by the elements of earth and so forth, because they arise out of the elements. This is according to Devendrabuddhi. Prajñākaragupta states that one would have accepted that form and so forth are separate from the elements, so they are not supporter and supported in nature.[188]
gnyis pa 'byung ba la brten par bshad pa'i dgongs pa la/
b. The intent in explaining that they are supported by the elements
la la dag na re/ 'o na ji ltar na 'byung ba chen po rgyur byas pas zhes tha snyad du byed ce na/ bshad pa/
Some might wonder how the convention “on the basis of the great elements” could be used. To explain:
de rten sgra yang rgyu don nam/ / yang na rang gi rten dag dang / / dbyer med par ni gnas pa'i phyir/ / rten yin gzhan du 'thad ma yin/ /
161. The expression “on the basis of” means cause, Or else since they exist inseparably From their supports, they are supports. It otherwise would not be logical.[189]

ces smos te/ gzugs la sogs pa'i 'byung ba las gyur pa de 'byung ba las brten par bshad pa'i sgra'am/ lung yang 'byung ba de gzugs sogs grub zin gnas pa'i rten du ston pa ma yin gyi/ rgyu'i don du ston pa yin nam/ yang na 'byung gyur rang dang dus mnyam pa'i rang gi rten 'byung ba dag dang dbyer med par ni gnas pa'i phyir/ 'byung gyur ni rang gi rten 'byung ba dang rten dang brten par 'thad pa yin la/ 'dod chags la sogs pa ni gzhan 'byung gyur bzhin du rten dang brten par 'thad pa ma yin no/ /

The expressions or scriptures that explain that form and so forth that are derived from the elements are on the basis of the elements do not teach that the elements are supports for form and so forth to persist. after being created. Instead, they mean causes, or else that they (the elementally derived[190]) exist inseparably from the elements that are their supports and simultaneous with them. For that reason, it is tenable to say that the elementally derived and their support—the elements—are supporter and supported. But it would not be logical to say otherwise that desire and so forth are supporter or supported, unlike the elementally derived.
gsum pa de'i lan dgag pa la/
c. Refuting the response
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
gal te myos sogs nus pa bzhin/ / dbyer yod ce na/
162ab “Just like the potency to intoxicate And such, it's separable.”

zhes smos te/ gal te chang dang chang gi myos pa'i nus pa gnyis rten dang brten pa ma yin kyang / chang tsha bar gyur pa las chang gi rdzas ldog pa med du zin kyang chang gi myos pa'i nus pa ldog pas de dag dbyer yod pa bzhin du 'dir yang rtags ma nges pa yin no zhe na/ ma nges pa ma yin te/ 'di ltar/

If you say that though beer and the potency to intoxicate are not supporter and supported, heating beer may not destroy the substance of the beer but does destroy its intoxicating potency, so they are separable. Similarly the evidence here is indeterminate, you say. It is not indeterminate. It is thus:
dngos po las/ / nus pa don gzhan nyid ma yin/ / dngos po 'jig 'gyur rten tshang bar/ / gnas na brten pa 'jig ma yin/ /
162b-d The potency Is not an object other than the thing. When a thing perishes, if the support 163a Remains intact, the supported does not perish.

ces smos te/ chang gi rdzas gnas kyang nus pa ldog pa de ni ma yin te/ chang gi dngos po las chang gi nus pa don gzhan nyid ma yin la/ brten pa chang gi nus pa zhig nas rten chang gi dngos po 'jig par 'gyur zhing / rten chang gi dngos po tshang bar gnas shing ma zhig na brten pa chang gi nus pa de'ang 'jig pa ma yin pa'i phyir/ de dag dbyer med 'bral mi rung du gnas pa'i phyir ro zhes pa rgyan gyi'o/ /

It is not so that the substance of the beer remains while its potency is destroyed. The potency of beer is not another object than the thing that is beer. When the supported (the potency of the beer) perishes, the support (the thing beer) also perishes, and if the support (the thing beer) remains intact and does not perish, the supported (the potency of the beer) also does not perish. For that reason, they exist indivisibly, unable to be divided. This is according to Prajñākaragupta.
de la gzhan dag na re/
Others say with regard to this:
gal te de mtshungs zhe na/
163b If you say this is similar,
gal te chang dang myos pa'i nus pa dbyer med pa de dang mtshungs par 'byung ba dang / 'dod chags la sogs pa'i sems las byung ba dag kyang dbyer med do zhe na/ bshad pa/
If you say that similarly to how beer and its intoxicating potency are inseparable, the elements and mental factors such as desire are also inseparable, to explain:
min/ / snang ba tha dad can rtogs pas/ / 'byung sems tha dad nyid phyir ro/ /
163b-d not so. Perceived with separate appearances, The elements and mind are separate.

zhes smos te/ chang dang chang gi myos byed kyi nus pa dbyer med pa de ltar du 'byung ba dang sems dbyer med du mtshungs pa ma yin te/ 'byung ba dag las sems mtshan nyid tha dad pa nyid kyi phyir dang / snang ba tha dad pa can gyi shes pa ma 'khrul bas tha dad du rtogs pa'i phyir zhes pa lha'i'o/ /

It is not so that similar to beer and its potential to intoxicate, the elements and mind are inseparable, because the elements and mind have separate characteristics and because they are perceived separately by unmistaken cognitions with separate appearances. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
gnyis pa lus dang rnam pa mtshungs pa'i rtags kyis sgrub pa la/
(ii) Proving the aggregates are samsara through the evidence that the mind’s aspects would be similar to the body’s
ji srid lus ni 'gyur bar du/ / gzugs sogs bzhin du yid ngo bo/ / mtshungs 'gyur/
164a-c Until the body changed, the essence of The mind would still remain the same, like form, Et cetera.

zhes smos te/ sems ni lus la brten par gyur pa de'i tshe ji srid lus ni g.yo 'gul la sogs pa rnam pa gzhan du 'gyur gyi bar du yid blo'i ngo bo mi g.yo zhing 'gyur ba med par mtshungs par 'gyur te/ lus can dngos su brten pa'i phyir/ dper na g.yo 'gul med na de'i gzugs sogs la g.yo 'gul med pa bzhin no/ /

If the mind were supported by the body, until the body changed to another aspect such as moving and so forth, the essence of the mental mind would still remain the same without changing or moving, because it is directly supported by the physical. As an analogy, it is like how when someone does not move, their form et cetera do not move.
gal te lus la dngos su rten yang de'i tshe yul gzhan dang gzhan la rag las nas yid blo khyad par du gyur pa la skyon med ce na/ bshad pa/
If you say it is actually supported by the body, but at that time dependent upon other objects and other things, there are differences in mind, so there is no fault, to explain:
rnam par rtog pa ni/ / don gyi gzhan dbang can nyid gang / /
164cd And how is it that thoughts Could be dependent on an object

zhes smos te/ yid kyi rnam par rtog pa ni yul phyi rol don gyi gzhan dbang gis 'gyur ba can nyid gang las yin te/ yul la bltos pa med par bag chags sad pa tsam las skyes pa'i phyir ro zhes pa lha rgyan gnyis ka'i'o/ /

How is it that mental thoughts could change in dependence on an external object, because they arise from the mere awakening of imprints independent of the object? This is according to both Devendrabuddhi and Prajñākaragupta.
skyon de khyod nyid la'ang mtshungs so zhe na/ bshad pa/
If you say the same fault applies to us, to explain:
gang tshe lus la bltos med par/ / shes pa 'ga' zhig 'ga' zhig gi/ bag chags sad pa'i rgyur gyur pa/ / des na 'ga' zhig las 'ga' yin/ /
165. When independent of the body Some cognitions have as a cause The awakening of the imprints of some? Therefore some arise from some.

ces smos te/ rnam par rtog pa yul la g.yo ba gang gi tshe rten lus g.yo 'gul la bltos pa med par 'jug pa'i rnam par shes pa 'ga' zhig ni lus 'gyur ba med kyang g.yo bar mi 'gal te/ g.yo ba'i shes pa 'ga' zhig gi bag chags sad pa'i rgyur gyur pa las g.yo bar 'jug pa'i shes pa yin pa'i phyir/ des na nye bar len pa'i phung po lnga po 'khor bar grub pa yin te/ rnam par shes pa 'ga' zhig gi nyer len las rnam par shes pa 'ga' zhig skye ba yin gyi/ lus las skye ba ma yin pa'i phyir ro zhes pa rgyan gyi'o/ /

When thoughts move toward an object, some consciousnesses that engage independent of the movement of the support—the body— move even though the body does not change. This is not contradictory, because they are consciousnesses that move and engage from the cause that is the awakening of the imprints of some moving cognitions. Therefore it is proven that the five aggregates of grasping are samsara, because there are some consciousnesses that arise from the substantial cause of some consciousnesses but do not arise from the body. This is according to Prajñākaragupta.
gsum pa rnam shes min pas rnam shes kyi nyer len mi byed pa'i rtags kyis sgrub pa la/
(iii) Proving samsara through the evidence that what is not consciousness is not the substantial cause of consciousness
rnam shes min pa rnam shes kyi/ / nyer len min pa'i phyir yang grub/ /
166ab Nonconsciousness is not the substantial cause Of consciousness, so it is also proven.

ces smos te/ skyes bu skyes ma thag pa'i rnam par shes pa ni rang dang rigs mthun pa'i rnam par shes pa snga ma sngon du song ba can yin te/ nyer len can gyi rnam par shes pa yin pa'i phyir te/ rnam par shes pa min pa'i lus la sogs pa ni rnam shes kyi nyer len du rung ba ma yin pa'i phyir/ yang zhes pa'i sgras ni lus la sogs pa'i rgyu can yin na/ 'dod chags la sogs pa cig car thal ba'i phyir yang 'khor ba snga phyi yod par grub bo zhes lha rgyan gnyis ka'i'o/ /

The consciousness of a person who has just been born is preceded by an earlier consciousness of the same kind, because it is consciousness with a substantial cause. This is because the body and so forth that are not consciousness are not appropriate to be the substantial cause of consciousness. The word “also” means that if they had the body and so forth as a cause, desire and so forth would consequentially occur simultaneously, so previous and later samsara is also proven. This is according to both Devendrabuddhi and Prajñākaragupta.
la la dag na re/
Some might say:
gal te dngos po thams cad ni/ / rnam shes nus ldan phyir 'dod na/ /
166cd If you assert that all things are endowed With a capacity for consciousness,

zhes smos te/ gal te dngos po thams cad ni rnam par shes pa'i nus pa dang ldan pa mi gsal ba'i tshul du yod pa'i phyir/ rnam shes min pa las rnam par shes pa mi 'byung ba zhes bshad pa gang yin pa de kho bo cag kyang 'dod pas grub pa la sgrub pa'o zhe na/ bshad pa/

If you say, “All things are endowed with a capacity for consciousness that is present in an unapparent manner. For that reason, we also agree with the explanation that consciousness does not arise from nonconsciousness, so that is trying to prove what has been proven.” To explain:
rtswa sogs rtse na glang chen brgya/ / sngon tshe ma mthong yod do zhes/ / de skad grangs can phyugs las gzhan/ / ngo mtshar bcas pa su brjod rtsol/ /
167. Other than a Sāṃkhya ox, What modest[191] person would attempt To say there were on a blade of grass One hundred elephants not seen before?

zhes smos te/ sems dang glang po che mngon par gsal ba can ma yin pa'i 'byung ba dang rtswa sogs rnams las de nus pa'i ngo bor gnas par 'dod pa'i sems dang glang po che gang yin pa de mngon par gsal ba'i gnas skabs kyi sems dang glang po che gang yin pa de nyid yin nam/ 'on te gzhan nyid yin/ phyi ma ltar na gzhan yod pas de yod par rigs pa ma yin no/ / mngon par gsal ba'i gnas skabs kyi sems dang glang po che de nyid yin ce na/ rtswa mchog gi rtse na 'bras bu glang chen brgya sngon rgyu'i tshe na gsal bar ma mthong bzhin nus pa'i ngo bor yod do zhes de skad smra ba ni grangs can rang nyid phyugs dang 'dra ba'i blun po ngo tsha med pa'i khas len yin na/ de las gzhan rtog ge pa thams cad kyi gtsug gi nor bur bdag nyid rlom zhing ngo tsha dang bcas pa'i rgyang 'phen pa su zhig brjod pa la 'bad rtsol byed de byed par mi rigs so/ / gal te de dag yod na rang gi ngo bo dmigs par 'gyur ro/ /

Are the cognition and elephants asserted to exist as the essence of the capacity for such in the elements and grass that have unapparent cognition and elephants the same as or different from the cognition and elephants during the phase when they are apparent?[192] If it is the latter, since they are other, it is illogical for them to be present. If you say that they are the same as the cognition and elephants during the apparent phase, to say that there exist on a blade of grass the result— one hundred elephants—as the essence of capacity, though not clearly seen before during the time of the cause, is the immodest assertion of the Sāṃkhyas, who are as stupid as oxen. Other than them, what modest Cārvāka who imagines himself to be the crown jewel of intellectuals would attempt to say that? It is illogical to try. If they existed, their essence would be observed.
de bas na/
Therefore:
rgyu ni lan brgyar rnam phye yang / / ngo bo gang zhig snang gyur pa'i/ / ngo bo de ni sngar mi snang / / ji ltar de ni yod par 'gyur/ /
168. Any essence that appears, That essence did not appear before. Dissect the cause one hundred times, But how could it exist?

zhes smos te/ rgyu'i gnas skabs su rtswa dang 'byung ba ni lan brgyar blos ci tsam du rnam par phye zhing brtags na yang sems dang glang chen gyi ngo bo gang zhig yod na snang rung du gyur pa'i sems dang glang chen gyi ngo bo de ni sngar rgyu'i dus su mi snang ba'i phyir na/ ji ltar na sems dang glang chen gyi ngo bo de ni yod par 'gyur zhes lha rgyan gnyis ka'i'o/ /

Though one might mentally dissect and analyze grass and the elements one hundred times during the causal phase, if any essence of cognition or elephants existed, it would be able to appear, but that essence of a cognition or an elephant did not appear before during the time of the cause. For that reason, how is it that that essence of cognition or an elephant could exist? This is according to both Devendrabud-dhi and Prajñākaragupta.
bzhi pa skye ba snga ma med na ha cang thal ba la/
(iv) The absurd consequence if there were no past lives.
'gog byed kyi rigs pa dngos bshad pa/ de la rtsod pa spang ba/ dpe nyid mi 'thad pa/ chags sogs res 'ga' ba ma yin par thal ba'o/ /

This has four topics: A. Explaining the actual argument of the refutation, B. Refuting criticism of it, C. The untenability of the analogy, and D. The consequence that desire and so forth would not be occasional.
dang po ['gog byed kyi rigs pa dngos bshad pa] ni/
A. Explaining the actual argument of the refutation
snga na med pa 'byung ba la/ / chags sogs nges med thal bar 'gyur/ /
169ab It follows greed and such would be uncertain When those who didn't exist before arise.

zhes smos te/ gal te 'jig rten pha rol med par gyur pa de'i tshe rgyu snga na med pa'i sems can gyi lus kho na las chags sogs 'byung bar 'gyur la/ de ltar yin na sems can rnams chags sogs dang bcas te skye ba'i nges pa med par thal bar 'gyur la/ 'ga' zhig dang po nas 'dod chags dang bral bar yang 'gyur ro zhes rgyan gyis so/ /

If there were no next world, then greed and such would arise only from the cause, the bodies of sentient beings who did not exist before. If that were so, it would follow that it would be uncertain whether they would be born with greed and such. Some would also be free of desire from the first. This is according to Prajñākaragupta.
de la gzhan dag na re/
Others respond:
'byung ba'i bdag las ma 'das phyir/ / gal te kun chags sogs ldan na/ /
169cd If all had greed and such because they don't Transcend the character of the elements,
zhes smos te/ gal te sems can kun rgyu 'byung ba'i bdag nyid las ma 'das pa'i phyir/ 'dod chags dang zhe sdang la sogs pa dang ldan pas chags bral sogs mi srid ce na/ bshad pa/

If you say that because all sentient beings do not transcend the character of the elements, they would all have greed, hatred, and such, and thus freedom from attachment and so forth are impossible, to explain:
thams cad 'dod chags mtshungs par 'gyur/ /
170a Then all would have identical desire.

zhes smos te/ 'o na ni sems can thams cad 'dod chags dang zhe sdang la sogs pa che chung mtshungs par 'gyur te/ dngos rgyu 'byung ba mtshungs par yod pa'i phyir ro zhes rgyan gyi'o/ / lha dbang blo ni skyes bu 'byung ba'i bdag nyid las ma 'das pa ste/ de ltar na yang 'di yi kha dog dang dbyibs dang dbang po la sogs pa che chung mi mtshungs par 'gyur ro/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

Then all sentient beings would have identical degrees of desire, hatred and so forth, because the direct cause—the elements—is identically present. This is according to Prajñākaragupta. Devendrabuddhi states that even were people not to transcend the character of the elements, their color, shape, faculties, and so forth are dissimilar in size.[193]
kha cig na re/
Some might say:
gal te 'byung khyad las yin na/ /
170b “Not so, due to distinctions in the elements,”
zhes smos te/ gal te rgyu 'byung ba 'phel 'grib kyi khyad par las 'dod chags la sogs pa che chung mi mtshungs pa yin ce na/ bshad pa/
If you were to say that the different degrees of desire and so forth are due to distinctions in the increase or decrease of the cause, the elements, to explain:[194]
'byung rnams srog chags khyad med kyang / / khyad par 'di rten gang yin pa/ / de ni phul byung 'grib pa bzhin/ / de yod pa las de med 'gyur/ /
170cd In terms of living, there's no difference In the elements, and yet as the support 171ab For this distinction grows or else decreases, They'd go from having those to lacking them.

zhes smos te/ 'byung ba'i khyad par las chags sogs che chung tha dad du yod par mi rung ste/ khyod kyi lugs la 'byung ba rnams la srog chags dang / ches srog chags dang / ches shin tu srog chags la sogs pa'i khyad par med kyang / 'dod chags dang / ches 'dod chags dang / ches shin tu 'dod chags la sogs pa'i khyad par 'di rten du gyur pa'i 'byung ba gang yin pa de ni nyer len 'byung ba phul du byung zhing 'grib pa na/ 'bras bu chags sogs kyang phul du byung zhing 'grib par 'dod pa bzhin du sngar 'dod chags la sogs pa de yod pa las/ phyis de med pa'i sems can srid par 'gyur te/ rgyu 'phel 'grib kyi rjes su 'gro ldog byed cing 'bral rung yin pa'i phyir/

It is not logical that different degrees of desire and so forth would come from differences in the elements. In your tradition, there is no difference in the elements in terms of alive, very alive, and extremely alive, but there is a distinction between desirous, very desirous, and extremely desirous. As the elements that are the support for this distinction—the elements that are the substantial cause—grow or else decrease, the resultant desire and so forth would also increase and decrease. According to this assertion, it would be possible that they (sentient beings) would go from having those (desire and so forth) ear- lier to lacking them later, because desire and so forth would be entailed or reverse entailed by the increase or decrease of the cause and thus eliminable.
gnyis pa de la rtsod pa spang ba la/
B. Refuting criticism of it
la la dag na re/
Others say:
gal te chags sogs tha dad kyang / / rgyu mtshungs bdag nyid mi ldog phyir/ / min na/
171cd If it's not so since although separate, The causes of greed and such have the same nature, 172a Which has not ceased,

zhes smos te/ gal te 'dod chags la sogs pa 'phel 'grib tha dad kyang / de'i rgyu kun la mtshungs par rjes su 'gro ba'i 'byung ba spyi tsam gyi bdag nyid mi ldog pa'i phyir/ 'dod chags sogs gtan zad pa'i skyes bu'am 'byung ba yod pa ma yin te/ 'byung ba rtag par yod pa'i phyir ro zhe na/ bshad pa/

If you say that although their increase and decrease of greed and such may be separate, because their causes—the mere universal nature of the elements that are entailed by them all in the same way—have not ceased, it is not so that there could be a person or elements that have exhausted desire and so forth forever, to explain:
bdag nyid 'dra rgyu'i phyir/ / kun la 'dod chags 'dra bar 'gyur/ /
172ab because the causes are like In character, all would have like desire.

zhes smos te/ 'o na ni 'dod chags che chung gi bdag nyid du 'dra ba'i rgyu 'byung ba rtag pa las skyes pa'i chags can du mtshungs pa'i phyir na skyes bu kun las 'dod chags che chung 'dra bar 'gyur ro/ /

Well then, because they are all the same in being desirous people born from the cause that is like in the character of the degree of desire— permanent elements—all people would have like degrees of desire.
de'i dpe bstan pa'i phyir/
To give an analogy for this:
mtshungs bdag las byung ba lang gi/ shes pa'am 'dir yang sa sogs la/ / srog chags nyid sogs khyad par gyi/ / rim pa la lar yod ma yin/ /
172cd There are not any degrees of distinction In the perception of cow, which arises 173ab From the same nature, or in livingness, Et cetera, in earth and so forth here.

ces smos te/ dper na grangs can pas ba lang zhes pa de la ba lang dang / ches ba lang dang / ches shin tu ba lang zhes bya ba'i khyad par gsum med de/ ba lang gi shes pa'i rgyu mtshungs pa'i bdag nyid ba lang nyid las byung ba'i phyir zhes pa'am/ rgyang 'phen pa'i grub pa'i mtha' 'dir yang srog chags kyi 'byung ba sa sogs la srog chags dang / ches srog chags dang / ches shin tu srog chags nyid do zhes khyad par gyi rim pa la lar yod pa ma yin te/ rgyu 'byung ba mtshungs pa las skyes pa'i phyir ches 'dod pa bzhin no/ /

As an analogy, the Sāṃkhyas say that when one says “cow,” there are not three distinctions of “cow,” “very cow,” and “extremely cow,” because it arises from the nature of the same cause of the perception of a cow, cowness. Or here in the Cārvāka school, there are not any degrees of distinction between living, very living, or extremely living in the elements earth and so forth of living creatures, because they arise from the same cause, the elements, like extreme desire.
gsum pa dpe nyid mi 'thad pa la/
C. The untenability of the analogy.
dpe mi mtshungs pa'i rgyu mtshan/ 'byung gzugs dang mi mtshungs pa'i rgyu mtshan no/ /
This has two points: 1. The reasons it is not the same as the analogy, and 2. The reason it is not the same as the elements and form.
dang po [dpe mi mtshungs pa'i rgyu mtshan] la/
1. The reasons it is not the same as the analogy
la la dag na re/
Some say:
dro rim khyad par yod na yang / / dro med me 'ga' yod min pa/ / de bzhin 'dir yang zhe na/
173cd If you should say, “There are degrees of heat, But there's no fire that's without heat. Here, too, 174a It is the same,”

zhes smos te/ me la drod dang / ches drod dang / ches shin tu dro ba'i rim pa'i khyad par yod na yang dro ba gtan nas med pa'i me 'ga' yang yod pa ma yin pa de bzhin du sa la sogs pa 'dir yang 'dod chags la sogs pa che chung gi rim pa yod kyang / 'dod chags la sogs pa gtan med pa'i skyes bu mi srid par mtshungs so zhe na/ bshad pa/

If you should say, “There are degrees of heat in fire—hot, very hot, and extremely hot—but there is no fire that is entirely without heat. Here, too, there are degrees of desire in earth and so forth, but it is impossible for there to be a person who entirely lacks desire and so forth, so it is the same.” To explain:
min/ / dro las me gzhan bkag phyir ro/ /
174ab it is not so because It's been disproven fire is other than heat.
zhes smos te/ dpe de ni don dang mtshungs pa min te/ 'dod chags la sogs pa ni lus las 'bral rung gi rdzas tha dad yin la/ 'dir dro ba las me 'bral rung gi rdzas gzhan tshad mas bkag pa'i phyir ro/ /

That analogy is not the same as the meaning. Desire and so forth are a separate substance from the body and can be removed, but here it has been validly disproven that fire is a different, other substance than heat that can be separated from it.
dpe don mi mtshungs pa de bas na/
Because the analogy is not similar to the meaning:
gang zhig gzhan yod yon tan ni/ / khyad par rim pa dang ldan pa/ / de dag de yi khyad par ni/ / la lar chad 'gyur dkar sogs bzhin/ /
174cd When something has qualities that are other And that have a distinction in degree, 175ab Some of those—its features—in some cases Can be removed, like whiteness and so forth.

zhes smos te/ gang zhig srog chags sam sa la sogs pa las don gzhan 'bral rung du yod pa'i yon tan ni 'phel 'grib kyi khyad par gyi rim pa dang ldan pa'i phyir na/ 'dod chags la sogs pa de dag ni srog chags sam sa la sogs pa de yis la lar rgyun chad pa srid par 'gyur te/ dper na snam bu'i kha dog dkar po la sogs pa bzhin no zhes pa rgyan gyis so/ /

When something—a living being, earth, or so forth—has qualities that are other objects which can be removed and that have a distinction of degree of increase or decrease, it is possible that some of those (desire and so forth), which are its features, can be removed and stopped in some cases. For example, it is like the white color of a blanket and so forth. This is according to Prajñākaragupta.
gnyis pa 'byung gzugs dang mi mtshungs pa'i rgyu mtshan ni/
2. The reason it is not the same as the elements and form

kha cig na re/ snga na med pa 'byung ba la zhes pa'i rtags ma nges pa yin te/ gzugs dang dri ro sogs 'byung ba kho na'i chos yin na yang de dag gtan pa'i 'byung ba mi srid pa bzhin no zhe na/ bshad pa/

Some say that the evidence “It follows greed and such would be uncertain...”[195] is indeterminate because form, scent, taste, and so forth are predicates of the elements only, but it is impossible for the elements to always be them. To explain:
gzugs sogs bzhin du nges min te/ / de dag 'byung dang dbyer med phyir/ /
175cd They are not definite like form and such, Which are inseparable from the elements.

zhes smos te/ 'dod chags la sogs pa ni gzugs dang dri ro sogs 'byung ba la gnas pa bzhin du srog chags sam 'byung ba la nges par gnas pa min te/ gzugs sogs de dag 'byung ba dang dbyer med de 'bral mi shes pa yin la/ de srog chags sam 'byung ba don gzhan 'bral rung yin pa'i phyir/

They (desire and so forth) are not definitely present in living creatures or the elements, unlike form, scent, taste and such being present in the elements. Form and so forth are inseparable from the elements and cannot be removed from them, but desire and so forth are other objects that can be removed from living creatures or the elements.
kha cig na re/
Some say:
gal te de mtshungs zhe na/
176a If you say it's the same,
zhes smos te/ gal te gzugs dang dri ro sogs 'byung ba dang dbyer med yin pa de dang mtshungs par 'dod chags la sogs pa yang srog chags sam 'byung ba dang dbyer med pa yin no zhe na/ bshad pa/
If you say that it is the same as how form, scent, taste, and so forth are inseparable from the elements, desire and so forth are inseparable from living beings or the elements, then to explain:
min/ / chags sogs lhan cig skye thal phyir/ /
176ab it's not, because Desire and such would occur at the same time.
zhes smos te/ de yang bden pa min te/ gzugs dang dri ro sogs lhan cig skye ba bzhin du 'dod chags dang zhe sdang dang phrag dog la sogs pa yang lhan cig tu skye bar thal ba'i phyir ro/ /
That as well is not true, because it would follow that just as form, scent, taste, and so forth all arise at the same time, desire, hatred, jealousy, and such would also all arise at the same time.
gal te yul thag nye ba la bltos nas skye ba'i phyir 'dod chags la sogs lhan cig skye bar thal ba'i skyon med ce na/ bshad pa/
If you say that desire and so forth arise in dependence upon the proximity of the object, so there is no fault that they would arise simultaneously, to explain:
rnam par brtags pa yul yin phyir/ / yul yang nges byed ma yin no/ /
176cd Because the object is conceptual, The object also is not definite.

zhes smos te/ 'di ltar 'dod chags la sogs pa ni yul mi mdzes pa la yang ma thos par rnam par rtog pas sgro btags pa yul du byas te skye ba yin pa'i phyir/ yul mdzes pa la dmigs nas nges pa kho nar skye bar byed pa ma yin no/ /

Desire and so forth are not unheard of for unattractive objects; they take a conceptual projection as their object and arise. Because of this, it is not definite that they will only arise when focused on an attractive object.
bzhi pa chags sogs res 'ga' ma yin par thal ba ni/
D. The consequence that desire and so forth would not be occasional
skal mnyam rgyu dang bral ba'i phyir/ / chags sogs nges pa med pa'am/ / rgyu ni nye phyir blo rnams kun/ / thams cad kun tshe skye bar 'gyur/ /
177. From the cause of same status being absent, Desire and so forth are not definite, Or due to the cause always being present, All cognitions always would arise.

zhes smos te/ gang gi phyir skal mnyam gyi rgyu rang gi rigs 'dra snga ma las skye ba dang bral ba de'i phyir 'dod chags la sogs pa ni res 'ga' skye ba'i nges pa med pa'am/ yang na 'byung ba tsam gyi nyer len las skye ba yin na'ang 'dod chags la sogs pa'i blo rnams kun yul dus gnas skabs thams cad kun gyi tshe skye bar 'gyur te/ de ltar skye ba'i rgyu 'byung ba'i lus ni rtag tu nye bar yod pa'i phyir ro/ / de'i phyir/ goms las 'dod chags sogs gsal ba/ / mthong phyir/ zhes bya ba la sogs pa sngar bshad pa'i gtan tshigs thams cad kyis 'khor ba can gyi nye bar len pa'i phung po lnga po sdug bsngal du grub pa yin no zhes pa lha shAka gnyis ka'i'o/ /

From the cause of same status—arising from a previous instance of the same kind—being absent, desire and so forth are intermittent and have no definite arising. Or alternatively, were they to arise from the substantial cause of just the elements, all cognitions of desire and so forth would always arise for all objects, in all times, and on all occasions due to the cause for them to arise—the body that is the elements— always being present. For that reason, the reasons explained above such as “It's seen habituation intensifies / Desire and so forth...”[196] all prove that the five samsaric aggregates of grasping are suffering. This is according to both Devendrabuddhi and Śākyabuddhi.
gsum pa de'i rnam pa bshad pa la/
(c) Explaining its aspects.
mi rtag pa'i rnam pa/ sdug bsngal gyi rnam pa/ stong pa'i rnam pa/ bdag med pa'i rnam pa bshad pa'o/ /
This has four points: (i) An explanation of the aspect impermanence, (ii) The aspect suffering, (iii) The aspect emptiness, and (iv) The aspect selflessness.
dang po [mi rtag pa'i rnam pa] ni/
(i) An explanation of the aspect impermanence
de ni res 'ga' dmigs pa'i phyir/ / mi rtag
178ab It is impermanent as it's observed Occasionally
ces smos te/ nye bar len pa'i phung po lnga po de ni res 'ga' skye bar dmigs pa'i phyir mi rtag pa yin no/ /
As they[197] (the five aggregates of grasping) are observed to arise occasionally, they are impermanent.
gnyis pa sdug bsngal gyi rnam pa ni/
(ii) The aspect suffering
nyes pa'i rten phyir dang / / rgyu dbang phyir yang sdug bsngal yin/ /
178bc and suffering from being A support for faults and controlled by causes, too.

ces smos te/ de bzhin du phung po lnga po ni 'dod chags la sogs nyes pa rnams kyi rten yin pa'i phyir dang / rgyu'i stobs gzhan dbang dag gis zag pa dang bcas par 'byung ba'i phyir dang / yang gi sgras goms pa tsam la brten pa'i phyir sdug bsngal ba yin te/ gzhan dag thams cad sdug bsngal ba yin ces pa'i tshul gyis so zhes pa rgyan gyi'o/ /

Similarly, because the five aggregates are the support for faults such as desire, because they occur defiled, controlled by and under the power of causes, and because (as the word “too” indicates) they depend on mere habituation, they are suffering, as said in the verse “Others' control is always suffering.” This is according to Prajñākaragupta.[198]
gsum pa stong pa'i rnam pa dang / bzhi pa bdag med pa'i rnam pa ni/
(iii) The aspect emptiness and (iv) The aspect selflessness
bdag min byin gyis brlabs pa'ang min/ / rgyu min byin gyis rlob pa min/ /
178d Not self, nor taken into control either.

ces smos te/ 'di ltar nyer len gyi phung po lnga ni bdag min te/ gang gi phyir mi rtag pa dang gzhan dbang nyid yin pa de'i phyir gang zag gis stong pa yin te/ rtag pa'i bdag gis byin gyis brlabs pa'i bdag gi ba'ang ma yin pa'i phyir/ des na phung po bdag dang gcig dang tha dad gang du'ang med pa ni stong pa'i rnam pa yin la/ gcig tu med pa ni bdag med pa'i rnam pa'o/ / gzhan yang bdag ni phung po'i rgyu ma yin te/ phung po byin gyis rlob par byed pa po ma yin pa'i phyir/

179a Not cause, and not the one who takes control. The five aggregates of grasping are not a self, because they are impermanent and under another's control. Therefore, they are empty of being an individual's, because they are not something of mine that is taken into the control of a permanent self either. Therefore, the aggregates not being the same as or different from the self in any way is the aspect of emptiness. Not being the same is the aspect of selflessness. Additionally, the self is not the cause of the aggregates, because it is not the one who takes control of the aggregates.
gal te gtan tshigs ma grub bo zhe na/ bshad pa/
If you say the reasons are not proven, to explain:
rtag pa'ang ji ltar skyed byed yin/ /
179b How could the permanent be a producer?

ces smos te/ gtan tshigs ma grub pa ni ma yin te/ bdag rtag pa'ang ji ltar na phung po'i skyed byed yin te/ rtag pa la phan 'dogs pa'i bya ba med pa'i phyir zhes skabs gzhan du bshad zin pa'i phyir zhes lha'i'o/ / des na rgyu gcig las 'bras bu skye bar mi rigs so zhes bstan pa'i phyir/

The reasons are not unproven. How could a permanent self be the producer of the aggregates, since the permanent can perform no beneficial action, as has been explained at another point? This is according to Devendrabuddhi. Therefore to teach that it is illogical for a result to arise from a single cause:
de phyir gcig las du ma ni/ / dus tha dad par skye mi 'gyur/ /
179cd And for that reason, multiple will not Arise from one at separate times.

zhes smos te/ gang gi phyir bdag rtag pa rgyu ma yin pa de'i phyir/ bdag rtag pa gcig pu las phung po du ma ni dus snga phyi tha dad par skye bar mi 'gyur ro/ / de ltar ma yin na phung po cig car kho nar skye bar 'gyur te/ rtag tu rgyu ma tshang ba med par yod pa'i phyir ro/ / rigs pa gzhan yang /

Because a permanent self is not the cause, for that reason, multiple aggregates will not arise from one single, permanent self at separate earlier or later times. If it were otherwise, the aggregates would only arise simultaneously, because the causes would always be present, never incomplete. An additional logic:
rgyu gzhan dag ni tshogs na yang / / 'bras bu skye ba med pa'i phyir/ / rgyu gzhan rjes su dpog 'gyur na/ / de ni rtag rnams la yod min/ /
180. Even if other causes are assembled, Results do not arise, and for that reason One can infer that there are other causes. This is not present in the permanent.

ces smos te/ 'di ltar rgyu ma tshang na 'bras bu mi 'byung ba ni dper na mig shes kyi rgyu gzhan mig dbang dang yid byed dag ni tshogs na'ang dmigs rkyen gzugs ma tshang na 'bras bu mig shes skye ba med pa'i phyir/ mig shes skye ba la dbang yid las rgyu gzhan dmigs rkyen gzugs kyang tshang dgos par dpog nus par 'gyur na/ rgyu phan 'dogs byed du yod med kyi rjes su 'bras bu 'gro ldog byed pa de ni rgyu dag rtag pa dang / 'bras bu phung po rnams la yod pa ma yin no/ / de bzhin du rna ba dang sna dang lce la sogs pa'i dbang po lhag ma dang sgra sogs yul rnams la sbyar ro zhes lha'i'o/ /

If the causes are not complete, the result does not arise. For example, even when the other causes of an eye consciousness—the eye faculty and attention—are assembled, if the objective condition form is not present, the result—eye consciousness—does not arise. For that reason, one can infer that for an eye consciousness to arise, there is a cause other than the faculty and mind that must also be present, the objective condition form. When the cause is present or not as a beneficial factor, the result is entailed or reverse entailed, and this is not present with permanent causes and the result, the aggregates. This can similarly be applied to the remaining faculties—the ear, nose, tongue, and so forth—and the objects sound and so forth. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
gnyis pa spang bya kun 'byung gi bden pa bshad pa la/
ii. What is to be abandoned, the truth of the origin.
spyi'i don dang tshig gi don gnyis las/
This has two topics: (1) General discussion, and (2) The meaning of the text.
dang po [spyi'i don] ni/
(1) General discussion

kun 'byung gi bden pa gang zhe na/ da lta ba dang ma 'ongs pa'i nyer len gyi phung po lnga la chags shing zhen pa'i mtshan nyid can gyi sred pa ste/ ji skad du rgyas pa las/ de phyir sred pa srid rten can/ / zhes dang / mdo las kyang / sdug bsngal kun 'byung 'phags pa'i bden pa gang zhe na/ sred pa yang 'byung ba can dga' ba'i 'dod chags dang bcas pa de dang de la mngon par dga' ba'i ngang tshul can 'di lta ste/ 'dod pa'i sred pa dang / srid pa'i sred pa dang / 'jig pa'i sred pas so/ / zhes gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ / de la mdo'i don ni 'di yin te/ sred pa yang 'byung ba can zhes pa ni mdor bstan pa ste/ sred pa gang las kyang srid pa'i phung po 'byung ba ni kun 'byung zhes pa'o/ / rgyas par bshad pa ni/ dga' ba'i zhes pa la sogs pa ste/ da ltar gyi phung po la mngon par chags pa'i sred pa ni dga' ba'i 'dod chags dang bcas pa'i sred pa'o/ / ma 'ongs pa'i phung po mngon par 'dod pa'i sred pa ni de dang de la mngon par dga' ba'i ngang tshul can gyi sred pa'o/ / de'i dbye ba ni 'di lta ste zhes pa nas te/ de'ang phung po'i ngo bo tsam la sred pa ni srid pa'i sred pa yin la/ phung po'i gnas skabs bde ba thob pa la sred pa ni 'dod pa'i sred pa yin cing / sdug bsngal spangs pa la sred pa ni 'jig pa'i sred pa yin te/ ji skad du rgyas pa las/ bdag dang bdag gir 'dzin byas pa/ / rgyu yin/ ces pas srid sred dang / srog chags bde sdug thob pa dang / / 'dor 'dod 'jug pa de dag ni/ / 'dod dang 'jig sred yin par 'dod/ / ces pas 'dod pa'i sred pa dang / 'jig sred gnyis bstan pas so/ / yang na sred pa yang 'byung ba can zhes sogs tshig gsum gyis rim pa ltar/ ma 'ongs pa dang / da lta ba dang / 'das pa'i phung po la sred pa gsum bstan la/ lhag ma ni sngar bzhin no/ / chos mngon pa ba dag 'dod khams dang khams gong gi sred pa ni go rim bzhin du 'dod pa'i sred pa dang srid pa'i sred pa yin la/ sdug bsngal gyi phung po rgyun chad par 'dod pa ni 'jig sred do zhes bzhed do/ /

What is the truth of origin? you ask. It is craving that has the characteristic of being attached to and fixated on the five aggregates of grasping of the present and future. As it says in The Commentary: Thus craving is the support of existence.[199] A sutra also states: What is the noble truth of the origin of suffering? you ask. It is craving that arises again: that which has the desire of lust and that which has the nature of truly lusting that or there. It is this: the craving of desire, craving existence, and craving destruction. The meaning of the sutra is this: “It is craving that arises again” is the overview; any craving from which the aggregates of rebirth arise is the origin. The detailed explanation is “that which has the desire...” and so forth. The craving that is truly attached to the present aggregates is the craving that has the desire of lust. The craving that truly wants the future aggregates is the craving which has the nature of truly lusting that or there.[200] Its classifications are from “It is this...” Craving the mere essence of the aggregates is craving existence, craving the attainment of the aggregate's temporary pleasure is the craving of desire, and craving the elimination of suffering is craving destruction. In The Commentary: The cause is the attachment formed by clinging To me and mine[201] teaches the craving of existence. The lines: Acting on wishes to gain happiness And cast off suffering is asserted to be The craving of desire and of destruction.[202] teach both the craving of desire and the craving of destruction. Alternately, the three phrases from “craving that arises again...” respectively teach craving for the future, present, and past aggregates. The remainder is as above. Scholars of the abhidharma assert that craving in the Desire and higher realms are respectively the craving of desire and of existence, and wishing for the aggregates of suffering to cease is craving destruction.

gal te ma rig pa dang las kyang sdug bsngal gyi rgyu yin na/ ji ltar na sred pa nyid kun 'byung du 'chad par byed ce na/ ma rig pa dang las ni sdug bsngal 'phen byed kyi rgyu tsam yin gyi/ mngon par grub byed kyi rgyu ma yin pas rgyu'i gtso bo ma yin la/ sred pa ni gnyis ka yin pas gtso bo yin no/ / gtso bo bstan pas phal pa shugs la go bar dgongs nas mdo las sred pa nyid sdug bsngal gyi rgyur gsungs shing / slob dpon yang de ltar du bzhed pa yin te/ mi shes srid pa'i rgyu yin kyang / / ma brjod sred pa nyid bshad pa/ / rgyu ni 'phen par byed phyir dang / / de ma thag phyir las kyang min/ / ces gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ /

“If both ignorance and karma are also causes of suffering, how is it that only craving is explained as the origin?” you ask. Ignorance and karma are merely the propelling causes of suffering but not the causes that actually create it, so they are not the primary causes. Craving is both, so it is primary. By teaching the primary, the general are implicitly understood. It is with this in mind that the sutras say craving alone is the cause of suffering, and the Master also intends it thus. As he says: Although not knowing is a cause of existence, It is not mentioned—only craving is taught Since that propels the continuum to existence And is immediate. Karma is not either...[203]
gnyis pa tshig gi don la/
(2) The meaning of the text.
rgyu'i rnam pa/ kun 'byung gi rnam pa/ rab skye'i rnam pa/ rkyen gyi rnam pa bshad pa'o/ /
This has four topics: (a) An explanation of the aspect cause, (b) The aspect origin, (c) The aspect production, and (d) The aspect condition.
dang po [rgyu'i rnam pa] ni/
(a) An explanation of the aspect cause
res 'ga' ba nyid yin pas na/ / sdug bsngal 'di rgyu bcas nyid grub/ / rgyu med gzhan la mi bltos phyir/ / rtag tu yod pa'am med par 'gyur/ /
181. It's proven suffering has a cause Because it is occasional. The causeless always or never exists, Since it does not depend upon another.

zhes smos te/ yul dang dus res 'ga' skye ba nyid yin pas na/ ji skad bshad pa'i sdug bsngal gyi bden pa 'di ni rgyu dang bcas pa nyid du grub pa yin no/ / gal te de ltar ma yin na/ / rgyu med gzhan la mi bltos phyir/ / rtag tu yod pa'am med par 'gyur/ / zhes skyon so na gnas so/ /

Because it arises in occasional times and places, it is proven that the truth of suffering explained above has a cause. Otherwise, it would naturally have a fault: The causeless always or never exists, Since it does not depend upon another.
'di la 'ga' zhig na re/
With regard to this, some say:
ji ltar tsher ma la sogs kyi/ / rno ba nyid sogs rgyu med pa/ / de ltar 'di dag rgyu med 'gyur/ / zhes ni kha cig rab tu brjod/ /
182. “Just as the sharpness and so forth Of thorns and so forth have no cause, In the same way, these have no cause,” There are some who expound.

ces smos te/ ji ltar na tsher ma dang / pad+ma'i sdong bu dang / 'dab ma dang / ge sar dang snying po la sogs kyi rno ba nyid dang / dbyibs dang / kha dog dang / rtsub pa dang 'jam pa la sogs pa rgyu med pa de ltar sdug bsngal 'di dag rgyu med par 'gyur ro zhes ni tshu rol mdzes pa ba kha cig rab tu rjod par byed do/ /

“Just as the sharpness, shape, color, roughness, smoothness and so forth of thorns and a lotus stem, petal, stamen, pistil, and so on have no cause, in the same way these sufferings have no cause,” expound some Cārvākas.
de'ang ma yin te/
But this is not so:
gang yod nyid na gang skye ba'am/ / gang 'gyur na yang rnam 'gyur ba/ / de ni de rgyur rab tu 'dod/ / de ni de rnams la yang yod/ /
183. If when something exists, something arises Or when it changes, that is changed as well, It is considered as the cause of that, And such exists for those as well.

ces smos te/ chos gang phan 'dogs byed du yod pa nyid na 'bras bu gang skye ba'am/ chos gang 'gyur na yang 'bras bu rnam par 'gyur ba'i chos de ni 'bras bu de'i rgyur mkhas pa rnams kyis rab tu brjod par mdzad la/ de lta bu'i rgyu dang 'bras bu'i 'brel ba de ni tsher ma'i rno ba dang / pad+ma'i dbyibs dang / kha dog la sogs pa de rnams la yang yod pa yin te/ rang rang gi sa bon yod med kyi rjes su 'gro ldog byed pa'i phyir ro/ /

If when some phenomenon exists as a beneficial factor, some result arises, or a phenomenon which, when it changes, that result is changed as well, it (that phenomenon) is considered by the wise to be the cause of that result. Such a relation between cause and result exists for the sharpness of a thorn and the shape, color, and so forth of a lotus as well, because those are entailed or reverse entailed by the presence or absence of their own seeds.
de la gzhan dag na re/ reg bya'ang mig shes kyi rgyur 'gyur te/ reg bya log stobs kyis mig shes ldog pa'i phyir/ de ltar na rgyu 'bras 'khrul bar 'gyur ro zhe na/ bshad pa/

Others say of this that the tactile would also be the cause of eye consciousness because by force of a tactile object ceasing, eye consciousness also ceases. If that were so, cause and result would be confused, they say. To explain:
reg pa gzugs rgyu nyid yin phyir/ / mthong ba la ni rgyu mtshan yin/ /
184ab As touch is causative of form, it is A cause of seeing.

ces smos te/ gzugs kyi rgyur gyur pa'i reg pa ni gzugs kyi rgyu nyid yin pa'i phyir/ gzugs mthong ba'i mig gi shes pa la ni brgyud nas phan 'dogs pa'i rgyu mtshan can yin no/ / de'ang mig shes kyi gzung don du gyur pa'i gzugs kyi snga rol gyi dri ro yang mig shes kyi brgyud rgyur 'phangs pa yin no/ / de ltar na sdug bsngal rgyu med du 'dod pa bkag pa na/ kun byung sdug bsngal gyi rgyur grub pas rgyu'i rnam pa yin no/ /

As touch that is a cause of form is causative of form, it is indirectly a cause that benefits the eye consciousness that sees form.
