This also implies that the scent and taste that precede the form that is the apprehended object of eye consciousness are also indirect causes of eye consciousness. Thus refuting that suffering is causeless proves that the origin is the cause of suffering. This is the aspect of cause.
gnyis pa kun 'byung gi rnam pa ni/
(b) The aspect origin
rtag rnams bkag phyir dbang phyug la/ / sogs pa las kyang srid min te/ / nus med phyir ro/ /
184b-d Because permanents Have been refuted, it's not possible To be from Īśvara and so forth since 185a They've no capacity.

zhes smos te/ 'di ltar sdug bsngal ni dbang phyug dang / gtso bo dang skyes bu la sogs pa las kyang skye ba srid pa ma yin te/ rgyu rtag pa rnams las skye ba cung zad kyang yod pa min ces skabs gzhan du bkag zin pa'i phyir dang / dbang phyug la sogs pa la dus thams cad du 'bras bu skyed pa'i nus pa med pa'i phyir ro zhes pa lha'i'o/ / rgyan ni/ rim dang cig car du bskyed pa'i nus pa med pa'i phyir ro zhes gsung ngo / / de ltar dbang phyug la sogs pa'i rtag pa rgyu yin pa bkag pa na sdug bsngal mi rtag pa'i rgyu mtshan du grub pas kun 'byung ba grub bo/ /

Likewise, it is not possible for suffering to arise from Īśvara, the primal substance, the puruṣa,[204] and so forth because there is nothing at all that arises from a permanent cause, as has been refuted at other points, and since they (Īśvara and so forth) have no capacity to produce results at all times. This is according to Devendrabuddhi. Prajñākaragupta says it is because they lack the capacity to produce either successively or simultaneously.[205] Thus refuting that Īśvara and so forth are permanent causes proves that suffering has impermanent reasons, establishing the origin.
gsum pa rab skye'i rnam pa ni/
(c) The aspect production
de yi phyir/ / srid 'dod rgyu yin gang gi phyir/ / mi rnams yul gyi khyad par ni/ / yongs 'dzin de thob bsam pas byas/ /
185a-d For that reason, Wanting existence is the cause because Humans appropriate a particular place, Which is done through the intent to obtain that.

zhes smos te/ sred pa las rgyu gzhan las sam/ lus sam/ ma rig pa ni rab tu skye ba'i rgyu ma yin pa de'i phyir/ ma 'ongs pa'i skye ba don du gnyer ba'i rnam pa can gyi srid pa 'dod pa ni sdug bsngal rab tu skye ba'i rgyu yin te/ rgyu mtshan gang gi phyir na mi la sogs pa'i 'gro ba rnams yul gyi khyad par mngal la sogs pa'i skye gnas ni len cing yongs su 'dzin pa de'ang skye gnas de thob 'dod kyi bsam pa sred pas byas pa'i phyir/

Neither causes other than craving nor the body and ignorance are causes of production. For that reason, wanting existence that has the aspect of seeking a future birth is the cause that produces suffering. The reason for this is because wanderers such as humans grasp and appropriate a particular place, a mode of birth such as a womb, and that is done through craving, the intent of wanting to obtain that.

gal te yul gyi khyad par don du gnyer ba'i sred pa ni kun 'byung ba ma yin te/ 'di ltar/ bcom ldan 'das kyi mdo las/ kun 'byung 'phags pa'i bden pa gang zhe na/ gang 'di sred pa 'di ni kun 'byung ba can dga' ba'i 'dod chags dang ldan pa de dang der mngon par dga' ba can te/ 'di lta ste/ 'dod pa'i sred pa dang / srid pa'i sred pa dang / 'jig pa'i sred pa'o/ / zhes gsungs pa dang 'gal lo zhe na/ 'di'i lan la/ slob dpon lha dbang blo ni/ bshad ma thag pa'i skye ba'i gnas su nye bar 'gro ba'i sred pa gang yin pa de ni srid pa'i sred pa zhes bya ba'i ming can no/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

You might say, “The craving that seeks a distinctive place is not the origin because that would contradict what the Bhagavan said in a sutra: 'What is the noble truth of the origin of suffering? you ask. It is craving that arises again: that which has the desire of lust and that which has the nature of truly lusting that or there. It is this: the craving of desire, craving existence, and craving destruction.'” In response, Devendrabuddhi says, “The craving just mentioned that seeks the place of birth is named 'the craving of existence.'”[206]
slob dpon rgyan mkhan po ni/ 'di la 'gal ba med de/
Master Prajñākaragupta says that there is no contradiction here, because:[207]
de ni srid 'dod gang phyir yang / / srog chags bde sdug thob pa dang / / 'dor 'dod 'jug pa de dag ni/ / 'dod dang 'jig sred min par 'dod/ /
186. This is a wish for existence, because beings Acting on wishes to gain happiness And cast off suffering is asserted to be The craving of desire and of destruction.

ces smos te/ gnas dang longs spyod la sogs pa la sred pa de ni sred pa gsum kar 'dod de/ gang gi phyir yang srog chags rnams gnas la sogs pa don du gnyer ba'i sred pa ni srid pa'i sred pa yin la/ der bde ba thob par 'dod nas 'jug pa dag ni 'dod pa'i sred pa phan par 'dod pas lung dang 'gal ba 'ga' yang med pa'i phyir/ zhes gsungs so/ /

Craving for a place, possessions, and so forth is the three types of craving. This is because the craving of living beings seeking places and so forth is the craving of existence, and acting there to gain happiness is the craving of desire. As these are asserted to benefit, there is no contradiction of the scriptures at all.
bzhi pa rkyen gyi rnam pa bshad pa la/
(d) The aspect condition.
rnam pa dngos bshad pa/ de nyid lung dang sbyar ba/ de la rtsod pa spang ba'o/ /
This has three points: (i) The explanation of the actual aspect, (ii) Comparing that with citations, and (iii) Refuting criticism of that.
dang po [rnam pa dngos bshad pa] ni/
(i) The explanation of the actual aspect
bdag tu chags pa'i rgyu nyid las/ / bde min bde bar 'du shes pas/ / kun la rab tu 'jug 'gyur ba/ / de phyir sred pa srid rten yin/ /
187. Due to the cause of clinging to a self, One enters anywhere, conceiving of That which is not pleasure as being pleasure. Thus craving is the support of existence.

ces smos te/ ngar 'dzin gyi gzhi bdag tu chags pa'i rgyu nyid las byung ba'i sred pa gang yin pa de ni srid pa 'khor ba'i lhan cig byed pa'i rkyen nam rten yin te/ gang gi phyir don dam pa bde ba min pa la bde ba dang / mi rtag pa la rtag pa dang / bdag med pa la bdag dang / bdag gi ba med pa la bdag gi bar phyin ci log tu 'du shes pas gnas dang longs spyod la sogs pa kun la rab tu 'jug par 'gyur ba de'i phyir/

The craving that arises due to the cause of clinging to a self, the basis for ego-clinging, is the cooperative condition or support for cycling in existence. The reason is from erroneously conceiving of that which is not ultimately pleasure as being pleasure, of the impermanent as permanent, of the lack of a self as a self, and of what is not mine as being mine, one enters anywhere (all places) and acts on possessions and so forth.

de yang rten yin ces pas rkyen tsam yin gyi/ nye bar len pa nyid ni ma yin te/ de la nye bar len pa ni sems snga ma yin la/ de'i rkyen ni res 'ga' sred pa yin la/ res 'ga' ni snying rje yin no zhes slob dpon rgyan gyis so/ /

Saying it is a support means it is merely a condition and not the substantial cause itself. The substantial cause is the previous mind, and its condition is sometimes craving and sometimes compassion, according to Master Prajñākaragupta.[208]
gnyis pa de nyid lung dang sbyar ba ni/
(ii) Comparing that with citations
chags bral skye ba ma mthong phyir/ / zhes ni slob dpon rnams kyis gsungs/ /
188ab The masters have explained this is because Those free of desire are not seen to take birth.

zhes smos te/ 'dod pa'i khams la sogs pa la 'dod chags dang bral ba rnams 'khor bar skye ba ma mthong ba'i phyir/ 'dod chags nyid 'khor bar skye ba'i rgyu yin no zhes ni sngon gyi/ slob dpon dbyig gnyen la sogs pa rnams kyis/ sred dang bral la yang srid med/ / ces gsungs pas/ 'dir yang / sred pa srid rten yin/ / ces bshad pa yin no/ /

Because those free of desire for the Desire realm and so forth are not seen to take birth in samsara, desire itself is the cause for birth in the samsara, the masters of the past have explained, including Vasu-bandhu, who said “Those free of craving have no rebirth.” Thus here it is explained that “craving is the support of existence.”
de la tshu rol mdzes pa ba na re/
Some Cārvākas respond:
lus med chags pa ma mthong phyir/ / lus las kyang ni 'dod chags 'byung / /
188cd “Because without a body, desire's not seen, Desire arises from the body as well.”

zhes smos te/ 'dod chags dang bral ba 'khor bar skye ba ma mthong ba'i phyir/ 'dod chags 'khor bar skye ba'i rgyu yin pa de bzhin du lus med par chags pa ma mthong ba'i phyir/ lus las kyang ni 'dod chags 'byung bar 'dod dgos so zhe na/

“Just as birth in samsara is not seen without desire, so desire is a cause for rebirth in samsara. Without a body, desire is not seen, and because of that, you must accept that desire arises from the body as well,” they say.
de'i lan bstan pa'i phyir/
To give the response:
rgyu mtshan khas blangs phyir na 'dod/ / nyer len nyid ni bsal ba yin/ /
189ab Since we assert the reason, we accept, But being substantial cause has been refuted.

ces smos te/ lus las 'dod chags la sogs pa 'byung ba'i rgyu mtshan lhan cig byed rkyen tsam du khas blangs pa'i phyir na/ lus ni 'dod chags la sogs pa'i rkyen tsam dang / tshul bzhin ma yin pa'i yid la byed pa nyid nyer len gyi rgyu yin par ni 'dod pa yin la/ 'on kyang lus 'dod chags la sogs pa'i nyer len nyid yin pa ni bkag cing bsal ba yin pas skyon ga la yod/

Since we assert the reason that desire and so forth arise from the body acting as just a cooperative condition, we accept that the body is merely a condition for desire and so forth and that inappropriate attention itself is the substantial cause. However, we have refuted and disproven that the body is the substantial cause of desire and so forth, so how could there be a fault?
khyod nyid kyang de ltar khas len par byed na/ 'jig rten snga phyi med pa dang 'gal lo zhes bstan pa'i phyir/
To teach that if you were to accept this, it would contradict that there were no previous or future worlds:
rigs 'di rjes su 'dod na ni/ / rang nyid rang 'dod la gnod 'gyur/ /
189cd If you accept this reasoning, you will Contradict your own positions yourself.

zhes smos te/ thog ma med nas brgyud de 'ongs pa'i tshul bzhin ma yin pa'i yid byed dang / lus kyi tshogs pa 'dod chags la sogs pa'i rgyu dang rkyen yin pa'i rigs pa 'di yi rjes su 'brang bar 'dod na ni skye ba snga phyi grub par khas blangs pas/ rgyang 'phen rang nyid kyi khas len snga phyi 'gal ba des rang gi skye ba snga phyi med par 'dod pa de la gnod par 'gyur bas tshu rol mdzes pa ba khyod kyi dpyad pa ni rigs pa'i mes tshig pa yin no zhes rgyan gyi'o/ /

If you follow and accept this reasoning that the combination of inappropriate attention that has been passed down without beginning and the body are the causes and conditions for desire and so forth, you are accepting the proof of previous and future lives. Thus you Cārvākas, your own contradictory earlier and later positions will contradict your assertion that there are no past or future lives and you Cārvākas' analysis has been burnt by the fire of logic. This is according to Prajñākaragupta.
la la dag na re/
Others say:
gal te skye la chags mthong phyir/ / skye dang lhan cig 'byung zhe na/ /
190ab “Desire arises simultaneously With birth as it is seen at birth,” you say.
zhes smos te/ gal te srog chags rnams skyes ma thag la 'dod chags la sogs pa 'byung bar mthong ba'i phyir/ skye ba dang lhan cig tu 'dod chags la sogs pa 'byung ngo zhe na/ de'i lan bstan pa'i phyir/
If you were to say that since desire and so forth are seen to arise immediately after living beings are born, desire and so forth arise simultaneous with birth, to give the response:
skal mnyam skye phyir sngar grub yin/ /
190c Same status arising proves the previous.
ces smos te/ skyes ma thag pa'i 'dod chags la sogs pa ni skal mnyam gyi rgyu rang gi rigs 'dra snga ma las skyes pa'i phyir/ sngar skye ba snga ma'i gnas skabs kyi 'dod chags grub pa yin no/ /
As desire and so forth immediately after birth arise from their same status cause—a previous instance of the same kind—desire from the time of the previous birth is proven.
gsum pa de la rtsod pa spang ba la/
(iii) Refuting criticism of that

kha cig na re/ ma rig pa dang / sred pa dang / las gsum ka sdug bsngal gyi rgyu yin pa'i phyir/ de dang der mngon par dga' ba can gyi sred pa gcig pu sdug bsngal gyi rgyur bstan pa ji ltar yin ce na/ de'i lan bstan pa'i phyir/

Ignorance, craving, and karma are all three causes of suffering, so some might wonder why it is that only craving that “truly lusts for that” is taught to be the cause of suffering. To give the response:
mi shes srid pa'i rgyu yin kyang / / ma brjod sred pa nyid bshad pa/ / rgyu ni 'phel bar byed phyir dang / / de ma thag phyir las kyang min/ / de yod na yod med phyir ro/ /

190d Although not knowing is a cause of existence, 191. It is not mentioned—only craving is taught Since that propels the continuum to existence[209] And is immediate. Karma is not either Because though it is there, there's no becoming.

zhes smos te/ de kho na nyid mi shes pa'i ma rig pa ni srid pa'i sdug bsngal gyi brgyud nas rgyu yin kyang de'i rgyur ma brjod pa'i rgyu mtshan yod de/ ma rig pa tsam srid pa'i sdug bsngal gyi de ma thag rkyen ma yin pa dang / 'khor ba dngos su skul byed ma yin pa'i phyir dang / sred pa nyid skye ba len pa'i rgyur bshad pa ni/ nges par 'khor ba'i rgyu ni 'phel bar byed pa'i phyir dang / sred pa yod na de ma thag tu skye ba mngon par 'grub par 'gyur ba'i phyir/ las kyang sred pa med na 'khor bar skye ba'i rgyu ma yin te/ sred pa de yod na las 'khor ba'i skyed byed du yod cing / sred pa med na las yod kyang 'khor bar skye ba med pa'i phyir ro/ /

The ignorance that does not know suchness is an indirect cause of the suffering of existence, but there is a reason why it is not mentioned as its cause: ignorance alone is not the immediate condition for the suffering of existence, and it does not actually induce samsara. Only craving is taught to be a cause of taking birth, since that definitely propels the continuum of samsara and since birth is immediately effectuated upon the presence of craving. Without craving, karma is not a cause for rebirth in samsara, because if there is craving, karma does produce samsara, but without craving, even though it (karma) may be there, there is no birth in samsara.
gsum pa mngon du bya ba 'gog pa'i bden pa bshad pa la/
iii. What is to be manifested, the truth of cessation.
spyi'i don dang / tshig gi don gnyis las/
This has two topics: (1) General discussion, and (2) The meaning of the text.
dang po [spyi'i don] ni/
(1) General discussion
bde bar gshegs pa'i skabs su bshad zin la/
This has already been explained in the discussion of the sugata.[210]
gnyis pa la 'gog pa'i rnam pa/
(2) The meaning of the text.
zhi ba'i rnam pa/ gya nom pa'i rnam pa/ nges par 'byung ba'i rnam pa bshad pa'o/ /

This has four topics: (a) The explanation of the aspect cessation, (b) The explanation of the aspect peace, (c) The explanation of the aspect sublime, and (d) The explanation of the aspect emancipation.
dang po [zhi ba'i rnam pa] la/
(a) The explanation of the aspect cessation.
'gog pa mi srid par 'dod pa dgag/ de la rtsod pa spang ba'o/ /
This has two topics: (i) Refuting that cessation is impossible, and (ii) Refuting criticism of that.
dang po ['gog pa mi srid par 'dod pa dgag] ni/
(i) Refuting that cessation is impossible

'dir lam gyis 'bras bu sdug bsngal dang / kun 'byung bkag pa'i cha la 'gog pa'i bden par bshad pa la/ gzhan dag na re/ sdug bsngal rtag pa'i phyir/ de bkag pa'i 'gog pa'i bden pa mi srid do zhe na/ bshad pa/

Here the truth of cessation is explained to be the stoppage of suffering, the result, and of the origin through the path. Others say with regard to this that suffering is permanent, so a truth of cessation that stops it is impossible. To explain:
de ni gtan du ma yin te/ / rgyu la gegs sogs srid phyir ro/ /
192ab That is not eternal, as it is Possible to impede the cause and so on.

zhes smos te/ 'dir sdug bsngal de ni gtan du ba ma yin te/ rgyu dang ldan pa'i phyir/ ma khyab bo zhe na/ khyab ste/ rgyu dang ldan pa de la 'gal rkyen gegs dang / mthun rkyen rgyu tshogs ma tshang ba la sogs pa srid pa'i phyir ro/ /

Here, that (suffering) is not eternal because it has a cause. If you say that is inconclusive, it pervades, as it is possible that impediments might impede things with causes or that the assembly of causes, the favorable conditions, might be incomplete, and so forth.
gnyis pa de la rtsod pa spang ba la/
(ii) Refuting criticism of that.

thar pa mi srid pa'i rtsod spang / 'khor bar gnas pa'i rtsod spang / sems can du lta ba can du thal ba'i rtsod spang / chags pa can du thal ba'i rtsod spang / khong khro ba can du thal ba'i rtsod spang / grol ba med par thal ba'i rtsod spang dang drug go/

This has six points: A. Refuting the criticism that liberation is impossible, B. Refuting the criticism that remaining in samsara would be impossible, C. Refuting the criticism that the detached would have the view of sentient beings, D. Refuting the consequence that they would have desire, E. Refuting the consequence that one would have anger, and F. Refuting the criticism that there would be no liberation.
dang po [thar pa mi srid pa'i rtsod spang ba] la/
A. Refuting the criticism that liberation is impossible
la la dag na re/
Others say:
'khor phyir thar pa med ce na/ /
192c “Because they cycle, there's no liberation.”

zhes smos te/ bdag gi mtshan nyid can gyi srog chags rnams ni 'khor bar 'khor ba'i chos can yin pa'i phyir 'khor ba las thar pa med do/ / dper na me dro ba'i chos can yin pas dro ba las mi thar pa bzhin no zhe na/ de'ang rigs pa ma yin no zhes bshad pa/

Because they (living creatures who have the characteristic of a self) have the property of cycling in samsara, there is no liberation from samsara. For example, since fire has the property of heat, it cannot be liberated from heat, you say. To explain that this is illogical:
ma yin 'dod dang ma grub phyir/ /
192d No, because we agree; it's not established.

zhes smos te/ thal ba de ni sangs rgyas pa la gnod byed du 'jug pa ma yin te/ bdag gi mtshan nyid can gyi srog chags rnams 'khor ba las thar pa med par 'dod pa dang / 'khor bar 'khor ba'i chos can yin pa ma grub pa'i phyir ro/ /

That consequence does not apply negatively to Buddhists, because we agree that living beings with the characteristic of a self have no liberation from samsara and because it is not established that they have the property of cycling in samsara.

'di la/ slob dpon rgyan ni/ gang zhig bcings pa de ni thar pa yod pa ma yin te/ de'i rang bzhin yin pa'i phyir ro/ / thar pa la yang bcings pa med de/ de ni rtag tu thar pa'i rang bzhin yin pa'i phyir ro/ / 'on kyang sems kyi rgyun ma dag par gyur pas tshogs pa'i khyad par las cha gzhan bskyed pa 'ba' zhig go/ de la phyi ma dag pa'i cha ni 'khor ba nyid du ma grub bo/ / don dam par ni 'khor ba pa 'ga' yang yod pa ma yin te/ skad cig rnams 'khor ba ma yin pa'i phyir dang / rgyun kyang don dam par med pa'i phyir ro/ / des na 'khor ba'i phyir zhes bya ba'i gtan tshigs ni ma grub bo/ / gang la thar pa yod pa'i thar pa po yang med do/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

Here Prajñākaragupta says: That which is bound has no liberation because that is its nature. In liberation there is no bondage, because that is always the nature of liberation. However, it is solely that another pure part is produced from distinctions in the assembly of the mental continuum that is impure. Then that later pure part is not established as samsaric. Ultimately, there are no samsaric beings because instants are not samsara and because the continuum does not ultimately exist either. Therefore the reason “because they cycle” is unproven. Nor is there is any liberated person who has liberation.[211]

'ga' zhig na re/ skyes bu rnams bdag nyid 'khor ba las grol zhing thar pa thob pa'i ched du lam la 'bad pa med par 'gyur te/ 'khor ba po dang / grol ba po'i bdag cung zad kyang med pa'i phyir zhe na/ bshad pa/
Some say that people would not strive at the path to free themselves from samsara and achieve liberation because there is not any self at all who cycles in samsaric or is liberated. To explain:
ji srid bdag chags ma bcom zhing / / de ni yongs su gdung gyur pa/ / de srid sdug bsngal sgro btags nas/ / rang bzhin du ni gnas pa med/ /
193. As long as attachment to a self has not Been conquered, they will be tormented. That long they will project their suffering, Not dwelling in the natural state.

ces smos te/ grol ba'i skyes bu ni thar pa'i ched du lam la 'bad pa med la/ ji srid bdag la chags pa ma bcom zhing / bdag tu 'dzin pa can gyi skyes bu de ni bdag dang bdag gir 'dzin pa'i dbang gis 'khor bar 'jug pa dang ldan pa de srid du sdug bsngal gyis yongs su gdung bar gyur pa yin te/ bdag la chags pa de srid du sdug bsngal ba po la bdag dang bdag gi bar sgro btags nas yul gyi gnas tshul gyi rang bzhin du ni gnas pa med pa'i phyir ro/ /

A liberated person does not strive at the path for liberation, but as long as attachment to a self has not been conquered, they (people who have ego-clinging) will enter samsara by force of clinging to a self and mine and be tormented by suffering for that long. This is because as long as they cling to a self, they will project the sufferer as being me or mine and not dwell in the natural state of the way objects are.
bdag 'dzin 'khor ba'i rgyu yin pa de bas na/
Clinging to a self is the cause of samsara. Therefore:
grol ba po ni med na yang / / log par sgro 'dogs gzhom phyir brtson/ /
194ab Though there is no one who is liberated, Strive to conquer false projections.

ces smos te/ thos pa dang ldan pa'i skyes bu ni grol ba po'i bdag ni don la med na yang lam la brtson par rigs te/ 'khor ba'i rgyu bdag tu log par sgro 'dogs pa gzhom pa'i phyir du brtson dgos pa'i phyir ro/ /

For learned individuals, even though actually there is no self who is liberated, it is logical to strive at the path, because one must strive to conquer the cause of samsara, falsely projecting a self.
gnyis pa 'khor bar gnas pa mi srid pa'i rtsod spang la/
B. Refuting the criticism that remaining in samsara would be impossible

la la dag na re/ bdag la chags pa dang bral ba rnams 'khor bar 'jug pa cung zad kyang med par 'gyur te/ 'khor ba'i rgyu bdag 'dzin spangs pas bdag la phan 'dogs pa la cung zad kyang mi blta ba'i phyir zhe na/ bshad pa/

Some might say that those who are free of attachment to a self would never enter into samsara, because they have abandoned the cause of samsara, clinging to a self, and thus would not view it as being of any benefit at all to themselves. To explain:
'dod chags bral ba'i gnas pa ni/ / brtse ba'am yang na las kyis yin/ / 'phangs la ldog med 'dod phyir ro/ /
194cd Remaining while free of desire Is from compassion or else karma, 195a As they do not wish to block the propulsion.

zhes smos te/ gtan tshigs de ni ma nges pa yin te/ 'dod chags dang bral ba 'khor bar gnas pa ni bdag la chags pa nyid kyis gnas pa ma yin te/ brtse ba chen po'am gzhan la phan pa'i phyir bzhugs pa yin gyi/ bdag nyid bde ba'i phyir ram/ sems can la chags pas gnas pa ma yin pa'i phyir dang / yang na nyan rang gi chags bral rnams kyang 'khor bar gnas pa ni bdag la chags pas gnas pa ma yin te/ sngon byas pa'i las kyi 'phangs pa'i phung po'i rgyun la rang gi ngang gis 'jug cing gnas pa'i phyir te/ las kyis 'phangs pa'i phung po'i rgyun la rang gi ngang gis 'jug pa ldog pa med par 'dod pa'i phyir ro/ / 'on te btang snyoms su byed pa yin te/ 'chi la dga' bar mi bya zhing / / gson pa la ni dga' mi bya/ / dper na gla ba'i gla bzhin du/ / kho bo dus la stong pa bzhin/ / ces bshad pa lta bu'o zhes pa lha'i'o/ /

The reason is indeterminate: Those who remain in samsara while free of desire do not remain because of clinging to a self. They stay from great compassion or to help others, not for their own happiness or from attachment to sentient beings. Or else alternatively the detached[212] listeners and self-buddhas who remain in samsara do not remain from attachment to a self but because the continuum of the aggregates propelled by previously committed karma naturally engages on its own and remains, because there is no wish to block the continuum of the aggregates propelled by karma naturally engaging on its own. Instead, they remain equanimous. As it is said: Do not take joy in death; Do not take joy in life. As if paying rent, I will stay for a time.[213] This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
'ga' zhig na re/ 'dod chags dang bral ba las kyis 'khor bar gnas pa yin na/ las des srid pa phyi mar yang mtshams sbyor bar 'gyur ro zhe na/ bshad pa/
Some might say that if those free of desire remain because of karma, that karma would also link rebirth to a later existence. To explain:
srid pa'i sred las rnam brgal ba'i/ / las gzhan 'phen nus ma yin te/ / lhan cig byed pa zad phyir ro/ /
195b-d For those who have transcended craving existence, Their other actions have no power to propel, Since cooperating factors have been exhausted.

zhes smos te/ skyon de'ang yod pa ma yin te/ srid pa'i rgyu sred pa las rnam par brgal ba'i ngang tshul can gyi dgra bcom pa la ni srid pa phyi mar mtshams sbyor ba'i las gzhan srid pa phyi ma 'phen nus kyi sred pa dang ldan pa ma yin te/ srid pa phyi mar mtshams sbyor ba'i lhan cig byed pa'i rgyu phyin ci log gi sred pa dang / srid pa'i sred pa gnyis zad pa'i phyir ro/ /

There is no such fault. For those arhats who have the nature of transcending craving, the cause of existence, their other actions that would link rebirth in later existences do not have the craving that has the power to propel future existence. This is since the cooperating causes that link rebirth in a later existence, erroneous craving and the craving for existence, have both been exhausted.
gsum pa sems can du lta ba can du thal ba'i rtsod pa spang ba ni/
C. Refuting the criticism that the detached would have the view of sentient beings

gzhan dag na re/ brtse ba ni sems can sdug bsngal las bskyab par bya ba'i phyir sems can la dmigs par 'gyur la/ de ltar yin na 'dod chags dang 'brel bas sems can du lta ba ma spangs par 'gyur ro zhe na/ bshad pa/

Others say that compassion focuses on sentient beings in order to protect them from suffering. If that is so, those free of desire would not have abandoned the view of sentient beings.[214] To explain:
sdug bsngal shes la 'gal med pa/ / 'du byed snga ma 'jug pa can/ / dngos chos brtse ba skye ba de/ / sems can rjes 'brel can ma yin/ /
196. Those who know suffering have no enmity. Continuing the previous conceptions, The actual quality compassion arises, But not in relation to a sentient being.

ces smos te/ sdug bsngal bden pa'i rnam pa mi rtag pa dang / sdug bsngal ba dang / stong pa dang / bdag med par shes pa de la snying rje dang 'gal ba'i zhe sdang med par sems can la snying rje goms pa'i 'du byed snga ma'i rjes su 'jug pa can yin pa'i phyir/ dngos po'i chos rang bzhin gyi brtse ba snying rje chen po skye ba can gyi chags bral gyi skyes bu de ni bdag tu lta ba dang sems can du lta ba dang rjes su 'brel ba can ma yin no/ /

Those who know the aspects of the truth of suffering—impermanent, suffering, empty, and selfless—have no enmity that would be contradictory of compassion, because they continue previous conceptions from cultivating compassion for sentient beings. For such a detached person in whom the actual quality of natural great love and compassion has arisen, it is not related to a view of the self or of a sentient being.
bzhi pa chags pa can du thal ba'i rtsod spang la/
D. Refuting the consequence that they would have desire
kha cig na re/ 'o na 'dod chags dang brtse ba la khyad par med de/ 'dod chags nyid brtse ba yin pa'i phyir zhe na/ bshad pa/
Some might say, “Well then, there is no difference between desire and compassion, because desire itself is compassion.” To explain:
de bdag min pa'i chos la ni/ / bdag gzhan sgro 'dogs pa las chags/ / sdug bsngal rgyun rig tsam las ni/ / brtse ba skye bar 'gyur ba yin/ /
197. Desire is from projecting another self Onto phenomena that aren't that self. Compassion arises out of mere awareness Of the continuum of suffering.

ces smos te/ 'dod chags dang brtse ba ni khyad par shin tu che ste/ rgyu tha dad pa'i phyir dang / yul tha dad pa'i phyir ro/ / 'di ltar 'dod chags ni dmigs yul can bdag dang bdag gi ba dang / rtag pa dang / bde ba de'i bdag nyid ma yin pa'i chos phung po la ni dmigs nas bdag med pa dang / bdag gi ba med pa dang / mi rtag pa dang sdug bsngal ba'i bdag nyid las gzhan bdag dang / bdag gi ba dang / rtag pa dang / bde bar sgro 'dogs pa las skye ba'i phyir dang / phung po la bdag dang bdag gi ba dang rtag pa dang bde bar sgro 'dogs pa med par dmigs yul sdug bsngal gyi rgyun rig pa tsam las ni brtse ba snying rje chen po skye bar 'gyur ba yin pa'i phyir ro zhes pa lha'i'o/ /

There is an enormous distinction between desire and compassion, because their causes are separate and their objects are separate. It is thus: desire arises from focusing on its object of focus, the aggregates— phenomena that are not that self-nature of being a self, mine, permanent, or blissful—and projecting onto them another self-nature than that character of being free of self, free of mine, impermanent, and suffering, projecting them as a self, mine, permanent, and blissful. Great compassion arises out of mere awareness of its object of focus, the continuum of suffering, without projecting a self, mine, permanence, or bliss onto the aggregates. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
lnga pa khong khro ba can du thal ba'i rtsod pa spang pa la/
E. Refuting the consequence that one would have anger
gzhan dag na re/ brtse ba 'dod chags kyi rang bzhin du mi 'gyur ba bden mod/ zhe sdang gi rang bzhin du ni 'gyur ba nyid do zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others say that it is true that love will not transform into the essence of desire, but it might become the nature of aversion. To explain:
gti mug nyes pa'i rtsa ba ste/ / de yang sems can 'dzin pa yin/ / de med nyes rgyu las khro min/ / des na brtse ba nyes med 'dod/ /
198. Delusion is the root of faults, and that Is to perceive as beings. Lacking this, There is no anger from the cause of faults. Thus we assert compassion to be faultless.

ces smos te/ 'di ltar gti mug ni 'dod chags dang zhe sdang la sogs pa nyes pa thams cad kyi rtsa ba ste/ de yang phung po la sems can du 'dzin pa'i rmongs pa yin la/ phung po la sems can du 'dzin pa'i gti mug de med pa'i phyir/ 'dod chags dang bral ba rnams nyes pa gti mug gi rgyu las sems can la khro ba ma yin te/ phung po la sems can du 'dzin pa med pa'i phyir ro/ / des na brtse ba snying rje chen po la nyes pa zhe sdang sogs med par 'dod pa yin no zhes pa rgyan gyi'o/ /

Delusion is the root of all the faults of desire, hatred, and so forth, and that is the delusion that perceives the aggregates as sentient beings. Because they lack this delusion that perceives the aggregates as sentient beings, those who are free of desire have no anger for sentient beings, which would come from the cause of faults, delusion, because there is no perception of the aggregates as a sentient being. Thus we assert that loving great compassion has no faults such as hatred and so forth. This is according to Prajñākaragupta.
drug pa grol ba med par thal ba'i rtsod spang la/
F. Refuting the criticism that there would be no liberation
gzhan dag na re/ 'dod chags dang bral ba rnams la sngon gyi las kyis 'phangs pa'i las kyi gzhan dbang can yin pa'i phyir/ 'khor ba las grol ba nyid ma yin ce na/ bshad pa/
Others say those who are free of desire are under the control of the karma propelled by previous acts, so that is not liberation from samsara. To explain:
grol med ma yin sngon 'du byed/ / zad nas gzhan mtshams mi sbyor phyir/ / 'du byed nus pa ma zad na/ / gang de gnas pa nyes med nyid/ /
199. They're not unliberated—prior formations Have been exhausted; they take no other birth. Those who remain without having exhausted The power of formations have no faults.

ces smos te/ dgra bcom pa rnams las kyis 'phangs pa'i dbang gis gnas pa yin kyang 'khor ba las grol ba med pa ma yin te/ sngon gyi 'du byed las kyi nus pa zad nas srid pa gzhan du nying mtshams mi sbyor ba'i phyir ro/ / 'du byed dge ba'i las kyi nus pa ma zad pa'i byang chub sems dpa' gang yin pa de snying rje'i dbang gis 'khor bar gnas pa la skyon yod pa ma yin te/ 'khor ba'i nyes pas gos pa med pa nyid kyi phyir ro zhes pa lha rgyan gnyis ka'i'o/ /

Arhats do remain through the power of the propulsion of previous actions, but they are not unliberated from samsara, because the power of karma, prior formations, has been exhausted and they will not take birth in another existence. Those bodhisattvas who, without having exhausted the power of the formations of virtuous karma, remain in samsara by power of compassion have no faults because they are not stained by faults of samsara. This is according to both Devendrabuddhi and Prajñākaragupta.
gal te snying rje'i dbang gis 'khor bar gnas pa yin na/ snying rje la rgyun chad med pas 'khor bar rgyun du gnas par 'gyur ro zhe na/ bshad pa/
You might say that if they remain in samsara by force of compassion, since compassion never ceases, they would remain continuously in samsara. To explain:
snying rje dman pa nyid phyir yang / / gnas pa'i 'bad rtsol chen po med/ / gang dag brtse ba chen po pa/ / gzhan gyi ngor ni bzhugs pa yin/ /
200. Since their compassion is inferior too, They do not make great efforts to remain, While those who are greatly compassionate Remain in the perceptions of others.

ces smos te/ 'phags pa nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas dgra bcom pa rnams ni snying rje dman pa nyid kyi phyir dang / 'du byed kyi las kyang zad par 'gyur ba'i phyir/ sems can gyi don du 'khor bar yun ring du gnas pa'i 'bad rtsol chen po med la/ sangs rgyas dang byang chub sems dpa' gang dag brtse ba chen po dang ldan pa sems can la mchog tu mnyes gshin pa byang chub tu sems bskyed pa sngon du song ba can de dag 'khor bar gdul bya gzhan gyi ngor ni bzhugs pa yin no zhes pa lha rgyan gnyis ka'i'o/ /

Since their (noble listener and self-buddha arhats') compassion is inferior and their karma of formation is being exhausted, too, they do not make great efforts to remain a long time in samsara for the sake of sentient beings. However, those buddhas and bodhisattvas who are greatly compassionate and supremely kind and gentle to sentient beings and who have previously aroused bodhichitta remain in samsara in the perceptions of others, students. This is according to both Devendrabuddhi and Prajñākaragupta.
gnyis pa zhi ba'i rnam pa bshad pa la/
(b) The explanation of the aspect peace.
mdor bstan pa dang / rgyas par bshad pa gnyis las/
This has two points: (i) A brief overview, and (ii) Detailed explanation.
dang po [mdor bstan pa] ni/
(i) A brief overview
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
gal te 'jig tshogs lta bral phyir/ / lam dang por ni srid med 'gyur/ /
201ab “Since they are free of personality view, There would be no rebirth on the first path.”

zhes smos te/ gal te/ gti mug nyes pa'i rtsa ba ste/ / de yang sems can 'dzin pa yin/ / ces bshad pa mi rigs so/ / gang gi phyir 'jig tshogs la lta ba dang bral ba de'i phyir zag pa med pa'i lam gsum gyi dang po mthong lam la gnas pa'i 'phags pa rgyun du zhugs pa la ni yang srid med par 'gyur ro/ / 'di ltar 'jig tshogs su lta ba dang / the tshom dang / tshul khrims dang / brtul zhugs mchog tu 'dzin pa spangs pas/ rgyun du zhugs par 'gyur ba yin la/ des na lam gzhan don med par 'gyur ro zhe na/ bshad pa/

You might say that the explanation “Delusion is the root of faults, and that / Is to perceive as beings...” is illogical because there would be no rebirth for noble stream-enterers who dwell on the first of the three undefiled paths—the path of seeing—since they are free of personality view.[215] They have abandoned personality view, doubt, and overesteeming discipline and austerity and thus become stream-enterers. Therefore the other paths would be pointless. To explain:
lhan cig skyes pa ma spangs phyir/ / spangs na'ang srid pa ga la yod/ /
201cd It's from not having abandoned the instinctive. If that's abandoned, how is there existence?

ces smos te/ 'phags pa rgyun du zhugs pa rnams kyis ni 'jig tshogs su lta ba mtha' dag spangs pa ni ma yin te/ kun brtags pa'i bdag tu 'dzin pa tsam spangs pa yin gyi/ 'jig lta lhan cig skyes pa ma spangs pa'i phyir/ lhan cig skyes pa'i 'jig lta spangs na'ang srid par skye ba ga la yod/

Noble stream-enterers have not abandoned all personality views, because they have abandoned just the imaginary perception of a self but not the instinctive personality view. If that instinctive personality view is abandoned, how could there be rebirth in existence?

des na 'jig tshogs su lta ba la/ kun btags dang / lhan skyes gnyis las/ kun brtags ni grub mtha' ngan pas btags pa'i rtag pa'i bdag la sogs pa 'dzin pa yin la/ lhan skyes ni sems can thams cad kyi thog ma med pa nas nga'o zhes 'dzin pa'o/ /

Therefore there are two personality views, the imaginary and the instinctive. The imaginary is holding there to be a permanent self and so forth as projected by inferior philosophical schools. The instinctive is the perception of me that all sentient beings have from beginningless time.
gnyis pa rgyas par bshad pa ni/
(ii) Detailed explanation
bde bar gyur pa'am sdug bsngal bar/ / ma gyur cig ces 'dod pa na/ / nga 'o snyam pa'i blo gang de/ / sems can la lta lhan cig skyes/ /
202. And when one thirsts, “May I be happy” Or else “May I not suffer,” The mind that conceives “I” is the Instinctive view of beings.

zhes smos te/ ji skad bshad pa ltar 'phags pa rgyun du zhugs pa rnams kyis 'jig lta lhan skyes spangs pa ma yin te/ bdag bde bar gyur cig ces pa'am/ sdug bsngal bar ma gyur cig ces mngon par 'dod pa'i rnam pa can gyi nga'o snyam pa'i blo thog ma med pa'i bag chags kyi dbang gis skyes pa gang yin pa de yod pa'i phyir dang / blo de yang sems can la lta ba'i 'jig lta lhan cig skyes pa yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

As just explained, noble stream-enterers have not abandoned instinctive personality view because the mind that conceives “I” with the aspect of wishing, “May I be happy” or else “May I not suffer” and that arises by force of beginningless imprints is present. That is the instinctive personality view that views sentient beings.
de'i gzhung 'dzugs par bya ba'i phyir/
To establish this position:
nga zhes mthong ba med par ni/ / 'ga' yang bdag la chags ma yin/ / bdag la sred pa med par yang / / bde ba 'dod pas mngon rgyug min/ /
203. Anyone who does not see a me Has no attachment to a self, And lacking any clinging to a self, They don't rush off, wanting happiness.

ces smos te/ 'phags pa rgyun du zhugs pa rnams kyis bdag lta lhan cig skyes pa spangs pa yin pa de'i tshe nga'o zhes mthong ba'i bdag tu lta ba med par ni de'i phyir 'ga' yang bdag la chags pa ma yin par 'gyur la/ bdag la chags shing sred pa med par yang bdag bde bar 'dod pas yang srid du mngon par rgyug pa ma yin no/ / de'i phyir bdag lta lhan cig skyes pa ma spangs pa'o/ /

If noble stream-enterers had abandoned the instinctive view of the self, they would have no view of the self that sees a so-called me. For that reason, they would have no attachment to a self at all. And lacking any clinging to or craving for a self, they would not rush off to rebirth, wanting happiness for themselves. For that reason, they have not abandoned instinctive view of the self.
'dis ni sems can du lta ba 'khor ba par bstan pa'i phyir/ sems can du lta ba mtha' dag spangs pa las gdon mi za bar thar bar 'gyur bas zhi ba'i rnam pa'o zhes pa lha rgyan gnyis ka'i'o/ /

This teaches that the view of sentient beings is samsaric. For that reason, once all views of sentient beings have been discarded, one will be liberated without a doubt, so this is the aspect peace. This is according to both Devendrabuddhi and Prajñākaragupta.
gsum pa gya nom pa'i rnam pa bshad pa la/
(c) The explanation of the aspect sublime.
bdag rtag pa gya nom yin pa dgag/ brjod du med pa'i bdag gya nom yin pa dgag pa'o/ /
This has two points: (i) Refuting that a permanent self is the sublime, and (ii) Refuting that an ineffable self is the sublime.
dang po [bdag rtag pa gya nom yin pa dgag pa] ni/
(i) Refuting that a permanent self is the sublime

gzhan dag na re/ 'khor bar bcings pa dang de las thar pa med par 'gyur te/ 'ching ba po dang / grol ba po'i bdag rtag pa med pa'i phyir/ dper na lha sbyin lcags sgrog gis bcings pa lta bu'o/ / des na 'ching grol gyi gzhir gyur pa'i bdag rtag pa yod de/ bcings pa las grol ba yod pa'i phyir/ dper na lha sbyin lcags sgrog las grol ba bzhin no zhe na/ bshad pa/

Others say that there would be no bondage in samsara and no liberation from that, because there is no permanent self who is bound or liberated. For example, it is like Devadatta being bound in iron chains. Therefore there is a permanent self that is the basis for bondage and liberation, because there is liberation from bondage. For example, it is like Devadatta being released from the iron chains.
sdug bsngal skye ba'i rgyu nyid ni/ / 'ching yin rtag la de gang las/ / sdug bsngal mi skye rgyu nyid ni/ / thar yin rtag la de gang las/ /
204. The causation for suffering to arise Is bondage. How could permanents have that? The causation for suffering not to arise Is freedom. How could permanents have that?

zhes smos te/ 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal skye ba'i rgyu nyid yin na ni 'khor bar 'ching byed yin pa las/ bdag rtag pa la 'ching ba de gang las yod de med par thal/ sdug bsngal skyed byed kyi rgyu ma yin pa'i phyir te/ rjes su 'gro ba dang ldog pa med pa'i phyir ro/ / de bzhin du sdug bsngal mi skyed pa'i rgyu nyid yin na ni thar pa yin pa las/ bdag rtag pa de la thar pa de gang las yod de med par thal/ sdug bsngal mi skyed pa'i rgyu ma yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

The causation for the suffering of samsara to arise is itself what binds one to samsara. How could a permanent self have that bondage? It follows it does not, because it is not a cause that produces suffering, since it does not entail or reverse entail that. Similarly, the causation for suffering not to arise is freedom. How could a permanent self have that liberation? It follows it does not, because it is not the cause for suffering not to arise.
gnyis pa brjod du med pa'i bdag gya nom pa yin pa dgag pa la/
(ii) Refuting that an ineffable self is the sublime

kha cig na re/ bdag rtag pa la 'ching ba dang thar pa yod pa ma yin pa ni bden mod kyi/ rtag pa dang mi rtag pa nyid du brjod du med pa'i bdag bcings pa dang thar par khas len pa'i phyir ro zhe na/ bshad pa/
Some say that it is true that a permanent self has neither bondage nor liberation, but they assert that a self that cannot be described as permanent or impermanent is bound or liberated. To explain:
mi rtag nyid du brjod med gang / / de ni 'ga' yi rgyu ma yin/ / brjod bya min la'ang bcings dang thar/ / ji lta bur yang yod ma yin/ /
205. What cannot be described as impermanent Is not the cause of anything at all. It is not logical—how could there be bondage Or liberation for the ineffable?

ces smos te/ bdag de skad cig ma'am 'on te ma yin grang / ma yin ce na/ mi rtag pa nyid du brjod du med pa'i bdag gang yin pa de ni 'bras bu 'ga' yi skyed byed kyi rgyu ma yin par thal te/ des na brjod par bya ba ma yin pa'i bdag de la'ang bcings pa dang thar pa gnyis ji lta bur yang yod pa ma yin no/ /

Is that self momentary or not? If you say it is not, it follows that the self which cannot be described as impermanent is not a cause that produces any result at all. Therefore, how could there be either bondage or liberation for a self that is ineffable? There is not.[216]
gal te bdag rtag pa nyid du brjod par bya ba ma yin pa'i phyir skyon med do zhe na/ bshad pa/
If you say there is no fault because the self cannot be described as permanent, to explain:
gang gi rang bzhin 'jig med pa/ / de la mkhas rnams rtag ces brjod/ / des na ngo tsha'i lta ba 'di/ / spongs la de mi rtag par smros/ /
206. The wise say that is permanent Whose nature never perishes. Therefore abandon this embarrassing view And say that it is permanent.[217]

zhes smos te/ gang gi rang bzhin 'jig pa med par gnas pa'i phyir/ bdag de la rtag pa yin ces brjod rigs par 'gyur te/ gang rang gi rang bzhin 'jig pa med par gnas pa de la mkhas pa rnams rtag ces brjod par mdzad pa'i phyir/ des na rtag pa dang mi rtag pa gang du'ang khas len mi nus pa'i gang zag gi bdag tu sgro 'dogs pa'i lta ba yin pa'i phyir/ mkhas pa'i tshogs la ngo tsha ba'am bdag tu sgro 'dogs pa'i lta ba 'di spongs la gang zag gi bdag de ni mi rtag par smros la/ byis pa'i rtsed mo'i rtog pa dang 'dra bar lung du ma bstan pa'i tshig la dmigs pas ci zhig bya zhes lha'i'o/ /

It would be logical to say a self whose nature remained without perishing is permanent, because the wise call permanent that which remains whose own nature never perishes. Therefore this view is a projection of an individual self that cannot be asserted to be either permanent or impermanent, so abandon this view which is embarrassing in the company of the wise or which is a projection of a self, and say that it, the self of the individual, is impermanent. “What use is there,” says Devendrabuddhi, “to focusing on ambiguous words that are like the thoughts from a child's game?”[218]

slob dpon rgyan mdzad pa ni/ ci ste gal te gzhan du mi 'gyur na/ gnyis ka'i rang bzhin du 'gyur ro zhe na/ zhes phyogs snga la brjod nas/ gang gi rang bzhin 'jig med pa/ / de la mkhas rnams rtag ces brjod/ / des na ngo tsha'i lta ba 'di/ / spongs la de mi rtag par smros/ / 'jig pa yang yin rtag pa yang yin no zhes bya ba 'di ni 'gal lo/ / gang gi phyir 'jig pa med pa de ni rtag pa yin te/ zhes gsungs pas ni gang zag gi bdag rtag pa dang mi rtag pa gnyis ka yin pa bkag nas/ des na gang zag gi bdag rtag pa dang mi rtag pa gnyis kar smra ba'i ngo tsha ba'i lta ba 'di spongs la de ni rtag par smros zhes par sbyar ro/ /

Master Prajñākaragupta presents the opponent's position saying, “If it does not become something else, it has the natures of both.”[219] Then he says: The wise say that is permanent Whose nature never perishes. Therefore abandon this embarrassing view And say that it's impermanent.[220] To say it perishes and yet is permanent is contradictory. The reason is that what does not perish is permanent...[221] Saying this refutes that the individual self is either permanent or impermanent. Therefore, abandon this embarrassing view that says that the individual self is both permanent and impermanent, and admit that it would be permanent.
bzhi pa nges par 'byung ba'i rnam pa ni/
(d) The explanation of the aspect emancipation

lam gyi bden pa'i zhar la 'chad pa yin te/ tshad ma rgyan las/ da ni lam gyi zhar la 'gog ba'i rnam pa nges par 'byung ba nyid bstan pa'i phyir bshad pa/ bshad zin lam de goms pa las/ / zhes gsungs pa'o/ /

This will be explained in connection with the truth of the path.[212] From The Ornament of Validity: Because the aspect of cessation emancipation is taught in connection with the path, now to explain “From cultivating the path that was taught...”[223]
bzhi pa blang bya lam gyi bden pa bshad pa la/
iv. What is to be adopted, the truth of the path.
spyi'i don dang / tshig gi don gnyis las/
This has two topics: (1) General discussion, and (2) The meaning of the text.
dang po [spyi'i don] ni/
(1) General discussion

lam gyi bden pa gang zhe na/ gang zhig goms pa rab kyi mthar phyin pa las goms pa po'i sems rgyud la nyon mongs pa'i bag la nyal gtan ldog par 'gyur ba'i ye shes te/ rgyas pa las/ bshad zin lam de goms pa las/ / gnas gyur/ ces gsungs pas so/ / ye shes de'ang gang zhe na/ bdag med par rtogs pa'i shes rab ste/ de ni bdag tu 'dzin pa'i gnyen po yin pa'i phyir dang / bdag 'dzin de yang nyon mongs pa kun gyi rgyu yin pas de nyid spangs pa na nyon mongs pa spang bar 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / de ltar yang rgyas pa las/ bdag dang bdag gir 'dzin bcas pa/ / 'dus byas spyod yul can chags ni/ / rgyu yin de yi gnod byed ni/ / bdag med mthong ba 'gal ba yin/ / ces gsungs so/ /

What is the truth of the path? you ask. It is the wisdom that, from the total perfection of meditation, blocks forever the predilections of the afflictions in the meditator's mind stream. The Commentary says: From cultivating the path that was taught, The basis is transformed.[224] What is that wisdom? you ask. It is the intelligence that realizes the lack of a self, because that is the antidote for clinging to a self, and because that clinging to a self is the cause of everything afflicted. Thus if that is abandoned, the afflicted will be eliminated. As The Commentary says: The cause is the attachment formed by clinging To me and mine whose sphere of experience Is the composite. What opposes that Is seeing selflessness, exclusive of it.[225]

bdag med pa de'ang rnam pa gnyis te/ gang zag dang chos kyi bdag med pa'o/ / de'ang nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas dag ni nyon mongs pa'i sgrib pa'i gnyen po nyid du gang zag dang bzung ba bdag med pa tsam sgom par byed de/ de tsam gyis rang rang bzhed don mya ngan las 'das pa 'grub pa'i phyir ro/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni shes bya'i sgrib pa'i gnyen por chos kyi bdag med pa gtso bor sgom par byed de/ shes bya'i sgrib pa ma spangs par rnam mkhyen thob par mi nus la/ de ma thob par gdul bya'i skal pa dang 'tshams par chos kyi 'khor lo bskor ba'i sangs rgyas kyi mdzad pa sgrub par mi nus pa'i phyir ro/ / des na bdag med pa rnam pa gnyis go rim bzhin du sngar ji skad bshad pa ltar bden pa bzhi dang / mtshan nyid gsum gyi sgo nas tshul bzhin du bsgom pa las gang zag dang chos su lta ba dang / de'i rgyu can gyi nyon mongs pa dang / shes bya'i sgrib pa ma lus par spang bar 'gyur ba yin no/ /

There are two types of selflessness, the selflessness of the individual and of phenomena. The listeners and self-buddhas meditate on just the selflessness of the individual and of the apprehended as antidotes for the afflictive obscurations, because that is enough to accomplish their desired aim, nirvana. Bodhisattvas meditate primarily on the self- lessness of phenomena as the antidote for the cognitive obscurations, because one cannot achieve omniscience without abandoning the cognitive obscurations and without achieving that, one will not be able to accomplish the deeds of a buddha and turn the Wheel of Dharma in accordance with students' capacities. Therefore meditating properly as previously described on the two types of selflessness by way of the four truths and three characteristics respectively, abandons entirely the views of an individual and phenomena as well as the afflictive and cognitive obscurations those cause.

bdag med pa gnyis po de'ang sgom pa'i lam gyi rim pa ji lta bu zhe na/ chos mngon pa las/ tshul gnas thos dang bsam ldan pas/ / sgom pa la ni rab tu sbyor/ / zhes bshad pa ltar 'khor ba las yid 'byung ba dang ldan cing / tshul khrims la gnas pa'i gang zag gis dang por bden pa dang / mtshan nyid gsum gyi gnas lugs la mkhas pa'i phyir du de dag ston pa'i gsung rab la thos pa byed do/ / de'i 'og tu thos pa'i don la rigs pas tshul bzhin du dpyod cing sems par byed do/ / de'i 'og tu bsam pa'i don la rtse gcig tu 'dris pas sgom par byed do/ / de ltar goms pa rab kyi mthar phyin pa las/ goms pa po'i sems rgyud gnyen po ye shes kyi ngang du gyur pas de'i mi mthun phyogs las dang nyon mongs pa ma lus pa 'gag par 'gyur la/ de dag 'gags pas de'i rgyu can gyi skye ba 'gag go/ de ltar na rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba yan lag bcu gnyis kyi 'jug pa nye bar zhi ste thar pa'i go 'phang thob par 'gyur ro/ /

What are the stages of the path of meditating on the two selflessnesses? As explained in the abhidharma: With conduct, listening, contemplation, Completely train in meditation.[226] An individual who has renunciation from samsara and dwells in discipline first listens to the scriptures that teach the nature of truths and the three characteristics in order to become knowledgeable about them. Following that, they properly analyze with logic the meaning of what they have heard and contemplate. Following that, they meditate by familiarizing themselves one-pointedly on the meaning they contemplated. When they come to the culmination of their meditation, the meditator's mind stream becomes the antidote, the nature of wisdom, and all the impediments to that, karma and the afflicted, entirely cease. When those cease, the birth they cause ceases. In this way, the progression of the twelve links of interdependence ceases, and they achieve the state of liberation.

gzhan dag na re/ gnyen pos spang bya spong ba mi 'thad de/ 'das pa dang da lta ba'i nyon mongs pa dang / bden 'dzin dag ni skyes zin pa'i phyir spong bar mi nus la/ ma 'ongs pa rnams ni ma skyes pa'i phyir spang mi dgos so/ / de'i phyir gnyen pos spang bya spangs pa'i thar pa med do zhe na/ de ni ma yin te/ 'di ltar spang bya'i rnam pa re re la'ang lam bzhi bzhi ste/ sbyor ba dang / bar chad med pa dang / rnam par grol ba dang / khyad par gyi lam mo/ / lam dang pos ni spang bya mgo gnon par byed cing / bar chad med pa'i lam dngos su 'dren par byed do/ / gnyis pas ni rang skyes pa dang spang bya 'gag pa dus mnyam par byed do/ / gsum pas ni de'i mjug thogs su skyes pa'i lam skad cig ma gcig go/ bzhi pas ni phyin chad skyes pa'i lam thams cad do/ / dang pos spang bya nyams smod par byed/ gnyis pas drungs 'byin/ gsum pas rnam grol mngon du byed/ bzhi pas spang bya thag sring bar byed pa'o/ /

Others say it is not tenable for the antidote to eliminate the discards, because the past and present afflictions and clinging to the truth have already arisen, so they cannot be eliminated, whereas the future ones have not arisen so there is no need to eliminate them. For that reason, there is no liberation that is eliminating the discards with the antidote, they say. That is not the case. For each aspect to be discarded, there are four paths: the path of joining, the path of no obstacles, the path of liberation, and the distinctive path. The first suppresses the discard and actually leads to the path of no obstacles. The second makes the discards cease at the same time as it arises. The third is the single instant of the path that immediately follows that. The fourth is all the paths that arise after that. The first weakens the discard, the second uproots it, the third manifests liberation, and the fourth distances one from the discard.

spang bya yang gnyis/ mngon 'gyur dang / sa bon no/ / dang po ni spong ba ma yin te/ 'das pa 'gags pa'i phyir dang / da lta ba dang lam mnyam du mi 'jug pa'i phyir dang / ma 'ongs pa ni ma skyes pas nyes pa bskyed mi nus pa'i phyir spang mi dgos so/ / des na sa bon nyid spong ba yin no/ / sa bon de'ang ma 'ongs pa spong gi 'das pa dang da lta ba rnams ni ma yin te/ skyes zin pas spong bar mi nus pa'i phyir te/ rgyas pa las/ ma tshang med rgyu de la ni/ / 'bras bu gang gi bzlog par nus/ / zhes gsungs pas so/ / ma 'ongs pa ni gnyen pos spang bya skye 'gyur gyi sa bon skye ba'i go bkag pa'i sgo nas spong bar nus pa yin te/ rgyas pa las/ skye 'dod nyes pa bcom pa'i phyir/ / gang yang skyon rnams 'gog byed pa/ / de skye las la nus 'gyur gyi/ / ji ltar byas pa nyams par 'gyur/ / zhes gsungs pas so/ / des na sa bon ma 'ongs pa skye ba ma bkag na de dag las nyon mongs pa dag skye bar 'gyur la/ nyon mongs pa las kyang nyes pa sna tshogs skye bar 'gyur bas de dag spang dgos shing / de spangs pas spang bya mngon gyur ma 'ongs pa dag kyang spang bar 'gyur te/ rgyu log na 'bras bu ldog par 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / des na sa bon spang ba'i gnyen po las logs su mngon 'gyur spong ba'i gnyen po bsgom mi dgos te/ rgyas pa las/ gnyis zad don du 'bad na yang / / las zad dub pa don med yin/ / ces gsungs so/ / gang yang mdo las/ 'dod chags kyi gnyen por mi sdug pa dang / zhe sdang gi gnyen bor byams pa dang / gti mug gi gnyen por rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba bsgom par gsungs pa de dag ma 'ongs pa la dgongs nas mngon 'gyur skye ba'i gnyen po yin kyang sa bon spong bar nus pa min te/ rgyas pa las/ byams sogs rmongs dang 'gal med phyir/ / shin tu nyes pa tshar gcod min/ / ces gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ /

There are two types of discard, manifest and seeds. The first is not abandoned, because the past have ceased and the present cannot engage simultaneously with the path. As the future have not arisen, they cannot produce faults, so discarding them is unnecessary. Therefore it is the seeds that are discarded. Among the seeds, it is the future that are discarded, not the past or present, because those that have arisen cannot be discarded. The Commentary states: And if the cause should not be incomplete, What would prevent it having a result?[227] The future seeds can be abandoned by way of the antidote blocking the gateway through which arising seeds arise. The Commentary states: Since it eliminates the fault of wanting To be reborn, that which prevents the faults Has power over the actions they produce, But how could what's been done be eliminated?[228] If future seeds are not prevented from arising, afflictions will arise from them, and various faults will arise from the afflictions. Thus they must be abandoned. Abandoning them also abandons future manifest discards, because when the cause is blocked, the result is also blocked. Therefore it is unnecessary to meditate on an antidote for the manifest separately from the antidote for the seeds. As it says in The Commentary: Even if one strives to exhaust them both, Tiring oneself to exhaust karma is pointless.[229] The sutras say to meditate on repulsiveness as the antidote for desire, loving-kindness as the antidote for hatred, and interdependence as the antidote for delusion. Those are intended as antidotes for the arising of manifest afflictions, but they are not able to discard the seeds, because as The Commentary explains: Since they are not exclusive of delusion, Loving-kindness and so forth do not Destroy the faults completely.[230]

gal te thog ma med pa nas 'dris pa'i chags sogs kyang gnyen pos 'joms pa ltar gnyen po bdag med rtogs pa'i ye shes kyang chags sogs kyis 'joms srid pas gtan du grol ba'i thar pa don med do zhe na/ de ni ma yin te/ chags sogs kyi 'khrul pa'i rkyen gyis yul gyi gnas lugs las gol bas rang bzhin gyi stobs chung ba'i phyir dang / de dag gtsang bde rtag sogs phyin ci log gi rgyu can yin la/ phyin ci log de dag kyang rtog pas sgro btags pa tsam pas glo bur ba yin gyi/ gnas lugs la ma zhugs pas stobs chung ba'i phyir ro/ / gnas gyur pa'i ye shes ni rang bzhin gyi stobs dang ldan pa yin te/ mi rtag stong bdag med sogs gnas lugs kyi yul can yin la/ dngos po rnams kyi gnas lugs gang yin pa de'ang rnam pa gzhan du bya bar mi nus pas rang bzhin gyi stobs dang ldan pa'i phyir ro/ / des na sems rgyud gnyen po ye shes kyi ngang du gyur pa chags pa skye ba'i skabs med pa yin te/ snang byed stobs ldan nye bar gnas pa'i yul du mun pa skye ba'i skabs med pa bzhin no/ / rgyas pa las/ sems kyi rang bzhin 'od gsal te/ / dri ma rnams ni glo bur ba/ / zhes dang / 'tshe ba med dang yang dag don/ / ngo bo nyid las phyin log gis/ / 'bad du zin kyang mi bzlog ste/ / blo ni de phyogs 'dzin phyir ro/ / zhes gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ /

You might say that just as the antidote can overcome desire and so forth habituated from beginningless time, it is also possible that the antidote, the wisdom of selflessness, could be overcome by desire and so forth as well, so the liberation of lasting freedom is pointless. That is not the case, because desire and so forth stray from the nature of the object through the condition of their own confusion, so their nature is weak. It is also because they are caused by the errors of purity, bliss, permanence, and so forth, but those errors are merely conceptual projections, so they are adventitious. Since they do not engage the actual state, they have little strength. The transformed wisdom is naturally powerful because it is the subject that perceives impermanence, emptiness, selflessness, and so forth—the nature. The nature of things cannot be made into anything else, so it is naturally powerful. Therefore when the mind stream has become the antidote wisdom, there is no chance for greed to arise, just as there is no chance for darkness to arise in an object near powerful illumination. From The Commentary: The nature of the mind is luminous; The stains are adventitious.[231] It also says: That which is mistaken about the nature Of nonhostility and the true meaning Does not interfere, though it might make an effort, Because the mind is inclined in that direction.[232]
gnyis pa tshig gi don bshad pa la/
(2) The meaning of the text.
bdag med rtogs pa grol bar rigs pa/ bdag 'dzin can grol bar mi rigs/ bdag 'dzin grol ba'i lung dgag/ las dang lus zad par grol ba dgag pa'o/ /

This has three topics: (a) It is logical that realizing selflessness is liberation, (b) It is not logical for those who cling to a self to be liberated, and (c) Refuting citations that say that those who have ego-clinging may be liberated.[233]
dang po [bdag med rtogs pa grol bar rigs pa] la/
(a) It is logical that realizing selflessness is liberation.
grol ba'i rgyu dngos/ de la rtsod pa spang ba'o/ /
The first has two topics: (i) The direct cause of liberation, and (ii) Rebutting criticism.
dang po [grol ba'i rgyu dngos] ni/
(i) The direct cause of liberation
bshad zin lam de goms pa las/ / gnas gyur/
207ab From cultivating the path that was taught, The basis is transformed.

ces smos te/ ji skad du sngar ston pa bshad pa'i skabs su/ rnam pa du mar thabs mang po/ / yun ring dus su goms pa las/ / zhes bya ba la sogs pas bshad zin pa'i lam gang yin pa de goms pa las bdag med par mthong ba'i lam de'i sgom pa yongs su rdzogs pa na nyes pa dang bcas pa'i sems de shin tu skye ba med pa'i chos can gnyen po'i bdag nyid du gnas gyur pa'i ye shes su 'gyur ro zhes lha'i'o/ /

From cultivating the path that was previously taught during the discussion of the teacher in the lines “From a long time of cultivation / In many ways with many methods...”[234] and so forth, one perfects the meditation of the path of seeing selflessness. At that time, the mind that has faults becomes a phenomenon that will not arise at all and becomes the transformed wisdom that is the nature of the antidote.[235] This is according to Devendrabuddhi.

rgyan mdzad pa ni/ sngar bshad zin pa'i lam gyi bden pa de nyid goms pa las/ gnas sems kyi rgyun nam kun gzhi dag par 'gyur te/ bdag dang bdag gir 'dzin pa dang mi mthun pa bdag med pa de'i bdag nyid du gyur pa na nyes pa mtha' dag dang bral bar 'gyur ro/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

Prajñākaragupta says: Cultivating the truth of the previously explained path purifies the basis, the continuum of mind or all-ground. When that becomes in character the selflessness that is incompatible with clinging to a self or mine, it becomes free of all the faults.[236]
gnyis pa de la rtsod pa spang ba la/
(ii) Rebutting criticism.
rtsod pa dang / lan gnyis/
This has two topics: A. The criticism, and B. The response.
dang po [rtsod pa] la/
A. The criticism
kha cig na re/
Others say:
gal te gnas gyur kyang / / lam bzhin skyon ni 'byung zhe na/ /
207bc “Though it transforms, The faults arise, just like the path,” you say.

zhes smos te/ gal te re zhig sems gnyen po'i bdag nyid du gnas gyur kyang / ji ltar nyes pa dang ldan pa'i sems la lam 'byung ba bzhin du lam dang bcas pa'i sems rgyud la yang skyon nyes pa ni slar yang 'byung zhing skye ba'i phyir/ 'khor ba la gtan du nges par 'byung zhing grol ba med do zhe na/

“Though it (the mind) may temporarily transform into the nature of the antidote, just as the path arises in a mind that has faults, the faults—wrongs—will once again arise and occur in a mind stream that has the path. For that reason, there is no lasting emancipation and liberation from samsara,” you say.
gnyis pa lan bshad pa la/
B. The response.
gnas gyur kyang nyes pa 'byung ba mi 'thad/ byams sogs rmongs pa'i gnyen por mi 'thad/ stong pa nyid kyi lta ba rmongs pa'i gnyen por sgrub pa'o/ /

This has three topics: 1. It is not tenable that faults arise even though there has been transformation, 2. It is not tenable for lovingkindness and so forth to be the antidote for delusion, and 3. Proving that the view of emptiness is the antidote for delusion.
dang po [gnas gyur kyang nyes pa 'byung ba mi 'thad pa] la/
1. It is not tenable that faults arise even though there has been transformation.
nyes pa la 'bad pa med pa/ nyes pas 'bad du zin kyang mi bzlog pa/ chags sdang gnyis spang gnyen du mi 'gyur ba'o/ /
This has three topics: a. The faults have no capacity, b. Though the faults may make efforts, they cannot block the path, and c. Attachment and aversion are not antidotes for each other.
dang po [nyes pa la 'bad pa med pa] la/
a. The faults have no capacity.
nyes pa skyed pa'i nus pa med pa/ yod kyang yun du mi gnas pa'o/ /
This has two topics: i. The lack of capacity to produce faults, and ii. Even when there is capacity, it does not last long.
dang po [nyes pa skyed pa'i nus pa med pa] la/
i. The lack of capacity to produce faults.
yul dang yul can gyi rang bzhin/ rang bzhin dang rang bzhin ma yin pa'i khyad par ro/ /
This has two points: (1) The nature of the object and subject, and (2) The distinction between what is the nature and what is not.
dang po [yul dang yul can gyi rang bzhin] ni/
(1) The nature of the object and subject
ma yin nus pa med phyir ro/ /
207d Not so, since they have no capacity.

zhes smos te/ lam goms pa'i sems rgyud la 'dod chags la sogs pa'i nyes pa slar yang skye ba ma yin te/ nyes pa rnams gnyen pos bcom nas slar skye ba'i nus pa med pa'i phyir ro/ / bdag med rtogs pa'i shes rab sogs sems kyi yon tan ni sems kyi rang bzhin yin pa'i phyir dang / nyes pa nyams te las bzlog pa'i phyir ro/ / de yang ji ltar zhe na/ bshad pa/

Desire and other such faults do not rearise in a mind stream habituated to the path, because the faults have been overcome by the antidote and they have no capacity to rearise. This is because qualities of the mind such as the intelligence that realizes the lack of a self are the nature of the mind and because the faults are the opposite of that.[237] How is that? you ask. To explain:
rnam shes yul 'dzin pa yi chos/ / ji ltar yod dang 'dzin pa dang / / yod pa yi ni bdag nyid de/ / 'di yi skyed par byed pa'ang yin/ / rang bzhin 'di yin/
208. The quality of consciousness—apprehending An object—apprehends it as is. The character of what is present Is also what produces it. 209a Such is the nature.

ces smos te/ 'di ltar yon tan sems kyi rang bzhin yin kyang nyes pa sems kyi rang bzhin ma yin te/ rnam par shes pa yul 'dzin pa'i rang bzhin nam chos ni/ yul de gnas tshul la ji ltar yod pa de ltar 'dzin pa yin pa dang / yul gyi rang bzhin kyang rang nyid ci ltar yod pa yi ni bdag nyid yin pa de ltar rang gi yul can rnam par shes pa 'di la rnam pa gtod pa'i sgo nas skyed par byed pa dang rtogs par bya ba'ang yin no/ / des na yul ni mi rtag pa dang / bdag med la sogs pa bcu drug gi rang bzhin yin la/ de lta bu'i rtogs pa ni chos bdag med par rtogs pa'i ye shes kyi rang bzhin yin pas/ yul dang yul can gyi rang bzhin ni 'di lta bu yin no/ /

In this way, qualities are the nature of the mind and faults are not. The nature or quality of consciousness is to apprehend an object. It apprehends it (that object) just as it is in its actual condition. The nature of the object—the character of what is present just as it is—is also what produces and what is realized by its conscious subject, the consciousness, by way of directing that toward itself. Therefore the nature of the object is the sixteen aspects of impermanence, selflessness, and so forth, and realizing that is the nature of the wisdom that realizes the selflessness of phenomena. Such is the nature of object and subject.
gnyis pa rang bzhin dang rang bzhin ma yin pa'i khyad par bshad pa ni/
(2) The distinction between what is the nature and what is not
'di las te/ / rkyen gzhan gyis ni gol 'gyur zhing / / ldog pa la ni rkyen la ltos/ / mi brtan sbrul gyi blo bzhin no/ /
209a-d But because of reasons That differ from that, it can deviate. Reversing that depends upon conditions, So that's unstable, like cognizing a snake.

zhes smos te/ de'i phyir bdag med pa'i lta ba de ni sems kyi rang bzhin yin la/ 'di las rtag bdag la sogs pa 'dzin pa de glo bur du 'khrul pa'i rkyen gzhan gyis ni bdag tu lta bar gol bar 'gyur zhing / 'khrul pa de dag ldog cing spong ba la ni gnod byed kyi tshad ma gnyen po goms pa'i rkyen la bltos pa'i phyir na/ rtsa ba med pa dang mi brtan pa dang rang bzhin yin te/ dper na thag khra la sbrul du 'khrul pa'i blo bzhin no zhes pa rgyan gyi'o/ / de'i phyir/

For that reason, the view of selflessness is the nature of the mind. But because of reasons that differ from that, adventitious confusion that holds that to be permanent, a self, and so forth, it can deviate into viewing a self. Reversing and eliminating those confusions depends upon the condition of cultivating the antidote, the valid cognition that refutes that. So for that reason, that is by nature baseless and unstable, like, for example, a cognition that confuses a mottled rope for a snake. This is according to Prajñākaragupta. For that reason:
sems kyi rang bzhin 'od gsal te/ / dri ma rnams ni glo bur ba/ / de phyir sngar yang nus med rnams/ / de bdag gyur la phyis nus med/ /
210. The nature of the mind is luminous; The stains are adventitious. For that reason, They have no power either earlier Or later when that becomes the character.

ces smos te/ bdag med par rtogs pa'i sems kyi rang bzhin nam gnas lugs de ni rtag pa dang sgro 'dogs pa la sogs pa'i mun pa dang bral ba'i 'od gsal ba yin te/ mi rtag pa dang bdag med pa la sogs pa bden bzhi'i rnam pa bcu drug po ji lta bar mthong ba'i phyir bdag tu chags pa la sogs pa'i dri ma rnams ni sems kyi rang bzhin ma yin te/ 'khrul pa'i dbang gis sems rgyud la glo bur du byung ba'i phyir/ sems kyi rang bzhin ma yin pa dang glo bur ba yin pa de'i phyir/ 'dod chags la sogs pa'i dri ma rnams sngar thos bsam gyis phung po bdag med par gtan la 'bebs pa'i dus su'ang bdag med rtogs pa la gnod pa'i nus pa med pa dang / phyis sems rgyud bdag med par rtogs pa'i lam de'i bdag nyid du gnas gyur pa la yang gnod par nus pa med do/ /

The nature or basic state of the mind that realizes selflessness is luminosity free of the darkness of permanence, projections, and so forth, because it sees the sixteen aspects of the four truths such as impermanence, selflessness, and so forth just as they are. The stains of attachment to a self and so forth are not the nature of the mind, since they appear adventitiously in the mind due to confusion. Because the stains such as desire and so forth are not the nature of the mind and are adventitious, they have no power to harm either earlier during the time of establishing that the aggregates are selfless through hearing and contemplating or later when the mind stream has become transformed into the character of that, the path of realizing selflessness.
gnyis pa nus pa yod kyang yun du mi gnas par bshad pa ni/
ii. Even when there is capacity, it does not last long
gzhan dag na re/ dad pa la sogs pa zhen pa'i dgra bcom pa nyams par bshad pa ma yin nam/ des na ji ltar skyon rnams slar mi skye ba yin ce na/ bshad pa/
Others say, “Isn't it explained that arhats whose faith and so on is weak regress? Therefore how is it that the faults do not rearise?” To explain:
nus yod na yang gnod pa can/ / bskyed nus snying po can dngos la/ / yun du gnas nus yod min te/ / sa rlon la ni me bzhin no/ /
211. Even when there is power, they lack the power To remain a long time in the entity That has the essence to produce what will Counteract them, like a fire on wet ground.

zhes smos te/ gal te skyon skye ba'i nus pa cung zad yod du chug na yang nyes pa'i tshogs la gnod pa can gyi bdag med par rtogs pa'i gnyen po bskyed nus pa'i snying po mchog tu gyur pa can yin pa'i phyir/ 'phags pa rgyun du zhugs pa la sogs pa 'ga' zhig gi sems kyi dngos po la chags sogs pa'i nyes pa yun ring du gnas pa'i nus pa yod pa ma yin te/ dper na chu 'dzag pa'i sa rlon pa la ni me skyes su zin kyang yun du mi gnas pa bzhin no zhes pa rgyan gyi'o/ /

Even when there is some slight power for the faults to arise, they (the faults such as desire) lack the power to remain a long time in the entity that is the mind of some noble stream enterers and so forth, because that is the supreme essence to produce the antidote, the realization of selflessness that will counteract them (the faults). It is, for example, just as how fire can arise on wet ground saturated with water but does not remain for long. This is according to Prajñākaragupta.
gnyis pa 'bad du zin kyang mi bzlog par bshad pa la/
b. Though the faults may make efforts, they cannot block the path

gzhan dag na re/ nyes pa'i bdag nyid du gnas pa la lam skye ba de de ltar lam gyi bdag nyid du gnas pa'i skyes bu la yang ci'i phyir nyes pa skye bar mi 'gyur te/ 'gal ba ni gnyis ka la yod pa'i phyir ro zhe na/ bshad pa/

Others say, “The path arises in those who dwell in the character of the faults, so why do the faults not arise in people who dwell in the character of the path, because both of them are exclusive of each other?” To explain:
'tshe ba med dang yang dag don/ / rang bzhin la ni phyin log gis/ / 'bad du zin kyang mi bzlog ste/ / blo ni de phyogs 'dzin phyir ro/ /
212. That which is mistaken about the nature Of nonhostility and the true meaning Does not interfere, though it might make an effort, Because the mind is inclined in that direction.

zhes smos te/ rtogs pa'i ye shes de ni mi mthun pa'i phyogs kyi 'tshe ba thams cad med pa dang / yang dag pa'i don gyi rang bzhin mi 'dra ba la sogs pa rnam pa bcu drug gi yul can ye shes de la ni rtag pa dang bdag tu 'dzin pa'i phyir phyin ci log gi blo rnams kyis 'bad du zin kyang slar mi bzlog ste/ blo ni gnyen po bdag med rtogs pa'i ye shes de'i phyogs 'dzin cing 'bad rtsol byed pa'i phyir dang / nyes pa med pas bzlog pa'i phyir ro zhes pa lha'i'o/

Because they hold it to be permanent and a self, minds that are mistaken about the wisdom of realization—the wisdom that has none of the hostility of the incompatibilities and that is the subject of the nature of the true meaning, the sixteen aspects such as impermanence and so forth—might make an effort, but that does not interfere. The reason is because the mind is inclined in the direction of the antidote—the wisdom that realizes selflessness—and makes efforts and because there are no faults, so they are blocked. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
gsum pa chags sdang spang gnyen du mi 'gyur ba bshad pa la/
c. Attachment and aversion are not antidotes for each other

gzhan dag na re/ bshad zin lam de goms pa las/ / gnas gyur ces bshad pa gang yin pa 'di la nges pa yod pa ma yin te/ bdag tu chags pa spong ba'i gnyen por bdag med par mthong ba mi rigs pa'i phyir/ dper na 'dod chags dang zhe sdang dag phan tshun 'dzin stangs 'gal ba yin du zin kyang gcig shin tu goms pa las gzhan shin tu nyams pa ma yin no zhe na/ bshad pa/

Others say that the above explanation “From cultivating the path that was taught, / The basis is transformed...”[238] is inconclusive about this, because seeing selflessness is not logically the antidote that eliminates attachment to a self. For example, desire and hatred have mutually exclusive manners of perception, but strong habituation to one does not thoroughly weaken the other, they say. To explain:
bdag 'dzin rgyu gcig can nyid dang / / rgyu dang 'bras bu'i dngos po'i phyir/ / 'dod chags khong khro phan tshun dag/ tha dad na yang gnod ma yin/ /
213. Since they have the same cause, which is self-clinging, And are entities that are cause and result, Desire and anger do not counteract Each other, even though they're separate.

ces smos te/ 'dod chags dang zhe sdang gnyis ka'ang bdag tu 'dzin pa'i rgyu gcig las skyes pa can nyid yin pa'i phyir dang / 'dod chags rgyu dang zhe sdang 'bras bu'i dngos por grub pa yang srid pa'i phyir/ 'dod chags dang khong khro dag 'dzin stangs phan tshun tha dad pa'i 'gal ba yin na yang phan tshun sa bon rtsa ba nas 'byin nus kyi gnod byed ma yin no/ /

Since they (desire and anger) both arise from the same cause (clinging to a self), and since it is possible to prove that desire is the entity that is the cause and anger the result, desire and anger do not counteract each other in a way that is able to uproot each other's seeds, even though they have separate, mutually exclusive manners of apprehension.
gnyis pa byams sogs rmongs pa'i gnyen por mi 'thad pa la/
2. It is not tenable for loving-kindness and so forth to be the antidote for delusion.
dngos dang / rtsod pa spang ba'o/ /
This has two points: a. Actual, and b. Rebutting criticism.
dang po [dngos] la/
a. Actual

kha cig na re/ zhe sdang gi gnyen por byams pa dang / 'dod chags kyi gnyen por mi sdug pa dang / rnam par 'tshe ba'i gnyen por snying rje dang / phrag dog gi gnyen por dga' ba dang / thams cad kyi gnyen por btang snyoms yin pa'i phyir/ byams pa la sogs pa'ang nyes pa'i gnyen po ci'i phyir ma yin ce na/ bshad pa/

Others say, “Loving-kindness is the antidote for hatred, repulsiveness the antidote for desire, compassion the antidote for hostility, sympathetic joy the antidote for jealousy, and equanimity the antidote for everything, so why aren't loving-kindness and so forth the antidotes for the faults?” To explain:
byams sogs rmongs dang 'gal med phyir/ / shin tu nyes pa tshar gcod min/ / nyes kun de yi rtsa ba can/ / de yang 'jig tshogs lta ba yin/ /
214. Since they are not exclusive of delusion, Loving-kindness and so forth do not Destroy the faults completely. It's the root Of all the faults: it is personality view.

ces smos te/ sems can la dmigs pa'i byams la sogs pa bsgom pa ni nyes pa'i rtsa ba nyon mongs pa can gyi rmongs pa dang 'gal ba med pa'i phyir/ nyes pa chags sogs shin tu rtsa ba nas tshar gcod pa ma yin no/ / khyab pa ma nges pa ma yin te/ nyes pa chags sogs kun nyon mongs can gyi gti mug de'i rtsa ba can gyi 'bras bu yin la/ nyon mongs can gyi gti mug de yang 'jig tshogs la lta ba yin pa'i phyir/

Since meditation on loving-kindness focused on sentient beings and so forth is not exclusive of the root of faults, afflicted delusion, it does not completely destroy from their root the faults of desire and so forth. The pervasion is not indeterminate, because all the faults of desire and so forth are results that have it (afflicted delusion) as their root, and it (afflicted delusion) is personality view.
gnyis pa [rtsod pa spang ba] ni/
b. Rebutting criticism

rang gi sde pa kha cig na re/ ma rig pa ni so sor rtog pa med pa'i rang bzhin mi gsal ba yin la/ 'jig tshogs su lta ba ni rtog pa'i rang bzhin ma yin nam/ ji ltar na ma rig pa 'jig tshogs su lta ba nyid ce na/ bshad pa/

Some Buddhist schools say, “Ignorance is an unclear nature that lacks discrimination, but isn't personality view considering[239] by nature? How is it that ignorance is personality view itself?”[240] To explain:
rig pa'i mi mthun phyogs nyid phyir/ / sems byung nyid kyis dmigs pa'i phyir/ / log par dmigs nyid ma rig par/ / gsungs phyir gzhan ni rigs ma yin/ /
215. Since it is the antithesis of knowing, Since it has a focus, being a mental factor, Since wrongly focusing was said to be Ignorance, others aren't tenable.
