ces smos te/ ji skad bshad pa'i ma rig pa ni bdag dang bdag gi bar lta ba'i mtshan nyid can gyi 'jig tshogs su lta ba las don gzhan du rigs pa ma yin te/ bdag med par rtogs pa'i rig pa ye shes kyi mi mthun phyogs su gyur pa'i 'gal zla dngos nyid yin pa'i phyir dang / rig pa bkag pa tsam yang ma yin te/ sems las byung ba yin pa nyid kyis dmigs pa dang bcas pa'i phyir te/ rten dang / dmigs pa dang / rdzas dang / rnam pa dang / dus de mtshungs ldan lngas sems dang mtshungs par ldan pa'i phyir dang / bdag med par rtogs pa'i rig pa'i ye shes las dmigs rnam phyin ci log par dmigs pa nyid ma rig pa yin par bcom ldan 'das kyi mdo las gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ / ji skad du 'phags pa zla ba sgrol ba'i ting nge 'dzin las/ de la ma rig pa dang bral ba gang zhe na/ yang dag pa ji lta ba bzhin du chos rnams la lhag par sgro 'dogs pa dang bral ba gang yin pa'o/ / zhes gsungs pa'i phyir dang / sa bcu pa'i mdo las kyang / de 'jig rten du 'byung ba dang / 'jig pa las rnam par lta ba'i tshe/ 'di snyam du sems te/ 'jig rten du dogs pa byung ba gang ji snyed pa de dag thams cad ni bdag tu mngon par zhen pa las byung ste/ bdag tu mngon par zhen pa dang bral na 'byung ba'ang med par 'gyur ro snyam mo/ / de 'di snyam du sems te/ byis pa'i blo can bdag tu mngon par zhen pa mi shes pa'i rab rib kyis bsgribs pa yod pa dang med pa la mngon par 'dod pa can du tshul bzhin ma yin pa'i yid las byung ba/ lam log par zhugs pa/ log par rjes su 'brang ba de dag ni bsod nams dang / bsod nams ma yin pa dang / mi g.yo ba'i 'du byed rnams kyang bsog ste/ 'du byed de dag gis yongs su bsgoms pa'i sems kyi sa bon zag pa dang bcas pa/ nye bar len pa'i las kyis ma la skyes pa dang / rga shi'i rang bzhin kyang srid pa mngon par grub pa 'byung ba nye bar 'grub pa yin te/ zhes gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ /

It is not logical that the ignorance just explained would be an object other than personality view characterized by self and mine, since it is the actual opposite and antithesis of wisdom, knowing the realization of selflessness. And it is since it is not a mere cessation of knowing but has a focus, being a mental factor, it is concurrent with mind through the fivefold concurrence of support, focus, substance, aspect, and time. Also it is since the Bhagavan said in the sutras that focusing wrongly with a focus and aspects other than the wisdom that realizes selflessness is ignorance. As it is said in the Noble Samādhi of the Lamp of the Moon, “What is being free of ignorance? It is being free of any extraneous projections onto phenomena as they are.” It is also said in the Sutra of the Ten Levels: When viewing the arising and destruction of the world, they think this: “All the bonds that arise in the world arise out of fixation on a self. If one is free from fixation on a self, there is no becoming in this world either.” They think this: “Those with childish intelligence who are fixated on a self, obscured by the cataracts of fixation and unknowing, and fascinated by existence and nonexistence, engage in wrong paths that arise out of inappropriate attention and follow the incorrect. They accumulate meritorious, unmeritorious, and unmoving formations. The seeds of that mind stained by those formations, with the defilements and grasping, in the future go to establish and arise in a rebirth whose nature is birth and aging and death.”[241]

kha cig na re/ bdag tu mngon par zhen pa ni lta ba yin la/ de'ang ma rig pa dang mtshungs par ldan pa yin pas/ lta ba'i sgo nas ma rig pa nyid du gsungs par shes par bya ba yin gyi/ 'jig tshogs su lta ba ma rig pa min no/ /

Others say that clinging to a self is view, and that is concurrent with ignorance. Thus it should be known that this is said to be ignorance in terms of the view, and personality view is not ignorance.

gal te ma rig pa nyid 'jig tshogs su lta ba yin na/ mdo las lta ba dang mtshungs par ldan pa'i ma rig pa gsungs pa'ang don med par 'gyur te/ lta ba ma rig pa dang mtshungs ldan ma yin pa'i phyir ro zhe na/ bshad pa/
If ignorance itself were personality view, it would be meaningless for the sutras to speak of ignorance concurrent with view, because view is not concurrent with ignorance. To explain:
'gal ba gang yin 'dir bshad bya/ /
216a To explain here what seems contradictory:

zhes smos te/ bcom ldan 'das kyi gsung 'ga' zhig tu ma rig pa dang 'jig tshogs su lta ba mtshungs ldan du gsungs pa dang 'gal ba ltar snang ba gang yin pa de dang nyon mongs pa can gyi ma rig pa 'jig tshogs su lta ba bshad pa'i skabs 'dir mi 'gal ba'i tshul ci rigs par bshad par bya'o/ / ji skad du/ mdo las/ lta ba dang mtshungs par ldan pa'i ma rig pa'o/ / zhes gang gsungs pa de ni rnam pa lngas mtshungs par ldan pa'i rdzas tha dad par ston pa ma yin gyi/ lta ba dang ldan pa'i ma rig pa zhes spyi dang khyad par tha dad du btags pa'i mtshungs ldan du ston pa'i phyir lung dang 'gal ba yod pa ma yin no/ / dper na blak+Sha dang ldan pa'i nags tshal zhes pa dang / lag pa dang ldan pa'i lus zhes pa lta bu'o/ / des na dmigs pa spyi dang 'jig tshogs su lta ba ni bye brag gam khyad par ro zhes grub bo zhes lha rgyan gnyis ka'i'o/ /

I will explain here how the apparent contradiction between some of the Bhagavan's words where he spoke of ignorance and personality view as concurrent and this context of explaining afflicted ignorance to be personality view is not actually a contradiction. When it speaks in the sutras of “ignorance that is concurrent with view,” that does not mean a separate substance with the fivefold concurrence. Instead, “Ignorance that has view” indicates a nominal concurrence of separate whole and parts, so there is no contradiction in the scripture. For example, it is like saying “A forest that has palasha trees”[242] or “a body that has a hand.” Therefore ignorance is proven to be the general and personality view to be a particular or feature, according to both Devendrabuddhi and Prajñākaragupta.
gsum pa stong pa nyid kyi lta ba rmongs pa'i gnyen por bsgrub pa ni/
3. Proving that the view of emptiness is the antidote for delusion
stong nyid lta dang de 'gal phyir/ / de yi rang bzhin nyes kun dang / / 'gal bar rab tu grub pa yin/ /
216b-d Because the view of emptiness is exclusive Of that, it's proven to be exclusive of The faults that have that as their nature.

ces smos te/ bdag med par mngon sum du rtogs pa'i stong pa nyid kyi lta ba dang / bdag tu lta ba de'i 'dzin stangs dngos su 'gal ba'i phyir/ bdag tu lta ba de'i rang bzhin gyi khyad par can dang / bdag tu lta ba las byung ba'i 'dod chags la sogs pa'i nyes pa'i khyad par kun dang lhan cig mi gnas pa'i 'gal ba rab tu grub pa yin te/ dper na khyad par grang reg dang 'gal ba'i me ni grang ba'i khyad par ba mo'i reg pa dang grang 'bras spu long byed la sogs pa'i rang bzhin dang 'gal ba lta bu'o zhes lha'i'o/ / des ni 'gog bden gyi nges par 'byung ba'i rnam pa yang bshad pa yin no zhes rgyan gyi'o/ /

Because the view of emptiness that directly realizes selflessness is actually exclusive of that view and the self's manner of apprehension, it is proven to be exclusive of coexistence with the whole that is the nature of self view and its features, all the faults such as desire and so forth born of the view of the self. It is, for example, just as fire exclusive of the feature cold touch is also exclusive of the natures of features of cold such as the touch of hoarfrost and results of cold such as getting goose bumps. This is according to Devendrabuddhi. Prajñākaragupta says, “This explains the aspect emancipation of the truth of cessation.”[243]
de la gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
zad min srog chags chos nyid phyir/ / gzugs sogs bzhin/
2173b If they are not exhausted, being the nature Of living beings, like form and such,

zhes smra ste/ gnyen po goms pa las nyon mongs pa ldog tu zin kyang zad nas slar mi skye ba'i chos can min te/ nyon mongs ni srog chags rnams kyi rang bzhin nam chos nyid yin pa'i phyir/ dper na 'byung ba'i gzugs dang me'i drod la sogs pa bzhin no zhe na/ bshad pa/

If you say that cultivating the antidote may block the afflictions, but they are not exhausted and nonarising phenomena, because the afflictions are the nature of living beings, just like, for example, the form of the elements, the heat of fire, and such, to explain:
min ma grub phyir/ / gnyen po'i phyogs dang 'brel ba na/ / ldog pa dag kyang mthong phyir ro/ /
217b-d not so. That is not proven. When connected to The antidote, they're seen to be relinquished.

zhes smos te/ 'dod chags la sogs pa'i nyon mongs pa rnams srog chags kyi chos nyid yin pa'i rgyu mtshan gyis gtan mi zad pa de ni min te/ srog chags kyi chos nyid du ma grub pa'i phyir dang / glo bur du bstan zin pa'i phyir/ srog chags las byung ba tsam la de'i chos nyid du brjod na yang gtan tshigs ma nges pa yin te/ thag pa la sbrul gyi shes pa bzhin du de las res 'ga' 'byung ba ni de'i rang bzhin du mi rung ba'i phyir dang / gnyen po bdag med mngon sum du rtogs pa'i phyogs dang 'brel ba na/ 'dod chags la sogs pa ldog cing 'grib pa dag kyang mthong ba'i phyir ro/ / dper na grang reg dang 'brel ba las rdo tshan la sogs pa'i dro ba'i reg pa ldog pa bzhin no/ /

It is not so that since afflictions are the nature of living beings, they cannot be extinguished forever, because they are not proven to be the nature of living beings and because they have been shown to be adventitious. If you say that what merely arises from living creatures is their nature, the reason is indeterminate, because just like the perception of a rope as a snake, that which arises intermittently from something is not appropriate as its nature. It is also because when connected to the antidote, the direct realization of selflessness, they (desire and so forth) are seen to be relinquished and lessened. For example, the connection to a cold touch reverses the touch of a hot rock and so forth.

gzhan dag ni 'dod chags la sogs la gnyen pos lan gcig med par byas kyang slar yang skye bar 'gyur te/ dper na gser bzhus pa na sla ba'i bdag nyid du gyur kyang / slar yang sra ba'i bdag nyid du log pa bzhin no zhe na/ bshad pa/

Others say that desire and so forth might be eliminated once by the antidote, but they will arise again. For example, when gold is melted, it becomes liquid in character but will return to being solid in character. To explain:
nyes pa rnam par 'gag pa ni/ / sra zhing slar yang skye med de/ / de bdag nyid kyi 'brel med dang / / thal ba bzhin du ma nges phyir/ /
218. Unlike solidity, they don't arise Again, because prevention of the faults Is not removable, since it's the nature, And since it's inconclusive, as with ash.

zhes smos te/ bdag med par mthong ba'i gnyen pos 'dod chags la sogs pa'i nyes pa rnams bcom nas rnam par 'gag pa'i sems rgyud de la ni gser gyi zhu ba me dang bral na sra ba slar skye ba bzhin du gnyen po dang bral bas 'dod chags la sogs pa slar yang skye ba med de/ gnyen po ni sems de'i bdag nyid yin pa nyid kyis 'brel ba med pa'i phyir dang / shing mes thal bar byas pa me dang bral kyang thal ba shing du mi ldog pa bzhin du gnyen po dang bral kyang nyes pa'i rgyu bdag tu 'dzin pa spangs pas 'dod chags la sogs pa slar skye bar ma nges pa'i phyir zhes pa lha'i'o/ /

In a mind stream where the antidote of seeing selflessness has overcome and prevented the faults such as desire, it is not like molten gold which becomes solid when fire is absent. When the antidotes are absent, they (desire and so forth) do not arise again, because the antidote is not removable, as it is the nature of that mind. And just as when fire has reduced wood to ash, the ash does not revert to wood even though the antidote may be absent, it is inconclusive that desire and so forth would rearise, since the cause of the faults—clinging to a self—has been abandoned. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
gnyis pa bdag 'dzin can grol bar mi rigs par bshad pa la/
(b) It is not logical for those who cling to a self to be liberated.
bdag bsgom pas thar pa thob pa mi rigs pa/ bdag gir zhen pa dang bral bas grol ba dgag pa'o/ /
This has two topics: (i) It is not logical to achieve liberation by cultivating a self, and (ii) Rebutting that freedom from clinging to mine brings liberation.
dang po [bdag bsgom pas thar pa thob pa mi rigs pa] la/
(i) It is not logical to achieve liberation by cultivating a self
gzhan dag na re/ bdag bsgom pas kyang grol bar 'gyur te/ bdag bsam par bya'o zhes lung las 'byung ba'i phyir/ des na bdag med lta bas ci bya zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others say that meditating on a self also brings liberation because there are scriptures that say, “Contemplate the self.” Therefore why bother with the view of selflessness? To explain:

gang zhig bdag mthong de la ni/ / nga zhes rtag tu zhen par 'gyur/ / zhen pas bde la sred 'gyur te/ / sred pas skyon rnams sgrib par byed/ / yon tan mthong bas yongs sred pa/ / nga yi zhes de'i sgrub byed len/ / des na bdag la mngon chags pa/ / de srid de ni 'khor bar 'gyur/ /

219. Those who see a self, saying “me” Will cling to it as if eternal. From clinging, they'll crave happiness, And craving will conceal the faults. 220. Seeing qualities, they'll lust for them And grasp at means to get the mine. Therefore as long as one is attached To a self, one is in samsara.

zhes smos te/ sems can rnams las gang su zhig bdag tu zhen cing mthong ba de la ni 'khor ba las grol ba yod pa ma yin te/ nga med pa la nga'o zhes rtag tu zhen par 'gyur la/ de ltar zhen pas bdag gi bde ba la sred pa skye bar 'gyur te/ sred pas bdag dang bdag gi ba'i skyon rnams sgrib par byed cing / de ltar bsgribs pas bdag dang bdag gi ba la yon tan du mthong bas de la yongs su sred pa'i phyir ro/ / de ltar yin pa de'i phyir/ khyod 'dod pa'i 'dod chags dang bral ba ni nga'i'o zhes bdag de'i sgrub byed len par byed do/ / des na ji srid bdag la zhen cing mngon par chags pa yod pa de srid du khyod kyi 'gro ba de ni 'khor bar 'gyur ro/ /

Among sentient beings, there is no liberation from samsara for those who fixate on and see a self. They will cling to the lack of a me, calling it “me” as if it were eternal. From clinging thus, craving for their own happiness arises, and craving will conceal the faults of the self and mine. As those are concealed, they will see the self and mine as qualities and lust for them. As that is so, you who are free of desire for the Desire realm[244] will grasp at the means to get the mine, the self's. Therefore as long as one has fixation on and attachment to a self, one will cycle in the destinations of samsara.
de'i gzhung 'dzugs pa'i phyir/
To establish this position:
bdag yod na ni gzhan du shes/ / bdag gzhan cha las 'dzin dang sdang / / 'di dag dang ni yongs 'brel bas/ / nyes pa thams cad 'byung bar 'gyur/ /
221. If there's a self, then one conceives of others. From the division into self and other, There's clinging and aversion. All the faults That are connected to those two arise.

zhes smos te/ skyes bu gang la bdag tu 'du shes pa yod na ni de la bltos pa'i gzhan du 'du shes pa yod la/ de yod na bdag dang gzhan gyi cha gnyis las go rim bzhin du 'dzin cing zhen pa dang yongs su sdang bar 'gyur zhing / bdag dang gzhan la chags pa dang sdang ba 'di dag dang ni yongs su 'brel ba'i skyon las phrag dog dang ser sna la sogs pa'i nyes pa thams cad 'byung bar 'gyur ro zhes lha rgyan gnyis ka'i'o/ /

Any person who has a conception of a self has the conception of other, which depends on that. If they have that, then from the division into self and other there are respectively fixated clinging and aversion, and all the faults—jealousy, stinginess, and so forth—that are connected to those two (clinging to self and aversion for others) arise. This is according to both Devendrabuddhi and Prajñākaragupta.
gnyis pa bdag gir zhen pa dang bral bas grol ba dgag pa la/
(ii) Rebutting that freedom from clinging to mine brings liberation.

bdag gir chags pa spang ba dgag/ bdag tu chags pa spang ba dgag/ bdag tu chags pa spong ba'i sgrub byed dgag/ don bsdu ba/ bdag gi ba spang na ha cang thal ba/ des na 'jig tshogs la lta ba spang bar gdams pa'o/ /

This has six topics: A. Rebutting that they have abandoned clinging to mine, B. Rebutting that they have abandoned clinging to a self, C. Rebutting the proof of abandoning clinging to a self, D. Summary, E. The absurd consequence of having abandoned mine, and F. Advice to therefore abandon personality view.
dang po [bdag gir chags pa spang ba dgag] la/
A. Rebutting that they have abandoned clinging to mine
kha cig na re/ kho bo cag gi grol ba'i skyes bu ni bdag chags pa dang ldan pa de ltar na'ang / bdag gir chags pa dang bral ba'i phyir 'khor bar 'khor ba ma yin no zhe na/ bshad pa/
Some say, “Our liberated individuals do have attachment to a self, but because they are free of attachment to 'mine,' they do not cycle in samsara.” To explain:
nges par bdag la chags pa ni/ / bdag gi la chags mi 'bral zhing / /
222ab Necessarily those who cling to a self Are not free of desire for mine.

zhes smos te/ nges pa kho nar bdag la chags shing zhen pa'i skyes bu ni 'khor ba las grol ba ni ma yin te/ bdag la chags pa dang ldan pa ni bdag gi ba la yang chags pa dang mi 'bral zhing ldan pa'i phyir zhes pa rgyan gyi'o/ /

Those individuals who are attached to and cling to a self necessarily are not liberated from samsara, because those who have attachment to a self also possess and are not free of desire for mine. This is according to Prajñākaragupta.
gnyis pa bdag tu chags pa spang ba dgag pa la/
B. Rebutting that they have abandoned clinging to a self.
'gog byed kyi rigs pa dngos/ chags pa skyon bcas yin pas spong ba dgag/ chags pa skyon bcas nyid kyang ma grub pa'o/ /
This has three points: 1. The actual logic of the rebuttal, 2. Rebutting that attachment is abandoned because it is faulty, and 3. Attachment is not even proven to be faulty.
dang po ['gog byed kyi rigs pa dngos] la/
1. The actual logic of the rebuttal
kha cig na re/ nyes med kyi bdag med pa'o/ / bdag la spangs pa yin no zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others say that there is no faultless self; the self has been abandoned. To explain:
nyes med bdag la chags pa dang / / bral ba'i rgyu yang yod ma yin/ /
222cd There is no cause for freedom from Attachment to a faultless self.

ces smos te/ khyod kyis grol ba thob par 'dod pa'i skyes bu ni sdug bsngal dang bral ba gcig tu rnam par 'tshe ba med pa'i nyes med kyi bdag yod pa ma yin pa'i phyir/ bdag la chags pa dang bral ba'i rgyu yang yod pa ma yin no/ /
The person you assert to have achieved liberation is not a faultless self free of suffering and solely free of hostility. For this reason, it is no cause for freedom from attachment to self.
gnyis pa chags pa skyon bcas yin pas spong ba dgag pa la/
2. Rebutting that attachment is abandoned because it is faulty
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
gal te chags pa skyon bcas na/ /
223a If you say clinging is what's faulty,
zhes smos te/ gal te bdag la nyes pa med kyang bdag tu chags pa skyon dang bcas pa yin pas mkhas pa rnams kyis bor bar bya ba yin te/ sbrul gyi sos zin pa'i sor mo bzhin no zhe na/ bshad pa/
If you say, “The self has no faults, but clinging to a self is faulty, so it is something the wise discard, like a finger that has been bitten by a snake,” to explain:
de las cir gyur de spong 'gyur/ / 'di yul sun phyung med par ni/ / de spong bar ni nus ma yin/ /
223b-d What comes of that? “It is abandoned.” Unless its object is disproved, One is unable to abandon that.

ces smos te/ bdag tu chags pa skyon dang bcas pa mthong ba de las cir 'gyur zhes dri bar bya'o/ / gal te de ltar mthong ba las bdag tu chags pa de spong bar 'gyur ro zhe na/ khyod kyi grol ba thob par 'dod pa'i skyes bu ni bdag tu chags pa 'di yi yul bdag gang yin pa de nyes pa dang bcas par mthong ba'i sgo nas med pa nyid du sun phyung ba med par ni bdag nyes pa med par mthong bas bskyed pa'i chags pa de spong bar ni nus pa ma yin no/ /

We ask what comes of seeing that attachment to a self is faulty. If you reply “From seeing it in this way, it (attachment to a self) is abandoned,” unless its (clinging to a self's) object is disproved and shown to not exist by way of seeing it as having faults, the person you assert as having achieved liberation is unable to abandon that clinging produced by seeing the self as faultless.
de'i gzhung 'dzugs par bya ba'i phyir/
To establish this position:
yon tan skyon dang rjes 'brel ba'i/ / 'dod dang sdang sogs spong ba ni/ / de dag yul la ma mthong bas/ / yin gyi phyi tshul gang gis min/ /
224. Desire, aversion, and so forth, which follow From qualities and faults, are eliminated By not perceiving those within the object, Not in the way external things would be.

zhes smos te/ gtan tshigs ma nges pa ma yin no/ / 'di ltar yul gang la yon tan dang skyon de dag mthong ba dang go rim bzhin du rjes su 'brel bar skyes pa'i 'dod chags dang zhe sdang dang phrag dog la sogs pa spong ba ni rgyu yon tan dang skyon de dag yul la ma mthong bas spong ba yin gyi/ yid kyi skyon dag ni phyi rol kyi tsher ma 'don pa'i tshul gang gi sgo nas spong nus pa ma yin no zhes pa lha'i'o/ /

The reason is not indeterminate. Desire and aversion, which respectively follow from seeing qualities and faults, and so forth including jealousy are eliminated by not perceiving those (qualities and faults, the causes) within the object. Mental faults cannot be discarded in the way that external things would be discarded, such as by pulling out a thorn. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
des na bdag tu chags pa skyon can du mthong bas bdag tu 'dzin pa ma yin gyi/ bdag gi yon tan mthong ba las chags pa skye ba bdag la yon tan du mthong ba spang dgos so zhes bshad pa/

Therefore it is not that we cling to a self through seeing attachment to a self as faulty. Instead, attachment arises from seeing the qualities of the self, so one must abandon seeing qualities in the self. To explain:
chags yon tan gyi chags min gyi/ / don gyi yon tan mthong bas yin/ / ma tshang med rgyu de la ni/ / 'bras bu gang gi zlog par byed/ /
225. Clinging is not from qualities of clinging; It is from seeing the object's qualities. And if the cause should not be incomplete, What would prevent it having a result?

ces smos te/ bdag tu chags pa skyon can du mthong bas bdag 'dzin spong nus pa ma yin te/ bdag 'dzin gyi rgyu dang 'gal ba med pa'i phyir te/ bdag tu chags pa rang nyid la yon tan can du mthong ba tsam gyis bdag la chags pa skye ba ma yin gyi/ don bdag gi yon tan mthong bas skye ba yin pa'i phyir ro/ / de'i phyir grol bar 'dod pa'i skyes bu chos can/ 'bras bu bdag tu 'dzin pa gang gis zlog par byed de bzlog par mi nus par thal/ bdag tu 'dzin pa'i ma tshang ba med pa'i rgyu bdag tu zhen pa yod pa de la ni de'i phyir rgyan gyis bsdu ba'i tshigs su bcad pa'o zhes bshad/

Seeing clinging to a self as faulty cannot abandon ego-clinging, because it is not exclusively the cause of ego-clinging. This is because clinging to a self does not arise from merely seeing clinging to a self as having qualities. Instead, it is from seeing the qualities of the object, the self. For that reason, for a person asserted to be liberated, the subject, what would prevent them having the result, ego-clinging? It follows that the result cannot be prevented, because the cause for clinging to a self is present and not incomplete. The Ornament explains, “This is a verse in summary.”[245]
gsum pa chags pa skyon bcas nyid kyang ma grub pa la/
3. Attachment is not even proven to be faulty
chags la skyon yang gang zhig mthong / /
226a And what is the faultiness you see in clinging?
zhes smos te/ bdag la chags pa la skyon yang gang zhig yod par mthong nas bdag tu chags pa de spong ba yin ces dris pa'o/ /
We ask, what is the faultiness you see in clinging to a self so that such clinging to a self is discarded?
de la gzhan dag na re/
Others respond:
gal te sdug bsngal rten ce na/ /
226b If it is the support for suffering,

zhes smos te/ gal te bdag tu chags pa las bde ba la yongs su sred pa dang ldan pa'i sdug bsngal du gyur pa'i 'khor ba len cing rten pa'i phyir/ bdag tu chags pa ni skyon dang ldan par grub ste/ dper na sbrul gyi sos zin pa'i sor mo bzhin no zhe na/ bshad pa/

If you say, “It is from clinging to a self that one grasps at samsara that is suffering conjoined with craving for happiness; it is the support. For that reason clinging to a self is faulty, like a finger that has been bitten by a snake.” To explain:
de lta'ang 'di la chags bral min/ / bdag gir mthong phyir dper bdag bzhin/ /
226cd Even so, this is not freedom from desire Because it's seen as mine, just like the self.

ces smos te/ bdag la chags pas sdug bsngal gyi rten byed pa de ltar na'ang bdag la chags pa 'di la chags bral yod pa min te/ bdag gir mthong zhing zhen pa'i phyir/ dper na bdag sdug bsngal gyi rten byed kyang chags pa dang bral ba min pa bzhin no zhes lha'i'o/ / rgyan las/ sdug bsngal gyi rten ni dang po nyid du bdag yin te/ bdag yod na zhen pas phyis sdug bsngal gyi rgyur 'gyur gyi/ bdag med na su zhig sdug bsngal/ zhes gsungs so/ /

Clinging to a self does support suffering, yet even so, this is not freedom from desire for that self-clinging, because it is seen as mine and fixated on. For example, it is like the self, for which one is not free of desire even though it supports suffering. This is according to Devendrabuddhi. The Ornament says: From the very first, the support for suffering is the self. If there is a self, fixation later causes suffering, but if there is no self, who suffers?[246]
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
gal te de med bdag sdug bsngal/ / rgyu min/
227ab If without those, the self were not the cause Of suffering,

ces smos te/ gal te 'di snyam du bdag sdug bsngal gyi rten byed pa ni bdag tu zhen pa dang / chos dang chos min pa dang / 'du byed pa dang lhan cig tu tshogs pa na yin gyi/ tshogs pa de dag med pa'i bdag gcig pus sdug bsngal gyi rgyu'am rten byed pa min no zhe na/ bshad pa/

If you think, “The self that supports suffering is assembled together with fixation on a self, dharma and non-dharma, and formations. Without those being assembled, the self alone is not the cause or support of suffering.” To explain:
de yang de dang 'dra/ / de ltar gnyis ka'ang skyon med pa/ / de phyir gnyis la chags bral min/ /
227b-d it would be similar. The both of them would thus be free of fault, And therefore neither is free of desire.

ces smos te/ 'o na bdag tu chags pa de yang skyon med du 'gyur te/ bdag de dang 'dra bar tshogs ma tshang bas sdug bsngal mi bskyed pa'i phyir/ de ltar na bdag dang bdag tu chags pa gnyis ka'ang so sor sdug bsngal gyi rgyu byed pa'i skyon med pa de'i phyir/ bdag dang bdag tu chags pa gnyis po gang la yang chags pa dang bral ba ma yin par 'gyur ro zhes rgyan gyi'o/ /

Well then, it (clinging to a self) would also be faultless, because similarly to the self, it does not produce suffering if the assembly is incomplete. Both of them (the self and self-clinging) would thus individually be free of the fault of causing suffering. And therefore neither the self nor clinging to a self would be free of desire. This is according to Prajñākaragupta.
gsum pa bdag tu chags pa spong ba'i sgrub byed dgag pa la/
C. Rebutting the proof of abandoning clinging to a self.

sdug bsngal du bsgom pas chags pa mi spong ba'i rgyu mtshan/ sdug bsngal du shes kyang chags pa mi ldog/ sdug bsngal dang bcas pa nyid kyang mi 'thad/ sdug bsngal du shes pa chags pa'i rgyu dang mi 'gal/ ser skya pa'i chags bral dgag/ sdug bsngal la yid byung ba chags bral ma yin/ chags bral nyid bshad/ sdug bsngal bsgom par gsungs pa dang 'gal ba spang pa'o/ /

This has eight topics: 1. The reason that meditating on suffering does not abandon attachment, 2. Even knowing ego-clinging to be suffering does not prevent attachment, 3. It would be untenable for a faultless self to have suffering, 4. Knowing it to be suffering is not exclusive of the cause of attachment, 5. Refuting the detachment of the Kāpilas, 6. Disgust with suffering is not detachment, 7. Explaining detachment itself, and 8. Rebutting that this is contradictory of the instruction to meditate on suffering.
dang po [sdug bsngal du bsgom pas chags pa mi spong ba'i rgyu mtshan] la/
1. The reason that meditating on suffering does not abandon attachment
chags pa spong ba'i dpe mi mtshungs pa/ bdag yod par 'dod pa mi rigs pa/ bdag tu chags pa yod na bdag gir chags pa spong mi nus pa/ bdag la chags pa dang bral na ha cang thal ba dang bzhi/

This has four topics: a. The analogies for discarding attachment are not comparable, b. It is not logical to assert the self exists, c. If there is attachment to a self, one is unable to abandon attachment to mine, and d. The absurd consequence if one were free of attachment to a self.
dang po [chags pa spong ba'i dpe mi mtshungs pa] la
a. The analogies for discarding attachment are not comparable.
bdag gi bcom pa chags bral gyi rgyu bstan pa/ gzhan gyi chags bral gyi rgyu dgag/ de'i lan dgag pa dang gsum/
This has three points: i. Teaching that eliminating the thought “mine” causes detachment, ii. Refuting what others assert to be the cause of detachment, and iii. Rebutting the response.
dang po [bdag gi bcom pa chags bral gyi rgyu bstan pa] ni/
i. Teaching that eliminating the thought “mine” causes detachment
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
gal te sbrul gzung yan lag bzhin/ / sdug bsngal bsgom pa spong 'gyur na/ /
228ab If like a snake-bitten limb, it were discarded By meditating upon suffering,

zhes smos te/ gal te dper na sbrul gyi sos bzung ba'i yan lag sdug bsngal du bsgom pas spong ba bzhin du bdag tu chags pa la sogs pa sdug bsngal du sgom par byed cing / sdug bsngal du bsgom pas bdag tu chags pa spong bar 'gyur bas/ de ltar na skyon med ces pa'i gtan tshigs ma grub bo zhe na/ bshad pa/

If you say that for example, one discards a limb that has been bitten by a snake by meditating on it as suffering, likewise one discards it (attachment to a self) by meditating upon it as suffering. Therefore the reason of being free of fault is not proven.[247] To explain:
bdag gi ba blo bcom pas 'di/ / 'dor ba yin gyi ldog pas min/ /
228cd Eliminating the concept of mine Abandons this; the opposite does not.

ces smos te/ sbrul gyi sos bzung ba'i yan lag la bdag gi ba'i blo bcom pas de'i sos zin pa'i yan lag 'di 'dor ba yin gyi/ de las bzlog pas bdag gi ba'i blo bcom bzhin du sdug bsngal du bsgom pa tsam las de'i sos bzung ba'i yan lag spong ba ma yin no/ /

The snake-bitten limb is forsaken by eliminating the concept of the snake-bitten limb being mine. Unlike eliminating the concept of mine, the opposite of that—merely meditating on it as suffering—does not get one to relinquish the bitten limb.
des na dpe de khyed la mi mtshungs so zhes bstan pa'i phyir/
Therefore, to teach that the analogy is not a good comparison for you either:
dbang po la sogs longs spyod kyi/ / rten nyid du ni bzung ba la/ / rang blo gang gis bzlog 'gyur te/ / de la chags bral de gang las/ /
229. In maintaining that the faculties And so forth are the supports for enjoyment, What will prevent the thought of them as mine? For them, how could there be detachment?

zhes smos te/ sdug bsngal du mthong yang mig gi dbang po dang lus kyi dbang po la sogs pa longs spyod kyi rten nyid du ni bzung ba la ste/ de'i phyir khyed 'dod pa'i 'dod chags dang bral ba'i skyes bu ni mig la sogs pa'i dbang po la sdug bsngal du mthong bas rang gi bar 'dzin pa'i blo gang gis na bzlog par 'gyur te/ de'i phyir mig gi dbang po sdug bsngal du bsgom pas mig sogs de la chags pa dang bral ba de gang las yin te ma yin no/ /

In maintaining that the eye faculty, body faculty, and so forth are the supports for enjoyment even while seeing them as suffering, what will prevent your individual free of desire for Desire who sees the faculties of the eye and so forth as suffering from thinking of them as mine? For that reason, how could there be detachment for them through meditating on the faculty of eye as suffering? There is not.
de'i dpe bstan pa'i phyir/
To teach an analogy for this:
lus las bog pa'i skra sogs la/ / yid 'byung blo ni skye 'gyur zhing / / gzhan la zhen bcas skye 'gyur ba/ / thams cad kyis ni mngon sum yin/ /
230. It's obvious to everyone That feelings of disgust arise For hair and such shed from the body While clinging occurs for the other.

ces smos te/ dper na bdag gi ba'i blo med pas lus las bog pa'i skra dang sen mo dang mchil ma sogs la yid 'byung zhing zhen pa med pa'i blo ni skye bar 'gyur zhing / gzhan ma bog pa'i skra la sogs pa la zhen pa dang bcas pa'i blo skye bar 'gyur ba ni skye bo thams cad kyi ni mngon sum yin pa'i phyir/ sdug bsngal mthong ba chags bral gyi rgyu ma yin par bdag gi ba'i blo bcom pa chags pa dang bral ba'i rgyu yin no zhes lha rgyan gnyis ka'i'o/ /

For example, since there is no thought of them as mine, feelings of disgust and non-attachment arise for hair, nails, spit, and such that are shed from the body while feelings of clinging occur for the other, hair and such that has not been shed. This is obvious to everyone, all people. For that reason, seeing suffering is not a cause of detachment, whereas eliminating the thought of mine is the cause of detachment. This is according to both Devendrabuddhi and Prajñākaragupta.
gnyis pa gzhan gyi chags bral gyi rgyu dgag pa la/
ii. Refuting what others assert to be the cause of detachment
bye brag pa na re/
According to the Vaiśeṣikas:
de la 'du sogs 'brel ba las/ / rang gi blo ni skye 'gyur ba'i/ /
231ab If the conception “mine” arose out of Relations of inherence and so forth,

zhes smos te/ gal te sdug bsngal bsgom pas 'dod chags la sogs pa spong yang lus las ma bog pa'i skra la sogs pa la bdag gi ba'i blo skye ba de la bdag dang 'phrod pa 'du ba dang / lus longs spyod kyi rten nyid dang / dbang po longs spyod kyi sgrub par byed pa nyid la sogs par 'brel ba las rang gi ba'i blo skye bar 'gyur ba'i phyir/ 'dod chags dang bral ba min no zhe na/ bshad pa/

Desire and so forth are abandoned by meditating on them as suffering, but the conception of “mine” that arises with regard to hair and so forth that have not been shed from the body arises out of relations of inherence between that and the self, the body as the support of enjoyment, the faculties as the means to get enjoyments, and so forth. For that reason, they are not free of desire, they say. To explain:
'brel te de bzhin nyid gnas phyir/ / mthong du zin kyang spong mi 'gyur/ /
231cd Since those relations would remain the same, Even if faults were seen, they'd not be abandoned.

zhes smos te/ de ltar khyod kyi 'dod chags dang bral bar 'dod pa'i skyes bu la bdag dang bdag gir chags pa la sogs pa nges par bskyed pa'i rgyu bdag dang 'du ba la sogs pa'i 'brel ba de sngar chags pa dang ma bral ba'i gnas skabs ji lta ba de bzhin nyid du phyis kyang gnas pa'i phyir na/ bdag dang bdag gir chags pa la sogs pa'i nyes pa mthong du zin kyang chags pa spong bar mi 'gyur bar thal lo/ /

If that were so, for the person you assert to be free of desire, the cause that definitely produces clinging to me and mine and so forth, the self and those relations of inherence and so forth, would remain exactly the same in later periods as they were in the previous period when they were not free of desire. For that reason, it would follow that even if the faults of clinging to me and mine were seen, clinging would not be abandoned.

grangs can pa na re/ bdag gi ba dang bdag 'du sogs su 'brel ba las chags pa skye ba ma yin gyi/ kho bo cag ji srid rang bzhin dang / skyes bu dbang sogs dang / gcig tu nges pa can gyi blo yod pa de srid du 'khor ba yin cing / gang gi tshe rang bzhin dang / skyes bu dbang sogs dang / gzhan yin par shes pa de'i tshe rang bzhin dang / skyes bu'i khyad par shes pa'i phyir grol ba yin no zhe na/ bshad pa/

The Sāṃkhyas say that attachment does not arise from relations of inherence to self or mine. As long as there is a conception that ascertains the primal substance to be the same as the puruṣa, faculties, and so forth, there is samsara. When one knows that the primal substance is different from the puruṣa, faculties, and so forth, then because one knows the distinction between the primal substance and the puruṣa, one is liberated, they say. To explain:
'du ba la sogs med na yang / / phan 'dogs nyid ni kun la yod/ /
232ab Even without inherence and so forth, There is the benefit for everything.

ces smos te/ 'phrod pa 'du ba la sogs pa med na yang rang bzhin dang / skyes bu dbang sogs dang / gcig tu 'dzin pa'i blo chags pa'i rgyu min te/ phyi rol gyi longs spyod zas gos la sogs pa skyes bu dang / gcig tu 'dzin pa med na yang phan 'dogs par byed pa nyid du mthong nas bdag gir chags pa ni kun la yod pa'i phyir/

Even without inherence and so forth, the mind that holds the primal substance to be the same as the puruṣa, faculties, and so forth is not the cause of attachment, because even without holding external enjoyments such as food, clothing, and so forth to be the same as the puruṣa, they are seen to be beneficial, and there is clinging to everything as mine.
gsum pa de'i lan dgag pa la/
iii. Rebutting the response
kha cig na re/
Others say:
sdug bsngal bskyed phyir sor mo bzhin/ / rang gi blo ni mi 'gyur na/ /
232cd If there were no idea of them as mine Since they, like a finger, produce suffering,

zhes smos te/ sdug bsngal bskyed pa'i rgyu yin pa'i phyir/ lus kyi dbang po la sogs pa la rang gi 'dzin pa'i blo ni skye bar mi 'gyur te/ dper na sbrul gyis zin pa'i sor mo la rang gir 'dzin pa'i blo med pas dor bya yin pa bzhin no/ /

Since they are causes that produce suffering, there would occur no idea of them (the body faculty and so forth) as mine. It is like, for example, a finger bitten by a snake: since there is no conception of it as mine, it is abandoned.
des na gtan tshigs ma grub bo zhe na/ bshad pa/
Therefore, the reason is not proven, they say. To explain:
gcig tu de ni sdug bsngal min/ /
233a They are not solely suffering.
ces smos te/ mtha' gcig tu lus dang dbang po la sogs pa de dang de ni sdug bsngal gyi rgyu ma yin te/ skabs 'ga' zhig tu bde ba bskyed pa'ang srid pa'i phyir ro/ /
They (the body, faculties, and so forth) are not solely the causes of suffering because it is also possible that they might produce pleasure in some instances.
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
phal cher dug bcas zas bzhin no/ /
233b “They mostly are, like poisoned food.”
zhes smos te/ lus dang dbang po la sogs pa ni phal cher sdug bsngal gyi rgyu yin pa'i phyir chags pa dang bral ba yin te/ dper na dug dang bcas pa'i zas bzhin no zhe na/ bshad pa/
“They (the body, faculties, and so forth) mostly are the cause of suffering. For that reason there is freedom from attachment, as with poisoned food,” you say. To explain:
khyad par can des la chags pas/ / de 'gal ba la chags bral 'gyur/ / khyad par can bde la sred pas/ / bde ba cung zad yongs su spong / /
233cd Because of lusting for superior pleasures, One is detached from what's exclusive of that. 234ab Because of craving a superior pleasure, One would forsake some minor satisfaction.

zhes smos te/ srog la gnod pa mi byed pa'i zas rnyed pa'i skyes bu ni srog la mi gnod cing lus stobs bskyed pa la sogs pa'i khyad par can gyi bde ba'i rgyur gyur pa'i kha zas dang longs spyod de la chags pas te/ de'i phyir srog la mi gnod pa'i zas de dang 'gal ba lus la gnod pa'i dug bcas kyi zas la chags pa dang bral bar 'gyur ro/ / khyab pa ma nges pa'ang ma yin te/ srog la mi gnod cing stobs 'phel ba'i khyad par can gyi bde ba'i rgyur gyur pa'i kha zas longs spyod rnyed cing / de la sred pas ni bde ba cung zad zhim pa dang 'grangs pa tsam gyi rgyu byed pa'i dug dang bcas pa'i zas yongs su spong ba'i phyir ro/ /

People who have found food that does not endanger their lives lust for food and enjoyments that cause the superior pleasures such as increasing physical strength without endangering their lives. Because of that, they will become detached from that poisoned food that endangers their lives, which is exclusive of that food which does not endanger their lives. The pervasion is not indeterminate, because when people find food and enjoyments that cause the superior pleasures such as increasing physical strength without endangering their lives, they crave those, because of which they would forsake poisoned food that causes some minor satisfaction by merely tasting good and being filling.
de dag gi gzhung 'dzugs pa'i phyir/
To establish these positions:
bsam med bdag la chags pa yi/ / ji ltar rnyed bzhin la 'jug ste/ / bud med dag ni ma rnyed pa/ / dud 'gro la 'dod spyod mthong bzhin/ /
234cd Unthinkingly, from clinging to a self, One acts upon whatever one obtains. 235ab It's just as men who cannot get a woman Are seen to perform carnal acts with beasts.

zhes smos te/ khyed zas khyad par can rnyed na dug can gyi zas mi za ba yin na'ang de tsam gyi chags pa dang bral ba ni ma yin te/ khyad par can gyi zas sogs bde ba'i rgyur gyur pa dngos su ma rnyed pas bsam pa med pa'i blun po kha cig bdag la chags pa'i dbang du gyur pa yis dug dang bcas pa'i kha zas la sogs pa ji ltar gang rnyed pa bzhin la 'jug cing chags pa'ang yod de/ dper na skyes bu chags pa dang ldan pa 'ga' zhig bud med dag ni ma rnyed pas dud 'gro mo la 'dod pa spyod pa mthong ba bzhin no zhes pa lha'i'o/ /

Even if you obtain superior food and do not eat poisoned food, that alone does not make you detached. Because they do not actually find superior food and so forth that cause pleasure, from coming under the power of clinging to a self, some unthinking fools act upon and cling to whatever poisoned food or so forth they obtain. For example, it is just as some lustful men who cannot get a woman are seen to perform carnal acts with female animal beasts. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
gnyis pa bdag yod par mi rigs pa la/
b. It is not logical to assert the self exists
kha cig na re/ thar pa'i gnas skabs na bdag de bde sdug sogs myong ba'i rten ma yin pas/ bdag gi bde ba la zhen pa med pa'i phyir/ bdag gi ba don du gnyer bar mi byed do zhe na/ bshad pa/

Some say that the self at the time of liberation is not the support for the experience of pleasure and pain, so there is no fixation on “my” pleasure, and therefore one does not seek mine. To explain:
bdag ni 'dod pa gang yin te/ / ji ltar de ni 'jig par 'dod/ / myong ba dang ni tha snyad dag/ yon tan kun gyi rten log pa/ / ji ltar zhen pa yin 'dod de/ / zhen pa'i rang bzhin de 'dra min/ /

235cd How could someone who loves the self So dearly wish it be destroyed? 236. How could fixation wish the basis Of all experience, conventions, And qualities would cease to be? The nature of fixation is not so.

ces smos te/ bdag ni yod par 'dod pa'i skyes bu thar par 'dod pa gang yin pa des ji ltar na bdag de ni myong ba la sogs pa'i rten du 'jig cing med par 'dod de/ bdag bde sdug sogs nyams su myong ba dang ni tha snyad dag shes rab la sogs pa'i yon tan kun gyi rten byed pa las log par 'dod pa dang / ji ltar bdag la bden par zhen pa yin par 'dod pa de 'gal ba'i phyir dang / myong ba la sogs pa'i rten byed pa ni bdag gi mtshan nyid yin par khas blangs pa'i phyir ro/ / des na bdag log par mi 'dod na myong ba la sogs pa'i rten bdag log par zhen pa'i rang bzhin de 'dra ba ma grub pa min no zhes pa lha'i'o/ /

How could a person said to be liberated who asserts[248] the self exists wish that it (that self) be destroyed and not exist as a support for experience and so forth? Because the wish that the self—the basis of all experiences of pleasure, pain, and so forth, of all conventions, and of all qualities such as intelligence—would cease to be is contradictory of the assertion that the self truly exists as they are fixated upon it. Therefore if the self is not accepted to cease, the nature of fixation is not, and is not established as being, such fixation on the cessation of the self, the support of experience. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
gsum pa bdag tu chags pa yod na bdag gir chags pa spong mi nus pa ni/
c. If there is attachment to a self, one is unable to abandon attachment to mine
rnam pa kun tu bdag 'dzin ni/ / bdag la chags pa brtan par byed/ / de ni bdag gir zhen pa yi/ / sa bon gnas skabs de nyid gnas/ /
237. Apprehending a self will reinforce In every way the clinging to a self. That is the seed of fixating on mine. In such a situation, that remains.

zhes smos te/ 'di ltar rnam pa kun tu bdag tu 'dzin pas ni bdag la chags pa brtan par byed pa yin la/ bdag la chags pa de ni bdag gir zhen pa'i sa bon yin pa'i phyir/ khyod kyi grol bar 'dod pa'i skyes bu 'di la ji srid bdag tu chags pa yod pa'i gnas skabs de srid du bdag gir zhen pa de nyid kyang gnas pa yin no/ / des na rgyu bdag tu chags pa dang ldan na 'bras bu bdag gi bar chags pa dang ldan pa yin te/ dper na nad kyi rgyu dang ldan na nad dang ldan pa lta bu'o/ /

In this manner, apprehending a self reinforces in every way the clinging to the self, and that clinging to a self is the seed of fixating on “mine.” For that reason, as long as the person you assert to be liberated is in such a situation of clinging to a self, that fixation on mine will remain. Therefore those who possess the cause—clinging to a self— also possess the result—clinging to mine—just as, for example, those who have the cause of illness have the illness.
de'i gzhung 'dzugs par bya ba'i phyir/
To establish these positions:
brtson yang yon tan cha brten gnas/ / 'jug ldan bdag gi ba la ni/ / chags bral gegs byed pa nyid dang / / de yi skyon yang sgrib pa yin/ /
238. Despite their efforts, behavior based upon The portions that are qualities prevents Freedom from attachment to a mine, And that conceals its faults as well.

ces smos te/ khyod kyi grol bar 'dod pa'i skyes bu ni bdag gir chags pa spong ba'i ched du brtson na yang bdag la chags na bdag gi ba'i yon tan gyi cha mthong ba la brten nas rkyen ji lta ba bzhin du bdag gir chags pa skye zhing 'jug pa dang ldan pa yin te/ bdag la chags pa ma spangs pa'i dbang gis bdag gi ba la ni chags pa dang bral ba'i gegs byed pa nyid kyi phyir dang / bdag gi ba de yi skyon mthong ba yang sgrib par byed pa yin pa'i phyir zhes pa lha'i'o/ /

Despite the efforts the people you assert to be liberated may make to abandon clinging to mine, if they are attached to a self, they see the portions of mine that are qualities. Based upon that, according to circumstances, clinging to me arises and they act. This is because not abandoning clinging to a self prevents freedom from attachment to mine and because that conceals the faults of mine from being seen as well. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
bzhi pa bdag la chags pa dang bral na ha cang thal ba ni/
d. The absurd consequence if one were free of attachment to a self
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
gal te bdag la'ang chags bral na/ /
239a If also free of clinging to the self,

zhes smos te/ gal te thar pa'i gnas skabs na ji ltar bdag gi ba dang bral ba de ltar bdag la'ang chags pa dang bral ba yin no/ / des na bdag tu chags pa'i sgo nas bdag lta bshad pa thams cad ma grub bo zhe na/ de la ni/ nyes med bdag la chags pa dag/ bral ba'i rgyu yang yod ma yin/ / ces bya bar nyes pa bshad zin la/ gzhan yang /

At the time of liberation, just as they are free of mine, they are also free of clinging to the self. Therefore, all the explanations of personality view in terms of clinging to a self are unfounded, they say. The faults of this have already explained in the verses “There is no cause for freedom from / Attachment to a faultless self.”[249] Additionally:
da ni chags bral gang yin med/ / de ni ji ltar bdag 'dor ba/ / sdug bsngal bsgom pa don med 'gyur/ /

zhes smos te/ thar pa'i gnas skabs na da ni bdag la chags pa dang bral ba po'i bdag gang yin pa de med par thal/ bdag la chags pa dang bral ba'i phyir dang / gzhan yang bdag gir chags pa spong ba'i ched du brtson pa'i skyes bu de ni ji ltar na bdag gi ba la chags pa dang bral ba'i don du sdug bsngal bsgom pa don med par 'gyur bar thal te/ bdag la chags pa dang bral ba'i sgo nas bdag 'dor bas bdag gi ba la chags pa dang bral bar grub pa'i phyir/

In that case, it follows that at the time of liberation, there is no self that is to be free of clinging to a self, because they are free of clinging to a self. Additionally, it follows that it would be pointless for a person who is trying to abandon clinging to mine to meditate on suffering in order to become free of attachment to mine in this manner, because the self has been discarded by way of becoming free of attachment to it, so it is proven that they are free of attachment to mine.
gnyis pa sdug bsngal du shes kyang mi ldog pa ni/
2. Even knowing ego-clinging to be suffering does not prevent attachment
de dag sdug bsngal bsgom pas kyang / / sdug bsngal nyid ni rnam shes byed/ / de ni sngar yang mngon sum nyid/ / de ltar na yang chags bral med/ /
240. By meditating on suffering as well, Suffering would be distinctly known itself, But that was evident earlier as well, And likewise they would not become detached.

ces smos te/ khyed kyi chags pa dang bral bar 'dod pa'i rnal 'byor pa de dag ni bdag gi ba sdug bsngal du bsgom pas kyang de la sdug bsngal nyid du ni mngon sum du rnam par shes par byed kyang bdag la chags pa'i phyir/ sdug bsngal du shes pa de ltar na yang bdag gi ba la chags pa dang bral ba med do/ / dper na sdug bsngal de ni sngar ma bsgoms pa'i so so skye bo'i gnas skabs na mngon sum nyid du mthong ba yin kyang bdag la chags pa dang ma bral ba bzhin no/ /

By meditating on mine as suffering as well, the yogis that you assert to be detached would distinctly know that directly to be suffering itself. However, because they cling to a self, even though they know it to be suffering, they would likewise not be free of attachment to mine. For example, earlier as well—during the period of being an ordinary individual before meditating on suffering—that was directly evident and seen, but they were not detached to a self.
gzhan dag na re/ skyes bu 'ga' zhig la lar chags yul gyi nyes pa mthong bas 'dod chags dang bral bar mthong ba'i phyir/ gtan tshigs ma grub pa'am ma nges pa nyid yin no zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others say, “It is seen that some people are freed of desire by seeing the faults of the object of attachment. Therefore your reason is not proven or is indeterminate.” To explain:
gal te de la nyes pa yis/ / skad cig de yi blo ldog kyang / / de la chags bral mi 'gyur te/ / 'dod ldan bud med gzhan la bzhin/ /
241. And if perchance because of something's faults, Their thoughts are displaced from it for a moment, They are not free of desire for that thing, As with a lustful man and other women.

zhes smos te/ bdag la chags pa dang ldan pa'i skyes bu 'ga' zhig gal te chags yul de la nyes pa 'ga' zhig mthong ba yis ji srid nyes pa mthong ba'i skad cig de srid du skyes bu de yi chags pa'i blo ldog kyang chags pa'i yul de la shin tu 'dod chags dang bral bar mi 'gyur te/ yul thams cad kyi chags pa ma spangs pa'i phyir te/ chags yul gyi yon tan mthong ba las kyang slar chags pa skye ba srid pa'i phyir/ dper na 'dod chags dang ldan pa'i skyes bus bud med 'ga' zhig la nyes pa mthong bas 'dod chags dang bral kyang bud med gzhan la chags pa dang ma bral ba bzhin no/ /

If perchance for some people who have self-clinging, when they see some faults in something that is the object of desire, their (the desirous people's) thoughts of desire might be displaced from it for the moment of seeing the faults, but they are not completely free of desire for that thing which is the object of desire, because they have not abandoned desire for all objects. This is because it is possible that desire will once again arise from seeing the qualities of the object of desire. For example, some lustful men see faults in some women and thus are free of desire for them, but they are not free of desire for other women.
de nyid kyi gzhung 'dzugs par bya ba'i phyir/
To establish this position:
blang dang dor bya'i khyad yod na/ / gcig la 'byung ba'i chags gang yin/ / de nyid rnam grangs kyis bskyed tshe/ / chags pa kun gyi sa bon yin/ /
242. If there's a difference between what to shun And what to appropriate, the attachment that Arises for the one becomes the seed Of all desires when they arise in order.

zhes smos te/ de'ang skyes bu 'ga' zhig gis mngon par 'dod par bya ba'i bud med lta bu la blang bya dang / mngon par mi 'dod pa'i bud med lta bu la dor byar zhen pa'i khyad par sna tshogs yod pa na/ blang byar 'dod pa'i yul gcig las 'byung ba'i 'dod chags gang yin pa de nyid rgyu rkyen gyi rnam grangs kyis bskyed pa'i tshe na chags pa kun gyi sa bon du gyur pa yin pa'i phyir/ 'dod chags dang bral bar 'dod pa'i skyes bu ni yul 'ga' zhig la re zhig chags pa dang bral kyang yul 'ga' zhig la chags pa de ni re zhig chags pa dang bral ba'i rgyu la yang brgyud nas chags pa skye ba'i sa bon yin no zhes pa lha'i'o/ /

If there are various differences between what to shun (such as the women some men do not want) and what to appropriate (such as the women they want), the attachment that arises for the one object that is desired to be appropriated becomes the seed of all desires when they arise through a variety[250] of causes and conditions. For that reason, the person asserted to be free of desire may be temporarily free of attachment to some objects, but the attachment they have for other objects is indirectly the seed for attachment to arise for that for which they are temporarily free of attachment. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
gsum pa sdug bsngal dang bcas pa nyid kyang mi 'thad pa ni/
3. It would be untenable for a faultless self to have suffering
skyon med yul can chags pa dang / / sgrub byed kyang ni skyon med yin/ / 'gro ba'ang de tsam nyid yin na/ / da ni gang la chags bral 'gyur/ /
243. Objects would have no faults, nor would attachment, And the means to attain would have none either.[251] If beings were just that, then in that case What would they be freed from attachment for?

zhes smos te/ gal te bdag skyon med pa de ltar yin na/ bdag skyon med la chags pa de'ang skyon med par 'gyur te/ bdag skyon med kyi yul can 'dun pa yin pa'i phyir te/ dper na thar pa la 'dun pa lta bu'o/ / de bzhin du bdag skyon med kyi longs spyod sgrub par byed pa dbang po la sogs pa'i bdag gi ba de dag kyang ni skyon med yin cing 'khor ba'i 'ching ba las grol bar 'gyur ro/ / de ltar na 'gro ba'ang bdag dang / bdag la chags pa dang / dbang po dang yul la sogs pa'i bdag gi ba de tsam nyid yin na/ da ni skyes bu de dag dang / bdag gi ba la chags pa dang / bdag gi ba gsum po gang la 'dod chags dang bral ba bsgom par bya bar 'gyur te/ bdag dang bdag la chags pa dang / bdag gi ba de dag la skyon med pa nyid kyi phyir ro/ / dang ni 'byed pa'i tshig go/

If the self were faultless, attachment to the faultless self would then be faultless, because it is interest that is the conscious subject of a faultless self, like interest in liberation. Similarly, the mine that is faculties and so forth, which are the means to attain the enjoyments of the faultless self, also would be faultless and freed from the fetters of samsara. Therefore, if beings as well were just that self, attachment to the self, and the mine that is the faculties, objects, and so forth, then in that case, those persons, attachment to mine, and mine would all three be something to meditate on as being freed from attachment, because the self, attachment to self, and mine would be faultless. The word “and” indicates a distinction.[252]
de la gzhan dag na re/
Others reply:
der de skyon bcas kyang yin na/ /
244a If that for it had faults as well,

zhes smos te/ gal te bdag der chags pa de ni bdag skyon med pa'i yul can ma yin kyang skyon dang bcas pa dag kyang yin te/ sdug bsngal gyi rten nyid yin pa'i phyir zhe na/ de ni khyod nyid la yang mtshungs so zhes bshad pa/
That (attachment) for it (the self) is not a faultless subject of the self, but has faults as well because it is the support for suffering, you say. To explain that this is similar for you as well:
de ni bdag la'ang mtshungs pa yin/ / der de'i skyon la chags bral med/ / da ni gang la de chags bral/ /
244a-d that also Would be the same for the self. It would not Be free of attachment for its faults, so then What would they be freed from attachment for?

zhes smos te/ khyod kyi grol bar 'dod pa'i skyes bu de la sdug bsngal gyi rten byed pa de ni bdag la'ang mtshungs pa'i phyir/ bdag skyon dang bcas pa yin par 'gyur la/ bdag der sdug bsngal de'i rten byed pa'i skyon de la 'dod chags dang bral ba med na da ni gang la bdag tu chags pa dang / bdag gi sdug bsngal gyi rten byed pa'i skyon du mthong bas de dag la chags pa dang bral te ma bral bar thal/ bdag sdug bsngal gyi rten byed pa'i skyon dang bcas par mthong bas bdag la chags pa dang bral ba med pa'i phyir ro zhes pa lha'i'o/ /

For the person you assert to be liberated, that (functioning as a support of suffering) would be the same for the self also. For that reason, the self would have faults. It (the self) would not be free of attachment for its faults, the support for its suffering, so then what attachment to a self and support for suffering would they be freed from attachment for by seeing the faults of those? It follows it would not be, because they are not freed of attachment to a self by seeing that it has the fault of supporting suffering. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
bzhi pa sdug bsngal shes pa chags pa'i rgyu dang mi 'gal ba la/
4. Knowing it to be suffering is not exclusive of the cause of attachment.
nyes pa mthong ba chags bral gyi rgyu ma yin pa/ yon tan mthong ba chags pa'i rgyu ma yin pa'o/ /
This has two points: a. Seeing faults is not the cause of detachment, and b. Seeing qualities is not the cause of attachment.
dang po [nyes pa mthong ba chags bral gyi rgyu ma yin pa] ni/
a. Seeing faults is not the cause of detachment

yon tan mthong ba las byung ba'i/ / zhen pa nyes pa mthong bas 'jigs/ / de ltar dbang sogs la de min/ / byis sogs la yang mthong phyir dang / / skyon ldan la yang yod phyir dang / / yon tan ldan yang gzhan dag la/ / med phyir 'das pa la sogs pa/ / bdag gi ba la med phyir ro/ /

245. Fixation born of seeing qualities Would be neutralized by seeing faults, But it's not so for faculties and so on Since it is seen in children and so forth,[253] 246. Since it occurs for what has faults as well, Since it does not occur for others even If they have qualities, and since there's none For the mine of the past, et cetera.

zhes smos te/ dbang po la sogs pa'i bdag gi ba skyon can du bsgom pa ni dbang sogs la chags pa'i rgyu dang mi 'gal ba'i phyir/ dbang po la sogs la chags pa'i gnyen po ma yin te/ ji ltar yul de la yon tan can du mthong ba las byung ba'i zhen pa zhig yin na ni yul de'i nyes pa mthong bas 'jig pa de ltar dbang po la sogs pa'i bdag gi ba la chags pa ni dbang po sogs la yon tan du mthong ba las skye ba de ma yin te/ byis pa dang phyugs la sogs pa skyon dang yon tan yod med kyi brtags dpyad dang bral ba la yang mig la sogs pa'i dbang po rnams la chags pa mthong ba'i phyir dang / rab rib dang long ba dang zhar ba dang gzugs ngan pa la sogs pa'i dbang po skyon dang ldan pa la yang dbang po sogs la chags pa yod pa'i phyir dang / dbang po'i yon tan dang ldan yang skyes bu gzhan dbang gi dbang po la bdag gir chags pa med pa'i phyir dang / bdag gi yan lag 'das shing zhig pa dang / rang gi lus las bog pa la sogs pa'i yan lag dang nying lag yon tan dang ldan pa la yang bdag gi bar chags pa med pa'i phyir ro/ /

Meditating on mine, the faculties, and so forth as faulty is not exclusive of the cause of attachment to the faculties and so forth. For that reason, it is not the antidote for attachment to the faculties and so forth. If there were fixation that was born of seeing an object as having qualities, it would be neutralized by seeing that object's faults, but it is not so that the attachment to the faculties and so on as mine arises from seeing the qualities of the faculties and so forth. This is because it is seen that children, cattle, and so forth lack any analysis as to whether there are qualities and faults, but they are attached to the faculties such as the eye; because it (attachment) occurs for the faculties and so forth that have faults such as cataracts, blindness, being crippled, being ugly, and so forth as well; because it does not occur for other beings' faculties even if the faculties have qualities; and since there is no attachment as mine for one's own appendages of the past that have perished or those limbs or appendages that have fallen from the body, et cetera, even if they have qualities.
gnyis pa yon tan mthong ba chags pa'i rgyu ma yin pa la/
b. Seeing qualities is not the cause of attachment

gzhan dag na re/ bdag gi ba'i blo de'ang yon tan mthong ba las 'byung bas de la sdug bsngal du bsgom pa ni bdag gi ba'i blo'i rgyur gyur pa yon tan mthong ba'i rgyun bcad pa las bdag gi ba la chags pa dang bral ba de ltar na gtan tshigs ma grub pa yin no zhe na/ bshad pa/

Others say that the thought “mine” arises from seeing qualities. Therefore meditating on them as suffering interrupts the continuum of the perception of qualities that causes the thought of mine. Due to that, one becomes free of attachment to mine, so therefore the reason is not proven, they say. To explain:
de nyid phyir na bdag gi ba'i/ / blo rgyu'ang yon tan mthong ba min/ / de phyir yon tan mi mthong bas/ / de yang spong ba ma yin no/ /
247. Thus for that reason, seeing qualities Is also not the cause of thinking “mine,” And therefore it is not eliminated By seeing that does not have qualities.

zhes smos te/ gang gi phyir byis sogs la yang mthong ba'i phyir/ zhes bya ba la sogs pa'i gtan tshigs de nyid kyi phyir na bdag gi ba'i blo skye ba'i rgyu'ang bdag gi ba la yon tan du mthong ba ma yin la/ bdag gi ba la yon tan mthong bas bdag gir chags pa bskyed pa ma yin pa de'i phyir/ bdag gi ba yon tan can ma yin par mthong bas bdag gi bar 'dzin pa'i blo de'i yang sa bon spong ba ma yin no/ / ji srid du bdag la chags pa dang ma bral bar de srid du bdag gi ba'i blo yod pa de bas na/ de srid du bdag gi ba la chags pa yod pa yin no zhes pa lha'i'o/ /

Thus for those reasons such as “Since it is seen in children and so forth...” and so on, seeing qualities in the mine is also not the cause that produces the thought “mine.” And because seeing qualities in mine does not produce clinging to mine, therefore the seeds of it— the mind that clings to mine—are not eliminated by seeing that mine does not have any qualities. Therefore, as long as one is not free of attachment to the self, one will have the thought “mine” and as long as one has that, one will have attachment to mine. This is according to Devendrabuddhi. To describe additional faults:
skyon gzhan yang brjod pa/ gzhan yang yod min yon tan ni/ / sgro 'dogs chags pas der yang mthong / / des na de rgyu gnod med can/ / bsgrubs pas de la ji ltar gnod/ /
248. Projections of nonexistent qualities Because of clinging are seen there as well. Therefore, how can accomplishing that which Does not prevent the causes prevent it?

ces smos te/ 'di ltar skyon gzhan yang khyod kyi 'dod chags dang bral bar 'dod pa'i skyes bu des bdag gi ba'i skyon mthong nas sdug bsngal du bsgom pas de la 'dod chags dang bral bar mi 'gyur te/ bdag gi ba la yod pa ma yin pa'i yon tan ni yod par sgro 'dogs shing bdag la chags pas bdag gi ba la yon tan can der yang mthong zhing / skyon mthong ba'i go skabs shin tu med pa'i phyir/ bdag gi chags pa de yon tan mthong ba las byung ba ma yin par bdag gir 'dzin pa'i rgyu las byung ba des na bdag gir chags pa de'i rgyu la gnod pa med pa can yin pa'i phyir/ grol ba'i phyir du dbang po la sogs pa'i bdag gi ba sdug bsngal du bsgom pa'i cho ga bsgrubs pas bdag gi bar chags pa de la ji ltar gnod de mi gnod pa kho na'o zhes mjug bsdu ba'o/ /

There are these additional faults: the person you assert to be free of attachment does not become detached by seeing the faults of mine and then meditating on it as suffering. This is because they project nonexistent qualities as being existent and cling to a self, the qualities of the mine are seen there as well, and there is absolutely no opportunity to see faults. That attachment to mine does not arise from seeing qualities; the cause it arises from is clinging to mine. Therefore, because it does not prevent the cause of attachment to mine, how can accomplishing rituals of meditating for the sake of liberation on mine—the faculties and so forth—as suffering prevent it (attachment to mine)? It could only not prevent it. This is a summary.
lnga pa ser skya ba'i chags bral dgag pa la/
5. Refuting the detachment of the Kāpilas

ser skya pa na re/ kho bo ni yon tan mthong ba las chags par mi smra'o/ / 'o na ci yin ce na/ rang bzhin dang skyes bu dang blo la sogs pa gcig tu bzung ba'i rgyu las chags pa 'byung la/ rang bzhin dang skyes bu gzhan du shes pas rang nyid kyi blo 'dor ba'i phyir 'dod chags dang bral ba yin no zhe na/ bshad pa/

The Kāpilas say, “We do not say that attachment is from seeing qualities. If you wonder what it is like, holding the primal substance, the puruṣa, and the mind to be the same causes attachment to arise. Understanding the primal substance and the puruṣa to be different discards the thought of oneself, and thus one becomes free of desire.” To explain:

mchog gzhan don du gnyer phyir dang / / skye 'jig blo can nyid kyi phyir/ / skye bo 'di yis dbang sogs las/ / bdag ni tha dad gyur par shes/ / de phyir gcig nyid mthong bas kyang / / chags min bdag la chags pa de/ / dmigs pa'i nang gi yan lag la/ / ngo bo nyid kyis rjes chags 'gyur/ /

249. Because they seek another that is better And since they know arising and perishing, These individuals understand the self Is separate from the faculties and so forth. 250. Thus dinging is not due to seeing sameness. And for that reason those who cling to a self Will naturally become attached to the Perceptual internal body parts.

zhes smos te/ byis pa so so'i skye bo 'di yis 'dod chags dang bral bar thal/ dbang po la sogs pa las bdag ni tha dad du gyur par shes pa'i phyir/ ji ltar tha dad du shes she na/ rang rgyud kyi mig gi dbang po la sogs pa yon tan med pa'i gnas skabs las mchog gzhan bdag gi mig gi dbang po la sogs pa gzhan las khyad par du 'phags par gyur cig snyam du don du gnyer ba'i phyir dang / nga yi bdag gzhan du gyur cig ces ni ma yin pa'i phyir dang / bdag gnas par mthong ba la dbang po dang skra sen dang yan lag la sogs pa skye zhing 'jig par rtogs pa'i blo can nyid kyi phyir ro/ / rang bzhin dang skyes bu tha dad du shes pa 'dod chags dang bral ba'i rgyu ma yin pa de'i phyir rang bzhin dang skyes bu gcig nyid du mthong bas kyang 'dod chags skye ba'i rgyu ma yin te/ de gnyis gcig tu mthong ba med kyang chags pa skye ba yod pa'i phyir ro/ / des na bdag la chags pa de ni bdag gi bar chags pa'i rgyu yin te/ yul gzugs sogs la dmigs par byed pa'i shes pa'i nang gi yan lag mig sogs dbang po lnga la bdag gi'o zhes ngo bo nyid dam rang bzhin gyis rjes su chags pa skye bar 'gyur ba'i phyir/

It follows that these childish ordinary individuals are free of desire because they understand that the self is separate from the faculties and so forth. How do they know they are separate? you ask. It is because when the eye faculty and so forth in their continuums lack qualities, they seek another that is better, thinking, “May mine be better than other eye faculties or so forth,” and because they don't think, “May my self become something else.” It is also since they see themselves to remain while having the understanding that knows that faculties, hair, nails, limbs, and so forth arise and perish. Knowing that the nature and the individual are separate is not the cause of freedom from desire, and thus seeing the nature and individual as the same is not the cause for desire to arise, because clinging arises even without seeing those two as the same. And for that reason, clinging to a self is the cause of clinging to a mine, because attachment to the five faculties of eye and so forth—the internal body parts that make a cognition perceive an object such as form—as mine will inherently or naturally arise.
drug pa sdug bsngal la yid 'byung ba chags bral ma yin pa la/
6. Disgust with suffering is not detachment

gzhan dag na re/ srog chags rnams kyi de ltar gzhan gyi sdug bsngal mthong nas 'dod chags dang bral bar 'gyur ba nyid ma yin nam/ de ji ltar na sdug bsngal bsgom pas 'dod chags dang bral ba ma yin ce na/ bshad pa/
Others say, “Doesn't one become detached by seeing the suffering of others, living beings? How is it that one does not becomes detached by meditating on suffering?” To explain:
gang zhig da ltar sdug bsngal bas/ / yid 'byung de 'dra sdang yin gyi/ / chags bral ma yin de tshe yang / / chags sogs skabs gzhan 'tshol phyir ro/ /
251. Weariness felt for present suffering Is aversion—such is not freedom from desire. At that time, there is clinging and so forth, As one will seek another situation.

zhes smos te/ skyes bu gang su zhig da ltar sdug bsngal gyis gdungs pa'i nyes pa mthong ba bsgom pas yid 'byung ba gang yin pa de 'dra ba ni 'dod chags dang bral ba ma yin te/ sdug bsngal mthong ba'i yid mi bde bas zhe sdang dang mtshungs par ldan pa'i skyo ba yin te/ de'i phyir dper na 'phags pa gnas brtan pa'i sde pas/ yid mi bde ba thams cad ni zhe sdang dang mtshungs par ldan pa yin no zhes bshad pa lta bu'o/ / zhe sdang dang mtshungs par ldan pa'i skyo ba de 'dra ba ni chags pa dang bral ba ma yin te/ de dang chags bral gnyis ni mi dge ba dang dge ba tha dad pa'i mtshan nyid can yin pa'i phyir te/ bcom ldan 'das kyi yid mi bde ba de 'dra ba mi dge ba nyid yin na yang dge ba'i chos skyed par byed pa nyid yin pa'i phyir/ bstan par bya ba nyid yin par bshad do/ / gzhan yang sdug bsngal gyi yid mi bde bas skyo ba skyes pa de'i tshe'ang bdag gi ba la chags pa yod de/ sdug bsngal gyi gnas skabs las gzhan bde ba 'dod cing 'tshol ba'i phyir ro/ /

The revulsion such as that felt by a person who meditates on seeing the faults of being afflicted by present suffering is not freedom from desire. It is despondence concurrent with aversion from the mental displeasure of seeing suffering. Thus it is like the explanation from the noble Theravāda school that all mental displeasure is concurrent with aversion. Such weariness that is concurrent with aversion is not detachment because the two of them—this and detachment—have the different characteristics of being unvirtuous and virtuous. The Bhaga-van said that although such mental displeasure is solely nonvirtue, it can produce virtuous qualities, and therefore it is taught. Additionally, at that time that weariness arises because of displeasure with suffering, there is clinging to mine, as one will want and seek another situation than that of suffering, happiness.
de la gzhan dag na re/ zhe sdang gtan du 'byung ba nyid chags bral min no zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others say of this that a permanent arising of hatred is not detachment. To explain:
zhe sdang sdug bsngal rgyu can phyir/ / de ni de srid tsam du gnas/ / de log na ni rang nyid kyi/ / rang bzhin nyid la slar brten 'gyur/ /
252. Because aversion's source is suffering, It only stays as long as there is that. When that has ceased, they once again Return to their own nature.

zhes smos te/ zhe sdang ni sdug bsngal rgyur yod pa las skye ba can yin pa'i phyir sdug bsngal med kyang rgyun du 'byung ba ma yin no/ / des na zhe sdang de ni sdug bsngal yod pa de srid tsam du gnas pa yin gyi/ sdug bsngal de log cing med na ni zhe sdang yang log cing med pas 'dod chags rang nyid kyi rang bzhin de nyid la slar yang brten par 'gyur ro/ /

Because aversion arises from the presence of suffering as a cause or source, it does not continually occur even if there is no suffering. Therefore it (aversion) only stays as long as there is that suffering. When that suffering has ceased and is not present, aversion also ceases and is not present. Thus they once again return to their own nature itself.[254]
bdun pa chags bral nyid bshad pa ni/
7. Explaining detachment itself
gzhan dag na re/ 'o na sdug bsngal las yid 'byung ni zhe sdang nyid yin gyi/ chags pa dang bral ba nyid ma yin na 'dod chags dang bral ba zhes bya ba de'ang gang zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others ask, “Well if weariness with suffering is aversion and not detachment, then what is it that is called 'freedom from attachment?'” To explain:
blang dang dor bya spangs pa'i phyir/ / thams cad la ni mnyam snyoms can/ / tsan+dan ste'u mtshungs pa la/ / chags bral zhes ni brjod pa yin/ /
253. As they've abandoned shunning and adopting, Those who are equanimous toward all And for whom sandalwood and axes are The same are said to be free of desire.

zhes smos te/ khams gsum la 'dod chags dang bral ba'i 'phags pa dgra bcom pa la ni chags pa dang bral ba zhes ni brjod pa yin te/ bdag gi dngos po zhes bya ba nye bar len pa'i phung po'i tshogs nye bar mkho ba rnams 'di dang 'di ni nga dang nga'i'o zhes blang bya dang skyon la dor byar zhen pa spangs pa'i phyir dang / yid du 'ong ba dang mi 'ong ba'i yul thams cad la ni chags pa dang sdang ba med par mnyam pa'i btang snyoms can yin pa'i phyir dang / 'ga' zhig gis sems dang bas phyogs gcig nas tsan+dan gyi byug pas byugs pa la chags pa med pa dang / 'ga' zhig gis khong khro bas phyogs gcig nas ste'us yan lag bcad pa la dor byar zhen pa med par mtshungs pa la de de'i phyir ro/ / 'on kyang gnyis ka la rjes su chags pa dang khong khro ba med pa'i mtshan nyid can gyi btang snyoms su gnas par 'gyur ro zhes pa lha'i'o/ / rgyan las/ kho bo cag gi phyogs la ni chos nyid tsam mthong bas sems can mnyam pa nyid thob ste rjes su chags pa dang bral bas na rnal 'byor pa rnams chags pa dang bral ba yin gyi/ gzhan du ni ma yin no/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

Noble arhats who are are free of desire for the three realms are said to be free of desire because they have abandoned any fixation on the “entity” of the self—the necessary assemblies of the aggregates of grasping—as something to adopt as “this is me and this is mine” or faults as something to shun. It is also because they have the equanimity of equally feeling neither attachment nor aversion toward all objects, pleasant or unpleasant, and because they do not feel attachment when someone with a faithful mind massages them from one side with sandalwood, nor do they fixate on it as something to reject when another person chops their limbs with an axe out of anger; for them those are the same. “Instead, they dwell in the equanimity that has the characteristic of being free of attachment or aversion for either,”[255] according to Devendrabuddhi. From the Ornament: Our position is that by seeing the mere dharma nature, they achieve equanimity for sentient beings. Because they are free of attachment..., yogis are detached. It is not otherwise.[256]
brgyad pa sdug bsngal bsgom par gsungs pa dang 'gal ba spang ba la/
8. Rebutting that this is contradictory of the instruction to meditate on suffering.
gzhan dag na re/ 'o na ji ltar bcom ldan 'das kyis sdug bsngal bsgom par gsungs she na/ bshad pa/
Others ask, “Why then did the Bhagavan say to meditate on suffering?” To explain:
'du byed sdug bsngal la dgongs nas/ / sdug bsngal bsgom par gsungs pa yin/ / nged kyi de yang rkyen las skyes/ / de ni bdag med lta rten yin/ /
254. Thinking of the suffering of formations, He said to meditate on suffering. Ours as well arises from conditions, And that supports the view of selflessness.

ces smos te/ 'di ltar bcom ldan 'das kyis sdug bsngal gyi sdug bsngal tsam la dgongs nas sdug bsngal bsgom par gsungs pa ni ma yin te/ 'dod chags can rnams 'dod chags kyi bde ba nyams par 'gyur ba na phyogs su lhung ba dang bral ba'i sgo nas khyab pa 'du byed kyi sdug bsngal bsgom pa'i ngos su 'gyur ba la dgongs nas sdug bsngal bsgom par gsungs pa yin pa'i phyir dang / nged kyi bsgom bya khyab pa 'du byed kyi sdug bsngal de yang rgyu rkyen las skyes pa'i gzhan dbang skad cig ma tsam yin la/ de ni bdag med par lta ba'i rten tsam du bsgom par bya ba yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

The Bhagavan did not merely intend the suffering of suffering when he said to meditate on suffering: When the pleasures of desire abate for them, those who are desirous have the suffering of formation by way of falling to an extreme or losing something. Thinking of meditation on this aspect, he said to meditate on suffering. It is also because our object of meditation—the pervasive suffering of formation—as well is just the dependent momentariness that arises from causes and conditions, and we meditate on that merely as the support for the view of selflessness.
'du byed kyi sdug bsngal bsgom pa stong nyid rtogs pa'i lta ba'i rten yin na lta ba de rtogs pas ci bya zhe na/ bshad pa/
If meditating on the suffering of formation is the support for the view of realizing emptiness, what good is it to realize that view? you ask. To explain:
stong nyid lta bas grol bar 'gyur/ / bsgom pa lhag ma de don yin/ /
255ab The view of emptiness will liberate; Remaining meditations are for that sake.

ces smos te/ 'du byed kyi sdug bsngal bsgom pa las 'dus byas thams cad bdag dang bdag gi bas stong pa'i don dam pa stong pa nyid rtogs par 'gyur la/ stong pa nyid du lta bas 'khor ba'i 'ching ba las grol bar 'gyur ba'i phyir ro/ / des na mi rtag pa dang / sdug bsngal ba la sogs pa bsgom pa lhag ma gang yin pa de dag thams cad ni stong pa nyid de rtogs pa'i don du bsgom pa yin gyi/ de bsgom pas yongs su grol bar nus pa ni ma yin no/ /

From meditating on the suffering on formation, the ultimate emptiness of all composites being free of me or mine will be realized, and viewing emptiness will liberate one from the bonds of samsara. Therefore, remaining meditations on impermanence, suffering, and so forth are practiced for the sake of realizing that emptiness, but meditating on them is not able to completely liberate one.
de'i gzhung 'dzugs pa'i phyir/
To establish the text:
de phyir mi rtag las sdug bsngal/ / sdug bsngal las ni bdag med gsungs/ /
255cd Thus from impermanence is suffering; From suffering is selflessness, he stated.

zhes smos te/ mi rtag pa dang sdug bsngal bsgom pa ni stong pa nyid mthong ba'i thabs yin gyi/ dngos su grol ba'i rgyu ma yin pa de'i phyir thabs mi rtag pa bsgom pa las sdug bsngal shes la/ sdug bsngal shes pa'i rgyu las ni bdag med rtogs pa 'byung bar gsungs te/ ji skad du/ bcom ldan 'das kyis mdo las/ dge slong dag gzugs rtag pa ma yin nam/ mi rtag pa ma yin/ btsun pa mi rtag pa lags so/ / gang mi rtag pa de sdug bsngal ba yin nam/ bde ba yin/ btsun pa sdug bsngal ba lags te/ gang mi rtag pa de ni sdug bsngal ba rnam par 'gyur ba'i chos can lags so/ / de la 'di ni nga'i'o/ / 'di ni nga'i yin no/ / 'di ni nga'i bdag go zhes lta rung ngam/ btsun pa de ni ma lags so/ / zhes gsungs pa yin no/ / de nyid kyi phyir bcom ldan 'das kyi bstan pa ni stong pa nyid la gzhol ba yin no zhes pa lha rgyan gnyis ka'i'o/ /

Meditating on impermanence and suffering is a method of seeing emptiness but is not a direct cause for liberation. Thus for that reason, from the method of meditating on impermanence, one knows suffering. From the cause of knowing suffering, the realization of selflessness will arise, it was stated. As the Bhagavan said in a sutra: “Bhikshus, is form permanent or impermanent?” “Venerable, it is impermanent.” “Is that which is impermanent suffering or pleasant?” “Venerable, it is suffering. That which is impermanent is suffering, a changeable phenomenon.” “Is it logical to view that as 'This is mine' or 'This is my self'?” “Venerable, it is not.”[257] For that reason, the Bhagavan's teachings lead to emptiness. This is according to both Devendrabuddhi and Prajñākaragupta.
bzhi pa don bsdu ba ni/
D. Summary
chags bral min dang sred ldan dang / / rtsom pa kun la brten pa dang / / nyon mongs las las grol ba min/ / de 'dra 'khor ba pa zhes bya/ /
256. Those who have craving and aren't free of attachment, Dependent upon every undertaking, Not liberated from actions and afflictions— Such beings as these are called samsaric.
