zhes smos te/ de lta bas na khyod kyi 'dod chags dang bral bar 'dod pa'i skyes bu de 'dra ba ni 'khor ba pa zhes bya ba yin te/ bdag dang bdag gi ba la chags pa dang bral ba ma yin pa'i phyir dang / bde ba thob par 'dod pa dang / sdug bsngal 'dor bar 'dod pa'i sred pa dang ldan pa'i phyir dang / bde ba dang sdug bsngal blang ba dang dor ba'i bya ba la 'jug pa'i brtson pa kun la brten pa'i phyir dang / chags pa dang / sred pa dang / rtsom pa la 'jug pa de'i dbang gis nyon mongs pa dang / des kun nas bslang ba'i dge mi dge'i las las grol ba ma yin pa'i phyir/ dper na so so'i skye bo bzhin no/ /

Therefore, such beings as these, those you assert to be free from desire, are called samsaric beings because they are not free of attachment to a self and mine, because they have the craving of wishing to achieve pleasure and cast off suffering, because they are dependent on every undertaking to engage in taking up pleasure and giving up suffering, and because due to their attachment, craving, and engagement in efforts, they are not liberated from the afflictions and the virtuous or unvirtuous actions those motivate, like, for example, an ordinary individual.
lnga pa bdag gi ba spangs na ha cang thal ba ni/
E. The absurd consequence of having abandoned mine
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
bdag gi nyid ni mi 'dod na/ /
257a And if one were not to accept the mine,
zhes smos te/ gang gi tshe thar pa'i gnas skabs de'i tshe bdag gi ba nyid ni spang zhing mi 'dod do zhe na/ bshad pa/
At the time of liberation, mine has been abandoned and it is not accepted, they say. To explain:
de yi za ba po yang med/ / bya dang longs spyod mtshan nyid can/ / de tshe de yi bdag kyang med/ /
257b-d Then its consumer, too, would not exist. Its self, whose characteristics are action And experience, would also not exist.

ces smos te/ khyod kyi 'khor ba las grol bar 'dod pa'i bdag chos can/ bdag gi ba de yi za ba po'i bdag gi ba de yang med par thal/ bza' bar bya ba'am longs spyad bya bdag gi ba nyid med pa'i phyir/ 'dod pa yin pa de ltar na gang gi tshe bya ba la sogs pa byed pa dang / rnam smin la longs spyod pa'i mtshan nyid can mi 'dod pa de'i tshe de yi bdag kyang med par 'gyur ro/ /

Then for the self you assert to be freed from samsara, the subject, it follows that the mine that is the consumer's mine, too, would not exist, because there is no mine to consume or experience. As this is accepted, when its characteristics of performing actions and so forth and experiencing ripening are not accepted, at that time its self would also not exist.
drug pa des na 'jig tshogs la lta ba spang bar gdams pa ni/
F. Advice to therefore abandon personality view
de phyir grol 'dod thog med pa'i/ / rgyu can rigs mthun sa bon las/ / byung ba'i 'jig tshogs lta ba dag/ rtsa ba nyid nas dbyung bar gyis/ /
258. Therefore all those who wish for freedom should Eradicate the personality views That arise out of seeds of the same kind In a beginningless continuum.

zhes smos te/ gang gi phyir mya ngan las 'das pa'i grong khyer thob pa'i phyir du bdag med pa mthong ba nyid lam yin gyi/ gzhan sdug bsngal la sogs pa bsgom pa ni lam ma yin pa de'i phyir/ 'khor ba snying po med pa las grol bar 'dod pa khyod 'bad pa chen pos bdag med pa goms pas 'jig tshogs la lta ba dag rtsa ba nyid nas dbyung ba dang bcom par gyis shig go/ 'jig lta de'ang ci dang 'dra ba zhig ce na/ thog ma med pa'i rgyu can te rigs mthun pa'i sa bon rigs 'dra snga ma snga ma la brten nas phyi ma phyi ma 'byung ba ste/ thog ma med pa'i dus nas 'jug pa zhes bya ba'i don to zhes pa lha'i'o/ /

Because seeing egolessness is the path for reaching the city of nirvana whereas meditating on something else such as suffering is not the path, therefore you who wish for freedom from pointless samsara should with great effort eradicate from their roots and destroy personality views by cultivating selflessness. What are those personality views like? you ask. They have beginningless causes:[258] because of the seeds or previous instances of the same kind, later instances arise. “The meaning is that they have engaged since beginningless time,” says Devendrabuddhi.[259]
gsum pa bdag 'dzin can grol ba'i lung las dgag pa la/
(c) Refuting citations that say that those who have ego-clinging may be liberated.
dgag pa dngos/ de la rtsod pa spang ba/ ma mthong ba'i las zhig pas thar pa dgag/ bdag gi nus pa sbyor ba dgag/ 'khor ba mi srid par dgag pa'o/ /

This has five topics: (i) The actual refutation, (ii) Rebutting criticism of that, (iii) Refuting that destroying unseen karma liberates, (iv) Refuting that the power of a self would apply, and (v) Refuting that samsara is impossible.
dang po [dgag pa dngos] la/
(i) The actual refutation

la la dag na re/ bdag yod pa nyid dang / de'i thar pa yang lung las grub pa yin pa dang / thar pa de'ang gcig tu bde ba'i rang bzhin yin te/ de ni nam yang med par 'gyur ba ma yin la/ 'khor ba'i bde ba rnam par chad pa dang ldan pa yin pas/ de las yongs su mi skye ba de'ang dbang bskur ba'i cho ga las grub pa'i rig sngags kyi rtsom pa thams cad don med do/ / de skad du'ang / dbang po las 'das reg bya min/ / dngos po mig gi mthong ba yi/ / drang srong de dag tshig la ni/ / rjes su dpag pas gnod ma yin/ / skyes bus ma byas pa'i tshig la yang ngo zhes zer ro/ / de yang mi rigs so zhes bshad pa/

Some say that the self is existent and its liberation is proven in the scriptures.[260] Such liberation is solely the nature of bliss, and it never becomes nonexistent. Since samsaric pleasure has an end, it never produces complete satisfaction. Because this is established through rites such as empowerments, all the prior arguments are pointless.[261] As it is said: The words of the sages who have seen With their own eyes the entity That transcends the senses and cannot be touched Cannot be disproven by inference. It is the same with words that are not of human origin, they claim.[162] To explain that this is illogical:
lung ni de lta'i dngos yin pa'i/ / rgyu ma mthong ba rnams la ni/ / lung tsam gyis ni grol bar yang / / smra ba yongs su mgu byed min/ /
259. For those who have not seen the reasoning For why the scriptures have such reality, Stating that scriptures alone bring liberation Is not completely satisfying.

ces smos te/ gang dag rtog pa dang ldan pa grol bar 'dod pa rnams la dbang phyug gis dbang bskur ba'i lung tsam gyis ni grol bar yang smra ba'i lung de ni rtogs pa dang ldan par yongs su mgu bar byed pa'i lung ma yin te/ lung rang gi brjod bya'i don ni bden pa de lta bu'i dngos po can yin pa'i rgyu mtshan tshad mas ma mthong ba'i phyir/

For those discerning people who want liberation, the scriptures that state that the scriptures empowered by Īśvara alone bring liberation are not scriptures that are completely satisfying to the discerning, because they have not validly seen the reasoning for why the meaning expressed in the scriptures would have such reality.
de la gzhan dag na re/ sa bon la sogs pa la dbang bskur la sogs pa'i cho ga dang 'brel ba las myu gu la sogs pa mi skye ba'i chos can du mthong bas 'dir yang mtshungs so zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others say of this that it is seen that through rituals that empower seeds and so forth, the sprout becomes a non-arising phenomenon, and this is the same. To explain:
sa bon sogs grub cho ga ni/ / skyes bu mi bskyed par nus min/ / til mar bskus dang mes bsregs sogs/ / las kyang grol bar thal phyir ro/ /
260. Rites that affect a seed or so forth lack The power to make a human not be born Since it would follow that anointing oil And burning and so forth would liberate.

zhes smos te/ de ltar mtshungs pa ni ma yin te/ sngags btab pas sa bon la sogs pas myu gu mi bskyed par grub pa'i cho ga ni skyes bu skye ba phyi mar mi bskyed par nus pa ma yin pa'i phyir ro/ / gtan tshigs ma grub bo zhe na/ 'o na skyes bu la til mar gyis bskus pa dang / mes bsregs pa dang / phye mar byas pa dang / btsos pa dang btags pa la sogs pa las kyang grol ba thob par thal/ sa bon la til mar bskus pa la sogs pas myu gu mi bskyed pa'i phyir ro/ /

It is not the same: Rites that affect a seed or so forth, making it unable to produce a seedling, lack the power to make a human not be born in a later birth. If you say the reason is not proven, well then, it follows that anointing a person with sesame oil, burning them with fire, grinding them into flour, cooking them, crushing them, and so forth would liberate them because smearing seeds with sesame oil and so forth makes them not produce seedlings.
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
sngar lci ba dag phyis yang phyir/ /
261a “Since heavier before and lighter after,”

zhes smos te/ skyes bu'i sdig pa bra mas blangs te sbyin sreg byas pa las zad par 'gyur te/ snga phyir srang la bsgar ba na sngar srang khar lci ba dag las phyis yang bar mthong ba'i phyir zhe na/ bshad pa/

A person's misdeeds are exhausted when a guru takes him and performs a fire offering, since when he is weighed on a scale before and after, it is seen that he is heavier before and lighter after, they say. To explain:
sdig pa bcom par byas pa min/ / 'di yi lci nyid med gyur gyi/ / lus can min phyir sdig lci min/ /
261b-d But that does not eliminate misdeeds. Their weight may cease to be, but misdeeds are Not physical and thus do not have weight.

ces smos te/ sbyin sreg byas pa'i skyes bu sngar srang khar lci ba phyis yang bar mthong ba tsam gyis sdig pa bcom par byas par bsgrub nus pa ma yin te/ sbyin sreg gis mes gdungs pa las skyes bu 'di yi lus kyi lci ba chu dang sa nyid la sogs pa cung zad med par 'gyur gyi/ lus can ma yin pa'i phyir na sems kyi sdig pa ni srang gis gzhal bar bya ba'i lci ba dang yang ba ma yin no/ /

But that, merely seeing that a person who has performed a fire offering weighs more before and less after, is not able to prove that eliminates misdeeds, because through tormenting the person with fire in the fire offering, a slight amount of the weight of their body—water, earth, and so forth only—may cease to be, but misdeeds of the mind are not physical and thus do not have heavy or light weight that can be measured on a scale.
gnyis pa de la rtsod pa spangs ba la/
(ii) Rebutting criticism of that
kha cig na re/ dbang phyug gi dbang la sogs pa lam ma yin na/ khyed kyi'ang bdag med pa lam ma yin par 'gyur ro zhe na/ bshad pa/
Some say, “If empowerments of Īśvara and so forth are not the path, then your selflessness is not the path, either.” To explain:

log shes dang ni de las byung / / sred pa sems pa'i dbang dag gis/ / dman gnas 'gro ba skye ba yin/ / de phyir de bcad 'gro mi 'gyur/ / de tsam las ni 'byung ba'i phyir/ / skye la de dag nyid nus yin/ /

262. Due to the volitions of misconception And of the craving that is born of that, There's birth in the inferior destinations. Thus if that's severed, there is no migration. 263ab Those two themselves have power over birth Since it will occur merely due to them.

ces smos te/ sdug bsngal la phyin ci log tu bde bar 'dzin pa'i log pa'i shes pa dang ni de las byung ba'i 'khor ba don gnyer gyi sred pa dang mtshungs par ldan pa'i sems pa ni 'khor bar skye ba'i rgyu yin te/ de'i dbang dag gis dman pa'i gnas mngal la sogs pa gnas su nye bar 'gro ba dang skye bar 'gyur ba yin pa'i phyir ro/ / des na log sred 'khor ba'i rgyu yin pa de'i phyir/ bdag med par rtogs pa'i ye shes des log sred de bcad cing bcom na 'khor bar 'gro bar mi 'gyur la/ log sred de tsam las ni 'khor ba 'byung ba'i phyir/ 'khor bar skye ba la log sred de dag nyid 'khor ba bskyed pa'i nus pa dang ldan pa yin no/ /

Volitions concurrent with the misconception that erroneously holds suffering to be pleasure and with the craving of seeking samsara that is born of that are the causes of birth in samsara. Due to them, one will go to and be born in the inferior destinations such as the womb and so forth. Thus because mistaken craving is the cause of samsara, if the wisdom that realizes egolessness severs and eliminates that mistaken craving, there is no migration into samsara. Since it (samsara) occurs merely due to those mistaken cravings, those mistaken cravings themselves have the power over birth in samsara to produce samsaric birth.
gzhan dag na re/ sngon byas pa'i las kyang 'khor bar skye ba'i rgyur yod pa'i phyir/ ji ltar na 'khor ba de log sred de tsam las byung ba'i ngang tshul nyid yin ce na/ bshad pa/
Others say, “Previously committed actions are also causes of birth in samsara, so how is it that samsara has the nature of arising just from those mistaken cravings?” To explain:
sems pa de dag rang nyid las/ / yin phyir skye rgyu nyams pa nyid/ /
263cd Because those two intentions are themselves Actions, the cause for birth is not destroyed.

ces smos te/ sems pa de dag ma yin pa'i 'das pa'i las 'khor ba'i rgyu ma yin te/ rang nyid 'khor ba'i rgyur gyur pa'i las yin pa'i phyir/ des na dbang phyug gi dbang bskur ni thar pa'i lam ma yin te/ 'khor bar skye ba'i rgyu log sred nam yang nyams par byas pa med pa'i phyir/

Past actions that are not those two intentions are not the cause of samsara, because those two are themselves the actions that cause samsara. Therefore empowerments of Īśvara are not the path to liberation because they can never destroy the cause for birth in samsara, mistaken craving.
gsum pa ma mthong ba'i las zhig pas thar pa dgag pa la/
(iii) Refuting that destroying unseen karma liberates.
'gog byed kyi rigs pa dngos/ bdag gi yon tan dang tshogs pa dgag/ gtan tshigs ma grub pa spang ba'o/ /
This has two points: A. The actual logic of the refutation, and B. Refuting an assembly with the qualities of the self.[263]
dang po ['gog byed kyi rigs pa dngos] la/
A. The actual logic of the refutation
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
'gro dang rtogs rten byed pa yin/ / de ni ma mthong ba las gyur/ / ma mthong zhig phyir 'gro ba med/ / des na 'du byed sems pa min/ /
264. “The agents are supports for going and For realization. They're from the unseen. When the unseen is destroyed, there's no migration. So therefore it is formation, not volition.”

ces smos te/ gal te gnas las gnas gzhan du 'gro bar byed pa dang / yul gzugs la sogs pa rtogs pa'i rten nam rgyu byed pa ni mig la sogs pa'i dbang po rnams yin la/ byed pa de ni ma mthong ba'i chos dang chos ma yin pa'i las gang yang rung ba las skye bar 'gyur bas dbang bskur gyi cho gas ma mthong ba'i las zhig par byas pa'i phyir/ dbang bskur dang ldan pa'i dbang po la sogs pa dman pa'i gnas su 'gro ba med do/ / des na ma mthong ba'i las de ni dge ba dang mi dge ba nyi shu'i rjes su 'jug pas bskyed nus pa'i 'du byed yin gyi/ khyed cag 'dod pa'i log sred dang mtshungs ldan gyi sems pa min no zhe na/ bshad pa/

“The faculties of the eye and so forth are supports or causes for going from one place to another and for the realization of objects such as form. These agents occur from either the dharmic or the undharmic karma, which are both unseen. Thus when the ritual of empowerment destroys the unseen karma, there is no migration to inferior places for the faculties that have been empowered. So therefore it (the unseen karma) is the formation that can be produced by engagement in the twenty virtues and nonvirtues,[264] and it is not the volition concurrent with mistaken craving that you assert,” they say. To explain:
yod dang med pa'i rjes 'jug phyir/ / byed pa bskyed la blo yi ni/ / nus mthong gzhan gyi ma yin na/ / de yod de dag cis mi 'gro/ /
265. Since it is consequent to the presence or The absence, mind's capacity to produce The agent is perceived, but not the other's. If that is present, why would they not go?

zhes smos te/ log pa'i shes pa sred pa dang mtshungs par ldan pa'i blo ni phan 'dogs byed du yod pa dang med pa'i rjes su 'jug pa dang ldog pa can yin pa'i phyir/ byed pa dbang po drug bskyed pa la log sred kyi blo'i ni nus pa mthong ba yin gyi/ gzhan ma mthong ba'i las dge ba dang mi dge ba nyi shu'i rjes su 'jug pa'i 'du byed kyis bskyed pa ma yin no/ / des na dbang bskur thob kyang log sred de yod pa'i phyir/ byed pa dbang po de dag 'khor bar cis mi 'gro ste 'gro bar 'gyur ro zhes pa lha'i'o/ /

Since it is consequent to the presence or prevented by the absence of cognition that is concurrent with misconceptions and craving, the capacity of the mind of mistaken craving to produce the agents—the six faculties—is perceived. They are not produced by the other, formations that are consequent to the unseen karma of the twenty virtues and nonvirtues. Therefore, though one might receive an empowerment, because that mistaken craving is present, why would they (the agents or faculties) not go into samsara? They would go. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.
gnyis pa bdag gi yon tan dang tshogs pa dgag pa la/
B. Refuting an assembly with the qualities of the self
la la dag na re/
Others say:
gal te de dag nus med na/ /
266a If they had no capacity,
zhes smos te/ gal te log sred dang bdag gi yon tan gyi tshogs pa 'khor ba'i rgyu yin la/ de'ang dbang bskur gyi bcom pas de dag bskyed pa la nus pa med do zhe na/ bshad pa/
The cause of samsara is the assembly of mistaken craving and the qualities of the self. If those are destroyed by empowerment, they have no capacity to produce, you say. To explain:
dbang sogs byas ma thag de dag/ sems pa'i dbang gis 'dzin dang 'jug/ g.yeng dang 'gog pa med par 'gyur/ /
266a-d right after Initiation and so forth, there'd be No apprehension, engagement, disturbance, Or cessation under the power of volition.

zhes smos te/ de ltar yin na dbang bskur ba dang grol bar byed pa'i thabs sngags la sogs pa thob par byas ma thag pa'i skyes bu de dag log sred dang mtshungs par ldan pa'i sems pa'i dbang gis yul 'dzin pa dang / / yul rang gar 'jug pa bzlog pa dang mngon par 'dod pa'i yul la 'jug pa dang g.yeng ba mi mnyam par 'jug pa dang 'gog pa'i 'jig pa ste de dag med par 'gyur te/ dbang bskur ma thag tu log sred dang bdag gi yon tan gyi tshogs pa rnams kyi nus pa bcom par byas pas blo nyams pa'i phyir zhes rgyan gyis so/ / slob dpon lha dbang blo ni/ 'dzin 'phel 'khrug dang 'gog pa dag/ sems dpas 'gyur gyis dbang gis min/ / ces smos te/ rang gi yul la 'jug pa la bzlog pa med par 'dzin pa'o/ / 'phen pa ni rang gi yul la 'jug par byed pa'o/ / 'khrug pa bsnun pa la sogs pas blo ni 'gyur ba bskyed pa'o/ / 'gog pa ni blo'i rjes su mthun pa yod na yang 'khrug pa ldog pa yin no zhes bshad do/ /

If that were so, right after people received an initiation or means for liberation such as a mantra or so forth, for those people there would be no apprehension of objects, turning away from engaging an object at one's pleasure, engagement in a desired object, disturbance of engaging unevenly, or the perishing of cessation under the power of volition concurrent with mistaken craving. This is because immediately after initiation, the power of the assembly of mistaken craving and the qualities of the self would have been eliminated, so the mind would be impaired. This is according to Prajñākaragupta. Devendrabuddhi explains: It says, “There'd be / No apprehension, engagement, disturbance, / Or cessation under the power of volition.” Without anything to prevent the engagement of its own object, apprehension. Engagement causes engagement in the object. Disturbance is producing a change in the mind from a blow or so forth. Cessation is the cessation of disturbance even when it conforms with the mind.[265]
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
ci ste de tshe blo med phyir/ / mi 'gyur/
2673b “What if, because at that time there's no mind, They would not.

zhes smos te/ ci ste yang dbang bskur ba byas ma thag tu g.yeng ba dang 'gog pa la sogs pa yod kyang 'chi ba'i dus de'i tshe log sred la sogs pa'i blo med pa'i phyir/ byed pa dbang po la sogs pa 'phen par mi 'gyur ro zhe na/ de'i dbang sogs 'phen pa'i blo ci'i phyir med ces dri bar bya'o/ / de la gzhan dag na re/

“What if immediately after an initiation, there are distraction, cessation, and so forth, but because at that time (the time of death), there is no mind of mistaken craving and so forth, they (the agents of the faculties and so forth) would not be propelled,” they say. We ask why there would be no mind to propel the faculties and so forth. The opponents reply:
dri ma rnams kyis blo/ / mtshams sbyor de rnams nus med na/ /
267bc It's the stains that make the mind Link rebirth, but they lack capacity.”

zhes smos te/ log pa'i shes pa bdag tu chags pa la sogs pa nyon mongs pa'i dri ma rnams kyis blo'am gnas skabs gang yin pa de dag ni dbang ma bskur bas dbang po sogs srid par mtshams sbyor bar byed pa yin la/ dbang bskur bar byas na ni dri ma'i dbang gis dbang po de rnams srid par mtshams sbyor ba'i nus pa med par 'gyur ro zhe na/ bshad pa/

It is the stains of the afflictions such as misconceptions, clinging to a self, and so forth that make the mind or those faculties and so forth at the time of not having been empowered link rebirth in an existence. But if an initiation has been performed, they (the faculties) would lack the capacity to link rebirth due to the stains, they say.
gson pa nyid na'ang nus med 'gyur/ /
267d Then living, they'd be powerless as well.

zhes smos te/ 'o na dbang bskur thob pa'i skyes bu ni gson pa'i gnas skabs nyid na'ang log sred la sogs pa'i dri ma rnams kyis blos dbang po phyi ma mtshams sbyor ba'i nus pa med par 'gyur te/ gson pa'i gnas nas dbang gis log sred kyi nus pa bcom pa'i phyir/ des na dbang bskur ma thag tu grol bar 'gyur ro zhes pa rgyan gyi'o/ /

Then while the person who received the initiation were living, they (the stains such as mistaken craving) would be powerless to link to the next faculties as well, because the initiation would have eliminated the power of mistaken craving while they remained alive. “Therefore one would be liberated immediately upon initiation,”[266] according to Prajñākaragupta.
'dod par yang mi nus so zhes bstan pa'i phyir/
To teach that one cannot agree:
gnyen po dang ni rang gi phyogs/ / 'phel na 'grib dang 'phel ba'i phyir/ / nyes rgyun rang gi sa bon can/ / dbang bskur ba las ldog pa med/ /
268. Since when the antidote or their own side Increases, they will decrease or increase, The faults' continuum, with its own seeds, Is not averted by initiation.

ces smos te/ 'di ltar gnyen po bdag med rtogs pa'i ye shes dang ni log sred rang gi phyogs tshul bzhin ma yin pa'i yid la byed pa 'phel na go rim bzhin du 'grib pa dang 'phel ba'i phyir/ nyes pa'i rgyun tshul bzhin ma yin pa yid la byed pa rnams ni rang gi sa bon rigs 'dra snga ma las 'byung ba can yin pas/ de dag ma bcom par dbang bskur ba tsam las ldog pa med do zhes pa lha rgyan gnyis ka'i'o/ /

Since when the antidote—the wisdom that realizes selflessness—or mistaken craving's own side—inappropriate attention—increase, they will decrease or increase respectively, the faults' continuum of inappropriate attentions, which arises from its own seeds (previous instances of the same kind), is not averted by initiation without eliminating those seeds. This is according to both Devendrabuddhi and Prajñākaragupta.
bzhi pa bdag gi nus pa sbyar ba dgag pa la/
(iv) Refuting that the power of a self would apply.
bdag rgyur mi rigs pa/ bdag med pa la rtsod pa spang ba'o/ /
This has two points: A. The self cannot logically be a cause, and B. Refuting criticism of selflessness.
dang po [bdag rgyur mi rigs pa] la/
A. The self cannot logically be a cause
la la dag na re/ bdag gis log sred la sogs bskyed pa yin no zhe na/ bshad pa/
Some say that the self produces mistaken craving and so forth. To explain:
rtag la bltos pa med pa'i phyir/ / rim gyis skyed par byed pa dang / / byed dang mi byed pa dag ni/ / 'dra ba'i bdag nyid byed pa 'gal/ / rgyu dang 'bras bu'ang gcig par 'gyur/ /

269. Because the permanent is not dependent, It's contradictory for it to produce Sequentially and to have a like nature Of acting when it's acting and not acting. 270a Cause and result would be the same as well.

zhes smos te/ bdag rtag pa ni rgyu rkyen la bltos pa med pa'i rtag pa yin pa'i phyir/ 'bras bu rim gyis skyed par byed pa 'gal bar 'gyur ba dang / gzhan yang 'bras bu byed pa'i bdag dang / 'bras bu mi byed pa'i bdag rtag pa dag ni rkyen la mi bltos pa'i rtag par 'dra ba'i bdag nyid yin pa'i phyir/ 'bras bu mi byed pa'i dus na'ang 'bras bu byed pa 'gal bar thal lo zhes/ ji ltar dngos de rgyu yin pa/ / de ltar de nyid gang gi tshe/ / rgyu min de ni gang gi 'gyur/ / zhes bya ba'i skabs su rgyas par bshad zin to/ / rgyu'i gnas skabs kyi bdag dang / 'bras bu longs spyod pa'i gnas skabs kyi bdag gnyis gcig par 'gyur te/ de gnyis bdag rtag pa gcig yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

Because a permanent self would be a permanent that is not dependent upon causes and conditions, it would be contradictory for it to produce results sequentially. Additionally, because the self that is acting to make a result and the permanent self that is not acting to make a result would always have a like nature of not depending on conditions, it follows that would be contradictory for it to act to make a result during times when it was not making a result. This has already been explained in detail in the context of: Just as that entity is the cause, In the same way, then, at the times It's not the cause, why do you assert It is the cause, not not a cause?[267] The self during the phase of the cause and the self during the phase of enjoying the result would be the same, because the two are the same permanent self.
gal te gtan tshigs ma grub bo zhe na/ bshad pa/
If you say the reason is not proven, to explain:
de dag de las tha dad na/ / byed po za po nyams par 'gyur/ / nus pa yang ni 'grub ma yin/ /
270b-d If that were to be separate from those, The actor and consumer would be lost, And the capacity would not be proven.

ces smos te/ las gsog pa po dang rnam smin longs spyod pa po'i bdag de dag ni las gsog pa po dang rnam smin longs spyod pa po de las 'brel ba med pa'i tha dad yin pa'i phyir na/ las byed pa po dang rnam smin za ba po yin pa nyams par 'gyur la/ der ma zad bdag rtag pa chos can/ 'bras bu mi bskyed par thal/ 'bras bu bskyed pa'i nus pa yang ni tshad mas grub pa ma yin pa'i phyir/

If those[268] (the selves of those who accumulate karma and of those who experience its ripening) were to be separate from and unrelated to the accumulators of karma and the experiencers of its ripening, being the actor who does an act and the consumer of the ripening would be lost. Not only that, it would follows that the permanent self, the subject, does not produce a result because its capacity to produce a result would not be validly proven.
gnyis pa bdag med pa la rtsod pa spang ba ni/
B. Refuting criticism of selflessness

gzhan dag na re/ bdag 'ga' zhig kyang yod pa ma yin pa de'i tshe gzhan gyis dran pa dang / gzhan gyis byas pa gzhan gyis longs spyod pa dang / bdag gis nyams su myong ba'i dran pa ma yin pa dang / gzhan the tshom za ba gzhan gyis nges pa dang / gzhan gyis mthong ba gzhan gyis ngo shes pa la sogs par 'gyur ro zhe na/ bshad pa/

Others say that if some self did not exist, then another would remember, something done by one would be experienced by another, one would not remember what they had experienced, one would be certain of what another had doubted, one would recognize what another had seen, and so forth. To explain:
gzhan gyis dran dang longs spyod sogs/ / thal ba gnod byed ma yin te/ / 'ga'i yang dran pa med pa'i phyir/ / des na myong las dran pa 'byung / /
271. The consequence that another would remember, Experience, and so on does not refute, As there's no memory of anyone's. Thus memory is from experience.

zhes smos te/ gzhan gyis nyams su myong ba gzhan gyis dran pa dang / gzhan gyis byas pa gzhan gyis longs spyod pa dang / bdag gis myong ba bdag gis dran pa ma yin pa la sogs par thal/ bdag med pa'i phyir zhes pa'i thal ba de ni kho bo cag la gnod byed ma yin te/ rtag pa'i bdag 'ga'i yang sngar nyams su myong ba phyis dran pa med pas 'dod lan thebs pa'i phyir/ des na rtag pa'i bdag med kyang rang gi nyams su myong ba rgyud gzhan gyis dran pa ma yin gyi/ rang gi sngar nyams su myong ba las phyis dran pa 'byung ba yin no/ /

The consequence that because there is no self, another would remember what someone else had done, that another would experience the acts of someone else, that one would not remember what he had experienced, and so on do not refute us, as there is no later memory of anyone's—any permanent self's—earlier experience, and we answer that we agree. Thus although there is no permanent self, what one has experienced is not remembered by another continuum, because later memory arises from one's own previous experience.
lnga pa 'khor ba mi srid pa dgag pa la/
(v) Refuting that samsara is impossible.
dgag pa dngos/ de la rtsod pa spang ba/ dka' thub kyis grol ba dgag pa'o/ /
This has three topics: A. The actual refutation, B. Refuting criticism of that, and C. Refuting liberation through austerity.
dang po [dgag pa dngos] la/
A. The actual refutation
gzhan dag na re/ bdag med pas 'khor bar 'jug pa'ang med par 'gyur te/ bdag med na 'jig tshogs la lta ba yang med pa'i phyir/ des na 'khor ba nyid med pa nyid do zhe na/ bshad pa/

Others say that since there is no self, there would be no entry into samsara, because if there were no self there would also be no personality view. Therefore samsara itself would not exist. To explain:
bden pa bzhi la brtan pa dang / / bde dang nga dang nga'i zhes sogs/ / yang dag min pa rnam bcu drug/ sgro btags nas ni yongs su sred/ /
272. Projecting onto the four truths The sixteen unreal aspects of Being stable, pleasurable, me, And mine, and so forth, one has craving.

ces smos te/ 'khor ba'i rgyu yod pa'i phyir/ 'khor ba med pa ni ma yin te/ 'di ltar 'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi po'i rnam pa bcu drug las sdug bsngal gyi bden pa la mi rtag pa las ldog ste rtag cing brtan par sgro 'dogs pa dang / de bzhin du sdug bsngal la bde ba dang / bdag med pa la nga dang / stong pa nyid la nga'i zhes sgro 'dogs pa dang / de bzhin du kun 'byung gi bden pa la rgyu ma yin pa dang / kun 'byung ba ma yin pa dang / rab tu skye ba ma yin pa dang / rkyen ma yin ces dang / 'gog pa'i bden pa la 'gog pa ma yin pa dang / zhi ba ma yin pa dang / gya nom pa ma yin pa dang / nges par 'byung ba ma yin ces dang / lam gyi bden pa la lam ma yin pa dang / rigs pa ma yin pa dang / sgrub pa ma yin pa dang / nges par 'byin pa ma yin ces sogs yang dag pa ma yin pa phyin ci log rnam pa bcu drug tu sgro btags nas ni rtag pa dang bde ba la sogs par yongs su sred pa de 'byung bas na log sred gnyis 'khor ba'i rgyu yin pa'i phyir ro zhes pa lha'i'o/ /

Because the cause of samsara exists, samsara is not non-existent. It is like this: among the sixteen aspects of the four noble truths, by projecting being permanent and stable on the aspect impermanence of the truth of suffering, and likewise being pleasurable on suffering, being me on selflessness, being mine on emptiness, and so forth including projecting not being the cause, not being the origin, not being production, and not being a condition on the truth of origin; projecting not being cessation, not being peace, not being sublime, and not being emancipation on the truth of cessation; projecting not being the path, not being reasoning, not being accomplishing, and not being deliverance on the truth of path—the sixteen unreal, fallacious aspects—craving for the permanent, pleasurable, and so forth arises. Thus the two types of mistaken craving are the causes of samsara. This is according to Devendrabuddhi.

slob dpon shes rab 'byung gnas ni/ yang dag pa ma yin pa'i sgro btags pa nyid 'khor ba yin gyi/ don dam pa ni 'khor ba med do/ / yang dag pa ma yin pa'i rnam pa bcu drug po sgro btags pa'i rang bzhin yongs su sred pa can las kyi 'khor bar rlom pa yin gyi/ gzhan du ni 'khor ba srid pa ma yin no/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

Master Prajñākaragupta says: Samsara is unreal projection, and ultimately samsara does not exist. Those with craving for the nature of the projections of the sixteen unreal aspects imagine that they are in samsara due to karma, but samsara is not otherwise possible.[269]
lam gnyen po'i phyogs nyid du bstan pa'i phyir/
To teach that the path is the antidote itself:
de nyid la ni de 'gal don/ / de nyid rnam pa rjes rtogs can/ / legs bsgoms yang dag lta ba yis/ / sred pa rjes 'brangs bcas 'joms byed/ /
273. Meditating thoroughly on those With realization of the aspects of thatness— The meaning that is contrary to those— Right view eliminates craving and its suite.

ces smos te/ bden pa bzhi po de nyid la ni rtag pa dang bde ba la sogs pa de dag dang 'gal ba'i don 'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi po de nyid kyi rnam pa mi rtag pa dang sdug bsngal la sogs pa bcu drug rjes su rtogs pa can gyi bdag med par rtogs pa'i ye shes legs par bsgoms pa bdag med pa mngon sum du yang dag par mthong ba'i lta ba de 'khor ba spong byed kyi gnyen po yin te/ ma rig pa dngos su bcom pa'i sgo nas sred pa dang / de'i rjes 'brangs sdug bsngal gyi rgyur gyur pa'i ser sna dang phrag dog la sogs pa'i nyes pa dang bcas pa 'joms par byed pa'i phyir ro zhes pa lha'i'o/ / rgyan ni/ ma rig pa mtha' dag log pa'i mtshan nyid mya ngan las 'das pa'i yul mngon du byed par 'gyur ro/ / de'i phyir de kho na mthong bas sred pa log pa ni thar pa yin no/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

Meditating thoroughly on those (the four noble truths), the wisdom that realizes selflessness with realization of the sixteen aspects of those four noble truths—impermanence, suffering, and so forth—that are the meaning that is contrary to those—permanence, bliss, and so forth— the right view that properly sees selflessness directly is the antidote that discards samsara, because by way of actually eliminating ignorance, craving and its suite—stinginess, envy, and so forth that are causes of suffering—are eliminated. This is according to Devendrabuddhi. The Ornament states: The object nirvana, whose characteristic is the cessation of all ignorance, becomes visible. Therefore seeing suchness and stopping craving is liberation.[270]
gnyis pa rtsod pa spang ba la/
B. Refuting criticism of that
gzhan dag na re/ las dang lus yod pa'i phyir sred pa spangs pa ji ltar thar par 'gyur zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others ask how abandoning craving could be liberation since one has karma and a body.[271] To explain:
las dang lus dag gnas na yang / / gcig med phyir na rgyu gsum can/ / skye ba srid pa ma yin te/ / sa bon med par myu gu bzhin/ /
274. Though karma and the body still remain, It is impossible for that which has Three causes to be born since one is absent, Just as no sprout will grow without a seed.

zhes smos te/ 'di ltar 'khor ba'i rgyu'i gtso bo sred pa spangs pa'i skyes bu la las dang lus dag gnas na yang las dang lus dang sred pa ste rgyu gsum pa can du yod pa las gcig sred pa med pa'i phyir na/ slar yang 'khor bar skye ba len srid pa ma yin te/ dper na sa bon med par chu lud la sogs pa yod kyang myu gu mi 'byung ba bzhin no/ /

It is thus: for a person who has abandoned the primary cause of samsara (craving), though karma and the body still remain, since craving (one of the three causes karma, the body, and craving) is absent, it is impossible to once again be born in samsara, just as, for example, no sprout will grow without a seed even if there are moisture, manure, and so forth.
gzhan dag na re/ 'o na rgyu gsum las sred pa spangs pas grol na las dang lus kyang rgyu yin pa'i phyir/ 'di dag zad pa las kyang grol bar smra rigs so zhe na/ bshad pa/

Others say, “If one is liberated by abandoning craving among the three causes, since karma and the body are also causes, it is logical to say that one can be liberated by exhausting them.” To explain:
las dang lus dag spong min te/ / gnyen po dag ni med phyir dang / / nus med phyir ro sred pa ni/ / yod na slar yang 'byung phyir ro/ /
275. Not by discarding karma and the body, Because an antidote does not exist Since there is no ability because If there is craving, they will reoccur.

zhes smos te/ grol bar 'dod pa'i skyes bu rtogs pa dang ldan pa ni grol ba'i ched du las dang lus dag spong ba'i gnyen po la 'bad rtsol byed pa ma yin te/ sred pa ma bcom par las dang lus rtsa ba nas dbyung bar nus pa'i gnyen po dag ni tshad mas rtogs pa med pa'i phyir dang / sred pa ma spangs na las dang lus rtsa ba nas spong ba'i nus pa med pa'i phyir ro/ / gzhan yang sred pa ma spangs par ni yod na/ las dang lus dag lan gcig spangs kyang slar yang 'byung ba'i phyir ro zhes lhas so/ / rgyan las ni/ sred pa bzlog pa ma gtogs par las dang lus dag gi gnyen po gzhan ni yod do/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

People who want liberation and have realization do not make efforts at antidotes to discard karma and the body for the sake of liberation. This is because antidotes able to eradicate karma and the body without eliminating craving are not validly realized to exist, and since there is no ability to abandon karma and the body from their root if craving has not been abandoned. Additionally, if craving, not having been abandoned, is present, one might abandon karma and the body once, but they will reoccur. This is according to Devendrabuddhi. Prajñākaragupta says, “There is no other antidote for karma and the body than blocking craving.”[272]
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
gnyis zad don du 'bad na yang / /
276a Even if one strives to exhaust them both,
zhes smos te/ gal te las dang sred pa gnyis ka zad pa'i don du 'bad par byed do zhe na yang / bshad pa/
One might say that one should strive to exhaust them both, karma and the body. To explain:
las zad dub pa don med yin/ /
276b Tiring oneself to exhaust karma is pointless.

ces smos te/ sred pa zad par byed pa'i gnyen po las ma gtogs pa'i las zad par byed pa'i gnyen po la ngal zhing dub par byed pa don med yin te/ sred pa ma spangs par las spong mi nus shing slar yang 'byung ba dang / sred pa spangs na las spong mi dgos pa'i phyir ro/ /

Tiring and fatiguing oneself to exhaust karma with antidotes other than the antidotes that exhaust craving is pointless, because without abandoning craving, karma cannot be abandoned and will reoccur and if craving has been abandoned it is unnecessary to abandon karma.
gsum pa daka' thub kyis grol ba dgag pa la/
C. Refuting liberation through austerity.
dka' thub gcig gis las thams cad zad pa dgag/ las kyi nus pa 'dres pa dgag/ de la rtsod pa spang ba'o/ /
This has three points: 1. Refuting that a single austerity could exhaust all karma, 2. Refuting that the power of actions is mixed, and 3. Refuting criticism.
dang po [dka' thub gcig gis las thams cad zad pa dgag pa] la/
1. Refuting that a single austerity could exhaust all karma

nam mkha'i gos can pa kha cig na re/ lus gdung bas sngon byas pa'i las kyi 'bras bu longs spyod pa'i sgo nas zad pa dang / ma 'ongs pa'i las gsar pa ma bsags pa'i bar du grol ba yin no zhe na/ 'di la kha cig ni dka' thub kyis gdung ba rtsom pa las mi 'dod pa nyams su myong ba ni las kyi 'bras bu ma yin na/ gang las de'i 'bras bu longs spyod pas zad pa min te/ 'dod pa'i dbang gis 'jug pa'i phyir ro zhes zer mod kyi/ de ltar yin na skyes bu'i byed pas bsgrubs pa'i rgyal srid kyang las kyi 'bras bu yin par mi 'gyur ro/ / de bas na 'dod pa dang mi 'dod pa cung zad gang yin pa de thams cad las kyi 'bras bu yin te/ de skad du'ang / 'phags pa gnas brtan pa'i lung las/ bde 'gro 'am ni ngan 'gro yang / / skye mched lnga yi rkyen can gyi/ / sems ni mi 'dod skye gang gi/ sdig pa'i las kyi 'bras bur 'dod/ / ces bshad pa lta bu'o/ /

Some sky-clad Jain ascetics say that tormenting the body exhausts the results of previously committed actions by means of experience, and one is liberated as long as one does not commit new future actions. With regard to this, some say that if experiencing the unwanted from undergoing torments through austerities were not the result of karma, the experience of that action and its result would not exhaust it because one engages in it voluntarily. Though they say this, if it were so, a kingship that a man achieved through his actions would also not be the result of karma. Therefore, anything whatsoever—whether desired or not—is the result of actions. As it says in the scriptures of the noble elders: Whether the higher or the lower realms, The unwanted that arises from volition And has the five sense bases as conditions Is asserted to be the result of evil acts.[273]
des na dka' thub kyi gdung ba gcig gis las sna tshogs kyi 'bras bu sna tshogs zad par byed pa ma yin no zhes bstan pa'i phyir/
Therefore a single torment through austerities cannot exhaust the various results of various actions. To teach this:
'bras bu sna tshogs mthong ba'i phyir/ / las rnams nus pa tha dad du/ / rjes dpog des na dka' thub kyi/ / nyon mongs dngos gcig gis mi 'dzad/ /
276cd Since various results are seen, the powers Of actions are inferred to be distinct. 277ab Therefore a single entity inflicting Austerity cannot extinguish them.

ces smos te/ longs spyod chen po dang chung ngu dang nad dang nad med pa dang yan lag dang nying lag la sogs pa tshang ba dang ma tshang ba la sogs pa las kyi 'bras bu sna tshogs pa 'byung bar snang zhing mthong ba'i phyir/ skyes bu'i rgyud kyi las rnams 'bras bu du ma 'byin pa'i nus pa tha dad can du rjes su dpog par nus pa yin la/ 'bras bu sna tshogs 'byin par nus pa'i las de dag gi 'bras bu sna tshogs nyams su myong bar 'gyur ba des na dka' thub kyi nyon mongs kyi dngos po gcig gis las kyi 'bras bu thams cad longs spyod pa'i sgo nas las thams cad mi 'dzad cing zad par mi rigs so/ / dper na ko tra ba'i myu gu bskyed pa'i nus pa bcom pas nas dang sA lu'i myu gu bskyed pa'i nus pa bcom par mi 'gyur ba bzhin no/ /

Since various results of karma—great and little wealth, illness and good health, complete or incomplete limbs and appendages, and so forth—appear and are seen to arise, it can be inferred that the actions in a person's continuum have distinct powers to produce multiple results. The various results of those actions that have the power to produce various results are experienced, so therefore it is not logical that a single entity of the infliction of austerity could extinguish all karmas by way of experiencing all their results; it cannot extinguish them. For example, destroying the power to produce a millet seedling does not destroy the power to produce barley or sālu seedlings.
khyab pa ma nges pa yang ma yin te/
The pervasion is also not indeterminate:
rnam 'gas de bskyed 'bras bu ni/ / chung 'gyur rigs mi mthun can min/ /
277cd In some ways, the results that are produced Are lessened, but not those of different kinds.

ces smos te/ skra 'bal ba la sogs pa'i dka' thub kyis lus gdung ba'i rnam pa 'gas de lta bu'i sdug bsngal de skyed par byed pa'i mi dge ba'i las kyi 'bras bu ni chung ngur 'gyur bar byas pa tsam yin gyi/ mi dge ba dang rigs mi mthun pa can gyi dge ba'i las kyi 'bras bu zad par byas pa ma yin pa'i phyir zhes pa lha'i'o/ / rgyan las ni/ gang gi phyir/ rnam 'gas de bskyed 'bras bu ni/ / chung 'gyur rigs mi mthun can min/ / 'bras bu nyams su myong bas ni/ / zhes 'don par mdzad nas/ las gang gis de'i rigs can nyid kyi 'bras bu nye bar bskyed par bya ba'i phyir 'bras bu de'i cha nyams su myong ba'i phyir/ las des bskyed pa'i 'bras bu nyid nyams par 'gyur gyi/ de dang mi mthun pa'i 'bras bu ni 'grib pa ma yin no/ / zhes gsung ngo / / slob dpon rgyal ba can gyi 'grel pa las/ shin tu brgal dka'i las rnams byas pa ni/ / bdag nyid rnam par smad pas bsrab par 'gyur/ / bshags dang sdom par byed pa de dag gis/ / brtan du drungs nas bton pa ma yin no/ / zhes bdag smad pa dang / bshags pa la sogs pa'i rnam pa 'gas chung ba'am gnas skabs kyi las zad pa'i yin gyi/ rigs mi mthun pa can ni ma yin no/ / zhes bshad do/ /

In some ways—such as by tormenting the body through austerities like pulling out hair—the results of unvirtuous actions that produce such suffering can be merely lessened, but those results of virtuous actions different in kind from nonvirtues are not extinguished. This is according to Devendrabuddhi. The Ornament cites the root as: In some ways, the results that are produced Are lessened. By experiencing results Of conditions of a different kind...[274] It then says: Any action produces results only of its own class. Because a portion of that is experienced, the result produced by that action is lessened, but results incompatible with it are not diminished.[275] Master Jina's commentary explains: The actions done that are extremely hard to transcend Might be palliated by abusing oneself, But self-laceration and bondage Do not eradicate them lastingly...[276] He thus explains that some manners of abusing oneself—lacerating oneself—can exhaust small or temporary acts, but not those of a different class.
gnyis pa las kyi nus pa 'dres pa dgag pa la/
2. Refuting that the power of actions is mixed
gzhan dag na re/
Others say:
cis te dka' thub nus pa yis/ / nus pa 'dres pa zad pa na/ /
278ab “What if the power of austerity Were to extinguish powers that are mixed?”

zhes smos te/ cis te yang dka' thub kyi nus pa yis las kyi nus pa thams cad 'bras bu gcig 'byin nus su 'dres par byas te 'bras bu gcig po skra 'bal ba la sogs pa'i lus kyi gdung bas zad par byed pa yin ce na/ re zhig nus pa 'dres par 'dod pa'i phyogs la skyon 'di 'gyur te/

“But what if the power of austerity mixed all the power of actions into the power to produce one result, and that one result were extinguished by physical self-mortification such as pulling out one's hair and so forth?” First of all, there would be this fault from the proposition that the powers were mixed:
nyon mongs cha 'ga' spong ba'am/ /
278c A tiny bit of affliction would discard,

zhes smos te/ dka' thub can gyi skyes bu dka' thub kyi nus pa 'dres par byas pa'i las 'bras gcig spong ba la skra 'bal ba la sogs pa'i lus kyi gdung ba drag po rtsom pa don med par 'gyur te/ ba spu gcig btogs pa lta bu'i dka' thub kyis gdungs pa'i nyon mongs pa'i cha 'gas kyang de dag spong ba'i phyir te/ dka' thub des las thams cad 'bras bu de tsam bskyed nus su nus pa 'dres par byas pa'i phyir/ nus pa rags pa zad par byas pa'i phyogs la yang skyon yod de/ lus kyi gdung ba de las ngan pa'i 'bras bur gyur pa'i sdug bsngal yin nam 'on te ma yin dris pa la/

It would be pointless for people practicing austerity to strive at severe self-mortification of their body by pulling out their hair and so forth, because a tiny bit of the affliction of mortification through austerities such as pulling out a single body hair would also discard them. That is because that austerity would mix the powers of all actions into the power to produce that size result. There are also faults in the proposition that coarse power can be exhausted. We ask whether the mortification of the body is suffering that is the result of bad actions or not.
gzhan dag na re/
Others reply:
gal te dka' thub nyon mongs las/ / gzhan 'dod nyon mongs nyid ce na/ /
279ad If one asserted that austerity were Affliction that is other than affliction,
zhes zer te/ gal te dka' thub las gyur pa'i lus kyi gdung ba de las ngan pa'i 'bras bur gyur pa'i nyon mongs las gzhan dge bar 'dod do zhe na/ bshad pa/
If one were to assert that the mortification of the body from austerity is a virtue that is other than the affliction that results from bad actions, to explain:
nyon mongs med par kun spong 'gyur/ /
278d Or all would be abandoned sans affliction.

zhes smos te/ dka' thub byed pa'i skyes bus dka' thub las gyur pa'i lus kyi gdung bas las kyi nus pa rags pa zad par byas nas las kyi lhag ma cung zad spong ba la skra 'bal ba la sogs pa lus kyi gdung ba drag po rtsom pa don med par 'gyur te/ skra 'bal ba la sogs pa'i sdug bsngal nyon mongs pa med par dka' thub kyi las 'bras kun spong bar 'gyur ba'i phyir te/ nyon mongs kyi sgra ni sdug bsngal gyis mnar ba tsam la btags par zad kyi/ 'dod chags la sogs pa ni ma yin no/ /

Once a person who practices austerity has exhausted the coarse power of actions through the physical mortification from austerity, it would be pointless to strive in severe physical mortification such as pulling out the hair to eliminate the slight remainders of actions, because all the results of karma would be abandoned through austerity sans the affliction of suffering of pulling out hair and so forth. The word affliction designates just the misery from pain, not desire and so forth.
gal te dka' thub de las ngan gyi 'bras bur gyur pa'i sdug bsngal gyi nyon mongs pa nyid yin no zhe na/ bshad pa/
If you say that the austerity is an affliction of suffering resulting from bad actions, to explain:
de ni las 'bras yin phyir 'dis/ / nus pa 'dres sogs 'gyur ma yin/ /
279cd Because it is the result of an action, It would not mix the powers or so forth.

ces smos te/ skra 'bal ba la sogs pa'i lus kyi gdung ba rtsom pa'i dka' thub de ni mi dge ba'i las kyi 'bras bur gyur pa'i sdug bsngal nyid yin pa'am/ yang na las kyi rnam smin gyi 'bras bu yin pa'i phyir/ 'dis las kyi nus pa 'dres par byed pa dang zad par byed pa la sogs par 'gyur ba'i lam ma yin no/ /

Because it (the austerity from engaging in physical mortification such as pulling out one's hair) is suffering that is the result of an unvirtuous action or else the fully ripened result of an action, it is not a path that would mix the powers of karma, extinguish them, or so forth.
gsum pa de la rtsod pa spang ba ni/
3. Refuting criticism
gzhan dag na re/ khyed kyis kyang bdag med par rtogs pa nyid las zad pa'i thabs su 'dod pa dang / las zad pa'i thabs de lam ma yin par khas blangs pa 'gal lo zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others say, “But you assert that realizing selflessness is itself a method to extinguish karma, and that contradicts your position that methods to exhaust karma are not the path.” To explain:
skye 'dod nyes pa bcom pa'i phyir/ / gang yang skyon rnams 'gog byed pa/ / des bskyed las la nus 'gyur gyi/ / ji ltar byas pa nyams par 'gyur/ /
280. Since it eliminates the fault of wanting To be reborn, that which prevents the faults Has power over the actions they produce, But how could what's been done be eliminated?

zhes smos te/ gang gi phyir ma 'ongs pa na las skye bar 'dod pa'i nyes pa 'dod chags la sogs pa'i sa bon bcom pa de'i phyir/ gang yang skyon 'dod chags la sogs pa rnams 'gog par byed pa bdag med par rtogs pa'i lam rnams ni 'dod chags la sogs pa nyon mongs pa des bskyed pa'i las spong ba la nus pa dang ldan par 'gyur ro/ / de ltar na sngar ma byas pa'i las spong ba la nus pa dang ldan pa yin gyi/ ji ltar na 'das pa'i las byas pa rnams ni nyams shing zad par 'gyur te mi 'gyur ba kho na'o/ / de la 'dir gal te 'das pa'i las la brten nas brjod pa de'i tshe ma grub pa yin la/ ma 'ongs pa'i las la brten nas ni grub pa la bsgrub pa yin no zhes pa lha'i'o/ / rgyan las ni/ gang zhig gdon mi za bar 'bras bu 'byin nus pa gang yin pa de ni gdon mi za ba kho nar 'bras bu 'byin pa yin te/ de'i don du'ang dka' thub can dag mngon par sbyor ba ma yin te/ de'i stobs kyis 'ong ba'i phyir ro/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

Because they eliminate the seeds of desire and so forth—the fault of wanting karma to arise in the future—the paths of realizing self- lessness that prevent the faults of desire and so forth have power over eliminating the actions they (those afflictions such as desire) produce. Therefore it has power to discard actions that have not previously been done, but how could the actions that have been done in the past be eliminated and extinguished? They could only not be. Devendrabuddhi says: If that were said based upon past actions, it would be unproven, but it is proven based on future actions, so this proves it.[277] Prajñākaragupta says: That which is without a doubt the power to produce a result will solely without a doubt produce a result. One does not train in austerities for its sake, because that comes from its power.[278]
gzhan dag na re/ sred pa yod na las 'byung ba bzhin du las las kyang sred pa 'byung bar 'gyur la/ de ltar na dgra bcom pa slar yang 'khor bar skye bar 'gyur ro zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others say that just as actions occur if there is craving, craving also arises from actions. Therefore an arhat would once again take birth in samsara. To explain:
las las nyes pa ma yin te/ / skyon ldan byed 'gyur bzlog las min/ /
281ab Faults aren't from actions. Those with faults Will act. Not from the opposite.

zhes smos te/ nyes pa zad pa'i skyes bu dgra bcom pa'i las de las 'dod chags la sogs pa'i nyes pa slar yang skye ba ma yin te/ log sred kyi skyon dang ldan na slar yang las gsar du gsog par byed par 'gyur gyi/ log sred kyi skyon las bzlog pa'i dgra bcom pa slar yang las gsar du gsog par byed pa ma yin pa'i phyir zhes lha rgyan gnyis ka'i'o/ /

The faults of desire and so forth will not rearise from the actions of an arhat, a person who has extinguished the faults. This is because those with the fault of mistaken craving will accumulate new actions, but those arhats who have turned away[279] from the faults of mistaken craving will not accumulate new karma ever again. This is according to both Devendrabuddhi and Prajñākaragupta.

gzhan dag na re/ las dge ba dang mi dge ba'i rgyu las go rim bzhin du 'bras bu tshor ba bde ba dang sdug bsngal 'byung la/ de dag las 'dod chags dang zhe sdang skye bar mthong ba'i phyir/ las las kyang nyon mongs pa 'byung ngo zhe na/ bshad pa/

Others say that virtuous and unvirtuous actions are the causes from which pleasurable and painful feelings, the results, arise respectively, and desire and hatred are seen to arise from those. Therefore afflictions arise from karma as well, they say. To explain:
log pa'i rnam rtog med par ni/ / bde ba las kyang 'dod mi 'gyur/ /
281cd Without mistaken thoughts, desire Will not arise, even from pleasure.

zhes smos te/ khams gsum la 'dod chags dang bral ba'i dgra bcom pa la log pa'i rnam par rtog pa nga dang nga'i zhes bya ba tshul bzhin ma yin par yid la byed pa med par ni ste/ de'i phyir tshor ba bde ba las kyang 'dod chags skye bar mi 'gyur ro zhes pa lha rgyan gnyis ka'i'o/ /

Arhats free from attachment for the three realms have no mistaken thoughts, the inappropriate attention of thinking “me” and “mine.” For that reason, desire will not arise even from sensations of pleasure. This is according to both Devendrabuddhi and Prajñākaragupta.
gnyis pa de las rang don phun tshogs bde gshegs grub pa ni/
2. Establishing from that the perfect benefit for self, the sugata
skyob las de nyid dang brtan dang / / ma lus khyad par mkhyen par grub/ / gshegs pa rtogs pa'i don phyir te/ / de phyir phyi rol pa dang slob/ / mi slob las lhag/
282. From the protector, his distinctive knowing Of suchness, stable and complete, is proven. Gata’s the meaning realized. Thus he surpasses Non-Buddhists as well as learners and nonlearners.

ces smos te/ gang gi phyir 'phags pa'i bden pa bzhi ston par mdzad pa nyid skyob pa yin pa las te de'i phyir bcom ldan 'das de ni bde bar gshegs pa yin no/ / de'ang gang zhe na/ de kho na nyid legs par mkhyen pa dang slar mi ldog par brtan par mkhyen pa dang / ma lus pa'i rnam pa'i khyad par mkhyen pa'i ye shes te yon tan gsum dang ldan pas bde bar gshegs par grub pa yin la/ bde bar gshegs pa de yang sngar spangs pa'i sgo nas bshad cing / 'dir rtogs pa'i don la bshad pa'i phyir te/ gang gi phyir don gsum dang ldan pa de'i phyir/ bcom ldan 'das ni spangs pa dang rtogs pa phun sum tshogs pa'i bde bar gshegs pa yin te/ de kho na nyid mkhyen pas phyi rol pa dang / brtan par mkhyen pas slob pa dang / rnam pa ma lus par mkhyen pas 'phags pa nyan thos dang rang sangs rgyas kyi mi slob pa las lhag cing khyad du 'phags pa yin no/ /

Because he teaches the four noble truths, he is the protector, and from (or because of) that, the Bhagavan is the sugata. What is that? you ask. Sugatahood is the wisdom of the distinctive knowing of knowing suchness excellently, of knowing irreversibly and stably, and of knowing all aspects completely. Possessing those three qualities proves him to be the sugata. Previously sugata was explained in terms of abandonment, but here it is explained as the meaning that is realized. Because he has these three meanings, the Bhagavan is the sugata who is the perfection of abandonment and realization. Thus by knowing suchness, he surpasses and is superior to the outsiders; by knowing stably, the learners; and by knowing all aspects without exception he surpasses the noble listener and self-buddha nonleamers.
gsum pa de las sbyor ba phun tshogs ston pa grub pa ni/
3. Establishing from that the perfect training, the teacher
de yi phyir/ / gzhan don mkhyen sbyor de ston pa/ /
283ab And for that reason, he who trains in knowing The benefit of others is the teacher.

zhes smos te/ don gsum mkhyen pa de'i phyir 'bras bu bde bar gshegs pa de las rgyu sbyor ba phun sum tshogs pa'i ston pa grub ste/ rgyu'i dus su gzhan don mkhyen pa'i phyir du bdag med bsgom pa'i lam la sbyor ba goms par mdzad pa'i phyir/ de ltar na rgyu'i dus su lam la goms par mdzad pa la ston par btags pa yin no/ /

And for that reason that he knows the three meanings, the cause— the teacher who is perfect training—is established from the result, the sugata. This is because during the causal stage, he cultivated training in the path of meditating on selflessness in order to know the benefit of others. In this way, cultivating the path during the causal stage is designated as the teacher.
bzhi pa de las bsam pa phun tshogs 'gro la phan bzhed grub pa ni/
4. Establishing from that the perfect intent, the wish to benefit others
de las brtse yin gzhan don ngor/ / don grub mdzad pa mi 'dor phyir/ /
283cd Love is from that: compelled by others' needs, He never abandons bringing benefit.

zhes smos te/ gzhan don du rang nyid lam la goms par mdzad pa'i ston pa de las gzhan la phan par bzhed pa'i brtse ba grub pa yin te/ gdul bya gzhan gyi ngor sbyor bas bden pa bzhi'i gnas lugs kyi don rtogs pa'i lam rang rgyud la grub par mdzad pa de yang 'gro ba rnams yal bar mi 'dor ba'i brtse ba snying rje chen po las byung ba'i phyir/ dper na myu gu grub pas sa bon grub pa bzhin no/ /

From that, the teacher who cultivated the path himself for others' sake, the love that wishes to help others is proven, because from the perspective[280] of others—disciples—he trained and accomplished the path of realizing the meaning of the nature of the four truths in his own being, and that as well arises from the great love and compassion that never abandons wanderers. As an analogy, proving a shoot proves a seed.[281]
lnga pa des na tshad mar grub pa ni/
5. Thus establishing he is valid
brtse bas legs dang ye shes las/ / bden pa gsung mdzad sgrub byed bcas/ / de gsung bar yang mngon sbyor ldan/ / gang phyir des na tshad ma nyid/ /
284. He taught the excellent from his compassion; From wisdom, truth and the means to establish. He was intent on teaching them as well, And for those reasons, he is therefore valid.

ces smos te/ bsam pa gzhan gyi sdug bsngal spong bar bzhed pa'i brtse ba chen po sngon du song bas bden pa bzhi'i gnas lugs rtogs pa'i nges par legs pa'i lam sbyor bas nyams su len cing gdul bya gzhan dag la yang ston pa 'byung la/ rgyu bsam sbyor phun sum tshogs pa gnyis po de las spangs pa dang ye shes phun sum tshogs pa'i bde bar gshegs pa ngo bo nyid kyi sku dang chos kyi sku gnyis 'grub cing / bde bar gshegs pa de las gdul bya'i sems kyi snang ba dang 'tshams par bden pa bzhi la blang dor byed pa'i tshul phyin ci ma log par gsung bar mdzad pa'i skyob pa longs spyod rdzogs pa dang sprul pa'i sku 'grub pas na/ 'bras bu don gnyis phun sum tshogs pa sgrub byed kyi rgyu bsam sbyor phun sum tshogs pa dang bcas pa'o/ / des na bcom ldan 'das chos can/ tshad ma nyid du grub pa yin te/ gang gi phyir rang nyid kyis mngon du byas pa'i rgyu 'bras phun sum tshogs pa de gdul bya gzhan dag la gsung par yang mdzad cing / de nyid la mngon par sbyor zhing 'god pa dang ldan pa de'i phyir/

Beginning with the intent, the great compassion that wishes to eliminate others' suffering, he then practiced by training in the path of the truly excellent that realizes the nature of the four truths, and thus became the teacher for others who needed to be tamed. Because of those two causes, the perfect intent and training, he accomplished sugata-hood that is the perfection of abandonment and wisdom, the two kāyas of the svābhāvikakāya and the dharmakāya. From that sugatahood, he accomplished the protector, the sambhogakāya and nirmaṇakāya who teach without mistake what to do and what not to do and the four truths appropriately for the perceptions in disciples' minds. Thus the result (the two perfect benefits) has the cause, the means to accomplish that (perfect intent and training). For those reasons, the Bhagavan, the subject, is therefore proven to be valid, because he teaches the perfect cause and result that he himself has manifested to other disciples as well, and because he is intent on that and can bring them to those states.
gsum pa bcom ldan 'das la tshad ma'i sgo nas bstod pa'i dgos pa bshad pa la/
C. Explaining the reason for praising the Bhagavan as being valid
'o na bcom ldan 'das de tshad med pa'i yon tan dang ldan na/ tshad ma nyid kyi sgo nas bstod pa la dgos pa'am rgyu ci yod ce na/ bshad pa/
Well then, if the Bhagavan has limitless qualities, what is the necessity or cause for praising him only in terms of validity? To explain:
de lta'i dngos ston bstod pa ni/ / de yi bstan pa nyid las ni/ / tshad ma'i de nyid grub don te/ /
285a-c Praising the teaching of such entities Is to establish the reality Of validity from his own teachings.

zhes smos te/ slob dpon phyogs kyi glang pos bcom ldan 'das la tshad ma de lta bu'i dngos por ston pa'i sgo nas bstod pa'i dgos pa ni bcom ldan 'das de'i bstan pa'i gsung rab nyid las ni tshad ma'i bstan bcos kun las btus kyi brjod bya mngon sum dang rjes su dpag pa'i tshad ma la sogs pa'i de kho na nyid ji ltar gsungs pa de ltar bshad pa yin gyi/ rang bzor byas pa ni ma yin no zhes pa grub pa'i don du ste/ mngon sum la sogs pa mdo las ji ltar gsungs pa'i tshul ni gzhung so so'i skabs su shes par bya'o/ /

The necessity for Master Dignāga to praise the Bhagavan in terms of teaching that the Bhagavan is such a valid entity is to establish that Dignāga explained the reality of perceptual validity, inferential validity, and so forth—the topic of the treatise The Compendium of Validity— just as the Bhagavan taught it in the scriptures of his own teachings and that Dignāga did not fabricate anything himself. The way that perception and so forth are taught in the sutras are taught can be known in the context of each of the texts.
gzhan dag na re/ mngon sum ni mdo las gsungs pa bden mod kyi/ rjes su dpag pa'i tshad ma ni ma gsungs pa kho na'o zhe na/ bshad pa/
Others say it is true that perception is taught in the sutras, but inferential validity is not taught at all. To explain:
rjes su dpag pa ma bzlog phyir/ / cung zad skye ba'i bdag nyid can/ / gang de thams cad 'gag chos can/ / zhes sogs rnam pa du mar ni/ / 'di yi sbyor ba'ang mthong phyir ro/ /
285d And inference as well is not refuted, 286. Because one sees such syllogisms as “Everything with the slightest nature of Arising is a phenomenon that ceases,” Et cetera, in many various ways.

zhes smos te/ 'di ltar rjes su dpag pa'i tshad ma ni bcom ldan 'das kyis ma bzlog cing ma bkag pa'i phyir tshad mar bzhed pa yin no/ / tshad mar mi bzhed na bzlog par mdzad de/ dper na pha rol bar du smra ba thams cad ni gsog ste/ nga gcig pu de nyid gsung ba yin no zhes sgra las byung ba'i tshad ma bzlog pa bzhin no/ / gzhan yang gang cung zad skye ba'i bdag nyid can gang yin pa de thams cad ni 'gag pa'i chos can yin no zhes rang bzhin gyi rtags yang dag pa'i sbyor ba la sogs pa rnam pa du mar ni rjes su dpag pa'i tshad ma 'di yi rgyu rtags kyi sbyor ba'ang bshad par mthong ba'i phyir ro/ /

It is thus: inferential validity was not refuted or negated by the Bhagavan, so therefore he considered it valid. If he had not accepted it as valid, he would have refuted it, just as, for example, he refuted verbal validity when he said, “All the outsiders have said up to now is false: I alone have taught thatness.” Additionally, it is because one sees that he has explained in many various ways the cause of inferential validity, reasons of such syllogisms with correct reasons of nature as “Everything with the slightest nature of arising is a phenomenon that ceases,” et cetera. :
des rtags kyi sbyor ba bzhed na de la brten pa'i rjes su dpag pa'ang bzhed par rigs so zhes bshad pa/
To explain that if he accepted syllogisms with reasons, it is logical that he also accepted the inferential validity based on them
med na mi 'byung mtshan nyid can/ / rtags ni rjes dpag rten yin no/ / bsgrub byas gtan tshigs khyab pa ni/ / bstan phyir de yang gsal bar bshad/ /
287. The basis of inference is reasons that Are characterized by not arising if absent. He explained these clearly, too, because he taugh Through propositions with reasons and pervasion.

ces smos te/ ji skad bshad pa'i med na mi 'byung ba'i mtshan nyid can gyi rtags ni rjes su dpag pa'i tshad ma'i rten yin pa de yang bcom ldan 'das kyis gsal bar bshad pa yin te/ bsgrub bya'i chos kyis gtan tshigs la rjes su 'gro ldog gi khyab pa dang / phyogs chos te tshul gsum tshang ba'i gtan tshigs ni gsal bar bstan pa'i phyir ro/ /

Reasons that have been explained are characterized by the reason that this will not arise if that is absent, as explained, are the basis of inferential validity. He (the Bhagavan) explained this clearly too, because he taught reasons fulfilling the three modes with entailing and reverse pervasions of the predicate of the proposition and with the propositional property.
gnyis pa mdo'i bshad par dam bca' ba ni/
Second, the pledge to compose the Compendium.
nas/ / tshad ma bsgrub phyir rang gi gzhung kun las/ / btus te sna tshogs 'thor rnams 'dir gcig bya/ /
I will, to prove validity. Compile from all my works and here Make what was scattered into one.

zhes bya ba gsungs te/ de ltar slob dpon phyogs kyi glang pos bcom ldan 'das la mchod par brjod nas bya ba ci byed ce na/ brtsam par bya zhes drang ngo / / gang na tshad ma kun las btus 'di'o/ / dgos pa gang gi phyir du na/ don gyi tshad ma bcom ldan 'das dang / de'i bstan pa gsung rab las byung ba'i tshad ma de nyid yang dag pa'i tshad ma nyid du rigs pas bsgrub par bya ba'i phyir du'o/ / tshul ji ltar na/ slob dpon phyogs glang rang gi gsung tshad ma'i sgrub byed ston pa rigs pa'i sgo la sogs pa kun las brjod bya'i don thams cad btus te'o/ / gzhung gzhan las bshad zin na 'dir btus pa la dgos pa med do zhe na/ ma yin te/ rjod byed kyi tshig sna tshogs pas rgyas shing gzhung so sor 'thor nas yod pa rnams la blo gros dang brtson pa chung ba dag gis bshad pa dang / nyan pa dang / lta ba dang / rtogs dka' bar gzigs nas de dag la brtse ba'i rgyus kun las btus 'dir rjod byed kyi tshig nyung ngus brjod bya'i don rgya chen po ston pa'i gzhung gcig tu mdzad na bshad pa dang / nyan pa dang / lta ba dang rtogs sla ba'i dgos pa yod pas so/ /

Once Master Dignāga has thus praised the Bhagavan, what will he do? you ask. He will write. What? This Compendium of Validity. What is the necessity? To prove that the Bhagavan, the actual validity, and his teachings—the validity that arises from scriptures—are authentic validity. In what manner? By compiling all the points on the topic from his, Master Dignāga's, own works that teach the proof of validity such as The Gateway to Logic. You might say that there is no need to compile here what was taught in other texts, but that is not the case. It is difficult for those with lesser intelligence and diligence to explain, listen to, read, and realize the various words of his texts that are long and scattered in different works. Seeing this, compassion for those people causes him to make here in this Compendium one work that teaches the vast meaning of the topic, expressing it with few words. Thus there is the necessity that it be easy to explain, listen to, read, and realize.

'di ltar bshad na/ gzhung kun zhes pa dang / sna tshogs 'thor gnyis mi zlos shing / kun las btus dang 'dir gcig bya/ / gnyis kyang mi zlos par 'gyur ro/ / ji skad du/ rang 'grel las/ phyag 'tshal nas tshad ma bsgrub par bya ba'i phyir rang gi rab tu byed pa rigs pa'i sgo la sogs pa rnams las 'dir gcig tu btus te tshad ma kun las btus brtsam par bya'i/ zhes gsungs so/ /

In explaining it thus, the phrases “all my works” and “scattered” are not redundant, and “compile from all” and “here make... into one” are also not redundant. As it says in the autocommentary: Having prostrated, in order to prove validity, I will compile my own analyses from The Gateway to Logic and so forth and compose The Compendium of Validity.[282]

'dir rnam 'grel mdzad pas bshad par dam bca' ba rnam par ma bkrol ba ni rtogs sla ba la dgongs pa yin te/ ji skad du/ lha dbang blo'i 'grel pa las/ bstan bcos kyi dang por phyag 'tshal ba'i tshigs su bcad pa phyed 'og ma rtogs sla ba nyid kyi phyir/ phyed gong ma nyid kyi bshad pa yongs su rdzogs par mdzad nas/ zhes gsungs pas so/ /

Here the author of the Commentary did not explain the pledge to compose. The thought is that it is easy to understand. As is said in Devendrabuddhi's commentary: The latter half of the first verse of the treatise is easy to understand, so now that the explanation of the first half has been completed...[283]

tshad ma kun btus rgya cher rnam par 'grel pa tshad ma legs par bshad pa thams cad kyi chu bo yongs su 'du ba rigs pa'i gzhung lugs rgya mtsho zhes bya ba las/ bcom ldan 'das tshad ma'i skyes bur grub pa zhes bya ba kun las btus kyi bshad pa'i dbang du byas pa'i le'u dang po'o// //

From the extensive commentary on The Compendium of Validity entitled The Ocean of Literature on Logic, Which Collects the Rivers of Fine Explanations of Validity, this was the first chapter of the explanation of the Compendium, called “Establishing that the Bhagavan is a Valid Being.”
! bkra shis dpal 'bar karma bka' brgyud bstan pa phyogs bcur rgyas pa'i 'dzam gling rgyan du shog/ // sarba mang+ga laM// //
May the blaze of auspiciousness, the teachings of the Karma Kagyu, flourish in the ten directions as an ornament of the world. Sarva mangalaṃ.
